References: <923554970.20010730155044@abacuslaw.com> <20010731062310.X30092@hagbard.davep.org> <1787530798.20010731113731@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <20010801064009.B30092@hagbard.davep.org>

[Quotes rearranged to have a more logical flow]

On Tue, Jul 31, 2001 at 11:37:31AM -0700, Brian Hays wrote:
> Dave:
> 
> >>   Does Harbour already have any bit-manipulation functions buried
> >>   somewhere? I'm looking at having a long "string", perhaps 1000 bytes,
> >>   and want to test/set bits at any bit-wise offset.
> 
> DP> I wrote some "bit-string" code for the GT library, perhaps that's easily
> DP> ported to harbour?
> 
> Thanks, I'll take a look. Was that in SOURCE\RTL\GT ?

Sorry, that was misleading wasn't it? No, I mean the GT library for Clipper
(as in the Clipper programming echo on the GT Power BBS network). Parts of
that library have been ported to harbour (contrib/libgt) but not all of it.
You'll find the whole library on The Oasis <URL:http://www.the-oasis.net/>.

Get the source and look at BITFLAGS.C. It might not be useful but it sounds
close to what you were after.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  1 12:29:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Wed Aug  1 11:29:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ToolTip error... found but not yet solved
In-Reply-To: <200108011006_MC3-DB02-BEE0@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <3B683C1B.28708.1C84BF7@localhost>

Hi John,

Are you really back ? Do you had a good hollyday ?

As you certainly seen, Ron added some new Pcode, not to speak 
about the fact it was or not necessary nor to the fact the Macro 
evaluation are a bit more different than with clipper, I can't anymore 
compile your sample nor my code because I miss some Prg files 
who need to be recompiled. 

So could you please send me all needed libs ( each one containing 
at least one prg. :-( ) ASAP ?

About the tooltips problem ;

I have reproduced the problem on a small (terminal) program so I 
can work on it even without your new libs.

The problem occur when some method are calling some code like ; 

Super:Create( ::Nx )

There The mechanism used to SuperCast the message Create 
also modify the self reference on the stack later, when workink on 
Create parameters, The OO system think we called Super:Nx wich 
does'nt exist ... I already have a solution here but it broked the 
scoping so as soon as I have a functional solution I will publich it.

In the meantime, you should avoid sending Self:Var as paramater 
to any Super:MethodName( ...) 


See you, 

-- 

Best regards,

J. Lefebvre <jflefebv@mafact.com>
Mafact SA/NV
Belgium
(See us at http://www.mafact.com)
jflefebv@mafact.com

>   Just a short answer: we can extend syntax if we don't break the
> existing code. Your __dblist() changes are breaking that code.

Just as small an answer, not true.

Macro support for list, doesn't "break" __dbList() or anything else, anymore
then extended macro support already "broke" __dbList(), and all other
functions and expressions where macro can be used.

of us who only want to get code, won't get the web pages also. Given
that the Harbour source code is checked out using "cvs checkout
harbour", perhaps the web site could be set up so that it gets checked
out using "cvs checkout website".

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  2 00:52:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Wed Aug  1 23:52:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
Message-ID: <8593875736.20010801205959@abacuslaw.com>

   OrdSetFocus("MyTag   ") failed on space-padded strings, so I
   had to trim it.
   Rather than burden all rdds with the trimming code, I did it
   locally in ads1.c.  The first idea was to just slam a NULL into the existing
   string at the first space, but it's a pointer to a parameter and that didn't
   seem safe, so I had to copy it.
   Does anyone see a more efficient way to do this?
   Should we move it to ordSetFocus in dbcmd.c?


   UNSIGNED8 pucTagName[ADS_MAX_TAG_NAME + 1];
   UNSIGNED8 * p;
   int i = 0;
   /* ADS can't handle a space-padded string--we have to trim it */
   p = (UNSIGNED8*) hb_itemGetCPtr( pOrderInfo->itmOrder );

   while ( i <= ADS_MAX_TAG_NAME && *p)
   {
      if ( *(p+i) == ' ')
      {
         pucTagName[i] = '\0';
         break;
      }
      else
         pucTagName[i] = *(p+i);
      i++;
   }
   ulRetVal = AdsGetIndexHandle( pArea->hTable,
               pucTagName, &phIndex );


 ---====---
 Brian Hays


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  2 04:19:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alex Strickland)
Date: Thu Aug  2 03:19:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
References: <8593875736.20010801205959@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <004501c11b22$48d485d0$12016b83@alspc.com>

Shouldn't "Im a tag   " be a valid tag which at best should become "Im a
tag"? And shouldn't anything to do with file names be submitted to a
function, say HB_FileNameNormalise() so that these kind of issues can be
dealt with in platform independent manner (back slashes -> forward slashes,
finding bad characters etc).

Regards
Alex

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  2 17:45:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Thu Aug  2 16:45:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
In-Reply-To: <200108021259.000000X0@Internet>
References: <8593875736.20010801205959@abacuslaw.com>
 <200108021259.000000X0@Internet>
Message-ID: <18115215448.20010802135823@abacuslaw.com>

David:

DGH> The big problem with the code that you posted is that it does NOT trim
DGH> the string, but merely truncates it at the first space.

I suppose you *could* consider "trimming" at the C level as having a
buffer of a particular size (meaning size+ 1 for the NULL), but I
don't think any of the harbour code I've reviewed tries to do that.
You would have to find the first space, if any, then dynamically
allocate exactly that much memory, strcpy to it, and release it.
I haven't seen that done (but I can't say I've read every line of
code, either ;-).
If it has to have a NULL anyway, why is buffer size an issue, with a
bigger one being a "big problem"?  Am I missing something?

DGH> Aside from that, I don't see any problem with trimming the string in
DGH> ORDSETFOCUS.
 OK.

 ---===--- 
 Brian Hays



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  2 17:58:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Aug  2 16:58:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
In-Reply-To: <18115215448.20010802135823@abacuslaw.com>
References: <8593875736.20010801205959@abacuslaw.com> <200108021259.000000X0@Internet>
 <18115215448.20010802135823@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <200108021657.000000XA@Internet>

** Reply to message from Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com> on Thu, 2 Aug
2001 13:58:23 -0700

> I suppose you *could* consider "trimming" at the C level as having a
> buffer of a particular size...

That's not what I'm referring to. What I'm referring to is that your
code truncates at the first space in the string, instead of truncating
at the first trailing space. In other words, your code will convert "A
TAG   " to "A", but it needs to convert it to "A TAG". You need to
change the code to start the search at the tail end of the string,
replacing all spaces with null characters until you find a non-space or
reach the start of the string.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  2 19:05:03 2001

David:

DGH> That's not what I'm referring to. What I'm referring to is that your
DGH> code truncates at the first space in the string, instead of truncating
DGH> at the first trailing space.

 Thanks for clarifying! Though I doubt tags are allowed to have
 internal spaces and it would have worked by luck,
 I should have done it as you suggest and will change it.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  2 20:03:02 2001

Shouldn't that be:

Otherwise you keep checking the 1st char of p.

Just for readability and consitency I would use:

       if( p[i] == ' ' )

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug  3 05:27:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri Aug  3 04:27:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <17196772674.20010803013456@abacuslaw.com>

Ron and David:
If you're curious, here's the new trimming code for
adsOrderListFocus().  I tried to avoid any significant performance
hit.

         UNSIGNED8 pucTagName[ADS_MAX_TAG_NAME + 1];
         ULONG i;
         char * pSrc = hb_itemGetCPtr( pOrderInfo->itmOrder );
         ULONG ulLen = hb_strRTrimLen( pSrc,
                        hb_itemGetCLen( pOrderInfo->itmOrder ), FALSE );

         if( ulLen > ADS_MAX_TAG_NAME )
            ulLen = ADS_MAX_TAG_NAME;

         for ( i = 0; i < ulLen; i++ )
            pucTagName[i] = pSrc[i];

         pucTagName[ulLen] = '\0';

         ulRetVal = AdsGetIndexHandle( pArea->hTable,
                     pucTagName, &phIndex );

  ---====---
  Brian Hays

   * source/rtl/profiler.prg
     + Added HB_Profile::ignoreSymbol().
     * Changed HB_Profile::gather() to use HB_Profile::ignoreSymbol() to
       decide if a symbol should be ignored. This will let developers
       modify what is and isn't ignored by subclassing HB_Profile and
       implementing their own version of HB_Profile::ignoreSymbol().

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug  3 13:28:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Aug  3 12:28:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
In-Reply-To: <17196772674.20010803013456@abacuslaw.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <17196772674.20010803013456@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <200108031226.000000XG@Internet>

** Reply to message from Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com> on Fri, 3 Aug
2001 01:34:56 -0700

I see two problems with this new version: The user may be relying on
the length of the tag name not changing unexpectedly and because the
string might be a constant (e.g., ORDSETFOCUS("TAGNAME "), this could
mess up future constant string optimizations. So you should copy first,
then trim. And you should use the ANSI C standard strncpy() function
instead of the for loop.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug  3 14:16:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri Aug  3 13:16:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
In-Reply-To: <200108031226.000000XG@Internet>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
 <17196772674.20010803013456@abacuslaw.com> <200108031226.000000XG@Internet>
Message-ID: <116228490041.20010803102333@abacuslaw.com>

David:

DGH> The user may be relying on
DGH> the length of the tag name not changing unexpectedly and because the
DGH> string might be a constant (e.g., ORDSETFOCUS("TAGNAME "), this could
DGH> mess up future constant string optimizations. So you should copy first,
DGH> then trim.
  This is the main reason this code exists. It would have been much
  easier to just alter the original string (as I indicated in my first
  msg, that would have removed the need for a copy altogether).
  I think you misunderstood what hb_strRTrimLen() does--it
  looks at the string and determines the correct length without
  trailing spaces, but does *not* alter the string.
  This simply allows the copy operation to know the correct length to
  copy.

DGH> And you should use the ANSI C standard strncpy() function
DGH> instead of the for loop.
  I had considered this, and would be happy to change it. But I found
  several places in the Harbour code where these kinds of small string
  copies were done byte-by-byte.  Is there a practical or
  philosophical reason why strncpy is better?

  Thanks!

  ---====---
  Brian Hays


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug  3 14:26:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Aug  3 13:26:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
In-Reply-To: <116228490041.20010803102333@abacuslaw.com>

Message-ID: <200108031324.000000XK@Internet>

** Reply to message from Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com> on Fri, 3 Aug
2001 10:23:33 -0700

> I think you misunderstood what hb_strRTrimLen() does--it
>   looks at the string and determines the correct length without
>   trailing spaces, but does *not* alter the string.

Yes, I did misunderstand. Sorry!
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug  3 14:30:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Aug  3 13:30:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
In-Reply-To: <116228490041.20010803102333@abacuslaw.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <17196772674.20010803013456@abacuslaw.com>
 <200108031226.000000XG@Internet> <116228490041.20010803102333@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <200108031328.000000XM@Internet>

** Reply to message from Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com> on Fri, 3 Aug
2001 10:23:33 -0700

> Is there a practical or philosophical reason why strncpy is better?

On platforms that have optimized string manipulation CPU opcodes,
strncpy can be considerably faster than copying byte by byte. Functions
that can provide optimization, such as strcpy, strncpy, or memcpy are
always preferable to byte-by-byte copies, with few exceptions. (One such
exception is a loop that copies while determining where to stop, based
on the contents of what is being copied.)
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug  3 14:52:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Fri Aug  3 13:52:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
In-Reply-To: <200108031328.000000XM@Internet>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEBJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
 <17196772674.20010803013456@abacuslaw.com>  <200108031226.000000XG@Internet>
 <116228490041.20010803102333@abacuslaw.com> <200108031328.000000XM@Internet>
Message-ID: <173230666671.20010803105950@abacuslaw.com>

David:

DGH> On platforms that have optimized string manipulation CPU opcodes,
DGH> strncpy can be considerably faster than copying byte by byte. Functions
DGH> that can provide optimization, such as strcpy, strncpy, or memcpy are
DGH> always preferable to byte-by-byte copies, with few exceptions. (One such
DGH> exception is a loop that copies while determining where to stop, based
DGH> on the contents of what is being copied.)
  OK, thanks.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug  3 20:04:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug  3 19:04:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour / IIS
In-Reply-To: <3.0.6.16.20010803140342.1dd746c6@mail.udg.mx>; from dmacias@mail.udg.mx on Fri, Aug 03, 2001 at 02:03:42PM +0000
References: <200108031601.f73G16n15465@mail.udg.mx> <3.0.6.16.20010803140342.1dd746c6@mail.udg.mx>

On Fri, Aug 03, 2001 at 02:03:42PM +0000, David Arturo Macias Corona wrote:

> And this occur mainly in the times when we do tests with my Harbour CGI
> program

"Mainly"? This suggests that you sometimes experience the problem when
you're not running a harbour compiled cgi. Is that the case?

> > Doesn't the web server in question keep logs? Don't those logs show why
> > the service stopped?
>
> The logs does not show anything about this. IIS just suddenly stop without
> trace

Perhaps you could write a guardian angel client to keep track of this? Have
it hit port 80 every few seconds and see if you get a response. If you don't
assume that the server has died and log the time. Compare the time with the
server's logs to see what requests were serviced prior to server death.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug  4 11:29:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sat Aug  4 10:29:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3B6C23E6.18928.AEB7FC@localhost>

    * doc/en/compiler.txt
    * include/hbapi.h
    * include/hbcomp.h
    * include/hbexpra.c
    * include/hbexprb.c
    * include/hbmacro.h
    * source/compiler/cmdcheck.c
    * source/compiler/expropta.c
    * source/compiler/exproptb.c
    * source/compiler/harbour.c
    * source/compiler/harbour.y
    * source/compiler/hbfunchk.c
    * source/compiler/hbusage.c
        * added command line switch which controls a compilation
          compatibility level -k<modes>
          Currently supported modes (can be joined):
          -kc  ==> 100% Clipper compatible (with some obvious bugs fixed)
          -kh  ==> harbour extensions enabled (default)
          -kx  ==> other xbase dialects extensions
        * new macro HB_COMP_ISSUPPORTED(<mode>) to check if a feature
          is enabled. Currently supported modes (defined in hbcomp.h):
          HB_COMPFLAG_HARBOUR  ==> -kh
          HB_COMPFLAG_XBASE    ==> -kx
        * extended macro support for expression lists is disabled by
          default (latest Ron's additions) - use -kx switch to enable

    * include/set.ch
    * source/vm/macro.c
    * source/macro/macro.y
    * source/macro/macroa.c
    * source/macro/macrob.c
        * added HB_SETMACRO() function to control various compatibility
          issues at the runtime. 
          HB_SETMACRO( <nFeature>, <lOnOff> )
          This controls the macro compiler's features. The feature can 
          be either enabled (.T.) or disabled (.F.)
          Currently available features (defined in set.ch file)
          HB_SM_HARBOUR => (enabled by default)
              enable/disable harbour extensions 
          HB_SM_XBASE => (disabled by default)
              enable/disable xbase dialects extensions
          HB_SM_SHORTCUTS => (enabled by default)
              enable/disable shortcut evaluation of logical expressions
          HB_SM_PREPROC => 
              enable/disable preprocessing (if harbour is build with
              HB_MACRO_STATEMENTS option)

    * source/rdd/dblist.prg
        * the array of expressions is scanned for extended macro lists
          when xbase compatibility is enabled (see HB_SETMACRO())
          
    * source/vm/asort.c
        * moved HB_ASORT_OPT_ITEMCOPY setting to hbsetup.h

    * include/hbsetup.h
        * updated/added descriptions of all #ifdef settings used
          in the harbour code
          (Please keep updated this file (and hbsetup.ch) if a new
          setting is used)
          
    + doc/en/macro.txt
        * initial documentation for macro compiler
        * documentation of HB_SETMACRO() function

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug  4 15:55:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (J. =?iso-8859-1?Q?Lal=EDn?=)
Date: Sat Aug  4 14:55:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DbList question
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEAJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <3B6C4582.121D0F7B@corevia.com>

Ron,
> BTW, what is the problem compiling an inline c code? Aren't you calling the
> c compiler first when using the -go?
Yes, but this is what I got:

----
Harbour Compiler 0.37a (Build 37) (2001.06.29) (Flex)
Copyright 1999-2001, http://www.harbour-project.org/
Compiling 'source\rdd\dblist.prg'...
100
source\rdd\dblist.prg(195) Error F0051  Inline C requires C output
generation, use -gc[n]
----

To fix this I can use temporal var to store the value of
hb_comp_iLanguage, so inline checks will pass, and later restore it's
value on finishing:

int iOldOutput = hb_comp_iLanguage;
hb_comp_iLanguage = LANG_C;
...
hb_comp_iLanguage = iOldOutput;

I don't know if this is a good "fix" (it seems a "hack" to me) or if it
will be thread safe.

WM_Regards,
José Lalín

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug  4 21:48:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)

Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100

>         * added command line switch which controls a compilation
>           compatibility level -k<modes>

>           -kc  ==> 100% Clipper compatible (with some obvious bugs fixed)
>           -kh  ==> harbour extensions enabled (default)

What effect exactly does -kc have? I can't find any trace of a logic
attempting to use this setting where one would expect (extended support in
macro). I got no errors compiling and running macros with Harbour extensions
(like ++, -=, etc., which generate errors in Clipper) while using -kc.

with:

   Error BASE/1004 No exported method: EVAL

This apparently resulting from the failure of:

   IF( HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_XBASE ) )

On line 79 of source/rdd/dblist.prg

Finally, why would you default to -kh and not -kc or -kx?

Ron

just in random times

because so seem

order to define "only with" or "inclusive with" Harbour program

with certains DLL, so maybe Harbour is off the problem

Anyway, I send the request to Harbour people because someone could have
something like this. We know that at last the raise of errors depend so
much of the environment of the processes and their concurrence

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 06:37:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)

Subject: [Harbour] New memvar function is needed( Ryszard )
Message-ID: <17911238401.20010805133519@belacy.belgorod.su>

 Ryszard,
  what about adding a function to memvars.c, which will return pointer to the
  memvar item, something like:

PHB_ITEM GetVarAddress( char *szName )
{
   PHB_DYNS pDyn;

   if( ( pDyn = hb_dynsymFind( szName ) ) != NULL && pDyn->hmemvar )
      return  &s_globalTable[ pDyn->hMemvar ].item;
   else
      return NULL;
}  

I want to get addresses of few Harbour level variables in C module at
the beginning of the program for following using, to avoid
calling of hb_dynsymFind() every time when this variable is
needed.
Is this address the same all the time the variable exists ?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 10:21:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sun Aug  5 09:21:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-05 14:20 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3B6D6572.22672.596C63E@localhost>

    *include/hbcomp.h
    *source/compiler/cmdcheck.c
    *source/compiler/hbusage.c
        * added new command line switch: -ki
        * added new flag: HB_COMPFLAG_HB_INLINE
        This switch enables support for HB_INLINE syntax
        (by default it is disabled)
        * all options used with -k switch are letter case sensitive
        * -kc (Clipper compatibility) clears all other switches (minimal
          set of features)
        
    *source/compiler/harbour.l
        * added support for -ki command line switch
        
    *source/compiler/harbour.sly
    *source/compiler/harbour.y
        * fixed line numer issues in generated pcode

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 10:33:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sun Aug  5 09:33:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: New memvar function is needed( Ryszard )
Message-ID: <3B6D6855.6806.5A20C94@localhost>

> Is this address the same all the time the variable exists ?

  No, because the memory block where memvar items are stored can be 
reallocated to store more memvars. You should store the memvar handle 
instead. This means that at least two functions should be added:

HB_HANDLE hb_memvarGetVarHandle( char *szName )
{
   PHB_DYNS pDyn;

   if( ( pDyn = hb_dynsymFind( szName ) ) != NULL )
      return  pDyn->hMemvar;
   else
      return 0; /* invalid handle */
}  

PHB_ITEM hb_memvarGetValueByHandle( HB_HANDLE hMemvar )
{
   if( hMemvar && hMemvar < s_globalTableSize )
      return  &s_globalTable[ hMemvar ].item;
   else
      return NULL;
}  

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 10:42:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Chen Kedem)
Date: Sun Aug  5 09:42:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DOC: errors in doc/en/compiler.txt
Message-ID: <3B6D4CA6.1395@synel.co.il>

doc/en/compiler.txt

During some changes in version 1.5 of the file, '-' was globaly
replaced with '='. This suppose to affect only separator lines
but unfortunately also changed FIELD-> references into FIELD=>
options '-v' into '=v' and Hyphan into Equal signs.

Would someone that know the original meaning be kind enough to
fix it ? I'll do it next week if I'll have the time.

http://cvs.sourceforge.net/cgi-bin/viewcvs.cgi/harbour-project/harbour/doc/en/compiler.txt.diff?r1=1.4&r2=1.5&diff_format=h


  Chen.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 10:55:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sun Aug  5 09:55:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3B6D6D83.24257.5B647D3@localhost>

>What effect exactly does -kc have? I can't find any trace of a logic
>attempting to use this setting where one would expect (extended support 
>in
>macro). I got no errors compiling and running macros with Harbour 
>extensions
>(like ++, -=, etc., which generate errors in Clipper) while using -kc.

  All -k<option> switches control the harbour compiler behaviour. They 
have no influence on the macro compiler that have separate set of runtime 
options controlled with HB_SETMACRO().

>
>Did you test your change with -kx and __dbList()? It seems to now break
>with:
>
>   Error BASE/1004 No exported method: EVAL
>

  Yes, I have tested it. You have to use -kx during compilation and you 
have to call HB_SETMACRO(HB_SM_XBASE, .T.) in your code to get support 
for macro list (not only in __dblist).

>This apparently resulting from the failure of:
>
>   IF( HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_XBASE ) )
>
>On line 79 of source/rdd/dblist.prg
>
>Finally, why would you default to -kh and not -kc or -kx?

Currently the only difference between -kc and -kh is compilation of 
logical expressions in a codeblock. For example:
EVAL( {|| 1 .AND. someVar, 3} )
will generate a runtime error if -kc is used. If -kh is used then the 
code is optimized to: 
EVAL( {|| 1, someVar, 3} )

  Later I plan to disable support for strong typing if -kc is used - 
however this is not an importand issue now.

  We added many HB_* functions and we fixed many Clipper bugs (it will be 
difficult or even not possible to get 100% Clipper compatibility here).

Then it is obvious that -kh can be the default setting.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 10:56:02 2001

Have made the changes...
do you want the updated file or is there a process by which I check it in
directly from cvs?

Regards

Fergus McDonald

----- Original Message -----
From: "Chen Kedem" <niki@synel.co.il>

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 11:27:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sun Aug  5 10:27:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <3B6D6D83.24257.5B647D3@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEECJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> >Did you test your change with -kx and __dbList()? It seems to now break
> >with:
> >
> >   Error BASE/1004 No exported method: EVAL
> >
>
>   Yes, I have tested it. You have to use -kx during compilation and you
> have to call HB_SETMACRO(HB_SM_XBASE, .T.) in your code to get support
> for macro list (not only in __dblist).

I intend to change the default then.

> >Finally, why would you default to -kh and not -kc or -kx?
>
> Currently the only difference between -kc and -kh is compilation of
> logical expressions in a codeblock. For example:
> EVAL( {|| 1 .AND. someVar, 3} )
> will generate a runtime error if -kc is used. If -kh is used then the
> code is optimized to:
> EVAL( {|| 1, someVar, 3} )
>
>   Later I plan to disable support for strong typing if -kc is used -
> however this is not an importand issue now.

Strong typing is already disabled unless -w3 is used. It is a warning level
issue, so please don't make such change.

>   We added many HB_* functions and we fixed many Clipper bugs (it will be
> difficult or even not possible to get 100% Clipper compatibility here).
>
> Then it is obvious that -kh can be the default setting.

No it isn't.

All of this change was nothing more then disabling my macro extensions,
while retaining your Clipper incompatible extensions. It's further
compounded with your statement regarding strong typing. I will re-enable my
code, which you had no authorization to disable, on my next session.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 12:36:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sun Aug  5 11:36:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-05 14:20 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <3B6D6572.22672.596C63E@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCECKDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

>     *include/hbcomp.h
>     *source/compiler/cmdcheck.c
>     *source/compiler/hbusage.c
>         * added new command line switch: -ki
>         * added new flag: HB_COMPFLAG_HB_INLINE
>         This switch enables support for HB_INLINE syntax
>         (by default it is disabled)
>         * all options used with -k switch are letter case sensitive
>         * -kc (Clipper compatibility) clears all other switches (minimal
>           set of features)

What's the logic in doing something like this?

Obviously the compiler will *not* support/generate inline code, *unless* the
source code *contains* inline c, and the output generation requested
supports c output.

Forcing the user to use such switch, when there is no logic involved, unless
specifically requested by means of the code, is plain silly.

I will re-enable my code which again you were not authorized to disable, on
my next session.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 12:43:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sun Aug  5 11:43:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3B6D86D0.32562.6191BA4@localhost>

Ron wrote:

> All of this change was nothing more then disabling my macro extensions,
> while retaining your Clipper incompatible extensions. It's further
> compounded with your statement regarding strong typing. I will re-
> enable my
>code, which you had no authorization to disable, on my next session.

  Do whatever you want.

  But please keep in mind:

Your code is not disabled - some features are disabled by default and 
there is an easy method to enable them with a single function call.

The strong typing is still not working correctly (for example, compile 
testwarn.prg => segmentation fault, compile treport.prg - many incorrect 
warnings). The command line switches are disabling/enabling warnings only 
- some reserved keywords are still used for strong typing with no method 
to use them in other context (only HB_INLINE is now disabled by default).

Features available with -kh and HB_SM_HARBOUR set to TRUE are *safe* 
features. This means that the valid Clipper code is still valid in 
Harbour. The macro compiler is extended only to support features that 
available in the normal code.

__dblist(), -kx and HB_SM_XBASE set to TRUE are causing that valid 
Clipper code will produce different results (see DBSEEK() example) - 
there will be needed changes in the code to get the same results. Support 
for macro as a standalone command and macro list expanding can cause 
problems simmilar to RETURN++ issues we were disscusing already. Thus the 
need to disable such features by default.

  Please do whatever you like but please, at least document all 
incompatibilites caused by your code and please follow -k<enable_option> 
functionality.

Regards, Ryszard

> I will re-enable my code which again you were not authorized to 
> disable, on my next session.

  Do you like a ping-pong game? :-(

Regards, Ryszard

PS. Sorry for breaking threading - I have to use a web access to emails.

> >     *include/hbcomp.h
> >     *source/compiler/cmdcheck.c
> >     *source/compiler/hbusage.c
> >         * added new command line switch: -ki
> >         * added new flag: HB_COMPFLAG_HB_INLINE
> >         This switch enables support for HB_INLINE syntax
> >         (by default it is disabled)
> >         * all options used with -k switch are letter case sensitive
> >         * -kc (Clipper compatibility) clears all other switches (minimal
> >           set of features)
>
> What's the logic in doing something like this?
>
> Obviously the compiler will *not* support/generate inline code,
> *unless* the
> source code *contains* inline c, and the output generation requested
> supports c output.

To clarify, this change has *no* effect what's so ever, on prgs that are
*not* using inline c, and only offers adverse effect on prgs that do use
inline c. So why oh why?

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 12:50:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast, Harbour)
Date: Sun Aug  5 11:50:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-05 14:20 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <3B6D6572.22672.596C63E@localhost>
Message-ID: <001d01c11dc6$3442fce0$6400a8c0@patrick2>

Ryszard,

>     *source/compiler/hbusage.c
>         * added new command line switch: -ki
>         * added new flag: HB_COMPFLAG_HB_INLINE
>         This switch enables support for HB_INLINE syntax
>         (by default it is disabled)
>         * all options used with -k switch are letter case sensitive
>         * -kc (Clipper compatibility) clears all other 
> switches (minimal
>           set of features)
>         
>     *source/compiler/harbour.l
>         * added support for -ki command line switch
>         
>     *source/compiler/harbour.sly
>     *source/compiler/harbour.y
>         * fixed line numer issues in generated pcode

Isn't this making things a bit complicated...
We need to recompile Harbour.exe to use Inline C code??

I can imagine that it is not gonna be simple to distribute a Harbour
build with a 3rd party lib like FiveWin. What Harbour.exe are they gonna
deliver?

Isn't it better to first consult the group before making such great
changes?

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 13:20:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sun Aug  5 12:20:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <3B6D86D0.32562.6191BA4@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEECMDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> The strong typing is still not working correctly (for example, compile
> testwarn.prg => segmentation fault, compile treport.prg - many incorrect
> warnings).

I don't experience any such GPF with any of the compilers I use. Please
report more details.

> The command line switches are disabling/enabling warnings only

Not true! None of the logic for strong typing is used, unless -w3 or -w4 is
used.

> - some reserved keywords are still used for strong typing with no method
> to use them in other context (only HB_INLINE is now disabled by default).

Which reserved keywords? Do you have any example to demonstrate the problem?
Only HB_INLINE? You didn't disable my arguments list support, in both
Harbour and macro compiler? What else?

> Features available with -kh and HB_SM_HARBOUR set to TRUE are *safe*
> features. This means that the valid Clipper code is still valid in
Harbour.

Smoke & mirrors again?

   What is unsafe exactly in inline c?
   What is unsafe exactly in arguments list macro, as array index?
   What is unsafe exactly in arguments list macro, as function parameters?

> The macro compiler is extended only to support features that
> available in the normal code.

Do you suggest that arguments list as function parameters, or array indexes,
etc. are not supported in normal code?

> __dblist(), -kx and HB_SM_XBASE set to TRUE are causing that valid
> Clipper code will produce different results (see DBSEEK() example) -
> there will be needed changes in the code to get the same results. Support
> for macro as a standalone command and macro list expanding can cause
> problems simmilar to RETURN++ issues we were disscusing already. Thus the
> need to disable such features by default.

Nonsense! The extended macro support is causing factors more of
"incompatibilities", which no one complained about. See my -= vs. == sample.

>   Please do whatever you like but please, at least document all
> incompatibilites caused by your code and please follow -k<enable_option>
> functionality.

Right after you point me to the file documenting the "incompatibilities"
caused by extended macro support.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 13:39:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Horacio_Rold=E1n?=)
Date: Sun Aug  5 12:39:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour / IIS
References: <3.0.6.16.20010805030907.1e2774d2@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <001601c11dcd$72240930$f004a8c0@ksoft20000507>

Maybe this it's not related to your problem but could help you.

I had an ASP application in WinNT 4 SP3 running fine.
I upgrade the server to Win2K (IIS5) and after that I had some troubles.

The service was running ok for 2 or 3 hours and after that IIS stopped
responding requests to any .asp page (even simple ones made for testing),
but it served the .html pages.
The server logs didn't show any errors by the time of the problem, but it
reported a few errors previously with no description.
The error number did not appeared in the docs or in MS Website.
I applied patchs, the SP1 but with no luck.

I know that this does not help you but you know you are not the only with
IIS troubles. As it says: "Mal de muchos, consuelo de tontos". :-)

The solution that worked for me was switching into apache for Win32.
Now my app runs even faster!

regards
Horacio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 13:59:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sun Aug  5 12:59:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-05 14:20 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3B6D98B3.6630.65EFA10@localhost>

> Isn't this making things a bit complicated...
> We need to recompile Harbour.exe to use Inline C code??

  No. HB_INLINE is compiled in harbour.exe always. However if -ki switch 
is not used then HB_INLINE is treated as usual identifier so it can be 
used as a variable or function name. If -ki switch is passed in a command 
line then HB_INLINE is treated as C inline.

> I can imagine that it is not gonna be simple to distribute a Harbour
> build with a 3rd party lib like FiveWin. What Harbour.exe are they gonna
> deliver?

  Either flex version or simplex one. No less, no more.

> Isn't it better to first consult the group before making such great
> changes?

  Sorry, I have started to use Ron's technique - first place a code and 
next defence it. 
  Please notice that no code was removed from the cvs repository. Only 
new command line switches were added to keep more control over available 
compilation options and to give the harbour user a control over Clipper 
incompatibilities.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 14:28:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sun Aug  5 13:28:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3B6D9F67.29638.6792B36@localhost>

> I don't experience any such GPF with any of the compilers I use. Please
> report more details.

Linux/gcc
gdb shows the source in some gclib function and is unable to show the 
backtrack info. 
The last warning (if -w3 is used) is for line 107.

> > The command line switches are disabling/enabling warnings only
>
> Not true! None of the logic for strong typing is used, unless -w3 or 
> -w4 is used.
>
> > - some reserved keywords are still used for strong typing with no 
method
> > to use them in other context (only HB_INLINE is now disabled by 
default).

> Which reserved keywords? Do you have any example to demonstrate the 
> problem?

  Please try to compile:
_hb_member := 1
_hb_class := 1

> Only HB_INLINE? You didn't disable my arguments list support, in both
> Harbour and macro compiler? What else?

  Arguments list support is enabled if -kx option is used or HB_SM_XBASE 
is set to .T. (unless I have missed this one but I have just checked and 
if( HB_XBASE_SUPPORT ) is placed correctly in code).
  Only HB_INLINE is enabled/disabled because it was very easy. Support 
for strong type is burried in many placed - the biggest problem is code 
burried in hbclass.ch thus I have delayed it for much later.

> Smoke & mirrors again?
>
>   What is unsafe exactly in inline c?
>   What is unsafe exactly in arguments list macro, as array index?
>   What is unsafe exactly in arguments list macro, as function
> parameters?

  OK. I know now that you were not reading my previous messages.

> Nonsense! The extended macro support is causing factors more of
> "incompatibilities", which no one complained about. See my -= vs. == 
> sample.

  Again. Valid Clipper code is compiled correctly and behave the same 
both in Clipper and Harbour. -= and ++ operators are not valid in Clipper.

cMacro := "field1,field2"
LIST &macro

is valid in Clipper and is valid in Harbour. However if xbase 
compatibility is enabled then this will produce different results. The 
same is true for macro used as an function argument and array index. 

> Right after you point me to the file documenting the "incompatibilities"
> caused by extended macro support.

  See doc/en/compiler.txt and a new file doc/en/macro.txt or maybe we 
should create a separate file for this purpose.

Regards, Ryszard


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 15:20:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sun Aug  5 14:20:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <3B6D9F67.29638.6792B36@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIECNDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > I don't experience any such GPF with any of the compilers I use. Please
> > report more details.
>
> Linux/gcc
> gdb shows the source in some gclib function and is unable to show the
> backtrack info.
> The last warning (if -w3 is used) is for line 107.

I'll check this.

> > > The command line switches are disabling/enabling warnings only
> >
> > Not true! None of the logic for strong typing is used, unless -w3 or
> > -w4 is used.
> >
> > > - some reserved keywords are still used for strong typing with no
> method
> > > to use them in other context (only HB_INLINE is now disabled by
> default).
>
> > Which reserved keywords? Do you have any example to demonstrate the
> > problem?
>
>   Please try to compile:
> _hb_member := 1
> _hb_class := 1

All tokens starting with _ are reserved by convention! Further all tokens
with the HB_ prefix are even more so reserved! Why would you make such
obvious dishonest claim?

> > Only HB_INLINE? You didn't disable my arguments list support, in both
> > Harbour and macro compiler? What else?
>
>   Arguments list support is enabled if -kx option is used or HB_SM_XBASE
> is set to .T. (unless I have missed this one but I have just checked and
> if( HB_XBASE_SUPPORT ) is placed correctly in code).
>   Only HB_INLINE is enabled/disabled because it was very easy. Support
> for strong type is burried in many placed - the biggest problem is code
> burried in hbclass.ch thus I have delayed it for much later.

We should default to either -kc or -kxi (if -ki is needed at all). Either we
are strictly Clipper compatible by default, or we use Harbour extensions by
default. Activating only extensions you developed have no basis in logic.

> > Smoke & mirrors again?
> >
> >   What is unsafe exactly in inline c?
> >   What is unsafe exactly in arguments list macro, as array index?
> >   What is unsafe exactly in arguments list macro, as function
> > parameters?
>
>   OK. I know now that you were not reading my previous messages.

You know very well I did. Please answer instead of hiding behind
speculations:

What is unsafe with inline c, that required you to disable it by default?

What is unsafe with arguments list macro as array index, that required you
to disable it by default?

What is unsafe with arguments list macro as function parameters, that
required you to disable it by default?

Please explain why should we support:

    cMacro := "SomeFun( Param1, Param2, ParamN )"
    ? &cMacro

and:

    cMacro := "Param1"
    ? SomeFun( &cMacro )

But not

    cMacro := "Param1, Param2, ParamN"
    ? SomeFun( &cMacro )

Or why should we support:

    cMacro := "SomeArray[ Index1, Index2, IndexN ]"
    ? &cMacro

and:

    cMacro := "Index1"
    ? SomeArray[ &cMacro ]

But not:

    cMacro := "Index1, Index2, IndexN"
    ? SomeArray[ &cMacro ]

???

> > Nonsense! The extended macro support is causing factors more of
> > "incompatibilities", which no one complained about. See my -= vs. ==
> > sample.
>
>   Again. Valid Clipper code is compiled correctly and behave the same
> both in Clipper and Harbour. -= and ++ operators are not valid in Clipper.

Just like arguments list macros are invalid in Clipper and produce an error
in 99% of cases.

> cMacro := "field1,field2"
> LIST &macro
>
> is valid in Clipper and is valid in Harbour. However if xbase
> compatibility is enabled then this will produce different results. The
> same is true for macro used as an function argument and array index.

You know very well that your sample is a *side* *effect* of an
*undocumented* Clipper behavior. This only *happens* to work in Clipper, and
would be better described as a BUG. It is a bug, because it uses an
expression without producing it's value. Any attempt to use such list in
Clipper strictly contradicts the Clipper macro documentation:

     -  Lists as arguments of commands:  The macro operator (&) will
        not fully substitute or compile a list as an argument of most
        commands.  In particular, these are commands where an argument list
        is preprocessed into an array or a code block.  Instances of this
are
        arguments of the FIELDS clause and SET INDEX.  An exception is the
        SET COLOR command which preprocesses the list of colors into a
single
        character string and passes it to the SETCOLOR() function.

> > Right after you point me to the file documenting the "incompatibilities"
> > caused by extended macro support.
>
>   See doc/en/compiler.txt and a new file doc/en/macro.txt or maybe we
> should create a separate file for this purpose.

You have already documented the arguments list macro an Harbour extension,
what would you like me to add?

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug  5 16:27:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Sun Aug  5 15:27:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-05 12:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIECNDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCECODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-08-05 12:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   + include/hbmsetup.h
   * include/hbmacro.h
     * Moved #defines of HB_SM_* to new file hbmsetup.h

   * source/compiler/harbour.c
   * source/vm/macro.c
   * source/compiler/genc.c
     + Added logic to automatically synchronize HB_SETMACRO() level with
the -k option supplied to compiler.

     /* HB_SETMACRO() may still be called explicitly, but now specifying
any -k option to Harbour will automatically provide same
       level of functionality in macro compiler. Example:

           harbour test -kc

        will restrict the compiler to the Clipper level mode, and will
automatically disable extended macro support in that module
        without requiring:

           HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_HARBOUR, .F. )
           HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_XBASE, .F. )

        By default all Harbour extensions are enabled - you can
use -kc, -kx -ki, etc., to disable any unwanted feature.

        We should still review the need to have -ki which I find absolutely
redundant and unproductive.
     */

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 07:03:05 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)

Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100

Ron,

> All tokens starting with _ are reserved by convention!

Perhaps that's excessive.

> all tokens with the HB_ prefix are even more so reserved!

Sounds OK.

> We should default to either -kc or -kxi

I don't see the logic.  I'd vote for -kc if that's the choice.

> What is unsafe with inline c, that required you to disable it by defaul=
t?

I'd prefer it disabled by default, whether it's unsafe or not. :-)

>    cMacro :=3D "Param1, Param2, ParamN"
>    ? SomeFun( &cMacro )

IMO that is a problem waiting to surface.  It can have 2 meanings:
a func called with 3 params or (my choice) a func with one param, in
this case a comma-expression.

Sticking to what Clipper does may be best. :-)

>    cMacro :=3D "Index1, Index2, IndexN"
>    ? SomeArray[ &cMacro ]

Similar issue.

> > cMacro :=3D "field1,field2"
> > LIST &macro
> >
> > is valid in Clipper and is valid in Harbour. However if xbase
> > compatibility is enabled then this will produce different results. Th=
e
> > same is true for macro used as an function argument and array index.

I suggest the Clipper behaviour be the default.  I don't personally
even see any point in having the non-Clipper behaviour.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 07:49:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug  6 06:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108060601_MC3-DB6E-CAB2@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 06:01:02AM -0400
References: <200108060601_MC3-DB6E-CAB2@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010806114106.I30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 06:01:02AM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Ron,
> 
> >    cMacro := "Param1, Param2, ParamN"
> >    ? SomeFun( &cMacro )
> 
> IMO that is a problem waiting to surface. It can have 2 meanings: a func
> called with 3 params or (my choice) a func with one param, in this case a
> comma-expression.

How could the above be seen as a function call with one parameter? I can't
see a comma-expression in the above. For this to be the case wouldn't the
above had to be either this:

,----
| cMacro := "( Param1, Param2, ParamN )"
| ? SomeFun( &cMacro )
`----

or this:

,----
| cMacro := "Param1, Param2, ParamN"
| ? SomeFun( ( &cMacro ) )
`----

Or did you mean something else by "comma-expression"?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 08:28:02 2001

On Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 11:46:03AM +0100, Fergus McDonald wrote:

> Does anyone know of any major issues or reasons why this driver has no
> code in place to output text?
> 
> If not, I'd like to work on it, cos I want a really minimal streams output
> for my clipper code running under GNU/Linux.

I think gtcgi is supposed to serve that purpose:

,----
| davep@hagbard:/usr/local/src/harbour/source/rtl/gtcgi$ head gtcgi.c
| /*
|  * $Id: gtcgi.c,v 1.4 2001/05/15 13:02:06 vszakats Exp $
|  */
| 
| /*
|  * Harbour Project source code:
|  * Video subsystem for plain ANSI C stream IO
|  *
|  * Copyright 1999-2001 Viktor Szakats <viktor.szakats@syenar.hu>
|  * www - http://www.harbour-project.org
`----

Hmm, confusingly gtstd makes the same claim:

,----
| davep@hagbard:/usr/local/src/harbour/source/rtl/gtstd$ head gtstd.c
| /*
|  * $Id: gtstd.c,v 1.21 2001/05/15 13:02:06 vszakats Exp $
|  */
| 
| /*
|  * Harbour Project source code:
|  * Video subsystem for plain ANSI C stream IO
|  *
|  * Copyright 1999-2001 Viktor Szakats <viktor.szakats@syenar.hu>
|  * www - http://www.harbour-project.org
`----

David, you reading this? We (or, rather, you did the coding IIRC) did some
work to provide a standard IO driver. Was gtstd supposed to serve that
purpose?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 08:53:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Mon Aug  6 07:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Unreleased memory block, Help needed  ...
Message-ID: <3B6EA150.19918.1056BFB@localhost>

Yes, I need help again :-((

Remember, the problem where ::Super:Create(::nX) was causing 
::Nx to be seen as ::Super:Nx :-(( (Full story on the mail history :-) )

My solution seemed simple

1) I create a New array of 1 elem. within hb_msgSuper() in 
classes.c 
2) I assign it the correct value to is uiClass and uiPrevClass 
BaseArray member to fool Harbour it's an object
3) I put the self object to it's 1st elem. to keep it as I will need it 
soon.
4) Treatment ...
When reaching Vmdo or VmSend (hvm.c), I first get the Method 
using the fake object, then I swap (using hb_itemswap() and 
hb_ArrayGetItemPtr() ) the fake object and the real Self on the 
stack and I would like to release the now unneeded array/object...
but any try to do this give me a very nice GPF...
If I don't do it, everythink is working but I get as many unreleased 
block as the Super method is called anywhere at the end of the 
program..

I suspect I use the wrong way to exchange the value on the stack.
Clearly when reaching VmSend and before luanching the pFunc 
(function) pointer I should have changed the current pSelf value on 
the stack and I _must_ release the old one ... I'm in fact not sure 
the exchange worked, this could explain the GPF when releasing it.

PS : I Can't use an hb_itemRelease( hb_itemReturn()) as this 
result in a NIL ITEM on the stack...

Any Idea, welcome ...

-- 

Best regards,

J. Lefebvre <jflefebv@mafact.com>
Mafact SA/NV
Belgium
(See us at http://www.mafact.com)
jflefebv@mafact.com

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 09:39:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Mon Aug  6 08:39:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-05 12:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas
Message-ID: <3B6EA655.6924.122BFA2@localhost>

Ron wrote:

>     /* HB_SETMACRO() may still be called explicitly, but now specifying
> any -k option to Harbour will automatically provide same
>       level of functionality in macro compiler. Example:

  Ron, please think a little.

  With your change you have destroyed a clear separation between compile 
time settings and the runtime settings. 

  Additionally you have killed the possibility to use a single global 
settings during the runtime because call to hb_macroSetMacro() is 
hardcoded in *EVERY* first prg level function/procedure contained in a 
module. It is the worst possible solution - because it will cause a 
random behaviour - the set of available options will depend on the order 
of called functions.
  This also kills the possibility to use settings at the runtime based on 
some configuration files. Now the programmer have to add a call to 
HB_SETMACRO() to every function/procedure to get the same behaviour in a 
whole application.

Please remove this horrible solution.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 12:31:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Aug  6 11:31:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtstd driver todo
In-Reply-To: <20010806122729.M30092@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <002501c11e61$653752b0$6400a8c0@patrick2> <001801c11e64$fdeaf040$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <20010806122729.M30092@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <200108061130.000000XQ@Internet>

** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Mon, 6 Aug
2001 12:27:29 +0100

> > Does anyone know of any major issues or reasons why this driver has no
> > code in place to output text?
> > 
> > If not, I'd like to work on it, cos I want a really minimal streams output
> > for my clipper code running under GNU/Linux.
> 
> I think gtcgi is supposed to serve that purpose:
> ...
> Hmm, confusingly gtstd makes the same claim:
> ...
> David, you reading this? We (or, rather, you did the coding IIRC) did some
> work to provide a standard IO driver. Was gtstd supposed to serve that
> purpose?

The GTCGI driver is a minimal streams output driver (the most it ever
does for cursor positioning is advance by one line and then space over
to the correct column position), but it does not support any keyboard
input whatsoever (it returns a CR character every time that Harbour
attempts to poll the keyboard).

Early on, the GTSTD driver attempted to emulate cursor positioning by
using LF and space characters, but all of that was stripped out for
reasons that I no longer remember and a search for "gtcgi or gtstd" in
my message archive subject lines did not uncover. Basically, GTSTD
supports ? (QOUT), ?? (QQOUT), and box/line drawing and supports
untranslated keyboard input via STDIN.

I see nothing wrong with taking the console output routines from GTCGI
and grafting them onto GTSTD.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 12:40:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Mon Aug  6 11:40:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtstd driver todo
References: <002501c11e61$653752b0$6400a8c0@patrick2> <001801c11e64$fdeaf040$0205a8c0@apollo> <20010806122729.M30092@hagbard.davep.org> <200108061130.000000XQ@Internet>
Message-ID: <005a01c11e8d$f104f320$0205a8c0@apollo>

right.. thinks are becoming clearer :)

Since gtcgi has no keyboard input, I've been working on gtstd here. I've
brought back in the unix OS keyboard support, and the output routines for
the last few revisions, and fixed a bug or two. It's working ok now for
straightforward command-line application stuff.

Do you guys want me to keep going?

Regards

Fergus

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 12:58:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Aug  6 11:58:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] How to join
In-Reply-To: <001e01c11db8$4f5987a0$0205a8c0@apollo>
References: <3B6D4CA6.1395@synel.co.il> <3B6D51B1.4635@synel.co.il> <001e01c11db8$4f5987a0$0205a8c0@apollo>
Message-ID: <200108061157.000000XU@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Fergus McDonald" <listsub@qvolution.com> on
Sun, 5 Aug 2001 15:09:57 +0100

> btw.. I'm very impressed with this project to date. I'd like to help with
> the work on the DBFCDX driver particularly.. who/what do I do to get
> involved..?

For starters, you can submit your changes to a SourceForge developer
who is willing to look your work over and upload it to CVS. For the
GTSTD changes, you can email the finished changes directly to me at
<harbour@spacemoose.com>.

After you've proven yourself (or if another developer vouches for you),
you should sign up at http://www.sourceforge.net/ and then post your
SourceForge ID here along with a request to be added to the Harbour
project as a developer. You will then be able to switch from anonymous
CVS access to developer CVS access and commit your changes directly.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 13:30:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon Aug  6 12:30:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108060601_MC3-DB6E-CAB2@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEDDDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > We should default to either -kc or -kxi
>
> I don't see the logic.  I'd vote for -kc if that's the choice.

Don't see which logic?

> > What is unsafe with inline c, that required you to disable it
> by default?
>
> I'd prefer it disabled by default, whether it's unsafe or not. :-)

How could it affect you, if you don't use it?

> >    cMacro := "Param1, Param2, ParamN"
> >    ? SomeFun( &cMacro )
>
> IMO that is a problem waiting to surface.  It can have 2 meanings:
> a func called with 3 params or (my choice) a func with one param, in
> this case a comma-expression.

It can't have 2 meanings, the Clipper language clearly documents the
difference. The proper form of a comma expression is:

   (Param1, Param2, ParamN)

> Sticking to what Clipper does may be best. :-)

IIRC, Clipper did support it up to S87. When I developed the support, it was
clear to me, that its omission from 5.x was pure "laziness".

> > > cMacro := "field1,field2"
> > > LIST &macro
> > >
> > > is valid in Clipper and is valid in Harbour. However if xbase
> > > compatibility is enabled then this will produce different results. The
> > > same is true for macro used as an function argument and array index.
>
> I suggest the Clipper behavior be the default.  I don't personally
> even see any point in having the non-Clipper behaviour.

Clipper had this support up to S87, most other xBase dialects have this
support. It wasn't your opinion of other Clipper shortcomings as I recall?

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 13:31:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug  6 12:31:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtstd driver todo
In-Reply-To: <001f01c11e74$235cf9e0$0205a8c0@apollo>; from listsub@qvolution.com on Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 01:34:28PM +0100
References: <002501c11e61$653752b0$6400a8c0@patrick2> <001801c11e64$fdeaf040$0205a8c0@apollo> <20010806122729.M30092@hagbard.davep.org> <001f01c11e74$235cf9e0$0205a8c0@apollo>
Message-ID: <20010806170850.P30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 01:34:28PM +0100, Fergus McDonald wrote:

> ah yes..
> that seems reasonable.
> but shouldn't gtstd have some sort of output? appears to be nothing in
> xPutch etc since revision 1.19

See David's response too. Further to my question to him I think I can recall
the reasons why GTSTD does nothing now. IIRC the idea was that GTSTD is a
"do nothing at all" driver so that people can build applications that use
the low level file I/O functions without the GT layer getting involved at
all.

Then you've got the GTCGI driver which attempts to do low level IO via the
GT layer.

That's my recollection anyway:

o GTSTD == Do absolutely nothing, allow programmer to use FWRITE() and the
  like to do output.

o GTCGI == Do minimal low level output via GT. Programmer uses QOUT() and
  friends to do output.

If the code doesn't reflect the above then there's probably some fixing
needs to take place.

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/
                                                http://www.boycottadobe.org/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 13:40:03 2001

Actually, let me have few more moments. I want to add minor extra logic, so
sync is only done once per application for main module only. Since this
takes place before any user code, it's only the default integration. User
can have complete separation if required for some odd reason.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 13:47:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Mon Aug  6 12:47:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108061245_MC3-DB95-109@compuserve.com>

Patrick,

> > I'd prefer it [inline c] disabled by default, whether it's unsafe or =
not. :-)

> Why? If you choose not to use it it does nothing at all...

If a PRG includes inline C I'd prefer to get a compile error with the
default compiler settings.  That way new users (and I) won't get
surprised so easily as might otherwise occur.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 13:47:15 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Mon Aug  6 12:47:15 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OrdSetFocus() bug
Message-ID: <200108061245_MC3-DB95-10B@compuserve.com>

Brian,

> Is there a practical or philosophical reason why strncpy is better?

In general, don't use strncpy for Clipper-compatible strings since
they can contain internal nulls and the copy should not stop at such
a null.  memcpy is what's normally wanted.  It's also easy for a
compiler to optimise. :-)

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 13:48:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Mon Aug  6 12:48:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108061245_MC3-DB95-108@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> > >    cMacro :=3D "Param1, Param2, ParamN"
> > >    ? SomeFun( &cMacro )
> > =

> > IMO that is a problem waiting to surface. It can have 2 meanings: a f=
unc
> > called with 3 params or (my choice) a func with one param, in this ca=
se a
> > comma-expression.

> How could the above be seen as a function call with one parameter?

Common (I hesitate to say "normal") parsing would result in that.  It
looks to be how clipper.exe parses it, if that's relevant. :-)

> I can't see a comma-expression in the above.

It's very easy to argue the opposite. :-)

Hmm... it can also have a 3rd meaning: a func with one param, which
when macroed is found to be badly-formed.

I suppose what I really meant was: I don't see how it can be Clipper-
compatible if it's compiled as anything but a func being passed one
param.  Whether that param is allowed with Clipper is another thing.

> For this to be the case wouldn't the above had to be either this:
> | cMacro :=3D "( Param1, Param2, ParamN )"
> | ? SomeFun( &cMacro )
> or this:
> | cMacro :=3D "Param1, Param2, ParamN"
> | ? SomeFun( ( &cMacro ) )

I would expect those would be calls with one param.  It depends on the
language's semantics/grammar as to whether the case at the top means
the same.

John.

On Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 04:39:11PM +0100, Fergus McDonald wrote:

> Since gtcgi has no keyboard input, I've been working on gtstd here. I've
> brought back in the unix OS keyboard support, and the output routines for
> the last few revisions, and fixed a bug or two. It's working ok now for
> straightforward command-line application stuff.
> 
> Do you guys want me to keep going?

As long as it doesn't change anything so that it's incompatible with current
workings I see no problem.

BTW, I've done a little digging to try and refresh my memory about the
conversation David and I had about the whole "standard" output thing that
lead to some changes being made. It started with a thread on usenet, look at
<URL:http://groups.google.com/groups?hl=en&safe=off&th=741464abc06a5ca1,10>,
that will give some background.

There was an exchange on the harbour lists too but, looking at the date of
the posts in <URL:news:comp.lang.clipper>, it would appear that this
exchange pre-dates us moving the mailing lists to Phil's box so the exchange
won't be in the archives that Phil has (David, perhaps the dates of the
above Google thread will give you some idea as to where in your archives
you'll find the exchange?).

As you can see from the above URL the problem was that GTSTD was blocking
for keyboard input when none was required. You might want to keep the issues
raised in that thread in mind.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 14:31:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug  6 13:31:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108061245_MC3-DB95-108@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 12:45:23PM -0400
References: <200108061245_MC3-DB95-108@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010806183027.R30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 12:45:23PM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > How could the above be seen as a function call with one parameter?
> 
> Common (I hesitate to say "normal") parsing would result in that. It looks
> to be how clipper.exe parses it, if that's relevant. :-)

I know how CA-Clipper sees it, perhaps you were on your holiday when Ron and
I had a "discussion" about this exact issue? Take a look at the pointers in
harbour news <URL:http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/#20010718092356>. See
<URL:http://www.matrixlist.com/pipermail/harbour/2001-July/007413.html> for
how I was wondering about this issue.

> > I can't see a comma-expression in the above.
> 
> It's very easy to argue the opposite. :-)

Actually I think it's very hard to argue the opposite. In CA-Clipper terms
what you posted was simply an error. If it's not an error one thing I can't
be is a comma-expression.

> Hmm... it can also have a 3rd meaning: a func with one param, which when
> macroed is found to be badly-formed.

That's the CA-Clipper version of events (see above). For it to be a list
expression it would have to be enclosed in parens other than the parens that
form the function call.

> I suppose what I really meant was: I don't see how it can be Clipper-
> compatible if it's compiled as anything but a func being passed one param.
> Whether that param is allowed with Clipper is another thing.

The only CA-Clipper compatibility available to us is to throw a runtime
error. If we decide to not throw a runtime error then the next obvious
interpretation is the one that Ron has implemented. Treating it as a list
expression strikes me as the least obvious interpretation available to us.

Ron,

> > > We should default to either -kc or -kxi
> >
> > I don't see the logic.  I'd vote for -kc if that's the choice.

> Don't see which logic?

As to why it's only the specific either-or choice above.

> > I'd prefer it disabled by default, whether it's unsafe or not. :-)

> How could it affect you, if you don't use it?

Anyone can use it in a file amongst many others I may get or be sent
(which includes Harbour itself).  I'd like the default settings for
Harbour to be that it behaves like Clipper so that I get an error if I
compile a file containing inline C, thus warning me of the situation.

> It can't have 2 meanings

I've posted them.

> the Clipper language clearly documents the difference

Please let me know where is doc'ed the meaning of SomeFunc( &macro ).

BTW, sometimes the Clipper docs are unclear/wrong and/or they conflict
with what the compiler/runtime do.  Maybe this is a case.

> The proper form of a comma expression is:
>   (Param1, Param2, ParamN)

Whether true or not, that doesn't alter that clipper.exe parses
SomeFunc( &macro ) as a function call with one param.

> IIRC, Clipper did support it up to S87.

A -kS87 option is fine by me if someone wants to do that. :-)

> When I developed the support, it was clear to me, that its omission
> from 5.x was pure "laziness".

I think it wasn't "laziness" but rather that Clipper 5, by design, is
more like most compiled languages and less like interpreted ones.

> Clipper had this support up to S87, most other xBase dialects have this=

> support.

Does your "most" include Xbase++ and VO?  Which _compiled_ Xbase
dialects do have this support?

> It wasn't your opinion of other Clipper shortcomings as I recall?

I'm not sure what your point is.  What does my opinion of some Clipper
shortcomings have to do with the current matter?  AFAIK the current
issue is unrelated.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 14:35:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug  6 13:35:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-05 12:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEDDDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 09:42:08AM -0700
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDCDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEDDDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010806183420.S30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 09:42:08AM -0700, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> Actually, let me have few more moments. I want to add minor extra logic,
> so sync is only done once per application for main module only. Since this
> takes place before any user code, it's only the default integration. User
> can have complete separation if required for some odd reason.

Would it have to be an odd reason? Suppose I write code that relies on one
way of working, compile it and provide you with a library. Throw in a number
of other such libraries, each author preferring their own switches. You then
want to mix their (binary distributed) libraries with your code. You
wouldn't the code of all those libraries using your switch preference would
you?

Put another way - would it be any less odd to not want the logic
short-cutting of every object (file) in an application be set by the switch
that was used to compile the "main" module of an application?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 15:31:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Mon Aug  6 14:31:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIECNDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <3B6D9F67.29638.6792B36@localhost>
Message-ID: <3B6EFF03.18682.27D2620@localhost>

On 5 Aug 2001, at 11:22, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> You know very well that your sample is a *side* *effect* of an
> *undocumented* Clipper behavior. This only *happens* to work in Clipper, and
> would be better described as a BUG. It is a bug, because it uses an
> expression without producing it's value. Any attempt to use such list in
> Clipper strictly contradicts the Clipper macro documentation:

   So are you trying to tell us that support for list expressions in a 
codeblock is a Clipper bug? For example - what is the difference between:

EVAL( {|| DBSEEK(somewhere),someField} )

and

cMacro:="DBSEEK(somewhere),someField"
EVAL( {|| &cMacro} )

  If Clipper compiles the first then it normal that the second is 
compiled correctly too. And both expressions produce a single value just 
like all expressions in Clipper.

> 
>      -  Lists as arguments of commands:  The macro operator (&) will
>         not fully substitute or compile a list as an argument of most
>         commands.  In particular, these are commands where an argument list
>         is preprocessed into an array or a code block.  Instances of this
> are
>         arguments of the FIELDS clause and SET INDEX.  An exception is the
>         SET COLOR command which preprocesses the list of colors into a
> single
>         character string and passes it to the SETCOLOR() function.

  Ron, this says all. The list of expressions is not supported in macro 
in the meaning as a list of separate expressions. In other words, in 
Clipper:

LIST field1,field2,field3

cannot be substituted with

cmacro:="field1,field2,field3"
LIST &cmacro

because "field1,field2,field3" is interpreted as "(field1,fiel2,field3)" 
wchich gives a single value because it is preprocessed as a list inside a 
codeblock.
  Clipper is clear here. The bug is in your thinking.

> 
> You have already documented the arguments list macro an Harbour extension,
> what would you like me to add?

  Do we have documented incompatibilities in __dblist() somewhere?

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug  6 15:32:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Mon Aug  6 14:32:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <3B6E8EF6.5B70@synel.co.il>
Message-ID: <3B6EFFF0.18654.280C190@localhost>

On 6 Aug 2001, at 15:35, Chen Kedem wrote:

> The new HB_SM_* constants in include/set.ch
> are defined outside the _SET_CH guard !

  All settings defined in _SET_CH are ignored by the preprocessor because 
_SET_CH is defined by default - it's definition is hardcoded inside a 
pptable.c.
  I decided to not change the pptable.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 05:22:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Aug  7 04:22:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <3B6EFF03.18682.27D2620@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEDIDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > You know very well that your sample is a *side* *effect* of an
> > *undocumented* Clipper behavior. This only *happens* to work in
> Clipper, and
> > would be better described as a BUG. It is a bug, because it uses an
> > expression without producing it's value. Any attempt to use such list in
> > Clipper strictly contradicts the Clipper macro documentation:
>
>    So are you trying to tell us that support for list expressions in a
> codeblock is a Clipper bug?

No, though block lists are inconsistent (elsewhere, list produces all values
unless parenthesized), this is not the side effect I was talking about. I
referred to:

   LIST &cMAcro

It is only incidental that LIST is preprocessed to use codeblocks. If anyone
implements LIST any other way, this wouldn't  have worked. Such side effect
should not be relied upon. The proper way to assure such behavior is to use
parenthesized expression.

> For example - what is the difference between:
>
> EVAL( {|| DBSEEK(somewhere),someField} )
>
> and
>
> cMacro:="DBSEEK(somewhere),someField"
> EVAL( {|| &cMacro} )
>
>   If Clipper compiles the first then it normal that the second is
> compiled correctly too. And both expressions produce a single value just
> like all expressions in Clipper.

I'm glad you noticed that. Now let's ask since it *does* correctly handle
the *list* macro in a code block, why should it fail with this:

cMacro:="DBSEEK(somewhere),someField"
SomeVar := ( &cMacro )

Or even this:

cMacro:="DBSEEK(somewhere),someField"
SomeFun( (&cMacro) )

Is there any reason it will correctly handle list macro (evaluating all
sub-expressions) in codeblock context, but not be able to do same with the
above???

Why shouldn't we consider it a bug?

If you see the point, I hope you'll realize that the list macro without
parenthesis, should also behave exactly as in the non macroed Clipper in all
contexts. Anything short of this must be considered a bug.

>   Ron, this says all. The list of expressions is not supported in macro
> in the meaning as a list of separate expressions. In other words, in
> Clipper:
>
> LIST field1,field2,field3
>
> cannot be substituted with
>
> cmacro:="field1,field2,field3"
> LIST &cmacro

Ryszard, this is only because of a serious Clipper implementation problem.
One shouldn't consider this limitation valid, just because the Clipper
implementation of LIST happened to use codeblocks. This is not necessary.
Again just ask your self if list macros *are* valid within codeblocks, why
shouldn't they work in other identical context like ( &cMacro ) and in such
commands?

> because "field1,field2,field3" is interpreted as "(field1,fiel2,field3)"
> wchich gives a single value because it is preprocessed as a list inside a
> codeblock.

No it is interpreted as "field1, field2, field3" which *in* *a* *codeblock*
is handled like any other list expression ( evaluate *each* sub expression,
and pop all but the last).

Had the Nantucket guys completed macro support to properly support lists, in
all other contexts, they could/should have used *nonblock* for the macro
expression, and would have had to solve macro lists in high level syntax
like LIST, much like my implementation, and much like you would have done,
if decided to support it.

>   Clipper is clear here. The bug is in your thinking.

Please rethink this.

> > You have already documented the arguments list macro an Harbour
> extension,
> > what would you like me to add?
>
>   Do we have documented incompatibilities in __dblist() somewhere?

We didn't have [AFAIK] any of our incompatibilities/enhancements documented.
I just started a new file /doc/en/clipper.txt with the portions I could
fill. There are many many more such items to add, including ones I may be
responsible for.

Ron


␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 14:14:03 2001

Subject: [Harbour] Unable to compile Harbour with today CVS ...
In-Reply-To: <3B6FB36A.28346.2EED0@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> Just to have an idea of what I does'nt find :-(, may I know where 
> was the problem ?

Had to change:

  extern ULONG hb_macroSetMacro( BOOL bSet, ULONG flag );

To:

  #ifdef __cplusplus
    extern "C" ULONG hb_macroSetMacro( BOOL bSet, ULONG flag );
  #else
    extern ULONG hb_macroSetMacro( BOOL bSet, ULONG flag );
  #endif

Ron

> > was the problem ?
