> 
>   extern ULONG hb_macroSetMacro( BOOL bSet, ULONG flag );
> 
> To:
> 
>   #ifdef __cplusplus
>     extern "C" ULONG hb_macroSetMacro( BOOL bSet, ULONG flag );
>   #else
>     extern ULONG hb_macroSetMacro( BOOL bSet, ULONG flag );
>   #endif

Well, any idea why this problem arise there but not for many other 
extern declaration ?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 14:28:12 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Aug  7 13:28:12 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEDCDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 09:16:58AM -0700
References: <3B6EA655.6924.122BFA2@localhost> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEDCDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010807095929.W30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Aug 06, 2001 at 09:16:58AM -0700, Ron Pinkas wrote:
> 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
>    * source/compiler/genc.c
>      ! Improved sync logic of HB_SETMACRO() level, to only activate once per
> module with same level used by compiler.

How is this syncing supposed to work from a Clipper programmer's point of
view? What should I see in my code?

For example, I've got two source files:

,----[ foo.prg ]
| #include "set.ch"
| 
| Function Main()
| 
|    ? HB_SetMacro( HB_SM_HARBOUR )
|    Bar()
|    ? HB_SetMacro( HB_SM_HARBOUR )
|    
| Return( NIL )
`----

and:

,----[ bar.prg ]
| #include "set.ch"
| 
| Function Bar()
| 
|    ? "In Bar ", HB_SetMacro( HB_SM_HARBOUR )
|    
| Return( NIL )
`----

I compile foo has normal (implied -kh, right?) and I compiler bar with
CA-Clipper compatibility turned on (-kc, right?).

Now, if I'm to understanding this "syncing" business HB_SM_HARBOUR should be
true in foo but false in bar, right?

I'm not seeing that when I run the above program:

,----
| .T.
| In Bar  .T.
| .T.
`----

Can someone correct my confusion?

-- 
Harbour is a free   | Harbour Web Site: http://www.harbour-project.org/
software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 14:32:07 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Aug  7 13:32:07 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108061331_MC3-DB82-D82A@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEDMDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > Don't see which logic?
>
> As to why it's only the specific either-or choice above.

Not "only". It's just more sensible to either disable all extensions, or
enable all such extensions, otherwise, what would be the *objective* guiding
principal?

> > > I'd prefer it disabled by default, whether it's unsafe or not. :-)
>
> > How could it affect you, if you don't use it?
>
> Anyone can use it in a file amongst many others I may get or be sent
> (which includes Harbour itself).  I'd like the default settings for
> Harbour to be that it behaves like Clipper so that I get an error if I
> compile a file containing inline C, thus warning me of the situation.

What would there be to warn, or for you to be concerned with?

> > the Clipper language clearly documents the difference
>
> Please let me know where is doc'ed the meaning of SomeFunc( &macro ).

This is not the issue we were debating. We were questioning the possible
ambiguity of the meaning of such expression. Don't you think that macro
expression should behave in the exact same [non ambiguous] way of their non
macroed counterparts?

> BTW, sometimes the Clipper docs are unclear/wrong and/or they conflict
> with what the compiler/runtime do.  Maybe this is a case.

I'm afraid that the macro inconsistencies, are nothing more then  an
indication of an incomplete body of work.

> > The proper form of a comma expression is:
> >   (Param1, Param2, ParamN)
>
> Whether true or not, that doesn't alter that clipper.exe parses
> SomeFunc( &macro ) as a function call with one param.

See above, and recent message to Ryszard, explaining why this should be
considered a bug.

> > When I developed the support, it was clear to me, that its omission
> > from 5.x was pure "laziness".
>
> I think it wasn't "laziness" but rather that Clipper 5, by design, is
> more like most compiled languages and less like interpreted ones.

Please explain how is that consistent with the fact that the macro is able
to compile practically any expression other then few odd omissions? Try to
revaluate your statement in light of Clipper "understanding" the same kind
of list macro in a code block context.

Clipper 5 is unlike most compiled languages, in that it offers an [almost]
complete run-time compiler for [just about] any expression that the compiled
language support. In light of what it does do, I consider what it can't
handle a bug. Simple list of such clear omissions include: exp++, --exp, exp
+= exp, (exp), and {|| &NestedBlcokMacro }. But also Var := ( &cListMacro )
etc,.

> > Clipper had this support up to S87, most other xBase dialects have this
> > support.
>
> Does your "most" include Xbase++ and VO?  Which _compiled_ Xbase
> dialects do have this support?

AFAIK, FoxPro, FlagShip, Clipper versions prior to 5.x, and Harbour :-).

> > It wasn't your opinion of other Clipper shortcomings as I recall?
>
> I'm not sure what your point is.  What does my opinion of some Clipper
> shortcomings have to do with the current matter?  AFAIK the current
> issue is unrelated.

The "judgment" ;-) that Clipper (consistent, documented, or not) must be the
guide. We should be more open minded to evaluation of bugs, shortcomings,
inconsistencies, etc, not just when it involves an issue pressing on
individual problem. The evaluation process should be as objective as
possible, from a language design, point of view.

* Hard to project friendliness in an intense technical arguments, please
forgive me if I come across too aggressive, just my opinionisem ;-).

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 14:46:12 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Tue Aug  7 13:46:12 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIECNDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <3B6D9F67.29638.6792B36@localhost>
Message-ID: <3B6FC702.10319.3A0441@localhost>

On 5 Aug 2001, at 11:22, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> > > Which reserved keywords? Do you have any example to demonstrate the
> > > problem?
> >
> >   Please try to compile:
> > _hb_member := 1
> > _hb_class := 1
> 
> All tokens starting with _ are reserved by convention! Further all tokens
> with the HB_ prefix are even more so reserved! Why would you make such
> obvious dishonest claim?

  Most reserved keywords don't use the underscore or HB_ refix (NEXT, 
WHILE, etc) but can be used in identifier context (some are less or more 
limited). Also most underscored symbols can be reused by the user. 
  There are three taboo symbols however: _hb_member and _hb_class and 
HB_INLINE - they cannot be reused in a different context.

  Ron, not all programmers live on isolated island. Some of them need 
cooperate in environments where shared resources exist. These shared 
resourses may know nothing about the harbour and may use names that are 
reserved words in harbour. Hence the need to define a minimal set of 
reserved words and the need to allow reuse these words in different 
context.

Regards, Ryszard


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 14:47:30 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Aug  7 13:47:30 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108071316_MC3-DBBB-1DD0@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDNDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > For it to be a list expression it would have to be enclosed in
> > parens other than the parens that form the function call.
>
> That's not necessary.

It is necessary from the standpoint of the documented syntax of expressions.

> It looks like we're deadlocked.  What happens next - a vote?  Or does
> someone implement the behaviour they like and thus more or less force

Well we already have a switch to control this behavior, why would you
suggest forcing?

something happen, end up having more of a say then those less active. This
is just an observation, not related to Harbour in any way.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 15:05:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Tue Aug  7 14:05:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo>

Been working on the gtstd driver, and loathe as I would be to make changes
to gtapi.c, there does seem to be a problem in the hb_gtWriteCon function.

After calling hb_gtWrite() to output the 'visible' text as it were, it then
makes changes to the row/col position based on control chars parsed earlier,
and informs the gt driver of the new position via hb_gtSetPosContext (line
1059, revision 1.151).

However, it does this with HB_GT_SET_POS_AFTER method, which implies the
positional change has already taken place on the physical device, where in
fact it has not. I believe it should be HB_GT_SET_POS_BEFORE.

This doesn't have any impact on the slang or ncurses drivers anyway, cos
they both ignore the method parameter and alwasy set the pos, but in the
gtstd i'm trying to limit making physical pos changes to BEFORE mode (which
I think is the intention), and it doesn't work unless the above change is
made.

Anyone care to agree/disagree?

Regards

Fergus



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 15:10:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Aug  7 14:10:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <20010807095929.W30092@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> How is this syncing supposed to work from a Clipper programmer's point of
> view? What should I see in my code?

Syncing is only provided for the main module, so that any user's explicit
setting will not be overridden. Rather then have completely obscured
default, it simply attempts to offer just a slightly more relevant staring
point.

I still find serious problems with the implementation of HB_SETMACRO() over
all.

I think this management, should be completely automated and compile time
driven. Otherwise, *every* well behave module *anyone* develops, *must*
first save current settings, then set the desired level, and later restore
previous values, for *every* macro activation. This seems redundant, and can
be achieved automatically.

In essence, we could add just 1 more byte after the HB_MACROPUSH* opcodes
which indicate the compile time flag for that module. The HVM processing of
the HB_P_MACROPUSH* will read the byte and set hbmacroSetMacro() with the
appropriate value.

Ryszard?

Ron



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 15:21:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Aug  7 14:21:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <3B6FC702.10319.3A0441@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEDPDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > All tokens starting with _ are reserved by convention! Further
> all tokens
> > with the HB_ prefix are even more so reserved! Why would you make such
> > obvious dishonest claim?
>
>   Most reserved keywords don't use the underscore or HB_ refix (NEXT,
> WHILE, etc) but can be used in identifier context (some are less or more
> limited). Also most underscored symbols can be reused by the user.
>   There are three taboo symbols however: _hb_member and _hb_class and
> HB_INLINE - they cannot be reused in a different context.

Ryszard, you know that this can easily be fixed if desired, based on context
(without having to use any compiler limitation switch)!

>   Ron, not all programmers live on isolated island. Some of them need
> cooperate in environments where shared resources exist. These shared
> resourses may know nothing about the harbour and may use names that are
> reserved words in harbour. Hence the need to define a minimal set of
> reserved words and the need to allow reuse these words in different
> context.

Ok, I'm just surprised that you appear so sensitive to reservation of odd
tokens like _hb_member, _hb_class, and hb_inline. It is somewhat odd, that
when I developed simple context based logic, to allow de-reservation of some
partially reserved Clipper tokens, you dismissed the need for it, yet these
far less likely to be used tokens, are of more interest to you.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 15:25:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue Aug  7 14:25:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
In-Reply-To: <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo>
Message-ID: <200108071424.000000YS@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Fergus McDonald" <fergus@qvolution.com> on
Tue, 7 Aug 2001 13:37:04 +0100

> However, it does this with HB_GT_SET_POS_AFTER method, which implies the
> positional change has already taken place on the physical device, where in
> fact it has not. I believe it should be HB_GT_SET_POS_BEFORE.

The only thing that HB_GT_SET_POS_BEFORE and HB_GT_SET_POS_AFTER are
telling the hb_gt driver is if this cursor positioning call is taking
place before or after text was written using the hb_gt driver. There is
no implication of whether or not a positional change has taken place,
which is entirely up to the hb_gt driver to determine.

For example, with the hb_gt driver gtwin, writing the text does not
actually change the cursor position, so the gtwin driver must set the
correct cursor position.

But with the hb_gt driver gtpca, the cursor position has changed and
the gtpca driver only needs to record the current cursor position. Which
should also be the case for the gtstd driver (i.e., the cursor needs to
be positioned BEFORE, but not AFTER, because writing text to STDOUT
changes the cursor position).
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 16:39:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Aug  7 15:39:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Unable to compile Harbour with today CVS ...
In-Reply-To: <3B6FCF01.1528.6EB945@localhost>; from jfl@mafact.com on Tue, Aug 07, 2001 at 11:20:33AM +0200
References: <3B6FB36A.28346.2EED0@localhost> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <3B6FCF01.1528.6EB945@localhost>
Message-ID: <20010807203802.F30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, Aug 07, 2001 at 11:20:33AM +0200, jfl@mafact.com wrote:
> Ron
> 
> >   #ifdef __cplusplus
> >     extern "C" ULONG hb_macroSetMacro( BOOL bSet, ULONG flag );
> >   #else
> >     extern ULONG hb_macroSetMacro( BOOL bSet, ULONG flag );
> >   #endif
> 
> Well, any idea why this problem arise there but not for many other 
> extern declaration ?

Most (all?) other extern declarations in harbour are in header files and
they are guarded with the likes of:

,----[ Excerpt from hbvm.h ]
| #if defined(HB_EXTERN_C)
| extern "C" {
| #endif
`----

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 16:50:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Tue Aug  7 15:50:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071424.000000YS@Internet>
Message-ID: <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo>

> For example, with the hb_gt driver gtwin, writing the text does not
> actually change the cursor position, so the gtwin driver must set the
> correct cursor position.

So.. in that case, the gtwin driver always sets the cursor position
regardless of BEFORE or AFTER..

> But with the hb_gt driver gtpca, the cursor position has changed and
> the gtpca driver only needs to record the current cursor position. Which
> should also be the case for the gtstd driver (i.e., the cursor needs to
> be positioned BEFORE, but not AFTER, because writing text to STDOUT
> changes the cursor position).


Yup. I think we're in agreement. So, it would then seem that the gtWriteCon
call should be using BEFORE, as otherwise the change to the current row
(after an LF for example) is only going to be noted by the driver, instead
of executed. Yes/No?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 16:51:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Aug  7 15:51:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEDKDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; from Ron@Profit-Master.com on Tue, Aug 07, 2001 at 02:12:57AM -0700
References: <200108061331_MC3-DB82-D82A@compuserve.com> <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEDKDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <20010807204231.G30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, Aug 07, 2001 at 02:12:57AM -0700, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> Clipper 5 is unlike most compiled languages, in that it offers an [almost]
> complete run-time compiler for [just about] any expression that the
> compiled language support. [SNIP]

Actually, Clipper 5 isn't at all unique in this regard. Examples of other
languages that are compiled (to byte-code) that are able to evaluate
themselves that spring to mind are perl, python and Common Lisp.

> over all.

shortcutting works.

> driven. Otherwise, *every* well behave module *anyone* develops, *must*
> first save current settings, then set the desired level, and later restore
> previous values, for *every* macro activation. This seems redundant, and
> can be achieved automatically.

This is my thinking too. I'd have thought that this would be best done as a
compile-time switch and only as a compile time switch.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 17:22:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue Aug  7 16:22:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
In-Reply-To: <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108071424.000000YS@Internet> <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo>
Message-ID: <200108071621.000000YW@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Fergus McDonald" <listsub@qvolution.com> on
Tue, 7 Aug 2001 20:49:45 +0100

> Yup. I think we're in agreement. So, it would then seem that the gtWriteCon
> call should be using BEFORE, as otherwise the change to the current row
> (after an LF for example) is only going to be noted by the driver, instead
> of executed. Yes/No?

No, because the only purpose for the flag is to communicate if the
cursor positioning call is being made before or after a call that writes
to the screen and in the case of gtWriteCon(), the cursor position is
being set *after* a call to hb_gtWrite(), not before, so the call *must*
use the AFTER flag.

Remember, the BEFORE or AFTER flag is *only* telling the hb_gt driver
*when* the call was made (before or after a write to the screen). It is
*not* telling the hb_gt driver what to do. That is *entirely* up to the
hb_gt driver.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 18:30:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue Aug  7 17:30:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-07 17:30 UTC-0400
Message-ID: <200108071729.000000Z4@Internet>

2001-08-07 17:30 UTC-0400 David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com>

  * source/rtl.net.c
    ! The OS/2 version is only for GCC builds.

David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 18:34:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Tue Aug  7 17:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071424.000000YS@Internet> <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071621.000000YW@Internet>
Message-ID: <004901c11f88$8844ad20$0205a8c0@apollo>

The problem I'm having is when gtWriteCon is called to output a newline. For
example, at the start of a QOUT(). Assume on say row 3, not near maxrow().

gtWriteCon traps the LF char in the string and advances its iRow working
variable (to 4). It doesn't call gtWrite at all. Then it passes the new iRow
value to the driver via SetPos, with AFTER mode. At this point, there has
been no output to the physical display and no cursor movement.

If the driver is able to jump to an absolute cursor position without
reference to the current position, it can disregard BEFORE/AFTER and always
move the cursor - which gtcrs and gtsln seem to do. gtstd doesn't have this
luxury so has to insert spaces/newlines only in BEFORE calls.

If gtWrite is called within gtWriteCon, the gtWrite function itself always
calls SetPosContext using AFTER anyway, so I don't see the imperative for
gtWriteCon to do a second AFTER call.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 19:42:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Aug  7 18:42:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108071316_MC3-DBBB-1DD0@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Tue, Aug 07, 2001 at 01:16:31PM -0400
References: <200108071316_MC3-DBBB-1DD0@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010807233526.J30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, Aug 07, 2001 at 01:16:31PM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > For it to be a list expression it would have to be enclosed in parens
> > other than the parens that form the function call.
> 
> That's not necessary.

Could you explain why not?

Here's how I look at it: Macro substitution is, for the most part, a program
text manipulation facility. That CA-Clipper and harbour are byte-code
compilers doesn't really enter into the discussion at this point. So, to
make sense of what "should be", we need to consider what the resulting code
would be if a programmer had written it into their editor. Right?

This:

,----
| Foo( 1, 2, 3 )
`----

is a function being passed three parameters. This:

,----
| Foo( ( 1, 2, 3 ) )
`----

being passed one parameter. Right?

So, viewing macro substitution as just that: macro substitution, logic would
suggest that:

,----
| cParams := "1, 2, 3"
| Foo( &cParams )
`----

is a function being passed three parameters and this:

,----
| cParams := "( 1, 2, 3 )"
| Foo( &cParams )
`----

is a function being passed one parameter.

I'm not sure how we can usefully view it as anything else. I'd hope for a
far more insightful explanation than "That's not necessary" before we see
any talk of "deadlock".

Personally I do have reservations about the idea of extending the macro
compiler in this way (see my previous pointers) but, if we were to extend it
this way, I fail to see how the two examples I give above can be read any
other way.

> It looks like we're deadlocked. What happens next - a vote? Or does
> someone implement the behaviour they like and thus more or less force it
> on everyone? :-(

Personally I'd hope to read some more detailed technical reasons and
objections before there's any talk of people forcing things on people.

-- 
Harbour is a free   | Harbour Web Site: http://www.harbour-project.org/
software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

Again 100% agree. I believe that the Run-Time setting (HB_SETMACRO()) should

file to be compiled by Harbour, may not know about Harbour to avoid [_]HB_
prefixed symbols, is IMO a stretch. If they indeed existed, they would have
immediately be confronted with the obvious reality, and could/would perform
needed correction, in about the same time it takes you to read this message.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 20:26:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Tue Aug  7 19:26:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
In-Reply-To: <004901c11f88$8844ad20$0205a8c0@apollo>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108071424.000000YS@Internet> <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108071621.000000YW@Internet> <004901c11f88$8844ad20$0205a8c0@apollo>
Message-ID: <200108071925.000000ZI@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Fergus McDonald" <listsub@qvolution.com> on
Tue, 7 Aug 2001 22:32:59 +0100

> The problem I'm having is when gtWriteCon is called to output a newline. For
> example, at the start of a QOUT(). Assume on say row 3, not near maxrow().
> 
> gtWriteCon traps the LF char in the string and advances its iRow working
> variable (to 4). It doesn't call gtWrite at all. Then it passes the new iRow
> value to the driver via SetPos, with AFTER mode. At this point, there has
> been no output to the physical display and no cursor movement.

You can add code to your hb_gt driver to track whether or not there has
been a call to hb_gtWrite() in between calls to hb_gtSetPosContext() and
use that information as part of the decision regarding whether or not to
physically adjust the cursor position in addition to recording it.

> ...
> If gtWrite is called within gtWriteCon, the gtWrite function itself always
> calls SetPosContext using AFTER anyway, so I don't see the imperative for
> gtWriteCon to do a second AFTER call.

Because gtWriteCon() isn't called for certain control characters that
change the cursor position and it is possible that the entire string
consists of such characters.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

operator error though. Ok, ok, yes, it was an over-engineered lisp powered
"cut & paste" error. ;>

I am, however, highly insulted by the implication that I'm a slow learner.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug  7 20:44:02 2001

------=_NextPart_000_0073_01C11F80.9BB9BB00

Dear Friends

tests\testbrw.prg

Can some one commit this file to me

 --

Luiz Rafael Culik

------=_NextPart_000_0073_01C11F80.9BB9BB00
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;
	name="testbrw.prg"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: attachment;
	filename="testbrw.prg"

/*
 * $Id: testbrw.prg,v 1.7 2001/08/04 22:33:00 mexposito Exp $
 */

// Harbour Class TBrowse and TBColumn sample

#include "inkey.ch"

function Main()

   local oBrowse :=3D TBrowseNew( 5, 5, 16, 30 )
   local aTest0  :=3D { "This", "is", "a", "browse", "on", "an", =
"array", "test", "with", "a", "long", "data" }
   local aTest1  :=3D { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10000, -1000, 54, 456342 =
}
   local aTest2  :=3D { date(), date()+4, date()+56, date()+14, =
date()+5, date()+6, date()+7, date()+8, date()+10000, date()-1000, =
date()-54, date()+456342 }
   local aTest3  :=3D { .t., .f., .t., .t., .f., .f., .t., .f., .t., =
.t., .f., .f. }
   local n       :=3D 1
   local nKey
   local lEnd    :=3D .f.
   local nCursor
   local cColor
   local nRow, nCol
   local nTmpRow, nTmpCol

   oBrowse:colorSpec     =3D "W+/B, N/BG"
   oBrowse:ColSep        =3D "=B3"
   oBrowse:HeadSep        =3D "=D1=CD"
   oBrowse:FootSep        =3D "=CF=CD"
   oBrowse:GoTopBlock    =3D { || n :=3D 1 }
   oBrowse:GoBottomBlock =3D { || n :=3D Len( aTest0 ) }
   oBrowse:SkipBlock     =3D { | nSkip, nPos | nPos :=3D n,;
                             n :=3D If( nSkip > 0, Min( Len( aTest0 ), n =
+ nSkip ),;
                             Max( 1, n + nSkip )), n - nPos }

   oBrowse:AddColumn( TBColumnNew( "First",  { || n } ) )
   oBrowse:AddColumn( TBColumnNew( "Second", { || aTest0[ n ] } ) )
   oBrowse:AddColumn( TBColumnNew( "Third",  { || aTest1[ n ] } ) )
   oBrowse:AddColumn( TBColumnNew( "Forth",  { || aTest2[ n ] } ) )
   oBrowse:AddColumn( TBColumnNew( "Fifth",  { || aTest3[ n ] } ) )
   oBrowse:GetColumn(1):Footing =3D 'Number'
   oBrowse:GetColumn(2):Footing =3D 'Strins'

   oBrowse:GetColumn(2):Picture :=3D '@!'

   oBrowse:GetColumn(3):Footing =3D 'Number'
   oBrowse:GetColumn(3):Picture :=3D '999,999.99'
   oBrowse:GetColumn(4):Footing =3D 'Dates'
   oBrowse:GetColumn(5):Footing =3D 'Logical'
   // needed since I've changed some columns _after_ I've added them to =
TBrowse object
   oBrowse:Configure()

   Alert( oBrowse:ClassName() )
   Alert( oBrowse:GetColumn( 1 ):ClassName() )

   oBrowse:Freeze =3D 1
   nCursor :=3D SetCursor( 0 )
   cColor :=3D SetColor( "W+/B" )
   nRow :=3D Row()
   nCol :=3D Col()
   @ 4,4,17,31 BOX "=DA=C4=BF=B3=D9=C4=C0=B3 "
#ifdef HB_COMPAT_C53
 oBrowse:Setkey(0,{|ob,nkey| Defproc(ob,nKey)})
while .t.
    oBrowse:ForceStable()
 if (oBrowse:applykey(inkey(0))=3D=3D -1)
   exit
endif
enddo
#else
While !lEnd
      oBrowse:ForceStable()

      nKey =3D InKey( 0 )

      do case
         case nKey =3D=3D K_ESC
              SetPos( 17, 0 )
              lEnd =3D .t.

         case nKey =3D=3D K_DOWN
              oBrowse:Down()

         case nKey =3D=3D K_UP
              oBrowse:Up()

         case nKey =3D=3D K_LEFT
              oBrowse:Left()

         case nKey =3D=3D K_RIGHT
              oBrowse:Right()

         case nKey =3D K_PGDN
              oBrowse:pageDown()

         case nKey =3D K_PGUP
              oBrowse:pageUp()

         case nKey =3D K_CTRL_PGUP
              oBrowse:goTop()

         case nKey =3D K_CTRL_PGDN
              oBrowse:goBottom()

         case nKey =3D K_HOME
              oBrowse:home()

         case nKey =3D K_END
              oBrowse:end()

         case nKey =3D K_CTRL_LEFT
              oBrowse:panLeft()

         case nKey =3D K_CTRL_RIGHT
              oBrowse:panRight()

         case nKey =3D K_CTRL_HOME
              oBrowse:panHome()

         case nKey =3D K_CTRL_END
              oBrowse:panEnd()

         case nKey =3D K_TAB
              nTmpRow :=3D ROW()
              nTmpCol :=3D COL()
              @ 0, 0 SAY TIME()
              DevPos( nTmpRow, nTmpCol )

      endcase
     =20
   end
#endif
   DevPos( nRow, nCol )
   SetColor( cColor )
   SetCursor( nCursor )

return nil
#ifdef HB_COMPAT_C53
function  defproc(ob,nkey)
Local nTmpRow,nTmpCol
        if nKey =3D K_TAB
              nTmpRow :=3D ROW()
              nTmpCol :=3D COL()
              @ 0, 0 SAY TIME()
              DevPos( nTmpRow, nTmpCol )
            ob:Refreshall()
        endif
        return 1
#endif

------=_NextPart_000_0073_01C11F80.9BB9BB00--

> > > I'm still confused then. Why do we have what seems to be a
> compile time
> > > setting *and* a run-time setting? Moreover, why do we have
> one (compile
> > > time) that can override the other (run-time). Or am I missing
> the point
> > > here?
> >
> > You are not alone. I can only imagine how confusing it must be
> for users,
> > if we feel this way.
>
> I'm now further confused by:
>
> ,----
> | 2001-08-07 13:45 UTC+0100 Ryszard Glab <rglab@imid.med.pl>
> | ...
>
> Ryszard, what's does all of this do? I get the, possibly incorrect,
> impression that the two of you are coding at cross purposes. Am I reading
> this wrong? What is this business of compile time *and* runtime settings?

Well not really cross purposes, but I can relate to the confusion. Ryszard
actually added the ability to disable the minimal syncing. This does not
conflict with my code, but rather complement it to a degree. I personally
don't see the need to disable it, which instead simply dictates an obscured
starting value, with complete disregard to any hinted intention.

Should we all agree that independent Run-Time switch is redundant and
confusing, and should we then replace it with the suggested automatic
management, driven by compile time switch, we will likely no longer need the
above.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 04:09:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Chen Kedem)

Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100

Ryszard,

> All settings defined in _SET_CH are ignored by the preprocessor
> because _SET_CH is defined by default - it's definition is hardcoded
> inside a pptable.c.
> I decided to not change the pptable.

With your point and with the fact that HB_SM_* constants are Harbour
extension, you should guard them with HB_EXTENSION and move them to
a separate file (somewhere like hbset.h or hbset.ch).

(My issue is about order in code and nothing about the necessity or
functionality of the code itself)


  Chen.

>Message: 3
>From: =?iso-8859-1?Q?Horacio_Rold=E1n?= <harbour_ar@yahoo.com.ar>

>Maybe this it's not related to your problem but could help you.
>
>I had an ASP application in WinNT 4 SP3 running fine.
>I upgrade the server to Win2K (IIS5) and after that I had some troubles.
>
>The service was running ok for 2 or 3 hours and after that IIS stopped
>responding requests to any .asp page (even simple ones made for testing),
>but it served the .html pages.
>The server logs didn't show any errors by the time of the problem, but it
>reported a few errors previously with no description.
>The error number did not appeared in the docs or in MS Website.
>I applied patchs, the SP1 but with no luck.
>
>I know that this does not help you but you know you are not the only with
>IIS troubles. As it says: "Mal de muchos, consuelo de tontos". :-)
>
>The solution that worked for me was switching into apache for Win32.
>Now my app runs even faster!

>regards
>Horacio



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 04:51:06 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Wed Aug  8 03:51:06 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-07 13:45 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3B700E7A.22316.15130D7@localhost>

    * doc/en/compiler.txt
        *updated to keep current compiler state
        
    * include/hbcomp.h
    * source/compiler/cmdcheck.c
    * source/compiler/genc.c
    * source/compiler/harbour.c
    * source/compiler/hbusage.c
        * added a new switch -ks that request the synchronization of
        compile time and runtime options (enabled by default).
        Use -kc to disable it.
        
    * source/compiler/harbour.l
        * fixed bug when HB_INLINE is interpreted as an identifier 
        (-ki option)

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 05:02:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast, Harbour)
Date: Wed Aug  8 04:02:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] HBMAKE, harbour -go and Harbour Final Users(Ron,Patrick,David,Dave,Ryszard,Jean,Phil,all)
In-Reply-To: <006101c11f98$f9431e20$90d4d7c8@culik>

Luiz,

> > hbmake is your baby so it's your call. If you're concerned that the=20
> > -go switch isn't "stable" enough yet, don't be. Even if it isn't=20
> > "stable" you'll
> > be doing harbour a service by ensuring that this feature of the=20
> > compiler receives more stress testing.
=20
> As I understand your point of view,you are saying if I enable=20
> the -go switch on harbour, this harbour compiler switch will=20
> be more tested.

> the make process.

be tested.

> don=B4t exist

of those directories so you wouldn't be able to create the config file.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 06:16:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Wed Aug  8 05:16:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071424.000000YS@Internet> <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071621.000000YW@Internet> <004901c11f88$8844ad20$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071925.000000ZI@Internet>
Message-ID: <001301c11fea$a9732af0$0205a8c0@apollo>

> ** Reply to message from "Fergus McDonald" <listsub@qvolution.com> on
> Tue, 7 Aug 2001 22:32:59 +0100
>
> > The problem I'm having is when gtWriteCon is called to output a newline.
For
> > example, at the start of a QOUT(). Assume on say row 3, not near
maxrow().
> >
> > gtWriteCon traps the LF char in the string and advances its iRow working
> > variable (to 4). It doesn't call gtWrite at all. Then it passes the new
iRow
> > value to the driver via SetPos, with AFTER mode. At this point, there
has
> > been no output to the physical display and no cursor movement.
>
> You can add code to your hb_gt driver to track whether or not there has
> been a call to hb_gtWrite() in between calls to hb_gtSetPosContext() and
> use that information as part of the decision regarding whether or not to
> physically adjust the cursor position in addition to recording it.

Well, I'd agree in so far as I don't want to change gtapi.c. However,
gtWrite isn't part of the driver so I don't think the driver should be
trying to track its usage. Because of that, I'd have to say it's a bit of a
kludge.

> > ...
> > If gtWrite is called within gtWriteCon, the gtWrite function itself
always
> > calls SetPosContext using AFTER anyway, so I don't see the imperative
for
> > gtWriteCon to do a second AFTER call.
>
> Because gtWriteCon() isn't called for certain control characters that
> change the cursor position and it is possible that the entire string
> consists of such characters.

Exactly.. but for these control characters no function in the driver is
called (before the SetPos call) which means no writes to the screen, and to
quote you from an earlier message: "the only purpose for the [iMethod] flag
is to communicate if the cursor positioning call is being made before or
after a call that writes to the screen".

Even if gtWriteCon handles a combination of printable text and
aforementioned control characters, the printable text is still written to
screen first via gtWrite calling hb_gt_Puts and then SetPos with AFTER
method. Any further changes to the cursor position are then communicated to
the driver via a second SetPos call (in gtWriteCon()), before which no
further writes to the screen have taken place.

I note also that none of the drivers except cgi and std make use of the
iMethod flag in their SetPos call.

Hope you don't mind me dragging this out.. although tiresome, I think it's
the correct to tease these points out in the public record of the mailing
list  :)

ne,

BTW, if we make SomeFunc( &cMacro ) with commas in cMacro mean
multiple params, presumably we count extra params for
	SomeFunc( param1, &cMacro, paramN )
and similarly for methods.

work properly?  I don't think Jean needs any extra difficulty right
now.

	HB_P_PUSHSYMNEAR	SomeFunc
	HB_P_PUSHNIL		// I guess this will vanish in due course?
	HB_P_PUSHLOCALNEAR	param1
	HB_P_FUNCTIONSHORT	1
Where the 1 is the param count.

What do you plan to change this to?  Will it affect all function calls
or just those with a macro?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 10:57:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Wed Aug  8 09:57:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKMEDIDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <3B6EFF03.18682.27D2620@localhost>
Message-ID: <3B71629A.19571.15311A6@localhost>

On 7 Aug 2001, at 1:24, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> No, though block lists are inconsistent (elsewhere, list produces all values
> unless parenthesized), this is not the side effect I was talking about. I
> referred to:

  I disagree. There is no inconsistency. There is no other context where 
list is used - the list of function's arguments is not comparable case 
because it is, by definition, a list of separate values.

> 
>    LIST &cMAcro
> 
> It is only incidental that LIST is preprocessed to use codeblocks. If anyone
> implements LIST any other way, this wouldn't  have worked. Such side effect
> should not be relied upon. The proper way to assure such behavior is to use
> parenthesized expression.

  This is not incidental but it is very logical choice - only codeblocks 
are able to proccess all valid Clipper expressions - this includes access 
to local and static variables. Implementing it, for example, as a macro 
will not allow for it. 
  The result of all valid Clipper expressions is always a single value. 
This is the proper and expected behaviour. &macro is an expression that 
also should return a single value and it was returning it until you 
decided to change it.

> I'm glad you noticed that. Now let's ask since it *does* correctly handle
> the *list* macro in a code block, why should it fail with this:
> 
> cMacro:="DBSEEK(somewhere),someField"
> SomeVar := ( &cMacro )
> 
> Or even this:
> 
> cMacro:="DBSEEK(somewhere),someField"
> SomeFun( (&cMacro) )
> 
> Is there any reason it will correctly handle list macro (evaluating all
> sub-expressions) in codeblock context, but not be able to do same with the
> above???

  Because a codeblock is a list of *code* blocks (expressions) - in other 
words it encapsulates the list of expressions. Notice that the value of a 
codeblock is the codeblock itself. It must be evaluated to get ,,access'' 
to the list contained in a codeblock.
  &macro was designed to operate on single expression only (if not used 
in a codeblock). Thus any attempt to process a list of expressions should 
fail.

> If you see the point, I hope you'll realize that the list macro without
> parenthesis, should also behave exactly as in the non macroed Clipper in all
> contexts. Anything short of this must be considered a bug.

  See above.

> Ryszard, this is only because of a serious Clipper implementation problem.
> One shouldn't consider this limitation valid, just because the Clipper
> implementation of LIST happened to use codeblocks. This is not necessary.
> Again just ask your self if list macros *are* valid within codeblocks, why
> shouldn't they work in other identical context like ( &cMacro ) and in such
> commands?

  I don't see it as an implemetation problem. It is very naturel solution 
to support all valid Clipper expressions, including local and static 
variables. Have you any idea how to give support for locals and statics 
withot using a codeblock?

> 
> > because "field1,field2,field3" is interpreted as "(field1,fiel2,field3)"
> > wchich gives a single value because it is preprocessed as a list inside a
> > codeblock.
> 
> No it is interpreted as "field1, field2, field3" which *in* *a* *codeblock*
> is handled like any other list expression ( evaluate *each* sub expression,
> and pop all but the last).

   We are talking the same here.

> Had the Nantucket guys completed macro support to properly support lists, in
> all other contexts, they could/should have used *nonblock* for the macro
> expression, and would have had to solve macro lists in high level syntax
> like LIST, much like my implementation, and much like you would have done,
> if decided to support it.

  The lists are handled correctly in Clipper except the limitation in a 
support for "(expr1, expr2)" syntax.

> We didn't have [AFAIK] any of our incompatibilities/enhancements documented.
> I just started a new file /doc/en/clipper.txt with the portions I could
> fill. There are many many more such items to add, including ones I may be
> responsible for.

  See doc/en/compiler.txt for the list of such incompatibilites that I 
was aware of.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 11:33:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Wed Aug  8 10:33:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <20010807095929.W30092@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <3B716B03.3620.173EB2A@localhost>

On 7 Aug 2001, at 11:11, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> I think this management, should be completely automated and compile time
> driven. Otherwise, *every* well behave module *anyone* develops, *must*
> first save current settings, then set the desired level, and later restore
> previous values, for *every* macro activation. This seems redundant, and can
> be achieved automatically.
> 
> In essence, we could add just 1 more byte after the HB_MACROPUSH* opcodes
> which indicate the compile time flag for that module. The HVM processing of
> the HB_P_MACROPUSH* will read the byte and set hbmacroSetMacro() with the
> appropriate value.
> 
> Ryszard?

  Why you are always trying to complicate a simple things? Please leave 
the separation between the compile time and the runtime settings and 
nothing more is required.
  Compile time settings are set by command line switch and runtime 
settings are set with HB_SETMACRO. Clean and simple.
  Every other solution will make things worse. 

  Not to mention that the compiler switches and hb_setmacro() can/will 
set quite different set of features.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 11:46:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed Aug  8 10:46:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] profiler counts wrong times
In-Reply-To: <3B712680.5D52F7B5@libero.it>; from maurilio.longo@libero.it on Wed, Aug 08, 2001 at 01:46:08PM +0200
References: <3B712680.5D52F7B5@libero.it>
Message-ID: <20010808154523.B30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, Aug 08, 2001 at 01:46:08PM +0200, Maurilio Longo wrote:

> I think profiler has some problems, look at this:

This is a known problem. It appears that the methods that the VM currently
uses to account for time spent in a function isn't reliable or portable. I
guess this problem is waiting for each platform supporter to provide a more
accurate method of measuring time.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 12:27:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed Aug  8 11:27:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
In-Reply-To: <001301c11fea$a9732af0$0205a8c0@apollo>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108071424.000000YS@Internet> <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108071621.000000YW@Internet> <004901c11f88$8844ad20$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108071925.000000ZI@Internet> <001301c11fea$a9732af0$0205a8c0@apollo>
Message-ID: <200108081126.000000ZK@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Fergus McDonald" <listsub@qvolution.com> on
Wed, 8 Aug 2001 10:15:25 +0100

> Well, I'd agree in so far as I don't want to change gtapi.c. However,
> gtWrite isn't part of the driver so I don't think the driver should be
> trying to track its usage. Because of that, I'd have to say it's a bit of a
> kludge.

You can track it's usage by tracking the usage of hb_gt_Puts(). And in
hb_gt_Puts() you also need to do physical cursor positioning if the
specified position doesn't match the stored position in the hb_gt driver.

> Exactly.. but for these control characters no function in the driver is
> called (before the SetPos call) which means no writes to the screen, and to
> quote you from an earlier message: "the only purpose for the [iMethod] flag
> is to communicate if the cursor positioning call is being made before or
> after a call that writes to the screen".

So I left out the word "potentially" (is in "potentially writes to the
screen").

> Even if gtWriteCon handles a combination of printable text and
> aforementioned control characters, the printable text is still written to
> screen first via gtWrite calling hb_gt_Puts and then SetPos with AFTER
> method. Any further changes to the cursor position are then communicated to
> the driver via a second SetPos call (in gtWriteCon()), before which no
> further writes to the screen have taken place.

Correct. Think of the BEFORE flag as meaning "Here is where the cursor
needs to be" and the AFTER flag as "Here is where the cursor should be."

> I note also that none of the drivers except cgi and std make use of the
> iMethod flag in their SetPos call.
> 
> Hope you don't mind me dragging this out.. although tiresome, I think it's
> the correct to tease these points out in the public record of the mailing
> list  :)

I don't mind at all. But I also don't think that there is any need to
change anything in gtapi.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

> this wrong? What is this business of compile time *and* runtime settings?

  Partially, yes we have not common purposes. 

  What is wrong with leaving the programmer the possibility to change 
some application behaviour at runtime?
  Why the programmer cannot request strict Clipper compatibility during 
compilation and at the same time use extended operators and object 
handling (assignments) during the runtime? 
  Why not use all extended macro capabilities in code where the 
programmer have full control and next use temporarily restricted set of 
macro capabilities when processed data are taken online from the user 
input?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 13:38:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed Aug  8 12:38:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <3B71629A.19571.15311A6@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEELDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > No, though block lists are inconsistent (elsewhere, list
> produces all values
> > unless parenthesized), this is not the side effect I was
> talking about. I
> > referred to:
>
>   I disagree. There is no inconsistency. There is no other context where
> list is used - the list of function's arguments is not comparable case
> because it is, by definition, a list of separate values.

Ryszard, you must know this can't be true, or else, *please* explain the
difference between:

Var := 1, 2, 3
Var := (1, 2, 3)
Var := Eval( {|| 1, 2, 3 }
Var := Eval( {|| (1, 2, 3) }

> >    LIST &cMAcro
> >
> > It is only incidental that LIST is preprocessed to use
> codeblocks. If anyone
> > implements LIST any other way, this wouldn't  have worked. Such
> side effect
> > should not be relied upon. The proper way to assure such
> behavior is to use
> > parenthesized expression.
>
>   This is not incidental but it is very logical choice - only codeblocks
> are able to proccess all valid Clipper expressions - this includes access
> to local and static variables. Implementing it, for example, as a macro
> will not allow for it.
>   The result of all valid Clipper expressions is always a single value.
> This is the proper and expected behaviour. &macro is an expression that
> also should return a single value and it was returning it until you
> decided to change it.

It is incidental, because it's an undocumented implementation detail. LIST
is the documented command, it's purely incidental that it's implemented by
means of any pre-processing, or __dbList(), etc. One could have implement
native parser support for LIST and still fully support the documented
Clipper LIST syntax, right?

It is also incidental, because *nowhere* [that I could found] is it
documented that Codeblock *does* support macros of lists!!!

Here is Clipper documentation for "{}" (curly brackets):

 -----------------------------------------------------------------------
 Syntax

     { <exp list> }                 (literal array)
     { |<param list>| <exp list> }  (code block definition)

 Operands

     <exp list> is a list of expressions of any type.  If the item is a
     literal array definition, it can contain another literal array
     definition.
 -----------------------------------------------------------------------

So, is it not fair to expect that given:

   cExpList := "1, 2, 3"
   bVar := {|| &cExpList }

the following should work too:

   cExpList := "1, 2, 3"
   aVar := { &cExpList }

Or, in the alternate, that given:

   cExpList := "1, 2, 3"
   aVar := { &cExpList }

produces a '&' error, so should:

   cExpList := "1, 2, 3"
   bVar := {|| &cExpList }

???

Please explain how should we resolve Clipper behavior here with the
documentation.

> > Is there any reason it will correctly handle list macro (evaluating all
> > sub-expressions) in codeblock context, but not be able to do
> same with the
> > above???
>
>   Because a codeblock is a list of *code* blocks (expressions) - in other
> words it encapsulates the list of expressions. Notice that the value of a
> codeblock is the codeblock itself. It must be evaluated to get ,,access''
> to the list contained in a codeblock.
>   &macro was designed to operate on single expression only (if not used
> in a codeblock). Thus any attempt to process a list of expressions should
> fail.

So a Macro *can* or *can't* represent a *list* of expressions in Clipper?

> > Ryszard, this is only because of a serious Clipper
> implementation problem.
> > One shouldn't consider this limitation valid, just because the Clipper
> > implementation of LIST happened to use codeblocks. This is not
> necessary.
> > Again just ask your self if list macros *are* valid within
> codeblocks, why
> > shouldn't they work in other identical context like ( &cMacro )
> and in such
> > commands?
>
>   I don't see it as an implemetation problem. It is very naturel solution
> to support all valid Clipper expressions, including local and static
> variables. Have you any idea how to give support for locals and statics
> withot using a codeblock?

Yes of course. LIST could have been supported directly by the parser, just
as easily.

> > Had the Nantucket guys completed macro support to properly
> support lists, in
> > all other contexts, they could/should have used *nonblock* for the macro
> > expression, and would have had to solve macro lists in high level syntax
> > like LIST, much like my implementation, and much like you would
> have done,
> > if decided to support it.
>
>   The lists are handled correctly in Clipper except the limitation in a
> support for "(expr1, expr2)" syntax.

Which is the point of this debate, is it not?

> > We didn't have [AFAIK] any of our
> incompatibilities/enhancements documented.
> > I just started a new file /doc/en/clipper.txt with the portions I could
> > fill. There are many many more such items to add, including
> ones I may be
> > responsible for.
>
>   See doc/en/compiler.txt for the list of such incompatibilites that I
> was aware of.

Ok we might need to consolidate compiler.txt, clipper.txt, and harbext.txt

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 13:48:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed Aug  8 12:48:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <3B718229.13545.1CE5588@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEEMDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

>   What is wrong with leaving the programmer the possibility to change
> some application behaviour at runtime?

It's wrong because the price for this, is complete lack of integration. It's
wrong, because it's *more* natural for the user to expect that if he
compiled a prg with -Kc  then the Macro Compiler (used in that same prg)
will conform with the same setting *by* *default*.

>   Why the programmer cannot request strict Clipper compatibility during
> compilation and at the same time use extended operators and object
> handling (assignments) during the runtime?

If you can provide complete automatic inheritance, and still provide such
freedom, then by all means go for it. Otherwise, offering the correct
default setting, is more important, if both can't be achieved together.

>   Why not use all extended macro capabilities in code where the
> programmer have full control and next use temporarily restricted set of
> macro capabilities when processed data are taken online from the user
> input?

See above.

Ron

Dave,

look at this:


Name                                Type       Calls    Ticks       Seconds
=================================== ========== ======== =========== ===========
ESEGUI                              Function      11395        8586       85.00
INTERPRETE                          Function          1        4471       44.00
AEVAL                               Function       1022        1584       15.00
DEVOUT                              Function       9352         432        4.00
DEVPOS                              Function      19635         157        1.00
ROW                                 Function      18700         110        1.00
STRTRAN                             Function       9558          63        0.00
__MVPRIVATE                         Function      22790          46        0.00
COL                                 Function       9350          45        0.00
LEN                                 Function      12167          20        0.00
DBSELECTAREA                        Function      11395          15        0.00
SELECT                              Function      11395          12        0.00


I let this program run for 45 seconds. Interprete() is the entry point and, as
you can see it says 44 seconds.
Interprete() calls Esegui() and Esegui() says 85 seconds! So it is plain wrong.
It seems that it adds Interprete()'s time to Esegui() one.

Is this possible?

*same* same as if it *was* parenthesized, *unlike* *every* other context in
Clipper, where such omission yields completely different results.



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 14:19:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed Aug  8 13:19:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] profiler counts wrong times
In-Reply-To: <3B717089.C4210548@libero.it>
References: <3B712680.5D52F7B5@libero.it> <20010808154523.B30092@hagbard.davep.org>
 <3B717089.C4210548@libero.it>
Message-ID: <200108081318.000000ZU@Internet>

** Reply to message from Maurilio Longo <maurilio.longo@libero.it> on
Wed, 08 Aug 2001 19:02:01 +0200

The problem is not in the counting of ticks, but in the conversion from
ticks to seconds. It's obvious that the conversion factor being used is
divide by 100. Given that your program ran for a total of 15,541 ticks
and you said that it ran for 44 seconds, the value that is being used
for ticks per second with GCC for OS/2 is off by about a factor of 3.5
and should be close to divide by 350.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 14:22:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Wed Aug  8 13:22:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEEMDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <3B718229.13545.1CE5588@localhost>
Message-ID: <3B71929F.25050.20EA32C@localhost>

On 8 Aug 2001, at 9:49, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> It's wrong because the price for this, is complete lack of integration. It's
> wrong, because it's *more* natural for the user to expect that if he
> compiled a prg with -Kc  then the Macro Compiler (used in that same prg)
> will conform with the same setting *by* *default*.

  And what you are offering instead? Many modules, libraries all compiled 
with different switches. Which module will win? What settings will be 
active in init procedures - what if programmer wants to use a single 
settings for whole application - including init procedures from modules 
from a library where the source is not available?

  In other words: total chaos during initialization and total 
recompilation of all available modules instead a simple change in 
configuration file of running application?

  The lack of integration is a big bonus then.

  How it can be ,,*more* natural'' to expect that two quite different 
subsystems (linked only with the common name) will bahave the same. More 
natural is expecting that they will be not related in any way.

> >   Why the programmer cannot request strict Clipper compatibility during
> > compilation and at the same time use extended operators and object
> > handling (assignments) during the runtime?
> 
> If you can provide complete automatic inheritance, and still provide such
> freedom, then by all means go for it. Otherwise, offering the correct
> default setting, is more important, if both can't be achieved together.

  But ,,complete automatic inheritance'' is the exact opposite (mutually 
exclusive features) of such freedom - then any attempt to achieve it will 
fail. The correct default setting is documented in doc/en/macro.txt - if 
it is not appopriate then it can be changed with a single HB_SETMACRO() 
call.

> >   Why not use all extended macro capabilities in code where the
> > programmer have full control and next use temporarily restricted set of
> > macro capabilities when processed data are taken online from the user
> > input?
> 
> See above.

  Sorry, I don't see any connection with the above. 

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 14:44:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Wed Aug  8 13:44:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071424.000000YS@Internet> <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071621.000000YW@Internet> <004901c11f88$8844ad20$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071925.000000ZI@Internet> <001301c11fea$a9732af0$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108081126.000000ZK@Internet>
Message-ID: <002b01c12031$97f867d0$0205a8c0@apollo>

> > Even if gtWriteCon handles a combination of printable text and
> > aforementioned control characters, the printable text is still written
to
> > screen first via gtWrite calling hb_gt_Puts and then SetPos with AFTER
> > method. Any further changes to the cursor position are then communicated
to
> > the driver via a second SetPos call (in gtWriteCon()), before which no
> > further writes to the screen have taken place.
>
> Correct. Think of the BEFORE flag as meaning "Here is where the cursor
> needs to be" and the AFTER flag as "Here is where the cursor should be."

In the second SetPos call mentioned above, I think it's definitely a case of
"needs to be" and not "should be".

>From what you're saying, the AFTER flag seems to be just some sort of sanity
check for the driver, but should not be acted upon to reposition the
physical cursor if the driver's internal tracking of teh cursor position is
different from the co-ordinates given with an AFTER flag.



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 15:12:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed Aug  8 14:12:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?
In-Reply-To: <002b01c12031$97f867d0$0205a8c0@apollo>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108071424.000000YS@Internet> <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108071621.000000YW@Internet> <004901c11f88$8844ad20$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108071925.000000ZI@Internet> <001301c11fea$a9732af0$0205a8c0@apollo>
 <200108081126.000000ZK@Internet> <002b01c12031$97f867d0$0205a8c0@apollo>
Message-ID: <200108081411.000000ZW@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Fergus McDonald" <fergus@qvolution.com> on
Wed, 8 Aug 2001 18:43:10 +0100

> In the second SetPos call mentioned above, I think it's definitely a case of
> "needs to be" and not "should be".

No, it's definitely a case of "should be", because most of the time, a
string actually gets written to the screen.

> >From what you're saying, the AFTER flag seems to be just some sort of sanity
> check for the driver, but should not be acted upon to reposition the
> physical cursor if the driver's internal tracking of teh cursor position is
> different from the co-ordinates given with an AFTER flag.

No, it's there for synchronization purposes. As in, "Here's what I have
the cursor position set to now." It has nothing to do with whether or
not the hb_gt driver should or should not physically move the cursor
position. It's up to the hb_gt driver to determine whether or not it
needs to physically change the cursor position to match. Changing this
one gtapi call to use BEFORE will not in any way help to determine
whether or not the cursor position should be physically moved. It
doesn't matter to the GTSTD driver if the value is BEFORE or AFTER for
this particular call, because it is going to have to track whether or
not anything has been written to the stdout device since the last cursor
positioning attempt and use that in it's determination of whether or not
go physically change the cursor position. But it could matter to other
drivers, which is why it must remain AFTER.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 15:20:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed Aug  8 14:20:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <3B71929F.25050.20EA32C@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEEODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > It's wrong because the price for this, is complete lack of
> integration. It's
> > wrong, because it's *more* natural for the user to expect that if he
> > compiled a prg with -Kc  then the Macro Compiler (used in that same prg)
> > will conform with the same setting *by* *default*.
>
>   And what you are offering instead? Many modules, libraries all compiled
> with different switches. Which module will win?

Every module will win! Each module will respect the setting that was
requested when it was compiled. Exactly like -Z switch.

Which module wins when different modules are compiled with/without -Z? ALL!

> What settings will be
> active in init procedures

The setting that was requested when compiling the respective module in which
each of the INIT procedures was created.

You must have not read the technical details of my suggested implementation.

> - what if programmer wants to use a single
> settings for whole application - including init procedures from modules
> from a library where the source is not available?

You mean he should be able to override the setting for a 3rd party LIB? If
this was the case, did you read my message that explained that now *every*
macro activation would *have* to be guarded with a save and later restore of
all the macro flags?

If the source is not available, doesn't it mean the setting the author
specified should be honored?

>   In other words: total chaos during initialization and total
> recompilation of all available modules instead a simple change in
> configuration file of running application?

What are you talking about? What you implemented is what will cause a
complete and total chaos! No one will need to recompile other modules
because one module requires certain setting if my approach is used. Each
compiled module, will encode the required setting for every macro activation
in that module.

>   The lack of integration is a big bonus then.

No. It's a clear indication for implementation lacking proper planning.

>   How it can be ,,*more* natural'' to expect that two quite different
> subsystems (linked only with the common name) will bahave the same.

No. They should NOT behave the same! Each will execute in a protected
environment, guaranteeing correct setting for each macro activation within
that specific module.

> More natural is expecting that they will be not related in any way.

Absolutely! But your implementation does not allow for that, *without*
having to *save* *every* macro setting *before* *every* macro activation,
and later *restore* *every* macro setting *after* *each* macro activation.
Or else total chaos will prevail!

> > If you can provide complete automatic inheritance, and still
> provide such
> > freedom, then by all means go for it. Otherwise, offering the correct
> > default setting, is more important, if both can't be achieved together.
>
>   But ,,complete automatic inheritance'' is the exact opposite (mutually
> exclusive features) of such freedom - then any attempt to achieve it will
> fail. The correct default setting is documented in doc/en/macro.txt - if
> it is not appopriate then it can be changed with a single HB_SETMACRO()
> call.

Not true. One must have freedom to specify correct setting for *his* module,
without warring about overriding someone else's module requirements. I can
easily implement a solution that will allow everyone the freedom to specify
correct setting for any module in compile time, and for that setting to be
*guaranteed* for every macro activation in that module, without any impact
on any other module!

> > >   Why not use all extended macro capabilities in code where the
> > > programmer have full control and next use temporarily
> restricted set of
> > > macro capabilities when processed data are taken online from the user
> > > input?
> >
> > See above.
>
>   Sorry, I don't see any connection with the above.

2 simple solutions:

1. Put the logic with the macro evaluation of user input in separate prg
compiled with the reduced setting.
2. Use #pragam -kc before that code fragment and later #pragme -k* after
that segment.

Ron

The first is a random collection of numbers written after 20 hours of 
hard work by the programmer who spends too much money on some lottery.

Second is a parenthesized expression valid in Clipper that returns a 
single value.

Third is a codeblock with the list of expressions. The list consists of 
three expressions.

Forth is a codeblock with the list of expressions. There is only a single 
expression on the list.

> >   This is not incidental but it is very logical choice - only codeblocks
> > are able to proccess all valid Clipper expressions - this includes access
> > to local and static variables. Implementing it, for example, as a macro
> > will not allow for it.
> >   The result of all valid Clipper expressions is always a single value.
> > This is the proper and expected behaviour. &macro is an expression that
> > also should return a single value and it was returning it until you
> > decided to change it.
> 
> It is incidental, because it's an undocumented implementation detail. LIST

used in all commands where FIELDS clause is accepted as it can be seen in 
std.ch. Have you really seen any fully documented software? With all 
details written black on white?

> is the documented command, it's purely incidental that it's implemented by
> means of any pre-processing, or __dbList(), etc. One could have implement
> native parser support for LIST and still fully support the documented
> Clipper LIST syntax, right?

  Ron, all commands are preprocessed in Clipper 5.x by design! This is 
not incidental! Please stop arguing such point of view.

> It is also incidental, because *nowhere* [that I could found] is it
> documented that Codeblock *does* support macros of lists!!!

  A codeblock supports a list of expressions.

> So, is it not fair to expect that given:
> 
>    cExpList := "1, 2, 3"
>    bVar := {|| &cExpList }
> 
> the following should work too:
> 
>    cExpList := "1, 2, 3"
>    aVar := { &cExpList }

  Ron, the codeblock and arrays are different beasts. Please do not 
expect that arrays will behave the same as codeblocks.

> Please explain how should we resolve Clipper behavior here with the
> documentation.

  See documentation for arrays and codeblocks.

> So a Macro *can* or *can't* represent a *list* of expressions in Clipper?

> Yes of course. LIST could have been supported directly by the parser, just
> as easily.

variables? By reference? OK but only if simple variable is used. What if 
complex expression is involved, for example: PADL(someField,nLen) where 
nLen is a local variable. You will have to create .... surprise :) 
some kind of codeblock. Why double efforts if a codeblock already exists?

  Ron, you are arguing to allow macro compilation of "expr1,expr2". Here 
is the example of syntax where there is obvious Clipper limitation that 
is beyond the scope of this debate.

References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEDJDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com> <006701c11f3d$c68dea60$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071424.000000YS@Internet> <001901c11f7a$1c485c60$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071621.000000YW@Internet> <004901c11f88$8844ad20$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108071925.000000ZI@Internet> <001301c11fea$a9732af0$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108081126.000000ZK@Internet> <002b01c12031$97f867d0$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108081411.000000ZW@Internet>
Message-ID: <004f01c12039$e1da0130$0205a8c0@apollo>

----- Original Message -----
From: "David G. Holm" <dholm@jsd-llc.com>
To: "harbour" <harbour@matrixlist.com>
Sent: Wednesday, August 08, 2001 7:09 PM
Subject: Re: [Harbour] gtapi.c gtWriteCon bug?


> ** Reply to message from "Fergus McDonald" <fergus@qvolution.com> on
> Wed, 8 Aug 2001 18:43:10 +0100
>
> > In the second SetPos call mentioned above, I think it's definitely a
case of
> > "needs to be" and not "should be".
>
> No, it's definitely a case of "should be", because most of the time, a
> string actually gets written to the screen.

The problem is whenever a string is written to the screen, this is done via
the gtWrite call, which itself calls the SetPos function with AFTER, quite
correctly, and the driver thus notes the new position without physically
doing anything. The row is then changed in gtWriteCon and the driver is
called again using AFTER with the new row value. The driver again notes the
new position and doesn't do anything, but as this point the physical cursor
hasn't moved to the new row, but now both gtapi and the driver think it has.

Anyway, I'm just ignoring AFTER calls from the gtapi and doing the tracking
internally, which is pretty much what the gtstd driver has been doing all
along. All the same, it's a bit wasteful to have gtWriteCon in gtapi parse
through the string to calc the new cursor position, and then have gtstd
repeat the same process in its AdjustPos function.

In any case, it's working with the gtapi as it is. I'll forward the source
shortly.

Regards
Fergus

I can understand your embarrassment. Clipper has a documented and
consistent(?) support for lists of expressions. In all cases *except* code
blocks, lists are interpreted as multiple arguments. You *must* group all
lists of expressions within parenthesis in order to produce a *single*
value, *except* within codeblocks. I believe most logical persons equate an
exception with inconsistency.

> > It is incidental, because it's an undocumented implementation
> detail. LIST
>
>   Yes, it is undocummented. And it is incidental that this feature is
> used in all commands where FIELDS clause is accepted as it can be seen in
> std.ch. Have you really seen any fully documented software? With all
> details written black on white?

and design specification.

> implemented by

> implement
> > native parser support for LIST and still fully support the documented
> > Clipper LIST syntax, right?
>
>   Ron, all commands are preprocessed in Clipper 5.x by design! This is
> not incidental! Please stop arguing such point of view.

Ryszard, this is an implementation detail, not a design
specification/requirement.

> > It is also incidental, because *nowhere* [that I could found] is it
> > documented that Codeblock *does* support macros of lists!!!
>
>   A codeblock supports a list of expressions.

This does not address the fact that macros of lists are generally *not*
supported, and that there is *no* documentation that macro of lists *are*
supported in codeblocks, but *not* in any other context, and maybe even
specify why!

be supported, but not the second?

In Clipper documentation both expressions specified as macro above, are of
the exact same kind.

> > Please explain how should we resolve Clipper behavior here with the

It would not require any use of references, a simple PUSH would be generated
within a loop in the scope of the *current* function.

obvious bugs. How else would you explain lack of support for simple

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 16:23:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed Aug  8 15:23:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEEODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEEPDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> Absolutely! But your implementation does not allow for that, *without*
> having to *save* *every* macro setting *before* *every* macro activation,
> and later *restore* *every* macro setting *after* *each* macro activation.
> Or else total chaos will prevail!

Actually worse, I forgot the required setting phase. So every macro
activation will have to look like this:

aMacroFlag[ HB_MACRO_HARBOUR ]   := HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_HARBOUR )
aMacroFlag[ HB_MACRO_XBASE   ]   := HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_XBASE )
aMacroFlag[ HB_MACRO_SHORTCUTS ] := HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_SHORTCUTS )
aMacroFlag[ HB_MACRO_PREPROC ]   := HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_PREPROC )

HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_HARBOUR, * )
HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_XBASE, * )
HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_SHORTCUTS, * )
HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_PREPROC, * )

&someMacro()

HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_HARBOUR,   aMacroFlag[ HB_MACRO_HARBOUR ] )
HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_XBASE,     aMacroFlag[ HB_MACRO_XBASE   ] )
HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_SHORTCUTS, aMacroFlag[ HB_MACRO_SHORTCUTS ] )
HB_SETMACRO( HB_SM_PREPROC,   aMacroFlag[ HB_MACRO_PREPROC ] )

Or maybe:

aMacroFlags := SaveMacroSettings()
&someMacro()
RestoreMacroSettings( aMacroFlags )

With appropriate logic in Save/RestoreMacroSettings()

Ron

On 8 Aug 2001, at 11:21, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> Every module will win! Each module will respect the setting that was
> requested when it was compiled. Exactly like -Z switch.
> 
> Which module wins when different modules are compiled with/without -Z? ALL!

  -Z switch controls generation of pcode during compilation. Thus it 
cannot be changed at runtime.

  I see the need to control macro compiler capabilities at runtime. 

  You don't see such need. 

Current code allows to control it regardless if you like it or not. 
Adding additional pcode to store compile time settings will kill the 
ability to change it at runtime. 

  Please, again, do whatever you want, I have better things to do. But 
any attempt to kill possibility to set capabilities at runtime will be 
disabled (#ifdef'ed) in some form by me as long as I will work here.
