From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 16:31:33 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed Aug  8 15:31:33 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <3B718229.13545.1CE5588@localhost>; from rglab@imid.med.pl on Wed, Aug 08, 2001 at 06:17:13PM +0200
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEEBDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>; <20010808002855.O30092@hagbard.davep.org> <3B718229.13545.1CE5588@localhost>
Message-ID: <20010808201333.E30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, Aug 08, 2001 at 06:17:13PM +0200, Ryszard Glab wrote:
> On 8 Aug 2001, at 0:28, Dave Pearson wrote:
> 
> > Ryszard, what's does all of this do? I get the, possibly incorrect,
> > impression that the two of you are coding at cross purposes. Am I reading
> > this wrong? What is this business of compile time *and* runtime settings?
> 
>   Partially, yes we have not common purposes. 
> 
>   What is wrong with leaving the programmer the possibility to change some
> application behaviour at runtime?

It's not control at runtime that bothers me, not in itself. It's this
mixture of compile time and runtime control. If I'm to understand the issue
it's about control of how macro expansion works and how compatible it is
with CA-Clipper. Right?

My concern here is that you might be using some code that I've written and
I've only supplied you with a binary (object) of that code. My code relies
on the macro compiler working in a specific way.

Now, you decide, at runtime, to set macro expansion compatibility to a value
that's different from my code. This might well have unexpected consequences
for the execution of my code and also for your code.

As I'm looking at harbour right now, and I could be wrong here - this is the
clarification I'm seeking of yourself and Ron, it would appear that I can
control how macro expansion works by using a compiler switch. That's fine -
I compile my code using the macro expansion compatibility level it needs and
I hand the object file over to you (probably as part of a library).

But, as I see it, it appears you can change this at runtime (see above).

The alternative is to control it all at runtime, in which case why the
compiler switch?

>   Why the programmer cannot request strict Clipper compatibility during
> compilation and at the same time use extended operators and object
> handling (assignments) during the runtime?

I'm afraid I don't follow this at all. Could you give a clear example? Why
would someone want to compile a PRG file with macro expansion compatibility
set one way yet change it, in the same PRG, to something else at runtime?

>   Why not use all extended macro capabilities in code where the programmer
> have full control and next use temporarily restricted set of macro
> capabilities when processed data are taken online from the user input?

Ok, I think I see what you're driving at here. I can see some use for this,
I'd have expected this, however, to either be controlled only by the
compiler or only at runtime, not a mixture. If people want different parts
of their code to use different compiler settings can't it be done with a
#pragma or something (like you can with Borland's Pascal compilers)?

To see the confusion I'm experiencing, the position I'm trying to clarify,
look at the problems I had while playing with this "sync" business. I'm
currently failing to figure out how all of this is supposed to work. Perhaps
yourself and Ron could document what should and shouldn't happen?

-- 
Harbour is a free   | Harbour Web Site: http://www.harbour-project.org/
software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 17:20:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Wed Aug  8 16:20:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] profiler counts wrong times
References: <3B712680.5D52F7B5@libero.it> <20010808154523.B30092@hagbard.davep.org>
 <3B717089.C4210548@libero.it> <200108081318.000000ZU@Internet>
Message-ID: <3B719E78.4F9D1EE4@libero.it>

David,

I wrote this small sample:

proc main(cArg)

   local nS := Seconds()

   Local oProfile := HB_Profile():new()
   __setProfiler( .T. )

   clear screen
   E10Sec()

   oProfile:gather()
   memoedit( HB_ProfileReportToString():new( oProfile:timeSort()
):generate( {|o| o:nTicks > 0 } ), 1,,,, .F. )

return

function E10Sec()

   local nS := Seconds()

   while Seconds() - nS <= 10
   enddo

return nil


And this is profiler result:



Name                                Type       Calls    Ticks       Seconds

=================================== ========== ======== ===========
===========
E10SEC                              Function          1        1001
10.00
SECONDS                             Function     508363         733
7.00
SCROLL                              Function          1           1
0.00


As you can see E10Sec() ran for exaclty 10 seconds.

I see three things here:

1) In more complex cases, like the one I posted earlier, calculation of
ticks spent is not correct
2) Since this sample ran for 10 seconds E10Sec() time spent should not be
reported as 10 sec but as 3 seconds since 7 seconds were spent inside
Seconds()  (Yes, questionable)
3) A division factor of 100 is correct for OS/2 EMX GCC


"David G. Holm" ha scritto:

> ** Reply to message from Maurilio Longo <maurilio.longo@libero.it> on
> Wed, 08 Aug 2001 19:02:01 +0200
>
> The problem is not in the counting of ticks, but in the conversion from
> ticks to seconds. It's obvious that the conversion factor being used is
> divide by 100. Given that your program ran for a total of 15,541 ticks
> and you said that it ran for 44 seconds, the value that is being used
> for ticks per second with GCC for OS/2 is off by about a factor of 3.5
> and should be close to divide by 350.
> --
> David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
> Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.
> _______________________________________________
> Harbour mailing list
> Harbour@matrixlist.com
> http://www.matrixlist.com/mailman/listinfo/harbour
>
> Thank you for participating in The Harbour Project.  Be sure to check
> http://www.Harbour-Project.org

|_|_|_|____| Team OS/2 Italia



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 17:36:20 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Wed Aug  8 16:36:20 2001
Subject: [Harbour] profiler counts wrong times
References: <3B712680.5D52F7B5@libero.it> <20010808154523.B30092@hagbard.davep.org>
 <3B717089.C4210548@libero.it> <200108081318.000000ZU@Internet> <3B719E78.4F9D1EE4@libero.it>
Message-ID: <3B71A252.47D38086@libero.it>

I've found where the problem lies, but I don't know how to fix it:

first I changed my sample this way:

proc main(cArg)

   Local oProfile := HB_Profile():new()
   __setProfiler( .T. )

   clear screen
   E10Sec(Seconds())

   oProfile:gather()
   memoedit( HB_ProfileReportToString():new( oProfile:timeSort() ):generate(
{|o| o:nTicks > 0 } ), 1,,,, .F. )

return

function E10Sec(nS)

   while Seconds() - nS <= 10
      inkey(1)
      E10Sec(nS)
   enddo

return nil

As you can see E10Sec() is now recursive and calls itself on an one second time
interval basis.

Now have a look at profiler output:


Name                                Type       Calls    Ticks       Seconds
=================================== ========== ======== =========== ===========

E10SEC                              Function         12        6600       66.00

INKEY                               Function         11        1100       11.00

E10Sec() spent 66 seconds!!!

This is because inside hb_vmDo if a functions calls itself its time is
calculated for every recursive call and not for the topmost only.

And Esegui() in my previous post is a recursive call as well.

regards.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 17:53:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Wed Aug  8 16:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] profiler counts wrong times
In-Reply-To: <3B71A252.47D38086@libero.it>
References: <3B712680.5D52F7B5@libero.it> <20010808154523.B30092@hagbard.davep.org>
 <3B717089.C4210548@libero.it> <200108081318.000000ZU@Internet>
 <3B719E78.4F9D1EE4@libero.it> <3B71A252.47D38086@libero.it>
Message-ID: <200108081652.0000010E@Internet>

** Reply to message from Maurilio Longo <maurilio.longo@libero.it> on
Wed, 08 Aug 2001 22:34:26 +0200

> This is because inside hb_vmDo if a functions calls itself its time is
> calculated for every recursive call and not for the topmost only.

And because E10() actually takes 11 seconds to run (because you use <=
10 instead of < 10), you get the sum of all the ticks from 100 through
1100, in steps of 100, which totals 6600.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug  8 20:25:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Wed Aug  8 19:25:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtstd driver update
Message-ID: <002101c12061$2501b530$0205a8c0@apollo>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_001A_01C12069.81D35450
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

To whomever wishes to test or post to cvs..

* source/rtl/gtstd/gtstd.c
! changed some internal char * items to BYTE * to better match external
functions
! Max row/col is 24/80 for unix compatible (would be better to do this for
all)
! ReadKey implementation for unix compatible OS: ch value wasn't been
initialised and only least-significant byte being set by fread() - upper
byte of the int value was random, leading to spurious ReadKey return values
! Fixed missing/extra outputting of newline character in SetPos and Scroll
functions
! Added use of backspace char to respond to leftward cursor repositioning
requests
! Added output of BEL character for tone() calls, with tracking of system
time to limit BEL outputs to 1 per second max

I've only tested this under GNU/linux and gcc. The ReadKey is still only
implemented for UNIX_COMPATIBLE_OS.

Redirection of stdin/stdout still works ok. To preserve the ability to
accept redirected stdin, I think maeans there should never be remapping of
any keycodes in this driver. Would be nice to have a way to pass in ALT-C
though.

Regards

Fergus

Content-Type: application/x-zip-compressed;
	name="gtstdupd.zip"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
Content-Disposition: attachment;
	filename="gtstdupd.zip"

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 06:54:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Aug  9 05:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-09 02:30 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <20010808201333.E30092@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEFCDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

2001-08-09 02:30 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
   * source/vm/macro.c
   * include/hbcomp.h
   * include/hbexprb.c
   * include/hbexprc.c
   * include/hbmacro.h
   * include/hbmsetup.h
   * include/set.ch
   * source/compiler/cmdcheck.c
   * source/compiler/genc.c
   * source/compiler/harbour.c
   * source/compiler/hbpcode.c
   * source/rdd/dblist.prg
   * source/vm/hvm.c
     - Removed support for syncing of macro setting with main module.
     - Removed support for -ks which is replaced with -kr.
     + Added default logic to auto synchronize all macro activations with
the compile time switches of each respective module.
     + Added -kr to disable auto synching, thus allowing Run-Time setting by
means of HB_SETMACRO().


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 06:54:18 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Aug  9 05:54:18 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <3B71AFF2.30961.2813135@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKGEFCDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

>   I see the need to control macro compiler capabilities at runtime.
>
>   You don't see such need.
>
> Current code allows to control it regardless if you like it or not.
> Adding additional pcode to store compile time settings will kill the
> ability to change it at runtime.
>
>   Please, again, do whatever you want, I have better things to do. But
> any attempt to kill possibility to set capabilities at runtime will be
> disabled (#ifdef'ed) in some form by me as long as I will work here.

Ok, I implemented the automatic synchronization with each module, but added
ability to disable it with -kr.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 07:22:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Aug  9 06:22:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B828@compuserve.com>

Ron/Dave,

I think the reason why runtime control of macro behaviour is needed
as well as compile-time control is this: in case an OBJ/LIB which was
compiled with the non-Clipper behaviour is linked into an app which
wants the Clipper behaviour.  (Or the inverse.)

The above should never happen with the -Z compiler option.

The above runtime control is only required if Clipper's macro
behaviour is extended e.g. in the way Ron has apparently already done.

If the runtime control isn't available then the practical effect may
be that add-on LIBs which use macroing may need to be made available
compiled in each of the settings. :-(

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 07:22:23 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Aug  9 06:22:23 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B826@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> > > For it to be a list expression it would have to be enclosed in pare=
ns
> > > other than the parens that form the function call.
> > =

> > That's not necessary.

> Could you explain why not?

You lost me I think.  Why should it be necessary?  A list expression
does not have to be in parens inside a code block so it could just as
easily not have to be inside parens inside a macro.

> Here's how I look at it: Macro substitution is, for the most part, a pr=
ogram
> text manipulation facility.

That's one POV but not the only one.  Another would be that &cMacro
is runtime evaluation and not really connected with substitution or
text manipulation.  One POV is that macroing is done to get a value
(and/or side effects of e.g. a function call).  Referring to it as
substitution can be misleading - it's about as true as saying aArr[i]
is substitution or len(cStr) is substitution.  In a sense they are,
but it strikes me as using English in a manner likely to cloud thought.

> So, to make sense of what "should be", we need to consider what the res=
ulting code
> would be if a programmer had written it into their editor. Right?

No.  It's only right given your POV.  From another POV it's wrong. :-)

> I fail to see how the two examples I give above can be read any
> other way.

I accept you think that.  However, there's an alternative way to
handle those examples.  Which of the ways is closer to the "spirit" of
Clipper is hard to say.  If one thinks of Clipper as an Xbase compiler
then your suggested way looks to me to be contrary to that.  However,
if one thinks of Clipper as primarily Xbase then it's arguably more
appropriate.

> Personally I'd hope to read some more detailed technical reasons and
> objections before there's any talk of people forcing things on people.

Me too, but the Harbour project doesn't exactly shine in that respect,
unlike many other community/free/open/whatever projects.

BTW, now that it's been pointed out that Clipper allows a macro to
be a list when inside a code block, I'm convinced that Nantucket
thought this through but didn't describe it in the shipped docs.  I
think Harbour should stay strictly Clipper compatible as regards
macroing a string containing a comma-separated list.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 07:22:39 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Aug  9 06:22:39 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B82A@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> It is also incidental, because *nowhere* [that I could found] is it
> documented that Codeblock *does* support macros of lists!!!
[snip]
> Please explain how should we resolve Clipper behavior here with the
> documentation.

Clipper's doc. is overall quite good, but hopelessly inadequate for
some purposes.  It is incomplete and/or imprecise in many areas.  It
also frequently does not explain the thinking behind many features.
E.g. lists/codeblocks/commas. :-(

I think this is a case where we cannot resolve the behaviour with the
doc.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 07:22:53 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Aug  9 06:22:53 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B827@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> > Anyone can use it in a file amongst many others I may get or be sent
> > (which includes Harbour itself).  I'd like the default settings for
> > Harbour to be that it behaves like Clipper so that I get an error if =
I
> > compile a file containing inline C, thus warning me of the situation.=


> What would there be to warn, or for you to be concerned with?

Supporting or maintaining code is almost certain to be much harder if
some C is present.  Even harder still if one doesn't realise it's
present because it's lurking inline in a PRG.

> > Please let me know where is doc'ed the meaning of SomeFunc( &macro ).=


> This is not the issue we were debating.

Partly it is - we need to be very aware that we're changing what
Clipper does.  In effect, we're doing language design, which is "like
a stroll in the park" according to Larry Wall IIRC.  Jurassic Park. :-(

> We were questioning the possible ambiguity of the meaning of such
> expression.

Yes.

> Don't you think that macro expression should behave in the exact
> same [non ambiguous] way of their non macroed counterparts?

Yes.  But there are two extra ways macroing a list could work in the
code above.

> > BTW, sometimes the Clipper docs are unclear/wrong and/or they conflic=
t
> > with what the compiler/runtime do.  Maybe this is a case.

> I'm afraid that the macro inconsistencies, are nothing more then  an
> indication of an incomplete body of work.

Maybe.  But we're guessing that's so.  We're also guessing as to how
Nantucket would've extended the support.

> > Whether true or not, that doesn't alter that clipper.exe parses
> > SomeFunc( &macro ) as a function call with one param.

> See above, and recent message to Ryszard, explaining why this should be=

> considered a bug.

Your message(s) state your opinion.  I'm not convinced that you're
right.

> > I think it wasn't "laziness" but rather that Clipper 5, by design, is=

> > more like most compiled languages and less like interpreted ones.

> Please explain how is that consistent with the fact that the macro is a=
ble
> to compile practically any expression other then few odd omissions?

The macro feature is more limited than what the compiler (clipper.exe)
can do.  It looks sensible to be guided by the compiler.

> Try to revaluate your statement in light of Clipper "understanding" the=
 same kind
> of list macro in a code block context.

That supports my argument. :-)  Actually, I think it tends to show
that Nantucket took care to prevent commas being macroed, except in
a code block.  That would argue for staying Clipper compatible, i.e.
not extending the macro feature to accept commas in other contexts.
So, both your meaning of SomeFunc( &cMacro ) and mine would be ruled
out.

OK, you've convinced me that Nantucket thought this through but didn't
describe it in the shipped docs.  I think Harbour should stay strictly
Clipper compatible as regards macroing a string containing a
comma-separated list.

> Simple list of such clear omissions include: exp++, --exp,
> exp +=3D exp, (exp), and {|| &NestedBlcokMacro }. But also
> Var :=3D ( &cListMacro ) etc,.

I tend to agree, except in the case of a list.

> We should be more open minded to evaluation of bugs, shortcomings,
> inconsistencies, etc, not just when it involves an issue pressing on
> individual problem. The evaluation process should be as objective as
> possible, from a language design, point of view.

I try hard to be open-minded.  I'm reluctant to re-design Clipper.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 07:24:05 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Thu Aug  9 06:24:05 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B82B@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> > presumably we count extra params for
> > 	SomeFunc( param1, &cMacro, paramN )
> > and similarly for methods.

> this is *already* implemented and works perfectly in all contexts
> where lists are supported, including the above.

It doesn't work except on the basis that a list inside a macro means
what you've decided it means.

> just compile such with macro and you can review for yourself.

I compiled some code.  The result is not my idea of "perfectly".
My initial thoughts were "weird" and "obscure".

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 09:15:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Aug  9 08:15:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B828@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Thu, Aug 09, 2001 at 06:21:21AM -0400
References: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B828@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010809130403.B3814@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Aug 09, 2001 at 06:21:21AM -0400, John Skelton wrote:

> I think the reason why runtime control of macro behaviour is needed as
> well as compile-time control is this: in case an OBJ/LIB which was
> compiled with the non-Clipper behaviour is linked into an app which wants
> the Clipper behaviour. (Or the inverse.)
> 
> The above should never happen with the -Z compiler option.

Why should it never happen with the -Z compiler option?

> If the runtime control isn't available then the practical effect may be
> that add-on LIBs which use macroing may need to be made available compiled
> in each of the settings. :-(

Isn't the same true of -Z too?

Land of the free? Yeah, right.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 09:15:19 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Aug  9 08:15:19 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B826@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Thu, Aug 09, 2001 at 06:21:18AM -0400
References: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B826@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010809130009.A3814@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Aug 09, 2001 at 06:21:18AM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > Could you explain why not?
> 
> You lost me I think. Why should it be necessary? A list expression does
> not have to be in parens inside a code block so it could just as easily
> not have to be inside parens inside a macro.

But a code block isn't a code substitution mechanism is it?

> > Here's how I look at it: Macro substitution is, for the most part, a
> > program text manipulation facility.
> 
> That's one POV but not the only one. Another would be that &cMacro is
> runtime evaluation and not really connected with substitution or text
> manipulation.

The heritage and usage of macro substitution says otherwise doesn't it?

>                     One POV is that macroing is done to get a value
> (and/or side effects of e.g. a function call).

The getting of a value or the calling of a function is, logically, something
that happens after the expansion/substitution has taken place. That's how I
recall macro substitution working in the likes of dBase and FoxBase and, to
a large extent, that's how it's "supposed" to work in Clipper too (with the
obvious exceptions under discussion).

>                                                Referring to it as
> substitution can be misleading - it's about as true as saying aArr[i] is
> substitution or len(cStr) is substitution.

I refer to it as substitution *because* it is so different from expression
evaluation. From a dBase/Clipper programmers point of view, when you've got
code like this:

,----
| c := "aArr[ i ]"
| n := &c
`----

you expect two things to happen on the second line. First you expect macro
substitution to take place. Second, you expect expression evaluation to take
place. I don't say "substitution" so as to be misleading, I say
"substitution" so as to highlight the difference.

>                                            In a sense they are, but it
> strikes me as using English in a manner likely to cloud thought.

Quite the opposite. I say "macro substitution" because that's its heritage.

> > So, to make sense of what "should be", we need to consider what the
> > resulting code would be if a programmer had written it into their
> > editor. Right?
> 
> No. It's only right given your POV. From another POV it's wrong. :-)

I'd be very surprised to find that this is only my POV. There's a long
history of usage behind what I'm saying.

> > Personally I'd hope to read some more detailed technical reasons and
> > objections before there's any talk of people forcing things on people.
> 
> Me too, but the Harbour project doesn't exactly shine in that respect,
> unlike many other community/free/open/whatever projects.

Positive input will change this. Feel free to provide positive input.

-- 
Dave Pearson                        |  OSLib - Timeslice release functions.
http://www.davep.org/               |     eg - Norton Guide reader for Linux.
http://www.davep.org/clipper/       |    weg - Norton Guide reader for Windows.
http://www.davep.org/norton-guides/ | dgscan - DGROUP scanner for Clipper.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 09:55:03 2001

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 12:32:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Aug  9 11:32:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B828@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKOEFEDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> I think the reason why runtime control of macro behaviour is needed
> as well as compile-time control is this: in case an OBJ/LIB which was
> compiled with the non-Clipper behaviour is linked into an app which
> wants the Clipper behaviour.  (Or the inverse.)

Ho no. That would be horrible. It would be the exact equivalent of allowing
a run-time control for ShortCuts (which is one of the macro settings we
control here). You see that would mean the author of a prg linking against
your LIB, may inadvertently override the requirement of your LIB modules.

You should be able to *dictate* at compile time, that your LIB is *immune*
from effect of such Run-Time control.

> The above should never happen with the -Z compiler option.

Of course, and the same is true here.

> The above runtime control is only required if Clipper's macro
> behaviour is extended e.g. in the way Ron has apparently already done.

No. It also controls other Harbour extensions, like Var++ Var+= and so many
other such extensions.

> If the runtime control isn't available then the practical effect may
> be that add-on LIBs which use macroing may need to be made available
> compiled in each of the settings. :-(

No exactly the opposite, it means your LIB is *guaranteed* to work and be
completely *protected* from any such runtime control, if you so desired.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 12:41:00 2001

John,

> > It is also incidental, because *nowhere* [that I could found] is it
> > documented that Codeblock *does* support macros of lists!!!
> [snip]
> > Please explain how should we resolve Clipper behavior here with the
> > documentation.
>
> Clipper's doc. is overall quite good, but hopelessly inadequate for
> some purposes.  It is incomplete and/or imprecise in many areas.  It
> also frequently does not explain the thinking behind many features.
> E.g. lists/codeblocks/commas. :-(
>
> I think this is a case where we cannot resolve the behaviour with the
> doc.

Is that how you explain lack of support for Var++, Var+=, etc.?

Is that how you explain lack of support for nested Codeblocks?

If you think it was intended, can you try and explain why? Or maybe you
expect me to adopt the attitude that "we are just not clever enough to
understand why Nantucket Gods did what they did, but there must be a
perfectly good reason for it?

If the above are clear omissions, why would you try to find [non-existent]
logic in such omissions?

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 13:04:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Aug  9 12:04:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108090621_MC3-DBE7-B827@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEFGDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > > Anyone can use it in a file amongst many others I may get or be sent
> > > (which includes Harbour itself).  I'd like the default settings for
> > > Harbour to be that it behaves like Clipper so that I get an error if I
> > > compile a file containing inline C, thus warning me of the situation.
>
> > What would there be to warn, or for you to be concerned with?
>
> Supporting or maintaining code is almost certain to be much harder if
> some C is present.  Even harder still if one doesn't realise it's
> present because it's lurking inline in a PRG.

I find this extremely prejudiced. I can't understand what will make any form
of C code harder to maintain, compared with any other language, including
Clipper or Harbour, for those who made the decision to use the language they
chose, for a given task.

How would your task be easier, if the C portion was missing, or sent in a
separate file?

> > Don't you think that macro expression should behave in the exact
> > same [non ambiguous] way of their non macroed counterparts?
>
> Yes.  But there are two extra ways macroing a list could work in the
> code above.

We can make it work practically any way we want it to be, the question is
whether it would be logical, and consistent with the language hosting that
macro facility.

> > > I think it wasn't "laziness" but rather that Clipper 5, by design, is
> > > more like most compiled languages and less like interpreted ones.
>
> > Please explain how is that consistent with the fact that the
> macro is able
> > to compile practically any expression other then few odd omissions?
>
> The macro feature is more limited than what the compiler (clipper.exe)
> can do.  It looks sensible to be guided by the compiler.

100% agree.

> > Try to revaluate your statement in light of Clipper
> "understanding" the same kind
> > of list macro in a code block context.
>
> That supports my argument. :-)  Actually, I think it tends to show
> that Nantucket took care to prevent commas being macroed, except in
> a code block.  That would argue for staying Clipper compatible, i.e.
> not extending the macro feature to accept commas in other contexts.
> So, both your meaning of SomeFunc( &cMacro ) and mine would be ruled
> out.

Would you care to offer a reason for such deliberate design decision?

> OK, you've convinced me that Nantucket thought this through but didn't
> describe it in the shipped docs.  I think Harbour should stay strictly
> Clipper compatible as regards macroing a string containing a
> comma-separated list.

I suppose you would have to convince us of the *correctness*, and reasoning
behind allowing us to perform:

//---------------------------------------------//
cMacro := "SomeArray[ Index1, Index2, IndexN ]"
SomeVar := &cMacro
//---------------------------------------------//

and also:

//---------------------------------------------//
cMacro := "Index1"
SomeVar := SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
//---------------------------------------------//

but not:

//---------------------------------------------//
cMacro := "Index1, Index2, IndexN"
SomeVar := SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
//---------------------------------------------//

Before I can support your suggestion.

> > Simple list of such clear omissions include: exp++, --exp,
> > exp += exp, (exp), and {|| &NestedBlcokMacro }. But also
> > Var := ( &cListMacro ) etc,.
>
> I tend to agree, except in the case of a list.

But why "except"? Surely we are entitled to be advised of the reasons. What
immense problem/danger are we trying to eliminate?

> > We should be more open minded to evaluation of bugs, shortcomings,
> > inconsistencies, etc, not just when it involves an issue pressing on
> > individual problem. The evaluation process should be as objective as
> > possible, from a language design, point of view.
>
> I try hard to be open-minded.  I'm reluctant to re-design Clipper.

Unless you provide some reasoning for the odd behavior we are discussing, we
can't view it as a design specification. And thus it's nothing more then bug
fixing.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 14:51:01 2001

Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100

Message-ID: <002101c120fb$ef76b960$3a2d5aa6@K6BW>

----- Original Message -----
From: "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com>
To: <harbour@matrixlist.com>
Sent: Thursday, August 09, 2001 9:06 AM
Subject: RE: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100


<snips>
>
> I find this extremely prejudiced. I can't understand what will make any
form
> of C code harder to maintain, compared with any other language, including
> Clipper or Harbour, for those who made the decision to use the language
they
> chose, for a given task.

Ron, isn't this begging the question?  If someone who has made the decision
to learn and use Clipper as a language then runs into code of another,
possibly unknown language, would he not be discouraged?

.>
> I suppose you would have to convince us of the *correctness*, and
reasoning
> behind allowing us to perform:
>
> //---------------------------------------------//
> cMacro := "SomeArray[ Index1, Index2, IndexN ]"
> SomeVar := &cMacro
> //---------------------------------------------//
>
> and also:
>
> //---------------------------------------------//
> cMacro := "Index1"
> SomeVar := SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
> //---------------------------------------------//
>
> but not:
>
> //---------------------------------------------//
> cMacro := "Index1, Index2, IndexN"
> SomeVar := SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
> //---------------------------------------------//
>

This is *exactly* the recommendation I received from the Clipper developers.
They recommended using arrays for list processing of the kind you represent
above.  They claimed it was a better approach and faster.  It was a
deliberate decision on their part.

I am reminded of the reason xBase was established.  I don't know if this is
a clear example, it is almost a frustrating one, but dBase was originally
written in Basic to provide an easy-to-use language for business
applications.  It wasn't written to be the ultimate programming language and
actually cut across sound programing concepts to provide quick solutions
designed for application.  It was a very simple language and elegant because
it was able to solve problems without introducing complexity.  It had
symmetry where it was needed, but relied upon singular solutions (I am
thinking of the "total on" command) when the business model asked for
simplicity.

Bill


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 14:52:01 2001

> > BTW, now that it's been pointed out that Clipper allows a macro to
> > be a list when inside a code block, I'm convinced that Nantucket
> > thought this through but didn't describe it in the shipped docs.  I
> > think Harbour should stay strictly Clipper compatible as regards
> > macroing a string containing a comma-separated list.

> developers about this subject when they removed the macro support
> after S97.
> Had to rewrite code, too.

Sorry, but I must dispute the above. I was a beta tester for 5.0, and had
numerous contacts with Nantucket throughout those years. My clear
recollection is, this was never intentional in a design context, but rather
an awareness/acceptance of a limitation which was down played, since macro
was now kind of a '2nd class citizen' in lieu of Codeblocks.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 15:24:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Thu Aug  9 14:24:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtstd driver todo
References: <002501c11e61$653752b0$6400a8c0@patrick2> <001801c11e64$fdeaf040$0205a8c0@apollo> <20010806122729.M30092@hagbard.davep.org> <200108061130.000000XQ@Internet> <005a01c11e8d$f104f320$0205a8c0@apollo> <20010806182158.Q30092@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <003e01c12100$6427a180$0205a8c0@apollo>

> As you can see from the above URL the problem was that GTSTD was blocking
> for keyboard input when none was required. You might want to keep the
issues
> raised in that thread in mind.

Don't seem to have any blocking issue here with the fread() code under
unix_os. There is a problem if you redirect stdin from a file, and use
inkey() to read it in the clipper code.. It works, but you have to take a
return value of 0 as being end of file. I think it may then be getting into
a sort of blocking situation otherwise.

stdout redirection seems to work fine. You mentioned earlier about gtstd
possibly being a null I/O driver. My feeling on this would be that as long
as gtstd is purely stdout based, you can always redirect it to nul anyway..

I just want gtstd to work with stdin/stdout, and provide expected console
functionality for ?/??, and straightforward horizontal positioning with
space/backspace/newline, which is what I hope is there with the update I
posted. I found with the current 1.21 version in cvs, newlines were either
being lost altogether in qout() output, or an extraneous newline was being
inserted when outputting on the max row position.

It would be nice to get a non-blocking read working for the non-unix
platforms.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 15:55:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Thu Aug  9 14:55:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <20010808201333.E30092@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <3B718229.13545.1CE5588@localhost>; from rglab@imid.med.pl on Wed, Aug 08, 2001 at 06:17:13PM +0200
Message-ID: <3B72F9EA.27433.2A3A509@localhost>

On 8 Aug 2001, at 20:13, Dave Pearson wrote:

> It's not control at runtime that bothers me, not in itself. It's this
> mixture of compile time and runtime control. If I'm to understand the issue
> it's about control of how macro expansion works and how compatible it is
> with CA-Clipper. Right?


  Yes. But compile time switches are controlling *compile time* 
generation of the pcode while the runtime setings are controlling 
generation of pcode during the runtime.

The compile time:
macro := "1,2"
SomeFunc( &macro )

The runtime:
macro := "1,2"
someExpr := "SomeFunc( &macro )" //this is from user input so the 
   // compiler will not be able to substitute the macro
somevar := &someExpr

 These settings control the way &macro is expanded - if it is a list of 
separate expressions or an invalid expression.
  If the module with the first example is compiled with macro list 
expansion enabled then it will be correctly expanded at runtime 
regardless of HB_SETMACRO() settings because the correct pcode is already 
placed so there is no need for additional sunchronization.

  The compile time switches have no connection with the runtime 
generation of the pcode in the second example thus compile time switches 
shouldn't control the runtime behaviour.
  The same is true for macro inside a literal array and an array index 
(taking aside any dangerous consequences and side effects of such 
behaviour).

  More problems are with LIST support which is related to macro list 
expansion. For example

LIST &macro

In Clipper and Harbour mode it will be preprocessed to:
__dblist( .T., { {|| &macro} }, ....

while in xbase compatibility mode (after the expression optimiser 
mangling):
__dblist( .T., { macro } ,,...)

  This breaks compatibility with other RDD which may always expect the 
array of codeblocks but also break early/late bindings of macro 
expression. In Clipper/harbour mode macro will be evaluated for every 
processed record while in xbase mode it will be evaluated only once (thus 
will ignore changes of the 'macro' value). 
  Again we need the compile time switch to control the generated pcode 
and a separate runtime switch to control the generation of pcode in case 
someone wants to macro compile __dblist() function like in this example:

cBlock := "{|param1| __dblist( .T., { {|| &param1} } )}"
EVAL( &( cBlock ), "someExpr" )

> My concern here is that you might be using some code that I've written and
> I've only supplied you with a binary (object) of that code. My code relies
> on the macro compiler working in a specific way.

  See above, code compiled withe a given compile time switch will run as 
expected with no synchronization needed and regardless of the runtime 
mode.

> Ok, I think I see what you're driving at here. I can see some use for this,
> I'd have expected this, however, to either be controlled only by the
> compiler or only at runtime, not a mixture. If people want different parts
> of their code to use different compiler settings can't it be done with a
> #pragma or something (like you can with Borland's Pascal compilers)?

  I hope the above explanation will clarify things a little.

  #pragma can be used to compile different parts of code however it will  
not help if someone needs to use the same code with different settings. 
If such code is a part of programmer's library used in many applications 
that it is more natural to move settings to the runtime to suppress 
recompilation of such library. 
  For example, as Ron pointed, the extended syntax provided by the macro 
compiler can cause problems in a context:
macro := "otherfield+=2"
REPLACE &somefield WITH &macro
when the data for macro evaluation can be entered by the user instead of:
macro := "otherfield+2"
then we need the possibility to disable such errors. However not always. 
If you divide your users as: dummy users, normal users and me 
(administators) then it is more natural to set the capabilities at 
runtime because the same procedure cannot be compiled with different 
settings and linked together. Creating three separate procedures is just 
wasting of time.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 16:00:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Bill Smith)
Date: Thu Aug  9 15:00:03 2001

Message-ID: <004b01c12105$7a731500$3a2d5aa6@K6BW>

----- Original Message -----
From: "Ron Pinkas" <Ron@Profit-Master.com>
To: <harbour@matrixlist.com>
Sent: Thursday, August 09, 2001 11:15 AM
Subject: RE: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100


> > I meant to say not "after S97" but "with S97".   Yes, support of macros
> > suffered with the introduction of alternative programming techniques.
It
> > was a deliberate decision with S97, however reluctant.
>
> I guess you mean S87.

I guess I did.

>
> Are you trying to suggest that removal of list macro support, was a design
> specification?

I know they did it, and described it in their change document when the new
software was introduced.  I know I had to code around it, and from all
reports it was not a poplular change.
>
> You suggest they decided Clipper would be a better language without it?

I don't know that.  I believe, from talking to the developers, that they
thought Clipper would be a better language with the new logic constructs
they introduced, and they assigned priority in that direction.

>
> You suggest they considered its omission from Clipper 5.x in comparison to
> previous versions of Clipper, and all versions of dBase, FoxPro etc. an
> intended advantage?
>

Regarding Clipper.  Is it necessary that Harbour be different?  Harbour is a
*Clipper* clone that has not yet reached Beta.  Does this effort further the
road to a beta release?

I'd have to go back to see in which version the change was made.  Do I look
to this as an advantage?  I didn't at the time but I am not sure of the
ramifications at present.  If inclusion means libraries may or may not be
usable, then it is a decided non-advantage.  If inclusion implies the
Clipper, now Harbour, user will be faced with a major research project to
second-guess a miriad of exotic run-time and complier parameters with hours
of study and testing to determine side effects, then hell no!  That is a
barrier that has killed many projects.

> I beg to differ. I *know* it was not implemented for lack of interest when
> balanced against the scope of the hardship/complexity involved.

Please keep in mind the poor innocent Clipper user who, embracing Harbour,
may have to retrace steps just to get to ground zero.  Symmetry is excellent
if it is simple and intutive.  It is called complexity or even fuzzy when it
isn't.

>
> Ron
>

Bill


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 16:34:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Luc Saffre)
Date: Thu Aug  9 15:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtwin.c:124: parse error before `s_HOriginal'
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20010809203812.00a6f370@mail.demetec.net>

Hello,

I am trying to join to the harbour team... but for the moment I cannot even 
make a successful build! :-(
I am using Cygwin on a Win2000 machine.
Probably I am making some stupid mistake. Perhaps somebody can help me to 
find it!

Here is what I do:
I downloaded the CVS snapshot and unzipped it to t:\soft\harbour
I set the following environment variables
  set HB_ARCHITECTURE=w32
  set HB_COMPILER=gcc
  set HB_GT_LIB=gtwin
  set CYGWIN=NOGLOB

Then, in bash, I go to the harbour directory and invoke "make":
   bash-2.05$ pwd
   /cygdrive/t/soft/harbour
   bash-2.05$ make

First, there is a lot of things that work. For example, harbour.exe is made.
But gtwin.c seems to not work:
   gtwin.c:124: parse error before `s_HOriginal'
is the first message of a long series of error messages.

The make continues for some time before really abandoning for good.
Some of the last messages are:
  /usr/lib/gcc-lib/i686-pc-cygwin/2.95.3-5/../../../../i686-pc-cygwin/bin/ld: 
cannot find -lgtwin
  collect2: ld returned 1 exit status
  make[2]: *** [ac_test.exe] Error 1


I downloaded the mailbox archive (file harbour.mbox) from
http://www.matrixlist.com/pipermail/harbour/
and searched it for the string "s_HOriginal".
I did not find anything.
So I decided to call for help: What am I doing wrong?

Luc
from Belgium


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 16:41:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Aug  9 15:41:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-08 15:30 UTC-0400 David G. Holm
Message-ID: <200108091540.0000010M@Internet>

2001-08-08 15:30 UTC-0400 David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com>

  * tests/gtstdtst.prg
      Submitted by "Fergus McDonald" <listsub@qvolution.com>
  	+ New test module for GTSTD terminal driver.

  * source/rtl/gtstd/gtstd.c
      Submitted by "Fergus McDonald" <listsub@qvolution.com>
    ! changed some internal char * items to BYTE * to better match
      external functions
    ! Max row/col is 24/80 for unix compatible (would be better to
      do this for all)
    ! ReadKey implementation for unix compatible OS: ch value wasn't
      been initialised and only least-significant byte being set by
      fread() - upper byte of the int value was random, leading to
      spurious ReadKey return values
    ! Fixed missing/extra outputting of newline character in SetPos
      and Scroll functions
    ! Added use of backspace char to respond to leftward cursor
      repositioning requests
    ! Added output of BEL character for tone() calls, with tracking
      of system time to limit BEL outputs to 1 per second max

    I've only tested this under GNU/linux and gcc. The ReadKey is still
    only implemented for UNIX_COMPATIBLE_OS.

    Redirection of stdin/stdout still works ok. To preserve the ability
    to accept redirected stdin, I think maeans there should never be
    remapping of any keycodes in this driver. Would be nice to have a
    way to pass in ALT-C though.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

** Reply to message from Luc Saffre <luc.saffre@gmx.net> on Thu, 09 Aug 2001 21:30:15 +0200

> I am using Cygwin on a Win2000 machine.

Following are the exports that I use. The key ones that
you appear to be missing are C_USR and L_USR.

export HARBOURDIR=/cygdrive/q/hb/harbour
export HB_ARCHITECTURE=w32
export HB_COMPILER=gcc
export HB_GT_LIB=gtwin
export HB_BIN_INSTALL=/usr/local/bin
export HB_LIB_INSTALL=/usr/local/lib
export HB_INC_INSTALL=/usr/local/include/
export C_USR=-mwin32
export L_USR=-mwin32
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

--pIo0sNt1rNo2aOd3mVa4iAl5eLr
Content-Type: text/plain; name=bld.sh; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename=bld.sh

export HARBOURDIR=3D/cygdrive/q/hb/harbour=0D=0Aexport HB_ARCHITECTURE=3Dw32=
=0D=0Aexport HB_COMPILER=3Dgcc=0D=0Aexport HB_GT_LIB=3Dgtwin=0D=0Aexport HB_=
BIN_INSTALL=3D/usr/local/bin=0D=0Aexport HB_LIB_INSTALL=3D/usr/local/lib=0D=
=0Aexport HB_INC_INSTALL=3D/usr/local/include/=0D=0Aexport C_USR=3D-mwin32=
=0D=0Aexport L_USR=3D-mwin32=0D=0A=0D=0Aecho harbour $1.prg -n -i$HB_INC_INS=
TALL $2 $3 $HARBOURFLAGS=0D=0Aharbour $1.prg -n -i$HB_INC_INSTALL $2 $3 $HAR=
BOURFLAGS=0D=0Aecho gcc $1.c -o$1.exe $CFLAGS $C_USR -I$HB_INC_INSTALL -L$HB=
_LIB_INSTALL -ldebug -lvm -lrtl -l$HB_GT_LIB -llang -lrdd -lrtl -lvm -lmacro=
 -lpp -ldbfntx -ldbfcdx -lcommon=0D=0Agcc $1.c -o$1.exe $CFLAGS $C_USR -I$HB=
_INC_INSTALL -L$HB_LIB_INSTALL -ldebug -lvm -lrtl -l$HB_GT_LIB -llang -lrdd =
-lrtl -lvm -lmacro -lpp -ldbfntx -ldbfcdx -lcommon=0D=0A
--pIo0sNt1rNo2aOd3mVa4iAl5eLr--

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 21:57:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Aug  9 20:57:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] PP Bug (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <3B72FEF3.68393E85@corevia.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEFNDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Hi Jose,

> today I got a bug report from a guy:
>
> ---
> There is a bug in pp.prg: it doesn't close the PPO file with FClose().
> On quitting my app, it is closed but if you call the pp two times from
> the app, the second time it doesn't build the PPO file.
> ---
>
> Could you review this ?

He must be using an older version. Current PP does close the PPO file
correctly.

Here is the code segment, starting at line# 2523:

   IF ProcName(2) == ""
      FClose( hPP )

      IF bCCH
         CompileToCCH( sSource )
      ENDIF
   ENDIF

He can add an Alert() message and confirm this.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug  9 23:05:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Aug  9 22:05:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <3B72F9EA.27433.2A3A509@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEFODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > It's not control at runtime that bothers me, not in itself. It's this
> > mixture of compile time and runtime control. If I'm to
> understand the issue
> > it's about control of how macro expansion works and how compatible it is
> > with CA-Clipper. Right?
>
>   Yes. But compile time switches are controlling *compile time*
> generation of the pcode while the runtime setings are controlling
> generation of pcode during the runtime.

Yes, and it's natural that compile time setting will serve as the default
for the run-time setting.

> The compile time:
> macro := "1,2"
> SomeFunc( &macro )
>
> The runtime:
> macro := "1,2"
> someExpr := "SomeFunc( &macro )" //this is from user input so the
>    // compiler will not be able to substitute the macro
> somevar := &someExpr
>
>  These settings control the way &macro is expanded - if it is a list of
> separate expressions or an invalid expression.
>   If the module with the first example is compiled with macro list
> expansion enabled then it will be correctly expanded at runtime
> regardless of HB_SETMACRO() settings because the correct pcode is already
> placed so there is no need for additional sunchronization.
>
>   The compile time switches have no connection with the runtime
> generation of the pcode in the second example thus compile time switches
> shouldn't control the runtime behaviour.
>   The same is true for macro inside a literal array and an array index
> (taking aside any dangerous consequences and side effects of such
> behaviour).

This is where we disagree. I believe it's more natural to expect that the
default run-time setting for compiling the macro in 2nd example should be
taken from the compile time setting, rather then some arbitrary default.
Even more problematic is the fact, that if the developer must rely on
run-time setting, he must SAVE + SET + RESTORE all flags for each macro
activation. It also means that had he not done so, his macros will produce
un-expected results when linked with code that makes use of HB_SETMACRO().

>   More problems are with LIST support which is related to macro list
> expansion. For example
>
> LIST &macro
>
> In Clipper and Harbour mode it will be preprocessed to:
> __dblist( .T., { {|| &macro} }, ....
>
> while in xbase compatibility mode (after the expression optimiser
> mangling):
> __dblist( .T., { macro } ,,...)
>
>
>   This breaks compatibility with other RDD which may always expect the
> array of codeblocks but also break early/late bindings of macro
> expression. In Clipper/harbour mode macro will be evaluated for every
> processed record while in xbase mode it will be evaluated only once (thus
> will ignore changes of the 'macro' value).
>   Again we need the compile time switch to control the generated pcode
> and a separate runtime switch to control the generation of pcode in case
> someone wants to macro compile __dblist() function like in this example:
>
> cBlock := "{|param1| __dblist( .T., { {|| &param1} } )}"
> EVAL( &( cBlock ), "someExpr" )

Wow, how can you be so dishonest? Why spread unfounded fears [again]?

1. RDD does NEVER get any Array related to anything to do with __dbList()!!!
RDD ALWAYS evaluate just ONE single value resulting from evaluation of a
CodeBlock within __dbList().

2. Flex version of Harbour does NOT even support early/late binding of
macros - Check tests/tstblock.prg!

3. The macro sample you provided &Macro is an EARLY form, and should be
evaluated only once!

4. You claim that the user of the LIST command should be aware of early/late
binding of CodeBlocks??? You think he should be aware of such low level
undocumented implementation detail, and possibly change the value of Macro
*during* the execution of the LIST LOOP??? Do you really understand where
are you going with this?

5. You know that the compile time setting is what determines the
optimization of a prg level __dbList(), and if someone created a macro to
call __dbList() it would not have to use a nested macro for the value,
because the __dblist() macro is already in string form (composed in run
time)!!! And *if* he did use a nested macro for some reason, he would expect
it to behave according to the same setting he used for his prg level
__dbList() won't you think?

6. If one still wanted for any reason, to have an independent run-time
setting for macro, to be determined by HB_SETMACRO() and not the compile
time setting he will just use -kr, right?

> > My concern here is that you might be using some code that I've
> written and
> > I've only supplied you with a binary (object) of that code. My
> code relies
> > on the macro compiler working in a specific way.
>
>   See above, code compiled withe a given compile time switch will run as
> expected with no synchronization needed and regardless of the runtime
> mode.

That's absolutely false! If the macro used any Harbour extension for
Example:

   cBlock := "{|param1| __dblist( .T., { {|| param1++ } } ) }"
   EVAL( &( cBlock ), "someVarOrField" )

It will *BREAK* unless the run-time setting supports the Harbour extension.
This will be *guaranteed* to work with the automatic synchronization,
regardless of how many modules are involved, and what different setting each
requires.

Don't you agree that for all macros, the developer *must* know the required
run-time support in compile time. Or else he couldn't even use
HB_SETMACRO(). The only [extremely rare] exception would be someone who
specify the HB_SETMACRO() arguments based on run-time determination. We both
know, this is very rare, but for this purpose the -kr is available.

> > Ok, I think I see what you're driving at here. I can see some
> use for this,
> > I'd have expected this, however, to either be controlled only by the
> > compiler or only at runtime, not a mixture. If people want
> different parts
> > of their code to use different compiler settings can't it be done with a
> > #pragma or something (like you can with Borland's Pascal compilers)?
>
>   I hope the above explanation will clarify things a little.
>
>   #pragma can be used to compile different parts of code however it will
> not help if someone needs to use the same code with different settings.
> If such code is a part of programmer's library used in many applications
> that it is more natural to move settings to the runtime to suppress
> recompilation of such library.
>   For example, as Ron pointed, the extended syntax provided by the macro
> compiler can cause problems in a context:
> macro := "otherfield+=2"
> REPLACE &somefield WITH &macro
> when the data for macro evaluation can be entered by the user instead of:
> macro := "otherfield+2"
> then we need the possibility to disable such errors. However not always.
> If you divide your users as: dummy users, normal users and me
> (administators) then it is more natural to set the capabilities at
> runtime because the same procedure cannot be compiled with different
> settings and linked together. Creating three separate procedures is just
> wasting of time.

Exactly for this kind of need the -kr is available.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 00:14:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Aug  9 23:14:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] PP Bug (Ron)
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEFNDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEFODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> He must be using an older version. Current PP does close the PPO file
> correctly.
>
> Here is the code segment, starting at line# 2523:
>
>    IF ProcName(2) == ""
>       FClose( hPP )
>
>       IF bCCH
>          CompileToCCH( sSource )
>       ENDIF
>    ENDIF
>
> He can add an Alert() message and confirm this.

Oops, silly me, the first line above is wrong (in that context). Have him
change that to:

   IF ProcName(1) == "MAIN"

I'll post the fix.

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 04:47:09 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Fri Aug 10 03:47:09 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEFODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <3B72F9EA.27433.2A3A509@localhost>
Message-ID: <3B73AEB4.24752.7B3695@localhost>

On 9 Aug 2001, at 19:06, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> >   The compile time switches have no connection with the runtime
> > generation of the pcode in the second example thus compile time switches
> > shouldn't control the runtime behaviour.
> >   The same is true for macro inside a literal array and an array index
> > (taking aside any dangerous consequences and side effects of such
> > behaviour).
> 
> This is where we disagree. I believe it's more natural to expect that the
> default run-time setting for compiling the macro in 2nd example should be
> taken from the compile time setting, rather then some arbitrary default.
> Even more problematic is the fact, that if the developer must rely on
> run-time setting, he must SAVE + SET + RESTORE all flags for each macro
> activation. It also means that had he not done so, his macros will produce
> un-expected results when linked with code that makes use of HB_SETMACRO().

  Sorry, I have over-simplified the whole thing. All what I have wrote 
earlier is true for xbase compability only - because only in xbase mode, 
we are generating different pcodes. These are really cases where there is 
no need for synchronization because the pcode cannot be changed at 
runtime.

  Yes, problems can appear in the case clipper-harbour compatibility 
where the same pcode is generated. For example:

macro := "somevar++"
SomeFun( &macro )

Since the macro expansion will take a place at runtime then the macro 
compiler will check the compatibility mode during compilation. If this 
code is compiled with harbour compatibility and the runtime is set to 
Clipper mode then we have problem here. We can solve it with:
- add some synchronization code, as Ron have done it
- ignore any synchronization and use the runtime settings only

  We can discuss ,,what is more natural'' for the very long time however 
there is no point in such discussion. Just give the programmer the choice.

  In other words if someone will find the better method to:
- allow to disable/enable Ron's additions to the macro list compilation 
and __dblist support which breaks Clipper compatibility (regardless if we 
agree that it is either a Clipper bug or carefully choosen design)
- allow to disable/enable extended harbour macro capabilities 
(compilation of ++, +=, etc) at runtime
  These two items are complicated with the fact that the first problem is 
resolved with different pcode generation at compile time while the second 
is generating the same pcode at compile time but is checked at runtime by 
the macro compiler.

> Wow, how can you be so dishonest? Why spread unfounded fears [again]?
> 
> 1. RDD does NEVER get any Array related to anything to do with __dbList()!!!
> RDD ALWAYS evaluate just ONE single value resulting from evaluation of a
> CodeBlock within __dbList().

  But any RDD can implement his own __dblist function to properly handle 
passed array of codeblocks.

> 2. Flex version of Harbour does NOT even support early/late binding of
> macros - Check tests/tstblock.prg!

  What it has common with the __dblist?

> 3. The macro sample you provided &Macro is an EARLY form, and should be
> evaluated only once!

Look for this example:
PROC MAIN
LOCAL macro
PRIVATE var

var :=1
macro :="IIF((var%5)==0, '===', STR(var,3))"
Test( {|| &macro} )

PROC TEST( bBlock )
LOCAL i
  FOR i:=1 TO 20
     ? EVAL( bBlock )
     M->var++
  NEXT
RETURN

  If it a macro is evaluated only once then you should see the same value 
repeated 20 times. If it is evaluated LATE then you will see something 
different. Just check it. This is simmilar code to __dblist().

> 4. You claim that the user of the LIST command should be aware of early/late
> binding of CodeBlocks??? You think he should be aware of such low level
> undocumented implementation detail, and possibly change the value of Macro
> *during* the execution of the LIST LOOP??? Do you really understand where
> are you going with this?

  This is what Clipper is doing. Someone might find it usable. Do we 
really have to break compatibility here?

> 5. You know that the compile time setting is what determines the
> optimization of a prg level __dbList(), and if someone created a macro to
> call __dbList() it would not have to use a nested macro for the value,
> because the __dblist() macro is already in string form (composed in run
> time)!!! 

  Ron, the function which is called can have different source then the 
value. It is possible that someone cannot stringify all required values 
if the simple macro expression solve many problems.

> And *if* he did use a nested macro for some reason, he would expect
> it to behave according to the same setting he used for his prg level
> __dbList() won't you think?

  This is your point of view. I expect that the runtime settings will be 
used.

> 6. If one still wanted for any reason, to have an independent run-time
> setting for macro, to be determined by HB_SETMACRO() and not the compile
> time setting he will just use -kr, right?

  Yes, now yes. After my changes.

> >   See above, code compiled withe a given compile time switch will run as
> > expected with no synchronization needed and regardless of the runtime
> > mode.
> 
> That's absolutely false! If the macro used any Harbour extension for
> Example:
> 
>    cBlock := "{|param1| __dblist( .T., { {|| param1++ } } ) }"
>    EVAL( &( cBlock ), "someVarOrField" )

  Yes, sorry. I have auto-suggested with the xbase compatibility issues 
when I was writing it.

> It will *BREAK* unless the run-time setting supports the Harbour extension.
> This will be *guaranteed* to work with the automatic synchronization,
> regardless of how many modules are involved, and what different setting each
> requires.
> 
> Don't you agree that for all macros, the developer *must* know the required
> run-time support in compile time. Or else he couldn't even use
> HB_SETMACRO(). The only [extremely rare] exception would be someone who
> specify the HB_SETMACRO() arguments based on run-time determination. We both
> know, this is very rare, but for this purpose the -kr is available.

  Then why you are arguing for macro list support so strongly? Give the 
programmer the possibility to choose what he wants instead of nonsense 
arguments. Don't enforce some behaviour because different programmers 
might have different needs.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 05:53:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Fri Aug 10 04:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108100452_MC3-DBF8-6A0A@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> > I think the reason why runtime control of macro behaviour is needed a=
s
> > well as compile-time control is this: in case an OBJ/LIB which was
> > compiled with the non-Clipper behaviour is linked into an app which w=
ants
> > the Clipper behaviour. (Or the inverse.)
> > =

> > The above should never happen with the -Z compiler option.

> Why should it never happen with the -Z compiler option?

Because the author of the algorithm should know whether -Z is needed
or not, and compile appropriately.  The user (i.e. caller) of the
OBJ/LIB should not have to know about this implementation detail.

> > If the runtime control isn't available then the practical effect may =
be
> > that add-on LIBs which use macroing may need to be made available com=
piled
> > in each of the settings. :-(

> Isn't the same true of -Z too?

No.  See above.

John.

beating your wife?" question.

IAC, it's a moot issue now that it's been shown that Nantucket thought
this through and decided not to allow lists in macros except in code
blocks.  (See my other messages, which I think crossed with yours.)

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 08:19:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Fri Aug 10 07:19:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108100718_MC3-DBFC-18C1@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> > > It is also incidental, because *nowhere* [that I could found] is it=

> > > documented that Codeblock *does* support macros of lists!!!
> > [snip]
> > > Please explain how should we resolve Clipper behavior here with the=

> > documentation.
> >
> > Clipper's doc. is overall quite good, but hopelessly inadequate for
> > some purposes.  It is incomplete and/or imprecise in many areas.  It
> > also frequently does not explain the thinking behind many features.
> > E.g. lists/codeblocks/commas. :-(
> >
> > I think this is a case where we cannot resolve the behaviour with the=

> > doc.

> Is that how you explain lack of support for Var++, Var+=3D, etc.?

> Is that how you explain lack of support for nested Codeblocks?

It's a guess as to the reasons for the above.

> If you think it was intended, can you try and explain why?

It's clear (see previous messages) that lists in macros were intended
only to be allowed in code blocks.  One reason why may well be that
Nantucket thought people would have opposite views as to how they
should be handled and thus decided to reject them - forcing people to
specify what they want in an unambiguous way.

> Or maybe you expect me to adopt the attitude that "we are just not
> clever enough to understand why Nantucket Gods did what they did,
> but there must be a perfectly good reason for it?

I suggest you stick to more helpful debate.

> If the above are clear omissions, why would you try to find [non-existe=
nt]
> logic in such omissions?

I don't say they are "clear omissions".  I've posted plenty of logic
about the situation.  I'm not keen to repeat it, so please re-read my
messages.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 08:20:05 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Fri Aug 10 07:20:05 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108100718_MC3-DBFC-18BF@compuserve.com>

Ron,

[original usage of "perfectly" omitted by Ron]
> > I compiled some code.  The result is not my idea of "perfectly".
> > My initial thoughts were "weird" and "obscure".

> You can use -kc or -kch when compiling, to get the alternate behavior t=
hat
> you seem to be happier with.

I thought it was -kc or -kh?  I'm confused by these changing -k
things. :-(

That's all very well as regards my code.  However, -kc (Clipper-
compatible) needs to be the default for this (list macro) feature.
Otherwise you're overuling what Nantucket clearly did deliberately.  I
don't feel you've at all demonstrated that you know better than them.
New users of Harbour should get the Clipper behaviour by default
unless you're able to make a really good case for changing the
behaviour.

If Harbour is to allow such list macros, it would probably be a good
idea not only to doc how to enable it but also to mention the kinds
of code it will break.  It may be worth mentioning that there was a
lengthy discussion of the feature with details of pros and cons.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 08:20:21 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Fri Aug 10 07:20:21 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108100718_MC3-DBFC-18C0@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> > Supporting or maintaining code is almost certain to be much harder if=

> > some C is present.  Even harder still if one doesn't realise it's
> > present because it's lurking inline in a PRG.

> I find this extremely prejudiced.

It's my many years of experience about Clipper code which includes any
C.

> I can't understand what will make any form of C code harder to
> maintain, compared with any other language, including Clipper or
> Harbour, for those who made the decision to use the language they
> chose, for a given task.

You may not understand it, but my experience shows it to be so.

> How would your task be easier, if the C portion was missing, or sent in=
 a
> separate file?

If there's no C the situation doesn't arise.  If it's in FILE.C then
it's rather obvious from the file name!

BTW, why you'd try to argue support-type issues with someone who's
done as much as I have beats me.

> > Yes.  But there are two extra ways macroing a list could work in the
> > code above.

> We can make it work practically any way we want it to be, the question =
is
> whether it would be logical, and consistent with the language hosting t=
hat
> macro facility.

As I've said, I think Nantucket's actions show we should learn from
them - and be strictly Clipper-compatible.

> > That supports my argument. :-)  Actually, I think it tends to show
> > that Nantucket took care to prevent commas being macroed, except in
> > a code block.  That would argue for staying Clipper compatible, i.e.
> > not extending the macro feature to accept commas in other contexts.
> > So, both your meaning of SomeFunc( &cMacro ) and mine would be ruled
> > out.

> Would you care to offer a reason for such deliberate design decision?

As I've said elsewhere, it may be that Nantucket people were aware
that a list in a macro could have two meanings, except in a code block
where they took extra care in at least 2 ways(see below).  They may
well have decided to disallow the list macro except in a code block
in order to force people to use an unambiguous piece of code.

The two ways Nantucket took care with code blocks:
1. they allow a macro where it would not be ambiguous
e.g. {|| &cMacro }
2. they added an error message for other cases
e.g. {|| {&cMacro} }
this error also occurs for cases that would not be ambiguous; perhaps
they didn't see enough need to try to figure out which would be OK
and which not.  Note that they chose the "safer" (more restrictive)
route.

> > OK, you've convinced me that Nantucket thought this through but didn'=
t
> > describe it in the shipped docs.  I think Harbour should stay strictl=
y
> > Clipper compatible as regards macroing a string containing a
> > comma-separated list.

> I suppose you would have to convince us of the *correctness*, and reaso=
ning
> behind allowing us to perform:
> cMacro :=3D "SomeArray[ Index1, Index2, IndexN ]"
> SomeVar :=3D &cMacro
> and also:
> cMacro :=3D "Index1"
> SomeVar :=3D SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
> but not:
> cMacro :=3D "Index1, Index2, IndexN"
> SomeVar :=3D SomeArray[ &cMacro ]

I don't know whether I can convince you.  However, the first two are
unambiguous whereas the latter is ambiguous - it's an example of the
very case where you want one behaviour and I originally wanted another
behaviour (but now I think Nantucket were right to disallow it).

> > > Simple list of such clear omissions include: exp++, --exp,
> > > exp +=3D exp, (exp), and {|| &NestedBlcokMacro }. But also
> > > Var :=3D ( &cListMacro ) etc,.
> >
> > I tend to agree, except in the case of a list.

> But why "except"?

Because it's not ambiguous.

> Surely we are entitled to be advised of the reasons.

Of course.  I thought it obvious. :-)

> What immense problem/danger are we trying to eliminate?

Ambiguity.  It would be great to avoid premature implementation and
endless threads, too.

> > I try hard to be open-minded.  I'm reluctant to re-design Clipper.

> Unless you provide some reasoning for the odd behavior we are discussin=
g

I have provided reasoning.

> we can't view it as a design specification. And thus it's nothing
> more then bug fixing.

I don't agree you can say "we" as you'd be speaking for others, whose
opinions are not yet known.  It's your opinion that it's a matter of
bug fixing.  I don't agree, and there's evidence Nantucket had good
reasons for what they did.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 08:20:40 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Fri Aug 10 07:20:40 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108100718_MC3-DBFC-18C2@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> I think the reason why runtime control of macro behaviour is needed
> as well as compile-time control is this: in case an OBJ/LIB which was
> compiled with the non-Clipper behaviour is linked into an app which
> wants the Clipper behaviour.  (Or the inverse.)

> That would be horrible. It would be the exact equivalent of allowing
> a run-time control for ShortCuts

It may or may not be horrible.  It's not the same as runtime control
of short cuts (-Z switch), however.

> You see that would mean the author of a prg linking against your
> LIB, may inadvertently override the requirement of your LIB modules.

But they may _need_ to do that, whereas they should never need to do
that with -Z.

> You should be able to *dictate* at compile time, that your LIB is *immu=
ne*
> from effect of such Run-Time control.

If you do that, the LIB may not be of use.  E.g. the LIB macros
something then SEEKs it.  I pass in a string containing a comma.  The
LIB mistakenly treats what I've passed as a list.  But really it was
user bad input.

The above is an example.  No doubt there are many other possible
scenarios.

This is _not_ like anything that can happen with -Z.

> It also controls other Harbour extensions, like Var++ Var+=3D and so ma=
ny
> other such extensions.

I have doubts as to the wisdom of that.

> > If the runtime control isn't available then the practical effect may
> > be that add-on LIBs which use macroing may need to be made available
> > compiled in each of the settings. :-(

> No exactly the opposite, it means your LIB is *guaranteed* to work and =
be
> completely *protected* from any such runtime control, if you so desired=
.

In the example above, you're wrong.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 13:47:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 13:56:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Aug 10 12:56:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] SourceForge bug #439465
Message-ID: <200108101255.0000011I@Internet>

Submitted by Luc Saffre (lsaffre):

In my source file there is a #xcommand directive like 

#xcommand EDIT DATA <oBrowse> ; 
[ MODE <nMode> ] ; 
(...) 
=> ddEdit( <oBrowse>, ; 
(...) 

Since release 37 this does no longer compile. Harbour 
says: 

Error F0006 Missing => in #translate/#command 

I compiled the same files successfully with release 36. 

It seems that the line continuation mecanism using ";" 
does not work in the first part of a #xcommand 
directive. 
If I modify the source so that the "=>" is on the same 
line as the #xcommand, then the source compiles.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.
