From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 15:09:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Aug 10 14:09:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>
In-Reply-To: <3B73AEB4.24752.7B3695@localhost>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEGEDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

> > This is where we disagree. I believe it's more natural to
> expect that the
> > default run-time setting for compiling the macro in 2nd example
> should be
> > taken from the compile time setting, rather then some arbitrary default.
> > Even more problematic is the fact, that if the developer must rely on
> > run-time setting, he must SAVE + SET + RESTORE all flags for each macro
> > activation. It also means that had he not done so, his macros
> will produce
> > un-expected results when linked with code that makes use of
> HB_SETMACRO().
>
>   Sorry, I have over-simplified the whole thing. All what I have wrote
> earlier is true for xbase compability only - because only in xbase mode,
> we are generating different pcodes. These are really cases where there is
> no need for synchronization because the pcode cannot be changed at
> runtime.

Thanks for the confirmation.

>   Yes, problems can appear in the case clipper-harbour compatibility
> where the same pcode is generated. For example:
>
> macro := "somevar++"
> SomeFun( &macro )
>
> Since the macro expansion will take a place at runtime then the macro
> compiler will check the compatibility mode during compilation. If this
> code is compiled with harbour compatibility and the runtime is set to
> Clipper mode then we have problem here. We can solve it with:
> - add some synchronization code, as Ron have done it
> - ignore any synchronization and use the runtime settings only
>
>   We can discuss ,,what is more natural'' for the very long time however
> there is no point in such discussion. Just give the programmer the choice.

Yes, already done.

>   In other words if someone will find the better method to:
> - allow to disable/enable Ron's additions to the macro list compilation
> and __dblist support which breaks Clipper compatibility (regardless if we
> agree that it is either a Clipper bug or carefully choosen design)

Why would you continue painting the list macro extension as breaking
compatibility, knowing that there are *factors* more of such extensions,
that you are responsible for, that you don't paint in that same negative
light - why?

> > Wow, how can you be so dishonest? Why spread unfounded fears [again]?
> >
> > 1. RDD does NEVER get any Array related to anything to do with
> __dbList()!!!
> > RDD ALWAYS evaluate just ONE single value resulting from evaluation of a
> > CodeBlock within __dbList().
>
>   But any RDD can implement his own __dblist function to properly handle
> passed array of codeblocks.

1. Nonsense. Could it possibly implement it not even using codeblocks, thus
completely wiping your theory that LIST command features *are* bound to the
low level implementation details?

2. Any new implementation of __dbList() will simply take advantage of
HB_aExpressions() just like __dbList() does.

> > 2. Flex version of Harbour does NOT even support early/late binding of
> > macros - Check tests/tstblock.prg!
>
>   What it has common with the __dblist?

It has to do with your argument about early/late compatibility, when the
"formal" build of Harbour does *not* even support this feature!!! Now I know
why, it appears you don't yet understand this concept (read below).

> > 3. The macro sample you provided &Macro is an EARLY form, and should be
> > evaluated only once!
>
> Look for this example:
> PROC MAIN
> LOCAL macro
> PRIVATE var
>
> var :=1
> macro :="IIF((var%5)==0, '===', STR(var,3))"
> Test( {|| &macro} )
>
> PROC TEST( bBlock )
> LOCAL i
>   FOR i:=1 TO 20
>      ? EVAL( bBlock )
>      M->var++
>   NEXT
> RETURN

This shows you don't understand the concept of early/late macro evaluation
in code block. Your sample above is using EARLY binding. The value of the
macro itself is only bound ONCE at the time the block is created. The
different value would be the same even if you didn't use macro at all! Maybe
the following [slight modification] can explain your mistake:

//-----------------------------------------------//
MEMVAR var, macro

PROC MAIN()

   PRIVATE macro
   PRIVATE var

   var :=1
   macro :="IIF((var%5)==0, '===', STR(var,3))"

   Test( {|| &macro } )
   Test( {|| &(macro) } ) // Now we use LATE binding - different MACRO value
will be used!!!

RETURN

PROC TEST( bBlock )

   LOCAL i

   macro := "'Late'" // Here we create new macro value, will only affect
LATE binding!!!

   FOR i:=1 TO 20
      ? EVAL( bBlock )
      var++
   NEXT

RETURN
//-----------------------------------------------//

Run the above with Clipper...

Do you *now* understand the difference between EARLY and LATE macro binding?
If you don't let me know, and I'll post more code to explain the issue in
more details.

>   If it a macro is evaluated only once then you should see the same value
> repeated 20 times. If it is evaluated LATE then you will see something
> different. Just check it. This is simmilar code to __dblist().

Do you now understand how mistaken you are?

> > 4. You claim that the user of the LIST command should be aware
> of early/late
> > binding of CodeBlocks??? You think he should be aware of such low level
> > undocumented implementation detail, and possibly change the
> value of Macro
> > *during* the execution of the LIST LOOP??? Do you really
> understand where
> > are you going with this?
>
>   This is what Clipper is doing. Someone might find it usable. Do we
> really have to break compatibility here?

We don't break compatibility, we offer the reduced Clipper macro support,
when using the -kc or -kh switch, just as with other Harbour extensions.

> > 6. If one still wanted for any reason, to have an independent run-time
> > setting for macro, to be determined by HB_SETMACRO() and not the compile
> > time setting he will just use -kr, right?
>
>   Yes, now yes. After my changes.

Well not exactly your change [maybe your imitative], but if it makes you
feel better, I'm all for it.

> > >   See above, code compiled withe a given compile time switch
> will run as
> > > expected with no synchronization needed and regardless of the runtime
> > > mode.
> >
> > That's absolutely false! If the macro used any Harbour extension for
> > Example:
> >
> >    cBlock := "{|param1| __dblist( .T., { {|| param1++ } } ) }"
> >    EVAL( &( cBlock ), "someVarOrField" )
>
>   Yes, sorry. I have auto-suggested with the xbase compatibility issues
> when I was writing it.

Thanks again for the confirmation.

> > It will *BREAK* unless the run-time setting supports the
> Harbour extension.
> > This will be *guaranteed* to work with the automatic synchronization,
> > regardless of how many modules are involved, and what different
> setting each
> > requires.
> >
> > Don't you agree that for all macros, the developer *must* know
> the required
> > run-time support in compile time. Or else he couldn't even use
> > HB_SETMACRO(). The only [extremely rare] exception would be someone who
> > specify the HB_SETMACRO() arguments based on run-time
> determination. We both
> > know, this is very rare, but for this purpose the -kr is available.
>
>   Then why you are arguing for macro list support so strongly? Give the
> programmer the possibility to choose what he wants instead of nonsense
> arguments. Don't enforce some behaviour because different programmers
> might have different needs.

You were arguing it just as strong, were you not? We were both arguing
technical aspects, we both knew that both alternatives were already
available under user choice, for quiet some time.

I'm not against giving the user the ability to choose for him self, I never
was.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 15:45:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)

John,

> > > Clipper's doc. is overall quite good, but hopelessly inadequate for
> > > some purposes.  It is incomplete and/or imprecise in many areas.  It
> > > also frequently does not explain the thinking behind many features.
> > > E.g. lists/codeblocks/commas. :-(
> > >
> > > I think this is a case where we cannot resolve the behaviour with the
> > > doc.
>
> > Is that how you explain lack of support for Var++, Var+=, etc.?
>
> > Is that how you explain lack of support for nested Codeblocks?
>
> It's a guess as to the reasons for the above.

The question was as to *your* opinion. Do *you* consider it *intentional* or
an indication of *incompleteness*?

Do you consider the resulting Error Message a "proof" of the deliberate
intention behind this lack of support?

> > If you think it was intended, can you try and explain why?
>
> It's clear (see previous messages) that lists in macros were intended
> only to be allowed in code blocks.  One reason why may well be that
> Nantucket thought people would have opposite views as to how they
> should be handled and thus decided to reject them - forcing people to
> specify what they want in an unambiguous way.

Please don't say that it's clear. It might be clear to you. I'm not alone
questioning your reasoning here.

John how could it be ambiguous, doesn't the Clipper documentation clearly
documents the difference between a list and a parenthesized list?

Do you consider this ambiguous:

   SomeFun( ( OtherVar := Prepared, NowParam ) )

   Or this:

   SomeFun( (1, 2, 3 ) )

as oppose to this:

   SomeFun( OtherVar := Prepared, NowParam )

   Or this:

   SomeFun( 1, 2, 3 )

If the above are not ambiguous (since they are allowed in clipper) although
producing complete different results, why would you claim that the macro
form of the above would be??? Also, why should I not be able to perform same
with macro, if allowed otherwise?

> > Or maybe you expect me to adopt the attitude that "we are just not
> > clever enough to understand why Nantucket Gods did what they did,
> > but there must be a perfectly good reason for it?
>
> I suggest you stick to more helpful debate.

I hope you can provide me with some valid technical reason that we indeed
can debate.

> > If the above are clear omissions, why would you try to find
> [non-existent]
> > logic in such omissions?
>
> I don't say they are "clear omissions".  I've posted plenty of logic
> about the situation.  I'm not keen to repeat it, so please re-read my
> messages.

Which logic have you posted to explain lack of support for:

1. cMacro := "SomeVar++" // and all other forms of Pre/Post
Increment/Decrement.
2. cMacro := "SomeVar += SomeVal" // and all other forms of '?=' operator
2. cMacro := "( SomeVar := SomeVal, OtherVal )"

I don't suppose you consider any of the above ambiguous do you? If you
contend these are not ambiguous, should we fix them or would such support be
considered "re-designing Clipper"?

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 16:28:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (PostMaster @ PTS)
Date: Fri Aug 10 15:28:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108100718_MC3-DBFC-18BF@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKEEGFDPAA.Default@Profit-Master.com>

> > You can use -kc or -kch when compiling, to get the alternate
> behavior that
> > you seem to be happier with.
>
> I thought it was -kc or -kh?  I'm confused by these changing -k
> things. :-(

Ryszard implementation of the -k uses -kc as resetting all extensions. You
can set your features request as follows:

-kc       // All extensions disabled.
-kch      // Only Harbour extensions, enabled.
-kcx      // Only xbase extensions enabled.
-kchx     // All extensions enabled (default).

-k[chx]r  // Will work as above plus indicate that Run-Time macro management
should be used (Auto Macro Synchronization disabled).

As a side effect to the implementation any -k[hx] that does *not* specify
'c' will have no effect.
As a side effect to the implementation any -k[hxr]c will ignore all flags
prior to the 'c' because the 'c' will reset all flags.

The above side-effects, are not bugs, and are documented in the code.

> That's all very well as regards my code.  However, -kc (Clipper-
> compatible) needs to be the default for this (list macro) feature.
> Otherwise you're overuling what Nantucket clearly did deliberately.  I
> don't feel you've at all demonstrated that you know better than them.
> New users of Harbour should get the Clipper behaviour by default
> unless you're able to make a really good case for changing the
> behaviour.

1. *Please* don't state, matter of fact, that such inconsistent and partial
implementation was "what Nantucket clearly did deliberately". You have never
established as much!

2. Have we demonstrated that we know better then them with regard to all
other default extensions?

3. What is the objective guiding principal as to when are we allowed to
"break" Clipper compatibility as the default Harbour behavior?

> If Harbour is to allow such list macros, it would probably be a good
> idea not only to doc how to enable it but also to mention the kinds
> of code it will break.  It may be worth mentioning that there was a
> lengthy discussion of the feature with details of pros and cons.

It will never break any code! The only code it effects, is code that would
produce an error in Clipper.

The only exception to the above is the LIST command, where such macro would
not produce an error in Clipper, but will only evaluate such values without
displaying them [other then the last].

Even under this exception, the Harbour extension will not "break" such code,
but simply display all values included in the macro (as would be expected by
anyone concerned with the command, rather then its incidental low level
implementation). Regardless, this enhanced behavior is already documented in
/docs/en/clipper.txt.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 17:25:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Aug 10 16:25:04 2001

John,

> > How would your task be easier, if the C portion was missing, or
> sent in a
> > separate file?
>
> If there's no C the situation doesn't arise.  If it's in FILE.C then
> it's rather obvious from the file name!
>
> BTW, why you'd try to argue support-type issues with someone who's
> done as much as I have beats me.

This thread was not an argument, but rather a question, which I sincerely
raised out of curiosity. As a side note, I've provided similar tech support
for probably just as many years, and I'm completely puzzled by your concern.

> > > Yes.  But there are two extra ways macroing a list could work in the
> > > code above.
>
> > We can make it work practically any way we want it to be, the
> question is
> > whether it would be logical, and consistent with the language
> hosting that
> > macro facility.
>
> As I've said, I think Nantucket's actions show we should learn from
> them - and be strictly Clipper-compatible.

Strictly compatible? Including all of Clipper macro's idiosyncrasies?

> > > That supports my argument. :-)  Actually, I think it tends to show
> > > that Nantucket took care to prevent commas being macroed, except in
> > > a code block.  That would argue for staying Clipper compatible, i.e.
> > > not extending the macro feature to accept commas in other contexts.
> > > So, both your meaning of SomeFunc( &cMacro ) and mine would be ruled
> > > out.
>
> > Would you care to offer a reason for such deliberate design decision?
>
> As I've said elsewhere, it may be that Nantucket people were aware
> that a list in a macro could have two meanings, except in a code block
> where they took extra care in at least 2 ways(see below).  They may
> well have decided to disallow the list macro except in a code block
> in order to force people to use an unambiguous piece of code.

1. Clipper documentation as to interpretation of lists leaves no room for
ambiguity!

2. If I accepted your argument, what makes the list ambiguous in the
following form:

   Var := ( &Macro )

   Why is this not supported, although absolutely non ambiguous?

> The two ways Nantucket took care with code blocks:
> 1. they allow a macro where it would not be ambiguous
> e.g. {|| &cMacro }
> 2. they added an error message for other cases
> e.g. {|| {&cMacro} }
> this error also occurs for cases that would not be ambiguous; perhaps
> they didn't see enough need to try to figure out which would be OK
> and which not.  Note that they chose the "safer" (more restrictive)
> route.

1. Lists are never ambiguous in Clipper syntax. You are the only person here
that claims such ambiguity.

2. You suggest we should take after their ["perhaps"] laziness?

> > I suppose you would have to convince us of the *correctness*,
> and reasoning
> > behind allowing us to perform:
> > cMacro := "SomeArray[ Index1, Index2, IndexN ]"
> > SomeVar := &cMacro
> > and also:
> > cMacro := "Index1"
> > SomeVar := SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
> > but not:
> > cMacro := "Index1, Index2, IndexN"
> > SomeVar := SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
>
> I don't know whether I can convince you.  However, the first two are
> unambiguous whereas the latter is ambiguous - it's an example of the
> very case where you want one behaviour and I originally wanted another
> behaviour (but now I think Nantucket were right to disallow it).

How can you claim that the first 2 are not ambiguous, yet the last *is*?
What is the difference? What is the possible alternate meaning? What would
be the basis for assuming such alternate meaning?

> > > > Simple list of such clear omissions include: exp++, --exp,
> > > > exp += exp, (exp), and {|| &NestedBlcokMacro }. But also
> > > > Var := ( &cListMacro ) etc,.
> > >
> > > I tend to agree, except in the case of a list.
>
> > But why "except"?
>
> Because it's not ambiguous.

But every other use of a list is just as unambiguous, including many other
contexts that even you agree are non ambiguous.
When do we consider it a bug, and when not?

> > What immense problem/danger are we trying to eliminate?
>
> Ambiguity.  It would be great to avoid premature implementation and
> endless threads, too.

The ambiguity is only there for anyone inventing alternate meanings to
lists, strictly against the documented non ambiguous nature of lists in
Clipper. This is indeed redesigning Clipper. Fixing the macro to fully
support the documented meanings is not re-designing Clipper, but rather
completing the implementation of macro.

> > > I try hard to be open-minded.  I'm reluctant to re-design Clipper.
>
> > Unless you provide some reasoning for the odd behavior we are discussing
>
> I have provided reasoning.

Sorry, but I must disagree.

> > we can't view it as a design specification. And thus it's nothing
> > more then bug fixing.
>
> I don't agree you can say "we" as you'd be speaking for others, whose
> opinions are not yet known.  It's your opinion that it's a matter of
> bug fixing.  I don't agree, and there's evidence Nantucket had good
> reasons for what they did.

1. We can disagree, and all opinions are indeed welcome.
2. It's only your opinion that "there's evidence Nantucket had good reasons
for what they did". Please don't state it as a fact, because it isn't, it's
just your speculation/guess/etc..

***
John, this is an intense technical argument, and again I must stop for a
second and assure you of my positive feelings toward you. When one doesn't
have the benefit of face expression, etc, such argument may appear "heated"
when it's not involving any emotions at all :-(.

Please read my argument as if containing lot's of smiles, and sadness only
for the fact, that we disagree.
***

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 17:49:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Fri Aug 10 16:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108100718_MC3-DBFC-18C2@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEGGDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > I think the reason why runtime control of macro behaviour is needed
> > as well as compile-time control is this: in case an OBJ/LIB which was
> > compiled with the non-Clipper behaviour is linked into an app which
> > wants the Clipper behaviour.  (Or the inverse.)
>
> > That would be horrible. It would be the exact equivalent of allowing
> > a run-time control for ShortCuts

Of course it is! Actually one of those flags is indeed the very same
(ShortCuts) flag.

Would you like to be able to control usage of ShortCuts in *your* macros at
compile time? Or would you leave that at the mercy of the consumer using
your lib?

Would you like to be able to control usage of Harbour extensions (like
Var++; Var += x; etc.) in *your* macros at compile time? Or would you leave
that at the mercy of the consumer using your lib?

> It may or may not be horrible.  It's not the same as runtime control
> of short cuts (-Z switch), however.

I hope you now see it is.

> > You see that would mean the author of a prg linking against your
> > LIB, may inadvertently override the requirement of your LIB modules.
>
> But they may _need_ to do that, whereas they should never need to do
> that with -Z.

Why would they need to override your specification of usage of ShortCuts in
macros in *your* modules?
Why would they need to override your specification of usage of Harbour
Extensions in macros in *your* modules?

> > You should be able to *dictate* at compile time, that your LIB
> is *immune*
> > from effect of such Run-Time control.
>
> If you do that, the LIB may not be of use.  E.g. the LIB macros
> something then SEEKs it.  I pass in a string containing a comma.  The
> LIB mistakenly treats what I've passed as a list.  But really it was
> user bad input.

1. But if you *intentionally* chose to support list macros, that is how it
must be interpreted. When you do choose to support list, you may apply logic
to evaluate/warn usage of commas within such macro, if you so desire.

2. If you enabled list support in run-time using HB_SETMACRO() before such
evaluation, you would still face the same dilemma, wouldn't you?

> This is _not_ like anything that can happen with -Z.

Of course it is, because:

  1. -z (HB_SM_SHORTCUTS) is indeed one of those flags under the
HB_SETMACRO() control.
  2. Enabling/Disabling Pre/Post Increments/Decrements against the intention
of the LIB supplier, would cause same kind of unexpected results, i.e.
chaos.

> > It also controls other Harbour extensions, like Var++ Var+= and so many
> > other such extensions.
>
> I have doubts as to the wisdom of that.

How would you suggest to control the support for such extensions?

> > > If the runtime control isn't available then the practical effect may
> > > be that add-on LIBs which use macroing may need to be made available
> > > compiled in each of the settings. :-(
>
> > No exactly the opposite, it means your LIB is *guaranteed* to
> work and be
> > completely *protected* from any such runtime control, if you so desired.
>
> In the example above, you're wrong.

No, in your example above, the LIB is guaranteed to work exactly as the
author of the code intended for it to work. Unless he relegate the decision
to the user by means of compiling his code with -kr.

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 10 22:54:02 2001

Date: Fri Aug 10 21:54:02 2001

> That's all very well as regards my code.  However, -kc (Clipper-
> compatible) needs to be the default for this (list macro) feature.
> Otherwise you're overuling what Nantucket clearly did deliberately. 

I'm inclined to agree with this. Clipper compatability first, 
extensions can be turned on by programmer who wishes to use them.

Default should always be Clipper compatability.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 12 11:54:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Sun Aug 12 10:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-06 09:15 UTC-0800 Ron Pinkas <ron@profit-master.com>

On 10 Aug 2001, at 11:11, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> This shows you don't understand the concept of early/late macro evaluation
> in code block. Your sample above is using EARLY binding. The value of the
> macro itself is only bound ONCE at the time the block is created. The
> different value would be the same even if you didn't use macro at all! Maybe
> the following [slight modification] can explain your mistake:

  Ok, sorry. You are right in this early/late issue. Thanks for reminding 
it for me. 

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 12 14:12:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Sun Aug 12 13:12:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108121310_MC3-DC27-C3F2@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> > Akin to the "have you stopped beating your wife?" question.

> I don't think it's fair to place my question in that sort of category.

Sorry, but that's how it struck (strikes) me.

> I'm really failing to see how anyone can't see the obvious different
> between a code block and macro expansion.

There are several differences.  Code blocks get the full PP and
compiler treatment, so can have #defines (etc), locals, statics, and
so on.  You're choosing a specific feature only, then describing it
using particular words.  Fair enough except that I don't really agree
with the choice of words. :-)

> To see then as similar would be like suggesting that `lambda' and
> `eval' are similar in Lisp.

I don't agree.  (Again)

Regardless, the I do think it's important that:
(a) Nantucket people clearly thought this issue through and handled it
in specific ways (i.e. it's not chance that Clipper does what it does)
(b) lists in macros are ambiguous yet there are unambiguous ways to
specify the equivalents
(c) if implemented Ron's/your way, some code can be broken, and the
same would apply if implemented the way I originally suggested

For all 3 reasons I think we should stick with the Clipper-compatible
way, at least for the default.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 12 14:13:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Sun Aug 12 13:13:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108121310_MC3-DC27-C3F3@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> > > Why should it never happen with the -Z compiler option?
> > =

> > Because the author of the algorithm should know whether -Z is needed =
or
> > not, and compile appropriately. The user (i.e. caller) of the OBJ/LIB=

> > should not have to know about this implementation detail.

> And the same could be true of the workings of macro expansion too could=
n't
> it? The author of said OBJ/LIB might have written their code expecting =
macro
> expansion to work a particular way.

Yes, it could be.  However, in some cases it may not be (see the
example I posted for Ron).  This is different with -Z, where the
author can (should :-) always be sure.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 05:06:06 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)

Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100

Land of the free? Yeah, right.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 05:06:28 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 13 04:06:28 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108121310_MC3-DC27-C3F2@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Sun, Aug 12, 2001 at 01:10:24PM -0400
References: <200108121310_MC3-DC27-C3F2@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010813081134.N30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Sun, Aug 12, 2001 at 01:10:24PM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > I'm really failing to see how anyone can't see the obvious different
> > between a code block and macro expansion.
> 
> There are several differences. Code blocks get the full PP and compiler
> treatment, so can have #defines (etc), locals, statics, and so on. You're
> choosing a specific feature only, then describing it using particular
> words. Fair enough except that I don't really agree with the choice of
> words. :-)

John, I understand that you disagree, there's little doubt about that now.
What I'd be interested in is the "why".

> > To see then as similar would be like suggesting that `lambda' and `eval'
> > are similar in Lisp.
> 
> I don't agree.  (Again)

Why? In Lisp `lambda' creates closures of code that retain details of their
environment that can be passed around and evaluated at will. `eval' takes
text and treats it as code. the expansion happens for every instance of
`eval'. How does that differ from an outline explanation of code blocks and
the macro expansion operator in Clipper? Why do you disagree?

> (c) if implemented Ron's/your way, some code can be broken, and the
> same would apply if implemented the way I originally suggested

Please note that it's not "my way" and please note that I share many of your
reservations and that I voiced them while you were away (did you check the
URLs I provided you with a while back?). I'm not personally advocating this
enhancement to the macro compiler but I am saying that I think your
interpretation of an expanded list in a function argument list isn't
consistent with reasonable expectation of how macro expansion works.

I'm also saying, despite the fact that you've claimed it a couple of times
now, that I'm not playing with words. There's much more thought to what I'm,
saying that simply picking and choosing words that serve my purpose.

> For all 3 reasons I think we should stick with the Clipper-compatible way,
> at least for the default.

I agree that Clipper compatibility should be the default if at all possible,
I don't think I've suggested otherwise. All I'm interested in is why you
seem to have (what appears to me) an odd interpretation of how an expanded
list in a function argument list should be handled. I'm looking for
something a little more verbose and explanatory than "I don't agree".

-- 
Harbour is a free   | Harbour Web Site: http://www.harbour-project.org/
software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 06:31:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 13 05:31:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] -go and empty harbour.cfg
Message-ID: <20010813103024.X30092@hagbard.davep.org>

I just noticed something else with the -go switch. If I create an empty
harbour.cfg (I was double checking that the other problem I reported was
down to having no harbour.cfg) I get random "rubbish" on the screen, I think
it's being reported from the shell due to the fact that the command isn't
defined (or, more to the point, it's defined as random rubbish).

For example:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ touch harbour.cfg
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ ls -l harbour.cfg
| -rw-rw-r--    1 davep    davep           0 Aug 13 10:28 harbour.cfg
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ harbour foo -go
| Harbour Compiler 0.37a (Build 37) (2001.06.29) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2001, http://www.harbour-project.org/
| Compiling 'foo.prg'...
| Lines 7, Functions/Procedures 2
| Generating C source output to 'foo.c'... Done.
| Building object module output for 'foo.c'...
| sh: <lots of random rubbish here>: command not found
| Done.
`----

Perhaps gencobj.c could do with some sanity checks?

--

platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 06:31:19 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 13 05:31:19 2001
Subject: [Harbour] -go core dump on GNU/Linux
Message-ID: <20010813100648.W30092@hagbard.davep.org>

This is a test on my main GNU/Linux box. There is no harbour.cfg in sight so
I'm wondering if this is the problem (I would follow the problem all the way
but I'm a little short on time right now).

Given a simple program I compile it with "harbour foo -go" and get a
segfault:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ cat foo.prg
| Function Main()
| 
|    ? "Hello, World"
| 
| Return( NIL )
|
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ harbour foo -go
| Harbour Compiler 0.37a (Build 37) (2001.06.29) (Flex)
| Copyright 1999-2001, http://www.harbour-project.org/
| Compiling 'foo.prg'...
| Lines 7, Functions/Procedures 2
| Generating C source output to 'foo.c'... Done.
| Segmentation fault (core dumped)
`----

The backtrace of the core dump is as follows:

,----
| davep@hagbard:~/temp$ gdb `which harbour` -core core
| GNU gdb 19991004
| Copyright 1998 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
| GDB is free software, covered by the GNU General Public License, and you are
| welcome to change it and/or distribute copies of it under certain conditions.
| Type "show copying" to see the conditions.
| There is absolutely no warranty for GDB.  Type "show warranty" for details.
| This GDB was configured as "i386-redhat-linux"...
| Core was generated by `harbour foo -go'.
| Program terminated with signal 11, Segmentation fault.
| Reading symbols from /usr/lib/libncurses.so.4...done.
| Reading symbols from /lib/libm.so.6...done.
| Reading symbols from /lib/libc.so.6...done.
| Reading symbols from /lib/ld-linux.so.2...done.
| #0  0x400dc57f in strtok () from /lib/libc.so.6
| (gdb) backtrace
| #0  0x400dc57f in strtok () from /lib/libc.so.6
| #1  0xbffff504 in ?? ()
| #2  0x805c721 in hb_compGenCObj (pFileName=0x80a3b40) at ../../gencobj.c:75
| #3  0x8072d2b in hb_compGenOutput (iLanguage=4) at ../../harbour.c:3574
| #4  0x8073343 in hb_compCompile (szPrg=0xbffff887 "foo", argc=3,
|     argv=0xbffff714) at ../../harbour.c:3785
| #5  0x806e0ad in main (argc=3, argv=0xbffff714) at ../../harbour.c:246
| (gdb)
`----

Looking at the code I suspect that the problem is that hb_searchpath() can't
gracefully handle NULL pointers, it would appear that, in this test case,
both pszEnv and pszCfg are NULL pointers:

,----
| (gdb) up
| #1  0xbffff504 in ?? ()
| (gdb) up
| #2  0x805c721 in hb_compGenCObj (pFileName=0x0) at ../../gencobj.c:75
| 75         hb_searchpath( HB_CFG_FILENAME, pszEnv, pszCfg );
| (gdb) inspect pszEnv
| $1 = 0x0
| (gdb) inspect pszCfg
| $2 = 0x0
`----

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 08:10:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Mon Aug 13 07:10:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108130708_MC3-DC34-3618@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> This thread was not an argument, but rather a question, which I sincere=
ly
> raised out of curiosity.

I understood it that way.  I didn't mean "argue" in a negative sense,
but in the "debate" sense.

> As a side note, I've provided similar tech support for probably just
> as many years, and I'm completely puzzled by your concern.

It's news to me that you regularly get sent other people's code/apps
including C code and provide support.  I can only say I almost always
find it much harder when the code I receive includes some C and that
I dread the idea of the C being obscured/hidden by being in a PRG.

> > As I've said, I think Nantucket's actions show we should learn from
> > them - and be strictly Clipper-compatible.

> Strictly compatible? Including all of Clipper macro's idiosyncrasies?

My statement was in the context of list macros.  However, it's been my
understanding that in general Harbour is supposed to be Clipper
compatible first and foremost, with any changes discussed and agreed
and only the ones which are definitely not controversial being enabled
by default - if then.  I don't know how many people are happy or
unhappy with list macros being added already and enabled by default.

> 1. Clipper documentation as to interpretation of lists leaves no room f=
or
> ambiguity!

I've asked elsewhere for the ref. to the doc; I'd like to check it.

> 2. If I accepted your argument, what makes the list ambiguous in the
> following form:
>
>    Var :=3D ( &Macro )
>
>    Why is this not supported, although absolutely non ambiguous?

It might be considered ambiguous, depending on what's in cMacro.
As to why it's not supported, clipper.exe compiled it OK.  I believe
it treats the parens as denoting grouping (unnecessary in this case),
rather than an insistence as to the meaning of any potential list
macro, so at runtime you'll get the usual error if you pass a list.
The compiler probably treats the parens as denoting grouping because
that's what the intent was by design, and the doc. for parens is
consistent with that.

> > The two ways Nantucket took care with code blocks:
> > 1. they allow a macro where it would not be ambiguous
> > e.g. {|| &cMacro }
> > 2. they added an error message for other cases
> > e.g. {|| {&cMacro} }
> > this error also occurs for cases that would not be ambiguous; perhaps=

> > they didn't see enough need to try to figure out which would be OK
> > and which not.  Note that they chose the "safer" (more restrictive)
> > route.

> 1. Lists are never ambiguous in Clipper syntax. You are the only person=
 here
> that claims such ambiguity.

It's ambiguous because there are at least 2 ways to it could work:
(a) If #2 above were allowed, it would be reasonable to say the code
block should return an array of one element.  If cMacro contains a
list then either it's an error or it's treated as a comma expression
(thus evaluating each part of the list and returning the last value).
(b) Your opinion is that the number of elements in the array would
depend on how many items were in cMacro, when it's a list.

> 2. You suggest we should take after their ["perhaps"] laziness?

It's only an opinion as to whether it was laziness.  They put in extra
code to allow a list macro within a code block at runtime, and extra
code in the compiler to detect and allow / disallow some cases in a
code block.  That's not "laziness" to my way of thinking.

> > > I suppose you would have to convince us of the *correctness*,
> > and reasoning
> > > behind allowing us to perform:
> > > cMacro :=3D "SomeArray[ Index1, Index2, IndexN ]"
> > > SomeVar :=3D &cMacro
> > > and also:
> > > cMacro :=3D "Index1"
> > > SomeVar :=3D SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
> > > but not:
> > > cMacro :=3D "Index1, Index2, IndexN"
> > > SomeVar :=3D SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
> >
> > I don't know whether I can convince you.  However, the first two are
> > unambiguous whereas the latter is ambiguous - it's an example of the
> > very case where you want one behaviour and I originally wanted anothe=
r
> > behaviour (but now I think Nantucket were right to disallow it).

> How can you claim that the first 2 are not ambiguous, yet the last *is*=
?

The first looks to be how arrays are implemented and doc'ed.  Surely
neither of us claims it's ambiguous.  The second also doesn't look
ambiguous.  If you're taking issue with my claims so far, please say
why.  The last one can be considered ambiguous in the same way as I
explained above:
(a) it can be regarded as an array with a single index (which if it
is a list macro is either an error or a comma expression)
(b) it can be viewed your way

I find it hard to believe you could not see these alternatives.  I
know you don't agree with case (a) but having to spell it out like
this does rather surprise me.

> > > > I tend to agree, except in the case of a list.
> >
> > > But why "except"?
> >
> > Because it's not ambiguous.

> But every other use of a list is just as unambiguous,

No.  See above.

> including many other contexts that even you agree are non ambiguous.

I'm not sure to what you're referring.

> When do we consider it a bug, and when not?

It's a bug when we change Clipper behaviour by default without very
compelling reasons.

I'd welcome a call for a vote, as this looks to be dragging on. :-(
The vote (IMO) would be whether this new code for list macros should
be enabled by default.

> The ambiguity is only there for anyone inventing alternate meanings to
> lists, strictly against the documented non ambiguous nature of lists in=

> Clipper. This is indeed redesigning Clipper. Fixing the macro to fully
> support the documented meanings is not re-designing Clipper, but rather=

> completing the implementation of macro.

Above I show why they can be ambiguous.  Others and I have also posted
evidence that Nantucket people put in extra work in this area and
chose not to do what you're doing.  I've posted an example where your
change would break an app.  I do not regard all that as "Fixing".

> > I have provided reasoning.

> Sorry, but I must disagree.

You disagree that I've provided it or you disagree with what I wrote?
IAC, an opinion is not enough to dismiss the issue and force this
change on everyone by default.  At least, an opinion isn't enough
when there's reasoned dissent and no vote has been taken.

> 1. We can disagree, and all opinions are indeed welcome.

:-)

> 2. It's only your opinion that "there's evidence Nantucket had good rea=
sons
> for what they did". Please don't state it as a fact, because it isn't, =
it's
> just your speculation/guess/etc..

It's not only my opinion.  Others and I have posted factual evidence.

> this is an intense technical argument, and again I must stop for a
> second and assure you of my positive feelings ...

:-)

Please understand my posts in the same way!

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 08:10:16 2001

Ron,

> Would you like to be able to control usage of ShortCuts in *your* macro=
s at
> compile time?

It's not a real question for me personally (I never use -Z, hardly
ever use macros, they don't involve short cuts, etc).  Also, I regard
-Z as only there for short term transition of S87 (etc) users who've
not yet made changes (if any) needed such that they can stop using -Z.

> Or would you leave that at the mercy of the consumer using your lib?

Given the above, that's moot.

> Would you like to be able to control usage of Harbour extensions (like
> Var++; Var +=3D x; etc.) in *your* macros at compile time?

Not really.  However, I don't think I've any objection to such control
being available.

> Or would you leave that at the mercy of the consumer using your lib?

Pass.  (My LIBs use almost no macros.)

> > It may or may not be horrible.  It's not the same as runtime control
> > of short cuts (-Z switch), however.

> I hope you now see it is.

I don't, sorry.  Besides, you're not using the situation I posted,
which was meant to be the use of short cuts within a LIB, outside of
macros - i.e. the common situation.

> > > You see that would mean the author of a prg linking against your
> > > LIB, may inadvertently override the requirement of your LIB modules=
.
> >
> > But they may _need_ to do that, whereas they should never need to do
> > that with -Z.

> Why would they need to override your specification of usage of ShortCut=
s in
> macros in *your* modules?

See above - that's not the situation I was referring to.

> Why would they need to override your specification of usage of Harbour
> Extensions in macros in *your* modules?

Again, that doesn't look to be what I was referring to.

> > If you do that, the LIB may not be of use.  E.g. the LIB macros
> > something then SEEKs it.  I pass in a string containing a comma.  The=

> > LIB mistakenly treats what I've passed as a list.  But really it was
> > user bad input.

> 1. But if you *intentionally* chose to support list macros, that is how=
 it
> must be interpreted.

But then it would not be "user bad input".  Since I stated "really it
was user bad input", you're supposed to answer based on that.  It's a
given, for the example stated.

> 2. If you enabled list support in run-time using HB_SETMACRO() before s=
uch
> evaluation, you would still face the same dilemma, wouldn't you?

There's no dilemma in the above example.  It's stated what the desired
behaviour is.  If HB_SETMACRO() would break that, it shouldn't be used.

> > > It also controls other Harbour extensions, like Var++ Var+=3D and s=
o many
> > > other such extensions.
> >
> > I have doubts as to the wisdom of that.

> How would you suggest to control the support for such extensions?

Let's finish with list macros.  In passing, however, it looks to me
like the settings for list macros and the above should be separate,
since list macros can be ambiguous but the above may not be.  The
default should be disabled, I feel, to retain Clipper compatibility.

> No, in your example above, the LIB is guaranteed to work exactly as the=

> author of the code intended for it to work.

You appear to have completely misunderstood the example.

John.

> > Otherwise you're overuling what Nantucket clearly did deliberately.  =

> > don't feel you've at all demonstrated that you know better than them.=

> > New users of Harbour should get the Clipper behaviour by default
> > unless you're able to make a really good case for changing the
> > behaviour.

> 1. *Please* don't state, matter of fact, that such inconsistent and par=
tial
> implementation was "what Nantucket clearly did deliberately". You have =
never
> established as much!

to refute it have you posted?  I think we should be guided by more
than your opinions.

l
> other default extensions?

That is irrelevant to this topic.

> 3. What is the objective guiding principal as to when are we allowed to=

> "break" Clipper compatibility as the default Harbour behavior?

Sometimes there can be objective reasons, but not always.  The array
limit of 4096 looks like a compromise based on 16-bit and fairly
small free RAM.  So, that's probably more objective than subjective.
There's evidence about list macros, so that also looks more objective
than subjective.  Your opinions look the opposite to me.

> > If Harbour is to allow such list macros, it would probably be a good

> > lengthy discussion of the feature with details of pros and cons.

it, please ask.

Not true.  My example is another.  There may well be more.

However, since there are now at least 2 cases where an app can be
broken by your change, I again say that I feel your change should not
be enabled by default.

VERY precisely though.  When he might seem to be arguing for the sake of

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 11:27:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Mon Aug 13 10:27:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108131026_MC3-DC47-C511@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> What I'd be interested in is the "why".

That doesn't appear to fit the context of the part that was above.

As I've posted, some specific cases of macroing lists can be ambiguous
(I've posted details again today) and ambiguity is not something I
think should be added.  However, supposing we'd had a vote and decided
to go ahead, my main feeling is that this feature should not be
enabled by default.  The "why" is because it can break existing code
and/or people's expectations.

In case your "why" was about:
> I'm really failing to see how anyone can't see the obvious different
> between a code block and macro expansion
I've already answered that I do see them as different, though not
necessarily as fitting the words you used to describe macros, so did
you want more or what?

> > > To see then as similar would be like suggesting that `lambda' and `=
eval'
> > > are similar in Lisp.
> > =

> > I don't agree.  (Again)

> Why?

I think what I really meant was something along the lines of: I don't
see why because List has specific things that this should influence
what we do in a specific case which can be taken to be ambiguous, and
which Nantucket put extra effort into disallowing, and I especially
don't see why we'd enable this new feature by default.  If Lisp really
addresses those issues as far as a Clipper developer is concerned, do
explain. :-)

> Please note that it's not "my way"

Sorry, you seemed to be in favour of what Ron's done.

> I think your interpretation of an expanded list in a function
> argument list isn't consistent with reasonable expectation of how
> macro expansion works.

I see only a few people commenting.  Not enough. :-(  If most Clipper
developers really would expect a macro to function the way Ron feels,
fair enough.

However, I still don't think it should be enabled by default.

> I agree that Clipper compatibility should be the default if at all poss=
ible,

:-)

> I don't think I've suggested otherwise.

Sorry - very likely you haven't.  You did seem to be supporting Ron,
and he's made it clear that he wants it his way (i.e. not Clipper
compatible) by default.

> All I'm interested in is why you seem to have (what appears to me)
> an odd interpretation of how an expanded list in a function argument
> list should be handled.

Since one of Clipper's major things was that it's a compiler, and
  SomeFunc( <param1> )
is clearly a func with a single param, it looks consistent that when
<param1> is &cMacro then it's still a func with a single param.  It's
not as if there's no other way to achieve the equivalent of Ron's way
of handling this.

However, I actually don't feel fanatically about this at all - but I
do think the change made should not be enabled by default.  I think
you got that message, though. :-)

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 12:35:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 13 11:35:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108131026_MC3-DC47-C511@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Mon, Aug 13, 2001 at 10:25:48AM -0400
References: <200108131026_MC3-DC47-C511@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010813163338.O30092@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Aug 13, 2001 at 10:25:48AM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > What I'd be interested in is the "why".
> 
> That doesn't appear to fit the context of the part that was above.

The main "why" I'm interested in is why someone should expect this:

,----
| cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
| Foo( &cMacro )
`----

to work out as a function being called with a single parameter. I don't
disagree that there's some useful debate to be had regarding how advisable
allowing the above is. What I'm interested in here is why anyone would see
the above as ambiguous. The existence of such ambiguity is, from where I'm
sat, at the heart of any "should we/shouldn't we" debate about the macro
expansion of lists.

As I've posted earlier, macro expansion has a heritage of being just that,
macro expansion. Back in the late 80s I was writing code that constructed
whole commands and then macro expanded them. From a dBase developers point
of view that's what the macro operator did, it did text replacement and/or
expansion (from a logical POV, not an implementation POV).

Now, as we all know, (Nantucket-)Clipper had to things slightly differently
so you could get away with macro expanding who commands and the like. Even
less so with (Nantucket-)Clipper 5.0 due to the compiler more or less
loosing any knowledge of commands.

My point here is that the "why" of me saying that this:

,----
| cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
| Foo( &cMacro )
`----

would appear to be "unambiguously" a function call with three parameters is
based on the reasoning and experience that I've reported earlier and have
given a summary above. I don't have a dBase/Fox to hand but the reasoning is
the same that would have had me thinking that this:

,----
| m->macro = "1, 2, 3"
| do foo with &m->macro
`----

would call a procedure with three arguments (he says, probably getting very
mixed up with the various dialects of "Xbase").

So, the "why" I'm wondering about is "why" you think the above case is
ambiguous.

> As I've posted, some specific cases of macroing lists can be ambiguous
> (I've posted details again today) and ambiguity is not something I think
> should be added. However, supposing we'd had a vote and decided to go
> ahead, my main feeling is that this feature should not be enabled by
> default. The "why" is because it can break existing code and/or people's
> expectations.

Agreed, see the URLs I posted the other day. I'm still not sure about this
ambiguity though. Or, more to the point, I'm still not sure about the source
of the ambiguity.

> > > > To see then as similar would be like suggesting that `lambda' and
> > > > `eval' are similar in Lisp.
> > > 
> > > I don't agree.  (Again)
> 
> > Why?
> 
> I think what I really meant was something along the lines of: I don't see
> why because List has specific things that this should influence what we do
> in a specific case which can be taken to be ambiguous, and which Nantucket
> put extra effort into disallowing, and I especially don't see why we'd
> enable this new feature by default. If Lisp really addresses those issues
> as far as a Clipper developer is concerned, do explain. :-)

It's not about addressing Clipper development concerns. I gave the
lambda/eval example to illustrate what I was saying about code blocks and
macro expansion as being very different things. The former creates a
"closure" of code that contains some binding to the parent environment and
it can be passed around the application and evaluated at will. Macro
expansion has none of those properties.

More to the point, code blocks are a data type, "&" is an operator. You'd be
hard pushed to find two things any more different.

Put another way, the lambda/eval similarity illustration was given to show
that when I asked:

,----
| But a code block isn't a code substitution mechanism is it?
`----

it wasn't intended as a question that falls into a:

,----
| "have you stopped beating your wife?
`----

category. Feel free to pick an illustration that isn't Lisp inspired.

> > Please note that it's not "my way"
> 
> Sorry, you seemed to be in favour of what Ron's done.

I believe that Ron's interpretation of list expansion within a function call
context (as illustrated above) is consistent with reasonable expectations of
macro expansion (the "why" of my "reasonable expectations" has be
re-documented above). That, however, isn't a judgement of the value of such
a feature.

> > I think your interpretation of an expanded list in a function argument
> > list isn't consistent with reasonable expectation of how macro expansion
> > works.
> 
> I see only a few people commenting. Not enough. :-( 

The number of people commenting seems to be the same as the upper limit of
people who care.

> Sorry - very likely you haven't. You did seem to be supporting Ron, and
> he's made it clear that he wants it his way (i.e. not Clipper compatible)
> by default.

I'm not supporting anyone, I'm especially not supporting the pro/con of the
default value of a given switch. I am, however, attempting to draw out the
reasons for your differing opinion in regard to what I've said about the
source of my "reasonable expectation".

> > All I'm interested in is why you seem to have (what appears to me) an
> > odd interpretation of how an expanded list in a function argument list
> > should be handled.
> 
> Since one of Clipper's major things was that it's a compiler, 

What does "being a compiler" tell us?

>                                                               and
>   SomeFunc( <param1> )
> is clearly a func with a single param, it looks consistent that when
> <param1> is &cMacro then it's still a func with a single param.  

Personally I'd defer such a decision until I knew the content of cMacro.

>                                                                  It's not
> as if there's no other way to achieve the equivalent of Ron's way of
> handling this.

I'm not sure I follow this.

> However, I actually don't feel fanatically about this at all - but I do
> think the change made should not be enabled by default. I think you got
> that message, though. :-)

Agreed, I do think that, as much as possible, any possibly "invasive"
enhancements to the language should be off by default. Within reason anyway.
I can't imagine that anyone could have a reasonable objection to that.

-- 
Dave Pearson                        |  OSLib - Timeslice release functions.
http://www.davep.org/               |     eg - Norton Guide reader for Linux.
http://www.davep.org/clipper/       |    weg - Norton Guide reader for Windows.
http://www.davep.org/norton-guides/ | dgscan - DGROUP scanner for Clipper.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 14:18:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon Aug 13 13:18:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108130708_MC3-DC34-361A@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEHEDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > > > Is that how you explain lack of support for nested Codeblocks?
> > >
> > > It's a guess as to the reasons for the above.
>
> > The question was as to *your* opinion.
>
> It doesn't read as such a request.
>
> I don't see its relevance to the issue under discussion.  I'd like to
> avoid thread drift since I really don't have the time spare that I'm
> already using!

That's not a avoiding a drift but rather avoiding the issue. I know first
hand of many omissions in Clipper's macro compiler and subsequent
discussions *I* personally had with higher level Nantucket personnel, that
made it crystal clear, that the macro compiler was (described in what to me
appeared as clear excuse) a lower priority.

Your attempt to ignore the obvious many many inconsistencies in Clipper's
macro compiler, as irrelevant to this discussion, is questionable imo.

After having implemented some of the missing support, it became even
clearer, that Nantucket developers, simply "cut corners".

Had you reviewed the code in question, and implemented such yourself, I'm
confident you'd feel the same.

Take for example the *fact* that *extremely* *simple* *to* *correct*
*bugs*,like lack of support for: Var++; ++Var; Var--; --Var; Var += exp (an
all other operator assignment), were *never* *corrected* in so many years
from 5.0 to 5.01, 5.1, 5.2(abcde) 5.3(ab). Doesn't that demonstrate the lack
of commitment to the completeness of the macro compiler?

> > > It's clear (see previous messages) that lists in macros were intended
> > > only to be allowed in code blocks.  One reason why may well be that
> > > Nantucket thought people would have opposite views as to how they
> > > should be handled and thus decided to reject them - forcing people to
> > > specify what they want in an unambiguous way.
>
> > Please don't say that it's clear. It might be clear to you. I'm
> not alone
> > questioning your reasoning here.
>
> There is evidence that Nantucket put in extra effort to detect lists
> in macros and allow them in only specific cases.  What evidential-
> based argument do you have to support your view?

The fact that they realized (what you would have known too had you
familiarized yourself with the relevant compiler code) that supporting the
list in codeblock did NOT require any additional logic, and could have been
easily excused from the otherwise error message, does *not* place it that
light you attempt to place it under. The technical facts, clearly
demonstrate, this was a "layman's decision". I'm confident most of us have
been "guilty" of this kind of a "crime" one time or another.

> > doesn't the Clipper documentation clearly documents the difference
> > between a list and a parenthesized list?
>
> As I thought you'd agreed, the doc. is not good enough in a number of
> ways.  Please point me to the generic doc. you refer to above, since
> I don't seem to be able to find it.

But we are talking about a well known behavior, that practically everyone
take advantage of, in infinite contexts. Its literally part of the
characteristics of the language. Even if there would have been no
documentation about it at all, you couldn't [successfully] argue its clear
and unambiguous place in the Clipper language.

> > > > Or maybe you expect me to adopt the attitude that "we are just not
> > > > clever enough to understand why Nantucket Gods did what they did,
> > > > but there must be a perfectly good reason for it?
> > >
> > > I suggest you stick to more helpful debate.
>
> > I hope you can provide me with some valid technical reason that
> we indeed
> > can debate.
>
> I've been trying to do so.  I've not made claims along the lines you
> posted above.

I disagree. I believe that closing your eyes to the number of clear problems
with the Clipper macro bugs, and desperately trying to make some sense of
it, qualify as attributing to the Nantucket developers an un-earned, not to
be questioned,  superiority [in this context].

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 16:23:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)

On  Monday, August 13, 2001, 23:14 Patrick Mast, Harbour <harbour@winfakt.com> wrote:

PMH> So, what does the  hb_hInstance => hInstance; change mean?
PMH> What did not work before?

  hInstance is a handle of an application instance, we get it as a
  parameter of WinMain() and should store it in some public variable (
  hb_hInstance ) for following using in some functions, for example,
  loading icons, bitmaps from resource file.

 Alexander
http://members.xoom.com/alkresin/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 16:53:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon Aug 13 15:53:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108130708_MC3-DC34-3618@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEHHDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > > As I've said, I think Nantucket's actions show we should learn from
> > > them - and be strictly Clipper-compatible.
>
> > Strictly compatible? Including all of Clipper macro's idiosyncrasies?
>
> My statement was in the context of list macros.  However, it's been my
> understanding that in general Harbour is supposed to be Clipper
> compatible first and foremost, with any changes discussed and agreed
> and only the ones which are definitely not controversial being enabled
> by default - if then.  I don't know how many people are happy or
> unhappy with list macros being added already and enabled by default.

Implementing the complete and proper macro support, for those interested in
complete macro functionality, does not take away from our ability to specify
the default functionality level. If we found out that any of the macro
extensions is/are unpopular, one assignment of the default value will have
to be changed.

> > 1. Clipper documentation as to interpretation of lists leaves
> no room for
> > ambiguity!
>
> I've asked elsewhere for the ref. to the doc; I'd like to check it.

My above statement should be revised to read <Clipper compiler
interpretation of lists leaves no room for ambiguity!> because I'm unable to
locate any reference to lists where one would expect under '()' operator. Do
you dispute that lists, parenthesized vs. non parenthesized, have a clear
and unambiguous meaning in the Clipper language?

> > 2. If I accepted your argument, what makes the list ambiguous in the
> > following form:
> >
> >    Var := ( &Macro )
> >
> >    Why is this not supported, although absolutely non ambiguous?
>
> It might be considered ambiguous, depending on what's in cMacro.
> As to why it's not supported, clipper.exe compiled it OK.  I believe
> it treats the parens as denoting grouping (unnecessary in this case),
> rather than an insistence as to the meaning of any potential list
> macro, so at runtime you'll get the usual error if you pass a list.
> The compiler probably treats the parens as denoting grouping because
> that's what the intent was by design, and the doc. for parens is
> consistent with that.

Please don't avoid the issue, again how is it ambiguous in light of this:

   Var := ( 1, 2, 3 ) // Non ambiguous for Clipper, produces valid
assignment of last element value
                         ( after evaluation of all sub-expressions, first).
   Var := 1,2,3       // Non ambiguous for Clipper, produces compile time
error.

   cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
   Var := ( &cMacro ) // Syntax error on ',' though acceptable in same exact
context elsewhere (codeblock).
   Var := { &cMacro } // Syntax error on ',' please note:
                         There is *no* ambiguity, as to the suitability of
lists in this context.

   cMacro := "{ 1, 2, 3 }"
   Var := &cMacro     // Non ambiguous for Clipper or Macro Compiler,
produces assignment of array from list.

   cMacro := "( 1, 2, 3 )"
   Var := &cMacro     // Syntax error on ',' though:
                         1. Acceptable in Clipper as grouped list.
                         2. Acceptable in Macro Compiler in similar context
of literal arrays lists.

Why should it not treat the expended macro as it treats any other compile
time expression?

> > > The two ways Nantucket took care with code blocks:
> > > 1. they allow a macro where it would not be ambiguous
> > > e.g. {|| &cMacro }
> > > 2. they added an error message for other cases
> > > e.g. {|| {&cMacro} }
> > > this error also occurs for cases that would not be ambiguous; perhaps
> > > they didn't see enough need to try to figure out which would be OK
> > > and which not.  Note that they chose the "safer" (more restrictive)
> > > route.
>
> > 1. Lists are never ambiguous in Clipper syntax. You are the
> only person here
> > that claims such ambiguity.
>
> It's ambiguous because there are at least 2 ways to it could work:
> (a) If #2 above were allowed, it would be reasonable to say the code
> block should return an array of one element.  If cMacro contains a
> list then either it's an error or it's treated as a comma expression
> (thus evaluating each part of the list and returning the last value).
> (b) Your opinion is that the number of elements in the array would
> depend on how many items were in cMacro, when it's a list.

But John, it shouldn't be about how me or you interpret it, it should be
treated *exactly* as if the expended macro was literal text provided in
compile time!!!

> > 2. You suggest we should take after their ["perhaps"] laziness?
>
> It's only an opinion as to whether it was laziness.  They put in extra
> code to allow a list macro within a code block at runtime, and extra
> code in the compiler to detect and allow / disallow some cases in a
> code block.  That's not "laziness" to my way of thinking.

If you were familiar with the underlying code, you would have known, that's
not true. They didn't have to add any logic, they just excused the list from
the error in the context of block, because it was trivial (no additional
logic was needed), the default behavior of the compiler is to push/pop all
expressions but the last, which is only pushed. Had they care enough they
would have excused Var := ( &cMacro ) too, because again no added logic
would be needed. Supporting all other contexts on the other hand, required
*significant* and/or *challenging*, and/or *laborious*, extra logic.

> > > > I suppose you would have to convince us of the *correctness*,
> > > and reasoning
> > > > behind allowing us to perform:
> > > > cMacro := "SomeArray[ Index1, Index2, IndexN ]"
> > > > SomeVar := &cMacro
> > > > and also:
> > > > cMacro := "Index1"
> > > > SomeVar := SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
> > > > but not:
> > > > cMacro := "Index1, Index2, IndexN"
> > > > SomeVar := SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
> > >
> > > I don't know whether I can convince you.  However, the first two are
> > > unambiguous whereas the latter is ambiguous - it's an example of the
> > > very case where you want one behaviour and I originally wanted another
> > > behaviour (but now I think Nantucket were right to disallow it).
>
> > How can you claim that the first 2 are not ambiguous, yet the last *is*?
>
> The first looks to be how arrays are implemented and doc'ed.  Surely
> neither of us claims it's ambiguous.  The second also doesn't look
> ambiguous.  If you're taking issue with my claims so far, please say
> why.  The last one can be considered ambiguous in the same way as I
> explained above:
> (a) it can be regarded as an array with a single index (which if it
> is a list macro is either an error or a comma expression)
> (b) it can be viewed your way

1. What would be the basis of interpretation a?
2. Could it not be the same kind of "error" when entered literally in the
prg?
3. Why would the prg compiler follow strict language syntax, yet macro
compiler be allowed to see ambiguity?

> I find it hard to believe you could not see these alternatives.  I
> know you don't agree with case (a) but having to spell it out like
> this does rather surprise me.

Not as much as I'm surprised that your argument allows for the macro
compiler to use different interpretations than the compile time compiler.

> > > > > I tend to agree, except in the case of a list.
> > >
> > > > But why "except"?
> > >
> > > Because it's not ambiguous.
>
> > But every other use of a list is just as unambiguous,
>
> No.  See above.
>
> > including many other contexts that even you agree are non ambiguous.
>
> I'm not sure to what you're referring.

Just check above, didn't you say:

   this error also occurs for cases that would not be ambiguous; perhaps
   they didn't see enough need to try to figure out which would be OK
   and which not.

???

> > When do we consider it a bug, and when not?
>
> It's a bug when we change Clipper behaviour by default without very
> compelling reasons.

Compelling to whom?

> I'd welcome a call for a vote, as this looks to be dragging on. :-(
> The vote (IMO) would be whether this new code for list macros should
> be enabled by default.

That would be self serving would it not? Why would you choose to ignore the
many other incompatibilities we introduced into the macro compiler? Could it
be any less objective?

> > The ambiguity is only there for anyone inventing alternate meanings to
> > lists, strictly against the documented non ambiguous nature of lists in
> > Clipper. This is indeed redesigning Clipper. Fixing the macro to fully
> > support the documented meanings is not re-designing Clipper, but rather
> > completing the implementation of macro.
>
> Above I show why they can be ambiguous.  Others and I have also posted
> evidence that Nantucket people put in extra work in this area and
> chose not to do what you're doing.  I've posted an example where your
> change would break an app.  I do not regard all that as "Fixing".

No, above you insist on allowing a *different* set of syntax rules for 2
compilers of the *same* language.

> > > I have provided reasoning.
>
> > Sorry, but I must disagree.
>
> You disagree that I've provided it or you disagree with what I wrote?
> IAC, an opinion is not enough to dismiss the issue and force this
> change on everyone by default.  At least, an opinion isn't enough
> when there's reasoned dissent and no vote has been taken.

I disagree that you provided reasoning. Between the above 2 options I would
select "disagree with what you wrote", but I meant a little more than that.

> > 2. It's only your opinion that "there's evidence Nantucket had
> good reasons
> > for what they did". Please don't state it as a fact, because it
> isn't, it's
> > just your speculation/guess/etc..
>
> It's not only my opinion.  Others and I have posted factual evidence.

There were no "others", and there were no "factual" evidence. There was one
individual, who described a *general* interpretation *he* made, based on
replies from Nantucket to concerns he had. I personally had *intense*
discussions with Nantucket Beta Team, and have the exact opposite
recollection. I did press them with more specific questions/challenges, and
because I do have *clear* recollection of the questions/challenges
responses, and because I now have intimate knowledge of the code involved, I
consider my "testimony" more material ("factual") to this debate.

> > this is an intense technical argument, and again I must stop for a
> > second and assure you of my positive feelings ...
>
> :-)
>
> Please understand my posts in the same way!

Great :-)

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 13 17:56:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Mon Aug 13 16:56:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108130708_MC3-DC34-3617@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEHIDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > Would you like to be able to control usage of ShortCuts in
> *your* macros at
> > compile time?
>
> It's not a real question for me personally (I never use -Z, hardly
> ever use macros, they don't involve short cuts, etc).  Also, I regard
> -Z as only there for short term transition of S87 (etc) users who've
> not yet made changes (if any) needed such that they can stop using -Z.

John, not specifying -z *is* an explicit decision to *do* use shortcuts in
your code.

If your code has:

   IIF( Exp1 .OR. Exp2, ... )

Where Exp2 *must* *only* be evaluated *if* Exp1 produces a .F. value, The
above *will* produce erroneous results if -z was to be specified.

Now, if you had the above in a macro, the same erroneous results would be
produced, *unless* you could as the author of such code, to specify that the
above code *must* use logic shortcuts.

So the question remains:

   Would you like to be able to *control* (i.e. enable or disable - in your
case enable)
   usage of ShortCuts in *your* macros at compile time?

> > Or would you leave that at the mercy of the consumer using your lib?
>
> Given the above, that's moot.

Not at all! If I used your macro (which assumes Shortcuts are enabled) and
disabled ShortCuts in my code, your macro would have produced erroneous
results.

> > Or would you leave that at the mercy of the consumer using your lib?
>
> Pass.  (My LIBs use almost no macros.)

If you use *any* macros (even if was just one single one), you have to be
able to control it's execution environment.

> > > It may or may not be horrible.  It's not the same as runtime control
> > > of short cuts (-Z switch), however.
>
> > I hope you now see it is.
>
> I don't, sorry.  Besides, you're not using the situation I posted,
> which was meant to be the use of short cuts within a LIB, outside of
> macros - i.e. the common situation.

Sorry I don't understand, could you please post specific code sample?

> > > > You see that would mean the author of a prg linking against your
> > > > LIB, may inadvertently override the requirement of your LIB modules.
> > >
> > > But they may _need_ to do that, whereas they should never need to do
> > > that with -Z.
>
> > Why would they need to override your specification of usage of
> ShortCuts in
> > macros in *your* modules?
>
> See above - that's not the situation I was referring to.

Sorry, I don't understand, you mentioned a macro of seek expression, I can't
see the point.

> > Why would they need to override your specification of usage of Harbour
> > Extensions in macros in *your* modules?
>
> Again, that doesn't look to be what I was referring to.

Please post a clear code sample, so I can address your exact issue then.

> > > If you do that, the LIB may not be of use.  E.g. the LIB macros
> > > something then SEEKs it.  I pass in a string containing a comma.  The
> > > LIB mistakenly treats what I've passed as a list.  But really it was
> > > user bad input.
>
> > 1. But if you *intentionally* chose to support list macros,
> that is how it
> > must be interpreted.
>
> But then it would not be "user bad input".  Since I stated "really it
> was user bad input", you're supposed to answer based on that.  It's a
> given, for the example stated.

No. if you *chose* to support lists in macros, it means *you* deliberately*
preferred the logical need to evaluate multiple expressions, *over* the
possibility of an error. It also means that you can peek at the macro, and
make some educated analysis, before any evaluation. If you didn't, this same
macro would have produced an *error* anyway. Because lists are not supported
in Clipper in this context of function argument.

> > 2. If you enabled list support in run-time using HB_SETMACRO()
> before such
> > evaluation, you would still face the same dilemma, wouldn't you?
>
> There's no dilemma in the above example.  It's stated what the desired
> behaviour is.  If HB_SETMACRO() would break that, it shouldn't be used.

Sorry, I just can't understand. We were arguing the need for compile-time
vs. run-time control of macro extensions. You specified an example of
possible ambiguity, between an error context, or intended multiple
expression. My point is that if you chose to see such ambiguity in the
above, same would be true, if the enabling was done in run-time would it
not?

> > > > It also controls other Harbour extensions, like Var++ Var+=
> and so many
> > > > other such extensions.
> > >
> > > I have doubts as to the wisdom of that.
>
> > How would you suggest to control the support for such extensions?
>
> Let's finish with list macros.  In passing, however, it looks to me
> like the settings for list macros and the above should be separate,
> since list macros can be ambiguous but the above may not be.  The
> default should be disabled, I feel, to retain Clipper compatibility.

1. All extensions groups are already separated. I'm lost as to your final
point though.

2. Do you see the same ambiguity in:

      cMacro := "Field1 -= (Exp)"

   ???

   Since Clipper does *not* support the above and will produce an error,
   is it possibly it was an input error attempting to do:

      cMacro := "Field1 == (Exp)"

   This group of numerous Harbour extensions, will definitely "break" much
more
   code then the list macro. Should we disable it by default too?

> > No, in your example above, the LIB is guaranteed to work exactly as the
> > author of the code intended for it to work.
>

Could you please explain...

Ron

> > > idea not only to doc how to enable it but also to mention the kinds

Clipper code.

> > Clipper.
>

> app needs - and is in the example I posted.
