exception* noted below.

> > The only exception to the above is the LIST command
>
> Not true.  My example is another.  There may well be more.

Please prove with code sample. Please show code that does *not* involve the
LIST command, and does *not* produce an ERROR in Clipper, that will produce
different results in Harbour, if list support in macros is enabled.

> However, since there are now at least 2 cases where an app can be
> broken by your change, I again say that I feel your change should not
> be enabled by default.

No there are no 2 cases!

1. No Clipper code the does *not* produce an ERROR will *not* be effected
when enabling list supports in macro!

2. The Clipper behavior, of list in macro while not producing an ERROR is
ERRONEOUS!

3. wonder how many Clipper users will agree with you that the following is
the expected Clipper behavior for:

   cFields := "FIELD->F_Name, FIELD->L_Name, FIELD->Age"
   LIST OFF &cFields

   a. R/T Error, because Clipper does not support macros of list as per
Clipper documentation.


   b. Display as follows:

            30

      because LIST arguments are implemented by means of codeblocks, which
although
      are not documented to support macros of list, in effect do, and since
lists
      in block will evaluate all expressions, but only produce the last
value, thus
      output of above code should only display the FIELD->Age.

   c. Display as follows:

      John     Skelton             30

      because this is what my code intended to do, that's how it worked in
my previous
      Clipper version, and that's how it worked in dBase, before I upgraded
to Clipper.

   What would you honestly think will be the *least* likely selected answer
if we queried every Clipper user on earth?

Do you really think that the Clipper user is supposed to be intimately
familiar with low level implementation, and understand that it's ok for the
macro list to not produce an error, yet "swallow" some of his expressions?

Do you really think majority of Clipper users will agree with you that
behavior (b) above should be described as "breaking their app"?

John, I'm confident we both are too committed to our different approaches at
this stage, and I don't expect we can convince each other either way. We are
becoming redundant. Let's leave our disagreement as such.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 03:40:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Aug 14 02:40:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] RE: FieldBl nuevo(an Enhaced version of fieldblock,fieldwblock
In-Reply-To: <000d01c12458$5af03c20$e6d4d7c8@culik>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKKEHKDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Luiz,

> Can you commit this file to me.
> I´m an bit busy right now, so i can´t commit until this weekend
>
> This enhaced version of fieldblock() and fieldwblock() functions
> was send to
> me By Manuel Exposito Suarez.
> I´ve tested , and is much more fastern then the one on CVS

Sorry, but this code is NOT Clipper compatible, and uses a macro to build
the block, against the explicit advice in Clipper's doc.

Try this sample with Clipper:

//--------------------------------//
Procedure Main()

   LOCAL b1, b2

   //USE TEST

   b1 := FieldBlock( 'First' )
   b2 := FieldWBlock( 'Last', 1 )

   USE TEST

   ? Eval( b1 ), Eval( b2 )

return

//--------------------------------//

BTW, after some review it seems the CVS code is not Clipper compatible
either. The block will not raise an error if the field does not exist.

Here is a code that will emulate Clipper behavior:

Function FieldBlock( cFldName )

   IF ValType( cFldName ) == 'C'
      RETURN {|xSet, nPos| nPos := FieldPos( cFldName ), IIF( nPos > 0,
IIF( xSet == NIL, FieldGet( nPos ), FieldPut( nPos, xSet ) ), &( "FIELD->" +
cFldName ) ) }
   ENDIF

RETURN NIL

Function FieldWBlock( cFldName, nWa )

   IF ValType( cFldName ) == 'C' .AND. ValType( nWa ) == 'N'
      RETURN {|xSet, nPos| nPos := FieldPos( cFldName ), IIF( nPos > 0,
IIF( xSet == NIL, (nWa)->( FieldGet( nPos ) ), (nWa)->( FieldPut( nPos,
xSet ) ) ), &( "FIELD->" + cFldName ) ) }
   ENDIF

RETURN NIL

BTW, it seems Clipper is using an assembler code for this function, and it
uses few internals I'm not familiar with.

Here are the referenced symbols:

extrn   __acrtused
extrn   _VSTR
extrn   __get_sym
extrn   __sysflags
extrn   __param
extrn   __ipushblock
extrn   __lparam
extrn   __eval
extrn   __tos
extrn   __nScanId

Anyone familiar with _VSTR, or __nScanId?

Ron

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 10:18:31 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Tue Aug 14 09:18:31 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108140917_MC3-DC64-17E0@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> And the author of a given body of code should know how they want macro
> expansion to work too, right?

Sadly, I don't think that's necessarily so.  The problem revolves
around the case where there are multiple authors, e.g. in the case of
an add-on LIB.  The LIB may be written with one behaviour of macros in
mind, and the other code may have the other behaviour needed.  Fine
until the one needs to use (e.g. call) the other, passing in something
to be macroed.  There are two behaviours which could occur; whichever
does occur could be the opposite of what's wanted.

I posted an example (where the caller wants a runtime error but
instead the list macro is accepted).  It's a simplistic example
designed to show that the issue does exist.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 10:19:01 2001

Ron,

> not specifying -z *is* an explicit decision to *do* use shortcuts in
> your code.

I am at a complete loss to understand how you could possibly think
that I don't know that.  Well, I do.  I also know what follows from
not using -Z.  I also said very explicitly what I regard as the
reason for -Z's existence.

> Would you like to be able to *control* (i.e. enable or disable - in
> your case enable) usage of ShortCuts in *your* macros at compile
> time?

I posted details of why it is of no interest to me.

> > Given the above, that's moot.

> Not at all! If I used your macro (which assumes Shortcuts are enabled) =
and
> disabled ShortCuts in my code, your macro would have produced erroneous=

> results.

Based on what I posted, you won't be using any macro of mine that
could do that.

> > you're not using the situation I posted,
> > which was meant to be the use of short cuts within a LIB, outside of
> > macros - i.e. the common situation.

> Sorry I don't understand, could you please post specific code sample?

This is an example of the common situation:
  IF exp1 .AND. exp2
and I (the author) will have specified at compile time how I want it
to behave.  In my case I never use -Z, because I've never wanted and
plan never to want that behaviour.

I can then supply the compiled code as a LIB and know how it will be
executed.  There is no issue of wanting runtime control of the above
short cut.  This is different from the situation with adding the
ability to have a list in a macro, where such control can be needed.
The problem is that the caller of a function in a LIB may want the
opposite behaviour to what the LIB author wants.  I think these can't
be reconciled by Harbour, if such a list macro is allowed.  I think
the LIB author would have to state what the situation is, or provide
two versions.

OK - you talked me into the ground. :-(

I'd like to hold onto just one thing: let's have list macros disabled
by default.

> > But then it would not be "user bad input".  Since I stated "really it=

> > was user bad input", you're supposed to answer based on that.  It's a=

> > given, for the example stated.

> No.

I stated a situation.  "No" rejects that example's stated basis.  I
see no basis for a discussion here. :-(

> if you *chose* to support lists in macros

I didn't.  The example didn't want the behaviour you've added.  The
example stated that.  Your change breaks the example.

> We were arguing the need for compile-time vs. run-time control of
> macro extensions.

Were we?  I'm just arguing that this new macro behaviour should be
off by default.  (I've also pointed out that a list in a macro could
be seen as ambiguous, but that's minor compared to the new feature
being on by default.)

> > The default should be disabled, I feel, to retain Clipper compatibili=
ty.

> I'm lost as to your final point though.

It looks simple (to me): the extensions, but particularly list macros,
should be disabled by default.

John.

> > > 1. Clipper documentation as to interpretation of lists leaves
> > no room for
> > > ambiguity!

le to

r.

> Do you dispute that lists, parenthesized vs. non parenthesized, have a =
clear
> and unambiguous meaning in the Clipper language?

operators. :-(

> Please don't avoid the issue

> again how is it ambiguous in light of this:
>   Var :=3D ( 1, 2, 3 ) // Non ambiguous for Clipper, produces valid
> assignment of last element value
>                         ( after evaluation of all sub-expressions, firs=
t).

Where is it doc'ed so as to be "non ambiguous"? ;-)  But I believe I
know what Clipper actually does with it.

>    Var :=3D 1,2,3       // Non ambiguous for Clipper, produces compile =
time
> error.

Yes.  Know why?  Want to change it?  If not, why not? :-)

>    cMacro :=3D "1, 2, 3"
>    Var :=3D ( &cMacro ) // Syntax error on ',' though acceptable in sam=
e exact
> context elsewhere (codeblock).

I found that.

>    Var :=3D { &cMacro } // Syntax error on ',' please note:
>                          There is *no* ambiguity, as to the suitability=
 of
> lists in this context.

If you take an interpretive/dBase POV.  If you take a "here's a comma
operator inside this macro" POV then you get a different, unambiguous
meaning. :-)

>    cMacro :=3D "{ 1, 2, 3 }"
>    Var :=3D &cMacro     // Non ambiguous for Clipper or Macro Compiler,=

> produces assignment of array from list.

OK.

>    cMacro :=3D "( 1, 2, 3 )"
>    Var :=3D &cMacro     // Syntax error on ',' though:
>                          1. Acceptable in Clipper as grouped list.
>                          2. Acceptable in Macro Compiler in similar con=
text
> of literal arrays lists.
> =

> Why should it not treat the expended macro as it treats any other compi=
le
> time expression?

reason for it to be enabled by default.  We don't know why Clipper
isn't the way you want.

> > It's ambiguous because there are at least 2 ways to it could work:
> > (a) If #2 above were allowed, it would be reasonable to say the code
> > block should return an array of one element.  If cMacro contains a
> > list then either it's an error or it's treated as a comma expression
> > (thus evaluating each part of the list and returning the last value).=

> > (b) Your opinion is that the number of elements in the array would

> it shouldn't be about how me or you interpret it, it should be

> compile time!!!

Where is Clipper defined like that?  In your mind, I think.  In some
other minds, too, I understand.  But it was explicitly disallowed by
some other (Nantucket) minds.  Awkward point that.  I still say
Harbour can be different, but I also say I don't think it should be
different by default.

time again?  I've asked we stop.  I intend to.  But I really disagree
if you force your behaviour to be enabled by default.  Please let's
at least vote.

> > It's only an opinion as to whether it was laziness.  They put in extr=
a
> > code to allow a list macro within a code block at runtime, and extra
> > code in the compiler to detect and allow / disallow some cases in a
> > code block.  That's not "laziness" to my way of thinking.

> If you were familiar with the underlying code, you would have known, th=
at's
> not true. They didn't have to add any logic, they just excused the list=
 from
> the error in the context of block, because it was trivial (no additiona=
l
> logic was needed), the default behavior of the compiler is to push/pop =
all
> expressions but the last, which is only pushed. Had they care enough th=
ey
> would have excused Var :=3D ( &cMacro ) too, because again no added log=
ic
> would be needed. Supporting all other contexts on the other hand, requi=
red
> *significant* and/or *challenging*, and/or *laborious*, extra logic.

You're making a lot of assumptions about the code in Clipper.  You
can easily be wrong.

> > > > > cMacro :=3D "Index1, Index2, IndexN"
> > > > > SomeVar :=3D SomeArray[ &cMacro ]
[snip]
> >     The last one can be considered ambiguous in the same way as I
> > explained above:
> > (a) it can be regarded as an array with a single index (which if it
> > is a list macro is either an error or a comma expression)
> > (b) it can be viewed your way

> 1. What would be the basis of interpretation a?

It's both commonly what compiled systems do and what Clipper actually
does.

> 2. Could it not be the same kind of "error" when entered literally in t=
he
> prg?

It could be.  In Clipper it's not.

> 3. Why would the prg compiler follow strict language syntax, yet macro
> compiler be allowed to see ambiguity?

The macro compiler wouldn't be seeing an ambiguity.  It would
presumably have a single view of what the expression meant.  Clipper
behaves like that.  The macro compiler might've looked at every macro
and if it were a list it could've treated it as a series of comma
operators, evaluating each expression and discarding all but the
last result.  Probably easy to do, but not what Clipper does.  We
don't know why.  You've tried to guess.  I may guess differently. :-)

> > I find it hard to believe you could not see these alternatives.  I
> > know you don't agree with case (a) but having to spell it out like
> > this does rather surprise me.

> Not as much as I'm surprised that your argument allows for the macro
> compiler to use different interpretations than the compile time compile=
r.

My suggested way would actually be more consistent.  A list in a macro
would always be evaluated left to right, discarding each result but
the last.  No need to care what surrounding context was outside the
macro.  Very simple, very clean.  Not the same as what you want.

> > > > > > I tend to agree, except in the case of a list.
> > > >
> > > > > But why "except"?
> > > >
> > > > Because it's not ambiguous.
> >
> > > But every other use of a list is just as unambiguous,
> >
> > No.  See above.
> >
> > > including many other contexts that even you agree are non ambiguous=
.
> >
> > I'm not sure to what you're referring.

> Just check above, didn't you say:

>    this error also occurs for cases that would not be ambiguous; perhap=
s
>    they didn't see enough need to try to figure out which would be OK
>    and which not.

Yes.  What was your point?

> > > When do we consider it a bug, and when not?
> >
> > It's a bug when we change Clipper behaviour by default without very
> > compelling reasons.

> Compelling to whom?

Harbour users.  Or a vote of developers.  Or - well, something more
than just doing it unilaterally in the face of dissention (sp?).
That's not how I understood Harbour was being developed.

> > I'd welcome a call for a vote, as this looks to be dragging on. :-(
> > The vote (IMO) would be whether this new code for list macros should
> > be enabled by default.

> That would be self serving would it not?

In what way?  If the decision goes against what I vote for, I'll
accept it.  I hope you'd do the same.  I'm not accusing you of being
self serving.

> Why would you choose to ignore the many other incompatibilities we
> introduced into the macro compiler? Could it be any less objective?

I'm happy to have a vote or votes on those.  Probably a good idea.
In what way is voting objective or not objective and why do you raise
that?  Don't you want democracy?

> > Above I show why they can be ambiguous.  Others and I have also poste=
d
> > evidence that Nantucket people put in extra work in this area and
> > chose not to do what you're doing.  I've posted an example where your=

> > change would break an app.  I do not regard all that as "Fixing".

> No, above you insist on allowing a *different* set of syntax rules for =
2
> compilers of the *same* language.

Actually, that's false.  See above.

> > > > I have provided reasoning.
> >
> > > Sorry, but I must disagree.
> >
> > You disagree that I've provided it or you disagree with what I wrote?=

> > IAC, an opinion is not enough to dismiss the issue and force this
> > change on everyone by default.  At least, an opinion isn't enough
> > when there's reasoned dissent and no vote has been taken.

> I disagree that you provided reasoning. Between the above 2 options I w=
ould
> select "disagree with what you wrote", but I meant a little more than t=
hat.

Words fail me.  My will to debate pointlessly certainly does.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 10:21:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Tue Aug 14 09:21:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108140917_MC3-DC64-17E7@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> From a dBase developers point of view that's what the macro operator
> did, it did text replacement and/or expansion (from a logical POV,
> not an implementation POV).

Then if Harbour is to be dBase compatible that's what it should do.

It conflicts with what Clipper does, so it should not be the default.

> | cMacro :=3D "1, 2, 3"
> | Foo( &cMacro )
> would appear to be "unambiguously" a function call with three parameter=
s is
> based on the reasoning and experience that I've reported earlier

With that background, and aiming for dBase compatibility, it's clear
how it should be handled.  With a different background, it can have
a different meaning (func. with one param).  With Clipper that macro's
not allowed, so for a Clipper-compatible system to allow it is an
addition.  It's ambiguous in the sense that there are two different
ways it could be added.

I was hoping for a response along the lines of "yes there are two but
actually we should pick <whichever> because <reason> (e.g. because
that's what a Clipper developer would expect)".  Your response based
on dBase may be what most Clipper developers would say (I don't know,
but it seems plausible).

> More to the point, code blocks are a data type, "&" is an operator. You=
'd be
> hard pushed to find two things any more different.

Right.  I don't think I've followed why you wanted to highlight that.

> | But a code block isn't a code substitution mechanism is it?

Depends a bit what one means by "substitution" (please don't mention
Slick Willy!).  "Parameterisation" is perhaps more what a code block
could be described as, but then we're into trying to figure out what
exactly the difference is between substitution and parameterisation,
and what a macro's for.  Hmm... one even should distinguish between
a macro's usage (&something) and its "creation" (better word?), i.e.
the "something".  Similarly we've the creation of the code block
(starts with "{|", continues to the closing "}") and its usage
(EVAL(...)).  Common usage (Clipper programmerese?) seems to be rather
careless (imprecise) about macros, frequently not distinguishing
between the something (a string) and the usage of the macro operator
(&).  I'm probably guilty of such imprecision; is it what made you
bring up lambda & eval?

> The number of people commenting seems to be the same as the upper limit=
 of
> people who care.

:-(

> What does "being a compiler" tell us?

Commonly, that it's not an interpreter.  Normally a compiler is rather
different from an interpreter, including what happens at runtime.  Now
with a background in (interpretive) dBase one may well want only some
of the typical features of a compiler (object files, LIBs, whatever).
One may or may not want the other common feature: that the runtime is
less dynamic than with an interpreter.  Commonly you don't get a
choice :-(, i.e. you get whatever the runtime does.  I guess that's
about the position with Clipper.

Many/most compiled environments would not be willing to regard
SomeFunc( &cMacro ) as anything but a function with a single param,
and Clipper pretty much is that way.  I'm not arguing that Clipper is
right or that in the context of a dBase background that
SomeFunc( &cMacro ) should be regarded as a func. with a single param,
but I am saying that commonly it would be taken as that.  There are
exceptions and from a dBase POV Harbour would be an exception.  From
a Clipper POV presumably Harbour would do what Clipper does. :-)

> >   SomeFunc( <param1> )
> > is clearly a func with a single param, it looks consistent that when
> > <param1> is &cMacro then it's still a func with a single param.  =


> Personally I'd defer such a decision until I knew the content of cMacro=
.

With a dBase POV, so would I.  Actually, I would from a Clipper POV
in the sense that it checks the result of the macro operation to make
sure it's not a list, then throw an error if it is.

> > It's not
> > as if there's no other way to achieve the equivalent of Ron's way of
> > handling this.

> I'm not sure I follow this.

I meant that instead of doing
  SomeFunc( &cMacro )
one could do
  &("SomeFunc(" + cMacro + ")" )
if I got the syntax right.  SomeFunc() now can't be a static, which
may be a nuisance.

> > However, I actually don't feel fanatically about this at all - but I =
do
> > think the change made should not be enabled by default. I think you g=
ot
> > that message, though. :-)

> Agreed, I do think that, as much as possible, any possibly "invasive"
> enhancements to the language should be off by default. Within reason an=
yway.
> I can't imagine that anyone could have a reasonable objection to that.

Quite.  But this feature _is_ enabled by default. :-(

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 11:33:02 2001

On Tue, Aug 14, 2001 at 09:17:32AM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > And the author of a given body of code should know how they want macro
> > expansion to work too, right?
> 
> Sadly, I don't think that's necessarily so. The problem revolves around
> the case where there are multiple authors, e.g. in the case of an add-on
> LIB. The LIB may be written with one behaviour of macros in mind, and the
> other code may have the other behaviour needed. Fine until the one needs
> to use (e.g. call) the other, passing in something to be macroed. There
> are two behaviours which could occur; whichever does occur could be the
> opposite of what's wanted.

I'm still confused. The above could easily describe problems with logic
shortcutting. Perhaps I'm still very confused about this business of there
been a compile time setting and a runtime setting. I'm not at all sure I
understand it.

> I posted an example (where the caller wants a runtime error but instead
> the list macro is accepted). It's a simplistic example designed to show
> that the issue does exist.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 11:33:23 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Aug 14 10:33:23 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108140917_MC3-DC64-17E7@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Tue, Aug 14, 2001 at 09:17:42AM -0400
References: <200108140917_MC3-DC64-17E7@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010814152857.P1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, Aug 14, 2001 at 09:17:42AM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > From a dBase developers point of view that's what the macro operator
> > did, it did text replacement and/or expansion (from a logical POV, not
> > an implementation POV).
> 
> Then if Harbour is to be dBase compatible that's what it should do.

That isn't, as we both know, the goal of harbour. Neither is it the
suggestion I'm making.

> It conflicts with what Clipper does, so it should not be the default.

I think I've said a few times now that I'm not arguing in favour of default
behaviour. But, in case it still isn't clear:

o I am not suggesting that this is good default behaviour.

o I am suggesting that macro expansion of a list within a function argument
  context should probably result in "N" arguments resulting, not one
  argument (assuming that such a enhancement is a good idea).

Nothing more, nothing less.

> With that background, and aiming for dBase compatibility, it's clear how
> it should be handled. With a different background, it can have a different
> meaning (func. with one param). With Clipper that macro's not allowed, so
> for a Clipper-compatible system to allow it is an addition. It's ambiguous
> in the sense that there are two different ways it could be added.

We're going over old ground again. You don't need to tell me that it is
ambiguous, it is obvious in the extreme that it is ambiguous. I'm not
interesting in being told that it is ambiguous because if it wasn't we
wouldn't be debating the pros and cons of the possible interpretations.

In a nutshell: I'm documenting some reasoning for one interpretation. You've
said you disagree with it. I've asked why and you've told me that there is
some ambiguity. I already knew that.

> I was hoping for a response along the lines of "yes there are two but
> actually we should pick <whichever> because <reason> (e.g. because that's
> what a Clipper developer would expect)". Your response based on dBase may
> be what most Clipper developers would say (I don't know, but it seems
> plausible).

IOW I gave you the response you desired a couple or so days ago? I outlined
how I would personally expect such an extension to work and I detailed the
reasons why I have such an expectation.

> [SNIP] I'm probably guilty of such imprecision; is it what made you bring
> up lambda & eval?

I think so. What I was trying to highlight is that a code block is a body of
compiled code, you can pass it around as such and it can and does carry some
detail about the environment in which it was instantiated (think lambda in
lisp). You can't, however, pass around a "macro" because there's no such
thing. There's only macro expansion/evaluation (that slash is there to point
out that there is obviously two modes of viewing macro "invocation").

At no point should anyone see a code block as something that is in any way
expanded, unlike a macro expanded/evaluated string.

> > What does "being a compiler" tell us?
> 
> Commonly, that it's not an interpreter. Normally a compiler is rather
> different from an interpreter, including what happens at runtime. Now with
> a background in (interpretive) dBase one may well want only some of the
> typical features of a compiler (object files, LIBs, whatever). One may or
> may not want the other common feature: that the runtime is less dynamic
> than with an interpreter. Commonly you don't get a choice :-(, i.e. you
> get whatever the runtime does. I guess that's about the position with
> Clipper.

I take it that we'd agree that Clipper is more like an interpreter than it
is like a "true" compiler? Moreover, many interpreters are compilers anyway.

> Many/most compiled environments would not be willing to regard SomeFunc(
> &cMacro ) as anything but a function with a single param, and Clipper
> pretty much is that way. [SNIP]

I was thinking about this this morning and I think the problem here might
well be that macro expansion/evaluation is done using an operator instead of
a function. For example, assume we had no "&" but instead had a function:

,----
| cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
| SomeFunc( MacroEval( cMacro ) )
`----

I'd expect the macro eval function to throw an error because cMacro doesn't
contain a valid like of Clipper code.

Point being, I think we're in agreement that it really all depends on if you
see this:

,----
| cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
| SomeFunc( &cMacro )
`----

as something employing macro expansion or macro evaluation (Clipper calls
the operator the macro evaluation operator IIRC so there's some scope for
backing up your interpretation there). If someone views the above as macro
*expansion* then it seems only sensible that they see a function being
passed three arguments. If, on the other hand, they see the above as macro
*evaluation* they should probably expect it to throw an error.

> I meant that instead of doing
>   SomeFunc( &cMacro )
> one could do
>   &("SomeFunc(" + cMacro + ")" )
> if I got the syntax right.  SomeFunc() now can't be a static, which
> may be a nuisance.

Right, I'm with you, there are alternative methods.

--

http://www.davep.org/               |     eg - Norton Guide reader for Linux.
http://www.davep.org/clipper/       |    weg - Norton Guide reader for Windows.
http://www.davep.org/norton-guides/ | dgscan - DGROUP scanner for Clipper.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 11:54:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Tue Aug 14 10:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <20010813163338.O30092@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <200108131026_MC3-DC47-C511@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Mon, Aug 13, 2001 at 10:25:48AM -0400
Message-ID: <3B7958EE.26734.15FD8A@localhost>

On 13 Aug 2001, at 16:33, Dave Pearson wrote:

> The main "why" I'm interested in is why someone should expect this:
> 
> ,----
> | cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
> | Foo( &cMacro )
> `----
> 
> to work out as a function being called with a single parameter. I don't
> disagree that there's some useful debate to be had regarding how advisable
> allowing the above is. What I'm interested in here is why anyone would see
> the above as ambiguous. The existence of such ambiguity is, from where I'm
> sat, at the heart of any "should we/shouldn't we" debate about the macro
> expansion of lists.

  The ambiguity appears if you look inside a Foo function. See the 
example:

cMacro :="DBSEEK(somwhere),FOUND()"
Foo( &cMacro )

FUNCTION Foo( lSomeFlag, lZAPdatabase )

  IF( lZAPdatabase )
   .....

  The other ambiguity is caused that in Clipper all expressions returns a 
single value. You seems to see the macro opertor as a text substitution 
method however there is, IMHO, a clear separation beetwen a text 
substitution:
cVar := "&somevar.sometext"
and a macro operator
&cMacro
  So far all operators are working on valid expressions - the comma 
separated list not enclosed in perens is not a valid Clipper expression.

  The ambiguity appears also in more complex expressions:
cMacro := "1,2,3"
Foo( &cMacro+4 )

  What parameters should be expected in Foo function? (1,2,3) or a 
runtime error or - and why not - (1,2,7). Why &macro is only limited to a 
standalone expression?

> 
> As I've posted earlier, macro expansion has a heritage of being just that,
> macro expansion. Back in the late 80s I was writing code that constructed
> whole commands and then macro expanded them. From a dBase developers point
> of view that's what the macro operator did, it did text replacement and/or
> expansion (from a logical POV, not an implementation POV).

  I disagree. A macro operator is compiling and evaluating a valid 
expression. Comma separated list is not a valid expression in Clipper.

> My point here is that the "why" of me saying that this:
> 
> ,----
> | cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
> | Foo( &cMacro )
> `----
> 
> would appear to be "unambiguously" a function call with three parameters is
> based on the reasoning and experience that I've reported earlier and have
> given a summary above. I don't have a dBase/Fox to hand but the reasoning is
> the same that would have had me thinking that this:

  Because you don't know here how many and what parameters are expected 
in Foo function.

> Agreed, I do think that, as much as possible, any possibly "invasive"
> enhancements to the language should be off by default. Within reason anyway.
> I can't imagine that anyone could have a reasonable objection to that.

  Unfortunatelly, the macro list support is enabled by default due to 
Ron's request.

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 12:23:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Tue Aug 14 11:23:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKCEHHDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <200108130708_MC3-DC34-3618@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <3B795F94.21173.2FF6B5@localhost>

On 13 Aug 2001, at 12:55, Ron Pinkas wrote:

> Please don't avoid the issue, again how is it ambiguous in light of this:
> 
>    Var := ( 1, 2, 3 ) // Non ambiguous for Clipper, produces valid
> assignment of last element value
>                          ( after evaluation of all sub-expressions, first).
>    Var := 1,2,3       // Non ambiguous for Clipper, produces compile time
> error.
> 
>    cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
>    Var := ( &cMacro ) // Syntax error on ',' though acceptable in same exact
> context elsewhere (codeblock).

  Because codeblock is an encapsulated list of expressions to evaluate.

>    Var := { &cMacro } // Syntax error on ',' please note:
>                          There is *no* ambiguity, as to the suitability of
> lists in this context.

  Yes, there is no ambiguity however there is no list of expressions 
here. There is a list of array elements. This is a big difference that 
you are ignoring here. Every expresion on the array list should return a 
single value. In other case allowing to support "1,2,3" here will cause 
ambiguity because you will never determine the size of the array without 
checking the value of 'macro'

> 
>    cMacro := "{ 1, 2, 3 }"
>    Var := &cMacro     // Non ambiguous for Clipper or Macro Compiler,
> produces assignment of array from list.
> 
>    cMacro := "( 1, 2, 3 )"
>    Var := &cMacro     // Syntax error on ',' though:
>                          1. Acceptable in Clipper as grouped list.
>                          2. Acceptable in Macro Compiler in similar context
> of literal arrays lists.

  Ron, '{}' operators are not the same as '()' parens. The literal array 
is not a list of expressions - it is a literal array.

> Why should it not treat the expended macro as it treats any other compile
> time expression?

  Because you are mixing different syntax.

> That would be self serving would it not? Why would you choose to ignore the
> many other incompatibilities we introduced into the macro compiler? Could it
> be any less objective?

  Because most incompatibilities are safe. Valid code will still work the 
same. With the new macro list some valid code will be broken. This is the 
reason why it should be disabled by default.

Regards, Ryszard

you've given as an example says nothing more, or less, than the little
example that you replied to (and I've snipped for the sake of brevity).

I'm puzzled by your response here because I can't see the cause of the

>   The other ambiguity is caused that in Clipper all expressions returns a 
> single value. You seems to see the macro opertor as a text substitution 
> method however there is, IMHO, a clear separation beetwen a text 
> substitution:
> cVar := "&somevar.sometext"
> and a macro operator
> &cMacro

Agreed, there is some distinction. What I'm saying, however, is that there
is some scope for this distinction being blurred. In the case of a list
being macro expanded in a function argument list context it seems to me that
the two possibly valid interpretations are a) it expands to an argument list
(yes, even splicing into an existing argument list) or b) it's an error
because "1, 2, 3" isn't really valid Clipper code.

>   So far all operators are working on valid expressions - the comma
> separated list not enclosed in perens is not a valid Clipper expression.

Agreed. In case it isn't clear (and I'll admit that my point is a little
stretched out over a few emails), what I'm saying is:

,----
| cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
| Foo( &cMacro )
`----

should, ideally, throw an error because the content of cMacro isn't valid
Clipper code. However, if it is decided that it shouldn't throw an error
(which is where I think we're at right now, right?) I'm suggesting that it
should be seen as a list of three arguments because it can't possibly be
seen as a list expression that would yield one argument.

>   The ambiguity appears also in more complex expressions:
> cMacro := "1,2,3"
> Foo( &cMacro+4 )
> 
>   What parameters should be expected in Foo function? (1,2,3) or a runtime
> error or - and why not - (1,2,7). Why &macro is only limited to a
> standalone expression?

I'd expect either a runtime error because "1, 2, 3" isn't valid Clipper code
or, failing that "Foo( 1, 2, 3+4 )".

> > As I've posted earlier, macro expansion has a heritage of being just
> > that, macro expansion. Back in the late 80s I was writing code that
> > constructed whole commands and then macro expanded them. From a dBase
> > developers point of view that's what the macro operator did, it did text
> > replacement and/or expansion (from a logical POV, not an implementation
> > POV).
> 
>   I disagree. A macro operator is compiling and evaluating a valid
> expression. Comma separated list is not a valid expression in Clipper.

Agreed. I've never been attempting to address the issue of the validity of
the macro expansion/evaluation of an "unguarded" list, what I have been
attempting to address is John's suggestion that this:

,----
| cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
| Foo( &cMacro )
`----

should result in FOO() being called with one argument. All I'm suggesting is
that, if it doesn't simply result in a runtime error because the content of
cMacro is invalid code (I think this is the better option) it should ideally
result in a function call with three arguments.

> > Agreed, I do think that, as much as possible, any possibly "invasive"
> > enhancements to the language should be off by default. Within reason
> > anyway. I can't imagine that anyone could have a reasonable objection to
> > that.
> 
>   Unfortunatelly, the macro list support is enabled by default due to
> Ron's request.

Agreed, I think it is unfortunate too. If such a feature is to be considered
as an enhancement it should ideally be off by default (see my initial
concerns about this from 2001-07-18. The pointers are still on the harbour
news page.

-- 
Dave Pearson                        |  OSLib - Timeslice release functions.
http://www.davep.org/               |     eg - Norton Guide reader for Linux.
http://www.davep.org/clipper/       |    weg - Norton Guide reader for Windows.
http://www.davep.org/norton-guides/ | dgscan - DGROUP scanner for Clipper.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 14:07:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Tue Aug 14 13:07:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] LIST Command - Survey
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEHODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

Dear Harbour users,

I will greatly appreciate it, if you can take a minute of your time to
answer 2 of the following 3, multiple choice, simple questions:

Given the following code:

    cFields := "FIELD->First, FIELD->Last, FIELD->Age"

    USE TEST
    LIST OFF &cFields WHILE RecNo() == 1

1. What do you *believe* Clipper behavior should be - *if* it was up to you?

   a. R/T Error, because Clipper does not support macros of list as per
Clipper documentation.


   b. Display as follows:

            91

      because LIST arguments are implemented by means of codeblocks, which
although
      are not documented to support macros of list, in effect do, and since
lists
      in block will evaluate all expressions, but only produce the last
value, thus
      output of above code should only display the value of FIELD->Age.

   c. Display as follows:

      Hommer     Simpson             91

      because this is what my code intended to do, that's how it worked in
my previous
      Clipper versions, and that's how it worked in dBase, before I upgraded
to Clipper.

2. What do you *think* Clipper actually does (same choices as above)?
   Please answer *only* if you don't know for sure, and haven't run the
code.

3. What do you believe you *know* Clipper behavior to be (same choices as
above)?
   Please answer *only* if you knew the answer *before* recent discussion on
this list.

* Please note you should only answer questions 1 and, 2 *or* 3.

TIA

Ron


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 14:41:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Paul Tucker)
Date: Tue Aug 14 13:41:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] LIST Command - Survey
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEHODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <06e301c124e7$f2306df0$b6122a0a@chasechevy>

1 c
3 b

However.

IMHO - I believe this should be handled by adding a different or modified
match marker, not by modifying the 'default' operation of the  macro
processor to occasionally deal with 'lists'.  That way, the resulting
side-effects are (hopefully) reduced.  (No I have not given this a lot of
thought)  ie: LIST ~Fields

I am somewhat curious how the other xbase dialects handle this?  (Flagship,
Xbase, etc)

Aside from the time required, there must have been some reason nantucket did
what they did.

Paul

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 14 20:04:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Tue Aug 14 19:04:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] LIST Command - Survey
In-Reply-To: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEHODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
References: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEHODPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>
Message-ID: <3118954645.20010814161815@abacuslaw.com>

Ron:

I wouldn't write that code, and therefore have not contemplated what
it should do if I did.  I find it irrelevant how many people would
guess one way or the other what Clipper would do as if that should
dictate Harbour behavior.
My only contribution to the discussion is
that, by default, Harbour should compile and run existing Clipper code
with the same results as Clipper 5.2 or 5.3.  Extensions and
improvements are great, and I'll probably turn them all on, but
existing code should not break at all with default settings for
Harbour.  That part is that simple.
I won't even try to apply it to the current macro issue, other than to
recommend what I see as the guiding prime directive:
existing code should not break at all with default settings for Harbour.

RP> Dear Harbour users,
RP> I will greatly appreciate it, if you can take a minute of your time to
RP> answer 2 of the following 3, multiple choice, simple questions:

 ---===--- 
 Brian Hays

Subject: [Harbour] ILink32 response file (Alberto)
In-Reply-To: <LLBBIKAMMCMELKOPIPANKEEHGIAA.alberto@a2sistemi.it>
Message-ID: <000001c1255b$feb65b60$0f2aa8c0@first>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C1256C.C2485320
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Alberto,

Here you have a very simple sample
to show you how to build a Ilink32
response file.

regards,

Antonio

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C1256C.C2485320
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;
	name="build.bat"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: attachment;
	filename="build.bat"

@ECHO OFF
CLS

if A%1 =3D=3D A GOTO :SINTAX
if NOT EXIST %1.prg GOTO :NOEXIST

ECHO Compiling...

set hdir=3Dc:\harbour
set bcdir=3Dc:\bcc55\bin

%hdir%\bin\harbour %1 /n /i..\include;%hdir%\include /p %2 %3 > clip.log
@type clip.log
IF ERRORLEVEL 1 PAUSE
IF ERRORLEVEL 1 GOTO EXIT

echo -O2 -e%1.exe -I%hdir%\include %1.c > b32.bc
%bcdir%\bcc32 -M -c @b32.bc
:ENDCOMPILE

echo c0w32.obj + > b32.bc
echo %1.obj, + >> b32.bc
echo %1.exe, + >> b32.bc
echo %1.map, + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\rtl.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\vm.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\gtwin.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\lang.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\macro.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\rdd.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\dbfntx.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\dbfcdx.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\debug.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\common.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %hdir%\lib\pp.lib + >> b32.bc

rem Uncomment these two lines to use Advantage RDD
rem echo %hdir%\lib\rddads.lib + >> b32.bc =20
rem echo %hdir%\lib\ace32.lib + >> b32.bc

echo %bcdir%\lib\cw32.lib + >> b32.bc
echo %bcdir%\lib\import32.lib, >> b32.bc

ECHO *=20
ECHO Linking...
%bcdir%\ilink32 -Gn -Tpe -s @b32.bc

rem delete temporary files
rem @del %1.c

IF ERRORLEVEL 1 GOTO LINKERROR
ECHO * Application successfully built
%1
GOTO EXIT
ECHO

:LINKERROR
rem if exist meminfo.txt notepad meminfo.txt
rem PAUSE * Linking errors *
GOTO EXIT

:SINTAX
ECHO    SYNTAX: Build [Program]     {-- No especifiques la extensi=A2n =
PRG
ECHO                                {-- Don't specify .PRG extension
GOTO EXIT

:NOEXIST
ECHO The specified PRG %1 does not exist

:EXIT
------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C1256C.C2485320--



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 15 04:42:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Patrick Mast, Harbour)
Date: Wed Aug 15 03:42:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ILink32 response file (Alberto)
In-Reply-To: <000001c1255b$feb65b60$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <000501c1255d$a72a5480$6400a8c0@patrick2>

Antonio,

> Here you have a very simple sample
> to show you how to build a Ilink32
> response file.
Please, if you send a file, ZIP it.

I use the new Outlook XP and it does NOT accept .BAT files. It just
removes the file from the mail. There is NO way to setup Outlook so that
it accepts that kind of files.
It also does not accept: .EXE, .HLP, .COM, .INF,.. Actualy, any file
extention that can "run" code.

Thanks! ;-)

Regards,

Patrick Mast
www.Patrick.Be.kz (By Bekz.net)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 15 12:39:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Wed Aug 15 11:39:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108151137_MC3-DC7C-6AB6@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> > > And the author of a given body of code should know how they want ma=
cro
> > > expansion to work too, right?
> =

> > Sadly, I don't think that's necessarily so. The problem revolves arou=
nd
> > the case where there are multiple authors, e.g. in the case of an add=
-on
> > LIB. The LIB may be written with one behaviour of macros in mind, and=
 the
> > other code may have the other behaviour needed. Fine until the one ne=
eds
> > to use (e.g. call) the other, passing in something to be macroed. The=
re
> > are two behaviours which could occur; whichever does occur could be t=
he
> > opposite of what's wanted.

> The above could easily describe problems with logic shortcutting.

Not at compile-time (which was what I meant).  At runtime, I mentioned
I use hardly any macros so it doesn't matter to me. ;-)  It does
matter for Harbour to be the same as Clipper, however, whatever way
Clipper behaves.

> Perhaps I'm still very confused about this business of there
> been a compile time setting and a runtime setting. I'm not at all sure =
I
> understand it.

I'm pretty sure I don't (understand the settings etc).

> > I posted an example (where the caller wants a runtime error but inste=
ad
> > the list macro is accepted). It's a simplistic example designed to sh=
ow
> > that the issue does exist.

> Like <URL:http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/#20010718092356> perhaps?

I thought/expected that was fixed (being the value left on the EVAL
stack)?

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 15 12:39:24 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Wed Aug 15 11:39:24 2001
Subject: [Harbour] LIST Command - Survey
Message-ID: <200108151137_MC3-DC7C-6AB4@compuserve.com>

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 15 12:39:52 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Wed Aug 15 11:39:52 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108151137_MC3-DC7C-6AB8@compuserve.com>

Dave,

> > Then if Harbour is to be dBase compatible that's what it should do.

> That isn't, as we both know, the goal of harbour. Neither is it the
> suggestion I'm making.

Right.

> o I am suggesting that macro expansion of a list within a function argu=
ment
>   context should probably result in "N" arguments resulting, not one
>   argument (assuming that such a enhancement is a good idea).

That's what I understood. :-)

> We're going over old ground again.

Sorry.  OTOH I hope Ron read/reads this part:

> You don't need to tell me that it is ambiguous, it is obvious in
> the extreme that it is ambiguous.

Ron says it's not ambiguous. :-(

> I'm not interesting in being told that it is ambiguous

Sorry.  Been directing the comment at the wrong person. :-(

> I'm documenting some reasoning for one interpretation. You've
> said you disagree with it. I've asked why and you've told me that there=
 is
> some ambiguity. I already knew that.

I've tried to explain the why someone might prefer the other meaning
of a list macro: that Clipper is a compiler and the more one considers
it a compiler and less an interpreter then the more likely one would
go for the dBase way of handling a list macro.  (Just putting this in
to complete the context - I see you're aware of this. :-)

> > I was hoping for a response along the lines of "yes there are two but=

> > actually we should pick <whichever> because <reason> (e.g. because th=
at's
> > what a Clipper developer would expect)". Your response based on dBase=
 may
> > be what most Clipper developers would say (I don't know, but it seems=

> > plausible).

> IOW I gave you the response you desired a couple or so days ago?

Not sure when, but at some point yes.

> At no point should anyone see a code block as something that is in any =
way
> expanded, unlike a macro expanded/evaluated string.

Right.  I'm guessing that was what you were getting at when you used
the word "substitution".  My concern at that was with the fine detail
of just what is meant.  Ah, reading on I see more from you in a
moment...

> I take it that we'd agree that Clipper is more like an interpreter than=
 it
> is like a "true" compiler?

Yes.

> Moreover, many interpreters are compilers anyway.

Yes.  Clipper's in some ways a "fake" compiler in that it
(deliberately) makes OBJ files containing pcode.  For good reasons,
but it sort of "misled" some people who were then rather surprised
when things such as Valkyrie & Rescue appeared.

It's where and why Clipper and its macro feature are positioned on
this compiler-interpreter spectrum that may help decide whether a list
in a macro should be allowed and what it should mean.  I don't seem
to have convinced Ron that this even _is_ an issue. :-(  Whereas, I
understand your position. :-)

Apart from wanting Harbour Clipper-compatible by default, I'm not
entirely sure what my position is about what a list macro should do
when enabled.  Something sane/clean, properly doc'ed, etc. :-)

> I think the problem here might well be that macro expansion/evaluation
> is done using an operator instead of a function

Maybe.  I do agree that if it were a function (your example below)
> | cMacro :=3D "1, 2, 3"
> | SomeFunc( MacroEval( cMacro ) )
then a list in a macro should probably not be seen as 3 params.

> I think we're in agreement that it really all depends on if you
> see this:
> | cMacro :=3D "1, 2, 3"
> | SomeFunc( &cMacro )
> as something employing macro expansion or macro evaluation

Yes.  On the understanding that "expansion" is intended to mean (as I
believe you do mean) that it's akin to re-writing the source code,
then compiling the part concerned _including_ the surrounding context
(the SomeFunc() here).  It looks a workable and useful extension, if
it is meant to (and does!) work like that.  The C Standard defines
some things as needing to work "as if" done in a certain way.  Maybe
in Harbour "&" could be defined to be like Clipper by default but when
macro extensions are enabled it changes to being as if this kind of
text substitution were done.  Hmm... not quite, as then:
  LOCAL x :=3D 1
  cMacro :=3D "x"
  SomeFunc( &cMacro )
would be allowed.

I suppose this kind of trouble is the result of an attempt to be
interpreter and compiler.  It doesn't make an exact definition of "&"
any easier, though.

> (Clipper calls the operator the macro evaluation operator IIRC so
> there's some scope for backing up your interpretation there).

Sort of, though the Clipper doc. doesn't exactly define "evaluation"
fully. :-(

> If someone views the above as macro *expansion* then it seems only
> sensible that they see a function being passed three arguments. If,
> on the other hand, they see the above as macro *evaluation* they
> should probably expect it to throw an error.

Or that it should be like a code block, i.e. the commas are operators
which evaluate their left arg, discard the result, then evaluate the
right arg.  As Ryszard says, this would then mean that "&" was like
other operators in that it would produce a single value.  It feels a
bit non-dBase, though.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 15 12:40:22 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Wed Aug 15 11:40:22 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108151137_MC3-DC7C-6AB5@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> the only thing I'm puzzled by, and take offense to, is your
> claim that I'm forcing my opinion - why would you do that?

Because you've enabled this feature by default.  That's not what
should happen in Harbour - because it's supposed to be Clipper-
compatible.

> Should I claim you are trying to force your opinion just because
> you are requesting the removal or default disabling of this feature?

You could claim it but it would be contrary to the stated aim of the
Harbour project.

> "Forcing" is a very strong word

True.  Unilaterally overriding the stated aims of the Harbour project
can merit it.

> I'm just surprised you didn't respond to my defense to your claim
> of the list extension breaking code

We've gone round in circles on that.  I say it's ambigous, Dave says
it's ambiguous, you say it's not.  I see no point in continuing.

> and most specifically breaking the LIST command.

Others have said that.  AFAIK all I did was defer to them.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 15 12:59:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Wed Aug 15 11:59:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108151137_MC3-DC7C-6AB5@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKAEIEDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> Because you've enabled this feature by default.  That's not what
> should happen in Harbour - because it's supposed to be Clipper-
> compatible.

John numerous macro extensions that are non Clipper compatible are enabled
by default, and were enabled since the time the macro compiler was
developed. You claim that adding the list extension, I should have treated
it differently, or else I'm forcing my opinion? Why?

> > "Forcing" is a very strong word
>
> True.  Unilaterally overriding the stated aims of the Harbour project
> can merit it.

I think you know better then to paint it this way. The list extension is
*negligible* when compared to the other non Clipper compatible macro
extensions - all enabled by default.

To say that I'm disappointed with your offensive and unwarranted attitude
will be an under statement.

Ron

On Wed, Aug 15, 2001 at 11:37:01AM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > > I posted an example (where the caller wants a runtime error but
> > > instead the list macro is accepted). It's a simplistic example
> > > designed to show that the issue does exist.
> 
> > Like <URL:http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/#20010718092356> perhaps?
> 
> I thought/expected that was fixed (being the value left on the EVAL
> stack)?

Eh? Where does the eval stack come into this? The above URL points to a
harbour news article that reports me wondering if a side effect of list
expansion might be considered a bug. As far as I can tell the issue still
stands (in so much as nothing has changed and there's nothing about eval
stacks involved).

<URL:http://www.matrixlist.com/pipermail/harbour/2001-July/007413.html> is
the email that the about harbour news URL points to.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 15 14:49:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed Aug 15 13:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108151137_MC3-DC7C-6AB8@compuserve.com>; from John_Skelton@compuserve.com on Wed, Aug 15, 2001 at 11:37:04AM -0400
References: <200108151137_MC3-DC7C-6AB8@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <20010815182901.E1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Wed, Aug 15, 2001 at 11:37:04AM -0400, John Skelton wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > I'm documenting some reasoning for one interpretation. You've said you
> > disagree with it. I've asked why and you've told me that there is some
> > ambiguity. I already knew that.
> 
> I've tried to explain the why someone might prefer the other meaning of a
> list macro: that Clipper is a compiler and the more one considers it a
> compiler and less an interpreter then the more likely one would go for the
> dBase way of handling a list macro. (Just putting this in to complete the
> context - I see you're aware of this. :-)

"More likely"? I thought you were suggesting that it would be "less likely".

> > I think we're in agreement that it really all depends on if you
> > see this:
> > | cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
> > | SomeFunc( &cMacro )
> > as something employing macro expansion or macro evaluation
> 
> Yes. On the understanding that "expansion" is intended to mean (as I
> believe you do mean) that it's akin to re-writing the source code, then
> compiling the part concerned _including_ the surrounding context (the
> SomeFunc() here). [SNIP]

Another useful way of looking at it (to see where I'm coming from) is to see
a "splicing" operation happening at runtime (I hesitate to mention ",@" in
Lisp back-tick expansion but if you recognise it you'll know what I mean).

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 15 15:34:02 2001

References: <200108151137_MC3-DC7C-6AB4@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <003001c125b8$be6254d0$0205a8c0@apollo>

1. c

don't see the point in being compatible with Clipper in generating run-time
errors for macro cases that Clipper doesn't handle. Why would existing
Clipper code have such statements? The only argument for this would be that
you don't want things that work in Harbour, but then don't work in Clipper
(5.x) ..  Maybe throw a warning.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 16 03:42:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David Arturo Macias Corona)
Date: Thu Aug 16 02:42:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Memory not released
Message-ID: <3.0.6.16.20010816014047.1d878212@mail.udg.mx>

I send this message for second time, hoping that someone can pay attention
on it

Badly, many people on the Harbour group, once more time, are deeply within
another Ron's endless discussions, who is forcing, once again, his code in
his way in the Harbour behaviour

Of course, this is delaying and delaying and delaying .... an better
Harbour: Clipper compatible compiler
Remember those ephic discussions with Victor Sz..., and Flex vs Simplex,
and Inline C, and PP, and macro expansions, ... and ...

Seem that he not feel how the time is flowing; months, and years, and in
consecuence we have an slow advance
In the last one and a half years, we only see five releases: 0.33, 0.34,
0.35, 0.36, 0.37

Many developers are tired seeing how their efforts are quickly reduced, but
no one try to do actions, almost evident,  to redirect the ship

Who(s) could remedy this and lead safe to Harbour ?

Gracias,
David Macias



One Harbour  0.37/BCC55.1/Windows 2000/DBFNTX used to sum record values,
show many times:

TODO: hb_waSyncChildren()

before to show results

At exit of the program, is showed something like this:

Total memory allocated: 79052 bytes (2745 blocks)
WARNING! Memory allocated but not released: 400 bytes (10 blocks)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 1 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 2 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 3 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 4 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 5 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 6 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 7 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 8 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 9 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)
fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 10 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)

In others runs, show different number of lines (blocks)

Line SGBLOCK( 2966 ) is an code block creation:
bBloque := &("{ "+bBloque+" }")
where bBloque is an valid character expresion to create an code block,
including their | | characters

This error has been happening along differents versions of Harbour
(0.33,0.34,0.35, ...0.37) in Windows 98, OS/2, WIndows 2000 ...

Maurilio Longo reviewed something like this in OS/2 weeks ago. Ocurrs
mainly with creation and maybe evaluation of code blocks

Gracias,
David Macias


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 16 03:44:01 2001

Message-ID: <3.0.6.16.20010816014322.1ebf77bc@mail.udg.mx>

David Macias




This was reviewed many months ago, but I hope an silly solution based in
Clipper compatibility

I have many Clipper programs using DBSELECTAR( x ), and compile/link/run in
Clipper without problems

When I try in Harbour,  can not link because " Unresolved external
'_HB_FUN_DBSELECTAR' ", so I must change to DBSELECTAREA( x ) in order to
link. 

There are many programs to change
I think if DBSELECTAR(x) work with Clipper, should work with Harbour
without changes

The same happen with DBCLEARREL

And EVENTMASK is not recognized too

Gracias,
David Macias

compatible with CA-Clipper where fixing the bug wouldn't impact on harbour
users.

There's little point in being exactly bug-compatible.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 16 06:26:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alberto Rubinelli)
Date: Thu Aug 16 05:26:02 2001
Subject: R: [Harbour] DBSELECTAR(), DBCLEARREL()
In-Reply-To: <3.0.6.16.20010816014322.1ebf77bc@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <LLBBIKAMMCMELKOPIPANAEFEGIAA.alberto@a2sistemi.it>

> I have many Clipper programs using DBSELECTAR( x ), and
> compile/link/run in
> Clipper without problems
>
> When I try in Harbour,  can not link because " Unresolved external
> '_HB_FUN_DBSELECTAR' ", so I must change to DBSELECTAREA( x ) in order to
> link.
>
> There are many programs to change
> I think if DBSELECTAR(x) work with Clipper, should work with Harbour
> without changes

I think best thing to do is to replace all DBSELECTAR in all files, with a
utility, but I have solved with a little support function:

function DBSELECTAR (xParameter)
return (DBSelectArea (xParameter))

You can do the same for the other truncated function.

It is not the best solution, but it work :)

(Bourne's) sh was that the doc made clear what would happen. :-)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 16 12:27:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ron Pinkas)
Date: Thu Aug 16 11:27:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
In-Reply-To: <200108160959_MC3-DCAB-CC69@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <LOBBKAFMMFGJIKLMEPAKIEIMDPAA.Ron@Profit-Master.com>

John,

> > numerous macro extensions that are non Clipper compatible are enabled
> > by default
>
> That comes as a surprise to me.

How could it be a surprise? I mentioned it NUMEROUS times over these past
few days! Could it be that you argued without properly reading the posts you
argue against?

> Was a vote taken?  If not, who enabled them by default?

No Vote was not taken, and it was implemented by Ryszard. It's my guess that
had a vote been taken, it would have been approved, because many times it
was said that we do NOT have to be 100% ERROR COMPATIBLE with Clipper.

> > > > "Forcing" is a very strong word
> > >
> > > True.  Unilaterally overriding the stated aims of the Harbour project
> > > can merit it.
>
> > I think you know better then to paint it this way.
>
> You should know better than to write that.  I meant what I wrote.

Ok. :-(

> > The list extension is *negligible* when compared to the other
> > non Clipper compatible macro extensions - all enabled by default.
>
> I don't agree.

What don't you agree with?

The macro list expression support, is a separate issue from __dbList()
optimization, and will NEVER effect any code, other than code that raises a
Clipper ERROR!!!

If you dispute this, you will have to PROVE this with a code sample, that
runs in Clipper WITHOUT raising an ERROR, and yet is producing different
results in Harbour (related to list macro).

You are UNABLE to produce such sample code, because in Clipper ALL macros of
lists, generate an ERROR with the exception of when inside CodeBlocks, and
the list macro extension, does NOT affect lists in CodeBlocks!!!

Thus, the list support is only ERROR INCOMPATIBLE, exactly like:

   Var++
   ++Var
   Var--
   --Var
   Var += ...
   Var -= ...
   Var *= ...
   Var /= ...
   Var %= ...
   Var ^= ...
   Nested blocks, And many others.

If you dispute it being negligible, in light of the above all being
supported, please explain. Remember it does NOT affect any VALID Clipper
code!!!

> > To say that I'm disappointed with your offensive and
> unwarranted attitude
> > will be an under statement.
>
> What do you believe was offensive?

Let's not go in circles John, you know I'm offended by your claim that I'm
forcing my opinion on this project. It is offensive because it's FALSE! The
group has accepted, and supported, enhancements that are ERROR INCOMPATIBLE
with Clipper, long before you joined. Before deciding that I'm forcing my
opinion, you should have known your facts better, rather than hide behind:

   "That comes as a surprise to me."

BTW, just recently I implemented an extension to accommodate *your* need, in
that case you said:

   "Much better idea. :-)  It was really needed in Clipper but never added."

I wonder how would you have argued against someone objecting the
enhancement, claiming that it was not implemented by Nantucket for a GOOD
reason???

Ron

On 14 Aug 2001, at 17:11, Dave Pearson wrote:

> ,----
> | cMacro := "1, 2, 3"
> | Foo( &cMacro )
> `----
> 
> should result in FOO() being called with one argument. All I'm suggesting is
> that, if it doesn't simply result in a runtime error because the content of
> cMacro is invalid code (I think this is the better option) it should ideally
> result in a function call with three arguments.

  OK, all is clear now. I agree also that the runtime error should be the 
default behaviour because we havealready (as John pointed) support for 
such functionality (although with some limitations):

dummyVar :=&( "Foo(&cMacro)" )
or
dummyVar :=&( "Foo("+cMacro+")" )

Regards, Ryszard

LRCG> btw did you compiled with /DCAAD and /DANIRO.

 Yes, now I got it.
 This is caused by the presence of commands ( not pp directives ) in
 #include files. But this isn't pp error - these lines are
 preprocessed correctly:

 ...
         Scroll(06,01,20,78 ) ; SetPos(06,01 )
#line 1 "TTTTTF.CH"
         IF menu0000=1
#line 1 "GA.CH"
GA0000()
#line 3 "TTTTTF.CH"
         ELSEIF menu0000=2
...

   Compiler doesn't accept this. Ryszard ?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 16 17:01:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Robert Haley)
Date: Thu Aug 16 16:01:02 2001
Subject: EventMask info (was [Harbour] DBSELECTAR(), DBCLEARREL() )
Message-ID: <000701c1268e$55c3ee80$73befdd0@hooperholmes.com>

David,

>From "CA-Clipper 5.3 - Guide to CA-Clipper" Norton Guide, "Commands"
section.

HTH & Regards,
Bob

 SET EVENTMASK
 Specify events to be returned by the INKEY() function
--------------------------------------------------------
 Syntax

     SET EVENTMASK TO <nEventMask>

 Arguments

     <nEventMask> specifies which events should be returned by the
     INKEY() function.  This argument can be any combination of the
following
     values which are defined in Inkey.ch:

     Inkey Constants
--------------------------------------------------------
     Constant       Value     Description
--------------------------------------------------------
      INKEY_MOVE     1         Mouse Events
     INKEY_LDOWN    2         Mouse Left Click Down
     INKEY_LUP      4         Mouse Left Click Up
     INKEY_RDOWN    8         Mouse Right Click Down
     INKEY_RUP      16        Mouse Right Click Up
     INKEY_KEYBOARD 128       Keyboard Events
     INKEY_ALL      159       All Mouse and Keyboard Events
--------------------------------------------------------

     If a value is not specified for SET EVENTMASK, the default value of 128
     (keyboard events only) will be used.

 Description

     The SET EVENTMASK command specifies which events should be returned by
     the INKEY() function.  Using this mask you can have INKEY() return only
     the events in which you are interested.

 Example

     The following example will inform INKEY() to terminate if a keyboard
     event occurs or the left mouse button has been clicked.  If no events
     occur within 5 seconds, INKEY() will terminate.

        SET EVENTMASK TO INKEY_KEYBOARD + INKEY_LDOWN
        ? INKEY( 5 )

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 16 18:52:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Thu Aug 16 17:52:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtstd.c / gtstdtst.prg update for MSVC
Message-ID: <004801c1269d$941b1b90$0205a8c0@apollo>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0045_01C126A5.F4E03C00
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Added conditional functionality for MS C compiler to use io and conio libs
to map stdin in the same manner as already implemented for unix version
(i.e. no blocking).

That is, if stdin is coming from console, inkey() returns 0 if no key
waiting, and if stdin is coming from a file, inkey() returns each char of
file and then always returns 0 once EOF is reached.

Regards


Fergus McDonald
Qvolution Limited
http://www.qvolution.com


------=_NextPart_000_0045_01C126A5.F4E03C00
Content-Type: application/x-zip-compressed;
	name="gtstd122upd.zip"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
Content-Disposition: attachment;
	filename="gtstd122upd.zip"

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 17 00:29:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Robert Haley)
Date: Thu Aug 16 23:29:02 2001
Subject: EventMask info (was [Harbour] DBSELECTAR(), DBCLEARREL() )
Message-ID: <000701c126cc$e458e720$ddbdfdd0@hooperholmes.com>

David,

> 1) Would translations also be needed for DBSELECTARE,

DBCLEARRELA, DBCLEARRELAT, DBCLEARRELATI, and DBCLEARRELATIO?

These would all map to "DBCLEARREL", which in-turn could map to the (> 10
char) internal "HB_" function name.
( AFAIK this is how CA-Clipper treats "library" function names / handles
this item. )

>2) Are there any other Clipper built-in function names that exceed 10
characters?
A representative 5.3 list follows..  It may be incomplete, though.

Regards,
Bob

>From "Functions A-M" and "Functions N-Z",  Clipper 5.3 Guide to Clipper NG:
-------------------
BLOBROOTGET
BLOBROOTLOCK
BLOBROOTPUT
BLOBROOTUNLOC
COLORSELECT
DBCLOSEAREA
DBCOMMITALL
DBCREATEIND
DBFIELDINFO
DBORDERINFO
DBRECORDINFO
DBRLOCKLIST
DBSETDRIVER
DBSETFILTER
DBUNLOCKALL
FIELDWBLOCK
GETAPPLYKEY
GETDOSETKEY
GETPOSTVALID
GETPREVALID
MEMOSETSUPER
MEMVARBLOCK
ORDISUNIQUE
ORDKEYCOUNT
ORDLISTCLEAR
ORDLISTREBUI
ORDSETFOCUS
ORDSETRELAT
ORDSKIPUNIQUE
RDDSETDEFAULT
READUPDATED

* following are listed in the CA-Clipper 5.3 NG, although
if memory serves these names were changed by [CA] :
(as "BLOBDIRECT" equals (10) chars..)
---------------------
BLOBDIRECTEXP
BLOBDIRECTGET
BLOBDIRECTIMP
BLOBDIRECTPUT

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 17 09:05:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Fri Aug 17 08:05:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: ChangeLog 2001-08-04 15:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <200108170802_MC3-DCBF-F324@compuserve.com>

Ron,

> How could it be a surprise? I mentioned it NUMEROUS times over these pa=
st
> few days!

Sure.  It surprised me.

> Could it be that you argued without properly reading the posts you
> argue against?

That's always a possibility, though I try to read with care.  It
doesn't apply in this case.  As I've said, I wanted to stick to the
specific new list macro feature.

> It's my guess that had a vote been taken, it would have been
> approved, because many times it was said that we do NOT have to be
> 100% ERROR COMPATIBLE with Clipper.

But in some cases these extensions prevent being compatible with
Clipper in other cases.  It may well be that people are on the whole
happy with that but it bears thinking about.

> > > The list extension is *negligible* when compared to the other
> > > non Clipper compatible macro extensions - all enabled by default.
> >
> > I don't agree.

> What don't you agree with?

As to whether it's negligible.

> If you dispute this, you will have to PROVE this with a code sample, th=
at
> runs in Clipper WITHOUT raising an ERROR, and yet is producing differen=
t
> results in Harbour (related to list macro).

As has been said (by Dave IIRC), it can be valid in a Clipper app to
raise errors, catch them, and continue.  That was the situation in the
example I posted.

It's also the case for the LIST command (as Ryszard posted).

> you know I'm offended by your claim that I'm forcing my opinion on
> this project.

I don't mean to offend.  However, adding a feature that's not
compatible with Clipper and enabling it by default without any vote
or consensus is a form of forcing.

> The group has accepted, and supported, enhancements that are ERROR
> INCOMPATIBLE with Clipper

Right.  But this current feature doesn't appear to fit that
description.

> long before you joined.

I guess you mean during the time when I wasn't subscribed.  I found
I couldn't cope with the volume on top of my other commitments.  That
still occurs. :-(

> just recently I implemented an extension to accommodate *your* need, in=

> that case you said:
>   "Much better idea. :-)  It was really needed in Clipper but never add=
ed."

Yes.  It can't AFAIK break any existing code because it's an extra PP
marker and clipper.exe would just issue an error message.

> I wonder how would you have argued against someone objecting the
> enhancement, claiming that it was not implemented by Nantucket for a GO=
OD
> reason???

I'd have asked what problem(s) it could add.  Then taken it from there.

BTW, I'm happy for that debate at any future time - the marker can be
disabled by default without bothering me. :-)  It's presence actually
covers up that the Harbour PP behaves a little differently than
Clipper, which is not ideal.  OTOH, the difference is pretty obscure
and the extra marker let me re-write PP things in a way I'd have
preferred if Clipper had allowed it.  Fine by me, but it's true that
someone could object (now or later).  I think we should start a new
thread if this really is an issue.

John.

Hi,

latest code from cvs, dbu, OS/2 GCC emx.

Trying to open attached .dbf file from command line, that is:

> dbu atc.dbf

gives this error:

Exception c0000005 at address 30629
Called from TBROWSE:_NCOLSWIDTH
Called from TBROWSE:NEW(236)
Called from TBROWSENEW(1203)
Called from TBROWSEDB(57)
Called from BROWSE(98)

Process terminated by SIGSEGV
SYS1808:
Il processo è terminato. Il codice per la diagnostica
software (codice dell'errore) è  0005.

But if I start dbu and then open the file everything is ok. I think
something inside rdd is corrupting memory.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 17 13:08:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Aug 17 12:08:02 2001
Subject: EventMask info (was [Harbour] DBSELECTAR(), DBCLEARREL() )
In-Reply-To: <000701c126cc$e458e720$ddbdfdd0@hooperholmes.com>
References: <000701c126cc$e458e720$ddbdfdd0@hooperholmes.com>
Message-ID: <200108171207.0000014G@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Robert Haley" <rhaley@cheshire.net> on Thu,
16 Aug 2001 23:29:57 -0400

It has been pointed out to me that the "problem" with function
identifiers that are longer than 10 characters is a "known problem" that
has two existing solutions:

1) Build Harbour with HB_C52_STRICT set.
2) Build Harbour with HB_SYMBOL_NAME_LEN set to 10.

And that adding all those extra mappings to Harbour would be a wrong
solution. However, if somebody wants to add a contrib module (or series
of modules) that map the 10 to actual length - 1 variations to the
appropriate long function names (either as functions or as
translations), then that would be fine.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

> DP> you intending to use some sort of free software or OpenSource licence or
> DP> will this be non-free software?
> 
>  It will be free, with sources available, with possibility to use it in
>  commercial applications( with mention of this library and its author, or
>  authors, if there will be other participants ).

Thanks for the info. I take it that when you say it will be free you mean
free of cost, not free as in the FSF's definition of free?

>                                                             The only thing
>  that I want to prevent - is using its code in other libraries without my
>  permission. 

Note that this does mean that the library won't be free software. Free
software would allow this (see harbour's libraries for example). Actually, I
suspect that such a requirement would meant hat it doesn't qualify as Open
Source software either (see item three of the Open Source Definition
<URL:http://www.opensource.org/docs/definition.html>).

Not that this is a problem or anything, I just thought I'd point it out in
case you did want to be at least OSD compliant.

>              Can I write the license text in few simple sentences, without
>  using some standard types of license ?

Possibly, depending on what you want to say. You're the copyright holder of
the code so you can write any licence you wish.

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/
