From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 17 15:31:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Ryszard Glab)
Date: Fri Aug 17 14:31:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-17 20:15 UTC+0100
Message-ID: <3B7D8057.17091.99D2BB@localhost>

    *doc/en/compiler.txt
    *source/compiler/hbusage.c
        *updated to keep current state of compiler switches
        
    *include/hbexprc.c
        *fixed support for "&macro" syntax (macro was not expanded in
        cases: "&macro.&(macro)"
        
    *include/hbapi.h
    *include/hbexprb.c
    *source/vm/hvm.c
    *source/vm/macro.c
        *optimized support for compile time switches synchronization

    *source/compiler/harbour.y
        *fixed support for #line directive

Regards, Ryszard

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 17 17:15:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Aug 17 16:15:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-17 16:10 UTC-0400 David G. Holm
Message-ID: <200108171613.0000014M@Internet>

2001-08-17 16:10 UTC-0400 David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com>

  Update from "Fergus McDonald" <listsub@qvolution.com>:

  * source/rtl/gtstd/gtstd.c
  * tests/gtstdtst.c
    + Added conditional functionality for MS C compiler to use io and
      conio libs to map stdin in the same manner as already implemented
      for unix version (i.e. no blocking). That is, if stdin is coming
      from console, inkey() returns 0 if no key waiting, and if stdin is
      coming from a file, inkey() returns each char of file and then
      always returns 0 once EOF is reached.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 17 17:18:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Aug 17 16:18:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtstd.c / gtstdtst.prg update for MSVC
In-Reply-To: <004801c1269d$941b1b90$0205a8c0@apollo>
References: <004801c1269d$941b1b90$0205a8c0@apollo>
Message-ID: <200108171617.0000014O@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Fergus McDonald" <listsub@qvolution.com> on
Thu, 16 Aug 2001 22:51:16 +0100

There is a problem with end-of-line wrapping. If you subtract out the
"> " below, then you have the output that I got with RSXNT with GTSTD, which inserted a blank line when wrapping the long string. (I copied gtstdtst.prg to another file and then stripped out everything but the code for this test, to confirm that the problem isn't an end-of-page problem).

> Testing long string via QOUT. 50 characters follow here: 98765432109876543210987
> 
> 654321098765432109876543210
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 17 21:30:04 2001

First, thanks to David G. Holm and Robert Haley, who are trying to fix
EVENTMASK, DBSELECTAR(), DBCLEARREL() and others things that I requested to
acommodate Harbour, without "talking" unnecesarily

Next, an reply to  "Mark W. Schumann", which seem to be who less understand
the sense of my messages, and he could not see behind the "talks" the
"help" to improve Harbour and disolve an another bad Harbour's time.
Obviously the group can return to those days of "Crew photos", "Harbour
T-Shirts", voting and friendly cooperation, and not merged in disputes. As
LInares said: "hipocresia" in now common, and many see that, but ignore to
take actions. Who are within the confution, not can see this confution

To John Skelton: You are right, English is not my first language and is
evident. The only of my English learning was in Secondary School (age
11-13) and most of us have troubles to express ideas in the language of
"The Land of Free", who have many walls build between US and Mexico and
consider others cultures as childs of an "Minor God". (Eso lo resume bien
una vieja cancion de Mecano)

Mi idioma es el castellano, la lengua de Cervantes, Sor Juana Ines de la
Cruz, Garcia Marquez, Octavio Paz y muchos otros que han mostrado que este
lenguaje es una delicia para hablarlo y escucharlo. Como ejemplos estan las
prosas y las metricas castellanas usadas en la enorme variedad de estilos
poeticos, su manejo de tiempos, etc. En fin, un lenguaje muy vasto. Eso me
hace sentirme muy ufano y satisfecho de usar y entender el castellano
Sadly, we have to translate ideas in a poor way to an poor and short
language as English. Is an practical, but short language who limits the
significance of many ideas

And now, Ron, again Ron, he is the center of attention again. In the list
of endless discussions I forget "Strong typing" and "lower file extensions"

About Ron, do not take care in excess, the menace to leave is just one more
of his typical behaviour
When I see his message, I thinked "yes, is a good movement (for him), wait
a little time to see the reactions". And the reactions were as he and I
expected, as in other Ron's menaces: an massive and strong support that
make forget the causes and let do what he is proposing
This was one of his most short messages, but with more impact, as he expected

Here in my place is what we call "an inverse psychology movement" (un
movimiento de psicologia inversa), which consist in simulate something to
cause exactly the opposite. In other words, menace suicide to get something
O en castellano: amenaza de suicidio para lograr un capricho

This is an typical movement and Ron has used it others times. Other time he
offered: "someone remove my access to CVS and someone include my work only
after has reviewed it". Of course, that was discarted

This movement cause an "common enemy" (even imaginary) and an strong
support, as we expected. Even Antonio Linares, who "think" to "hate" Ron,
react "protecting" (?) him. Protecting of what, or who ? Yes, does not
exist "the enemy", is just suggested and "clearly founded" by someone, but
this causes that many people forget the reasons of my messages

If the decision of Ron is formal, he can do it, without trying to involve
others, as he tryied. Does not need to be "removed", just not continue
accesing, but simulate the need "of removing for someone else", letting
them the "dirty job". Obviously, no one want to do this dirty job, as he
know. This is hipocresy

So, Ron, my friend, take it easy and let it be. Relax. Many places, and
even your home, are proper to rest, as in examples Puerto Vallarta, Cancun,
Acapulco, Puerto Angel, (we are now in Summer, as you) ... even Spain and
Brasil are good places

As all can see in my messages, no one even suggest that Ron need to be
removed, just he used this excuse
In his "closed mind", "hard head", or as you can name it, he only want see:
"Yes or Not", "All or Nothing", "Full or Empty", "Strong typing or bad
Harbour",  "Simplex or bad Harbour", "Macro expansions or bad Harbour", and
so on, as result, endless discussions that delay all the group, and at
last, his code in his way in Harbour: For those who does not want to see
it, this is "forcing" and some else like it

This is an very simple way of life, and very easily to live: just one of
two ways, and as result only my way. Is not bad, but affect others oftenly

As Ron and we know, he has many options:
- Ignore his menace and continue working, (and playing, sadly), "with
Harbour group", just until now is happening, including code and "pushing"
and forcing to be accepted by the group, in his way
- Apply his menace, but remove itself (just not contributing). I do not
like that, as all we know, because an creator not must be stopped, but
sometimes need to be redirected
- Contribute, but ASK to others. This is very difficult to him, and maybe
imposible, as he think
- Contribute, but let to others include to CVS(?) his work after evaluating
- Voting (is still used ?) about the direction of the contributions
- Relax an short or medium  time, stop contributing, and just seeing how
Harbour is moving. Maybe Harbour could get more movement and Clipper
compatibility
- Continue applyng changes to Harbour, but in "your own Harbour project
that does not affect Clipper compatabilities". Yes, use Harbour core and
improve it for your own uses, where "Clipper compatibility" has not care.
Of course, this is valid, is your work. Obviously, soon or later you will
be sharing your work with others.
As examples, some use Harbour with, ADS; other with MySQL, etc, for own
uses, but no one affect Clipper compatibility
- Stop as Harbour code developer, and just use your high abilities as "beta
tester", now in Harbour tests
- Contribute with ideas, but in the Harbour group direction

As you can see, Ron, the world is not closed as you sense it and are many
options there

What is suggested is just an "little big change in your mind" that help
Harbour group in an more productive way for all. This little big changes in
mind are very easy to do, we only need to do it, just it. You, your family
and other will be glad with it (yes, I know that you are SURE that your
actual way is the only valid). As in other time, I just tell to you: think
on it

Anyway, with any decision that he choose, he will have my support, and so
maybe we will get an better "Ron Pinkas"
This is because no one have the rights to force anyone to some decision, is
his right. What we could is use our experience to help

For all of you who do not understand at first time the reasons of my
message, I include it again to let them think on it:
"Clipper users and developers want to take an Clipper native source code
file and compile and run it with Harbour, without the need of changes of
code or settings by defaults"
Some contribution of Ron, as he know but do not want to recognize in
public, affect this and delay the entire project

In other case, I am glad with the notice of  "Alexander S.Kresin", about an
"GUI library". I hope not this limited it to Win32

Sorry for my english, in Spanish I use to do it better oftenly

Gracias,
David Macias

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug 18 00:28:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Eric Kiernan)
Date: Fri Aug 17 23:28:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Memory not released
In-Reply-To: <3.0.6.16.20010817204153.1f879732@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <NFBBJKJHGLHIPPBHGOLCKECACFAA.erickiernan@home.com>

I am a "lurker", an experienced Clipper developer, and I have watched many
of these things go back and forth.  I have a few observations over Ron
quitting.  First, I think that most of the developers have said it
correctly, that they don't want Ron to leave.  I think that the nature of
programming in a team is that sometimes people will butt heads.  I have done
it enough, myself, and, tomorrow, I am going to a party hosted by someone
whose relationship to me could be described as "Antonio vs. Ron".  We
actually like each other.  We disagree strongly at times.  We have said
harsh things.

I think that Ron said that he was quitting, because it just isn't worth it
to him anymore to be bashed like this.  I don't think there is a game here.
Even if there is, who cares.  He contributes ( apparently ), good code.  I
think we all need to realize, including the developers, that you can have
very strong, heated opinions, but that is what it is ( and from the recent
msgs, the developers do).  I'm not saying that the person who wrote the orig
msg about Ron and his many heated battles over time with various peoples was
"completely" wrong, I'm just saying that maybe it is because he cares about
the project.  If he is difficult, well hell, we all are.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug 18 04:03:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Sat Aug 18 03:03:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] First procedure
In-Reply-To: <LLBBIKAMMCMELKOPIPANKEGFGIAA.alberto@a2sistemi.it>
Message-ID: <001101c127b3$6b607f80$0f2aa8c0@first>

Alberto,

> Normally is the first file linked, but in this 
> case is the startup file c0w32.
> There is another way to set initial procedure ?

c0w32.obj is the startup, which means that is the
code that is executed just before the application
really starts, so it will _not_ replace or affect
your initial procedure.


Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug 18 07:34:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Fergus McDonald)
Date: Sat Aug 18 06:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] gtstd.c / gtstdtst.prg update for MSVC
References: <004801c1269d$941b1b90$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108171617.0000014O@Internet>
Message-ID: <004b01c127d1$40174700$0205a8c0@apollo>

Firstly, thanks for the check-ins and the tests David.

I am aware of the newline in the long string.. that's actually what I was
trying to demonstrate in the test program. As I see it, it's correct
behaviour.
It's caused by the gtapi, in deference to the 80 column terminal width.

>From the point of view that gtstd is after all a video driver sub-system,
trying to have absolutely no impact on the text output I think is
probably futile. Newline characters are not directly passed from something
like a QOUT() function (a 'programmer intended' newline) to the gtstd driver
itself - instead the gtapi calls the driver to write pieces of visible text
at certain cursor positions, and requests cursor repositioning at a new
line.
The gtstd driver has to guess that a newline is required based on the cursor
repositioning requests. The same thing happens with wrapping. The gtstd
driver can't tell the difference.

At the same time, I can see the problem in the case of trying to write
unix-style command line utilities (like 'tr' for example) that should have
clean stdin/stdout redirection. That clearly will not work as there is bound
to be newlines/spaces inserted into the output stream in sympathy with the
logical cursor.

If I wanted raw stdout in Clipper, I usually wrote to the handle directly
with fwrite() or whatever. It wasn't possible via any of the standard
terminal
drivers, so from a compatibility point of view, I don't think it would be
much of an issue.

Anyway, I await comments with interest :)

Regards

Fergus

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug 18 17:41:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sat Aug 18 16:41:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] compiler warnings
Message-ID: <156750301376.20010818134911@abacuslaw.com>

 The default setup for the Borland compiler yields this warning in
 Harbour api C code if a variable is initialized but then assigned a
 new value the first time it is used:
 
 Warning W8004 bitflags.c 134: 'FlagString' is assigned a value that is never used

 My C training long ago was to always initialize all values. Is this
 now out of style?  Is the appropriate fix for a clean compile:
 a) remove the initialization
 b) tell the compiler to ignore that warning
 c) live with the uncleanliness

 ??
 
 ---====---
 Brian Hays

> Warning W8004 bitflags.c 134: 'FlagString' is assigned a value

Subject: [Harbour] gtstd.c / gtstdtst.prg update for MSVC
References: <004801c1269d$941b1b90$0205a8c0@apollo> <200108171617.0000014O@Internet>
Message-ID: <002c01c12831$cd2977c0$0205a8c0@apollo>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0029_01C1283A.2E48C620
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Fixed newline insertion during wrap past last logical column. gtstd assumes
output is 80-column width and auto-wrap.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 19 03:32:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun Aug 19 02:32:03 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] compiler warnings
In-Reply-To: <000a01c12828$64ec5fa0$0f2aa8c0@first>
References: <000a01c12828$64ec5fa0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <21785723941.20010818233934@abacuslaw.com>

Antonio:



>> Warning W8004 bitflags.c 134: 'FlagString' is assigned a value
>> that is never used

>>  a) remove the initialization

AL> Yes. The compiler is warning you that initialization
AL> value never gets used, so why to do it ? 
AL> Antonio
 In the good old days, the idea was that pointers (in particular)
 should always be initialized to NULL so random memory locations
 wouldn't get accessed.  It was taught as a "good habit" at least when
 starting code. Sometimes a branch in the logic gets added or removed
 that changes whether the initialized value gets used.

 In a lot of the coding i've done for Harbour, I am modifying other
 people's code more than starting any from scratch. So I hesitate to
 change code that was clearly done from one "school of thought" before
 verifying the current standards for this project.  Thanks for the
 input.
 
 ---====---
 Brian Hays

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 19 04:50:08 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun Aug 19 03:50:08 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re:  Memory not released
In-Reply-To: <3.0.6.16.20010817192912.1d3f4f8a@mail.udg.mx>
References: <3.0.6.16.20010817192912.1d3f4f8a@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <68790411571.20010819005741@abacuslaw.com>

David Macias:

  You made some very important observations about Ron's interactions
  with people on this project. But you left out too many things for me
  to let you say what you did without comment.  You have grossly
  oversimplified things to imply it was all Ron's fault.
  You have no right to lay it all at his feet as if he created all
  the tense energy alone.  Surely there's a saying in Spanish similar
  to "it takes two to Tango"?

  If you want to recite all the topics of the past year that you didn't
  like reading about in the list, then your sense of philosophy should
  require you to review the ChangeLogs.  Do you have ANY idea how many
  times someone reported a problem--anywhere from a superficial bug to
  a major hole in processing--and NO ONE else responded?
  Ron fixed HUNDREDS of things for people like yourself when no one
  else would take the time to help.

  This last macro issue started as one such topic--he was "fixing" an
  issue that someone raised. OK, some other developers questioned his
  method, and he tried to explain a complex technical issue in his own
  way that is antagonistic with the other players involved.
  The fact is, if anyone else had offered that code, it would have
  been received differently. Ponder this, please.
  The fact is, Harbour is NOT error-compatible with Clipper in MANY
  places. Ron tried to explain many times that, within the macro code,
  Harbour is NOT error-compatible with Clipper because of other
  enhancements done by others.  Yet he got drilled with critiques
  because his code helping a very unusual case wasn't either.

  It is terribly unfortunate that his communication style clashed with
  others. This wasn't all his fault. It is terribly unfortunate, IMHO,
  that he couldn't ever let go of something for the sake of keeping
  the peace.  This *is* his fault -- though some see it as a virtue.

  So perhaps it is best he work independently now.  But if you are
  going to step in and write an epitaph for a man's work, you can't
  just write about the dirty laundry.  Every time you deliver an app
  using Harbour, it will be using more of his code than you know.
  Until you check those ChangeLogs.
  
  ---====---
  Brian Hays

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 19 08:18:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David Arturo Macias Corona)
Date: Sun Aug 19 07:18:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: DBSELECTAR(), DBCLEARREL() )
In-Reply-To: <200108181600.f7IG0kn12045@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <3.0.6.16.20010819061639.1d5fa610@mail.udg.mx>

>From: "David G. Holm" <dholm@jsd-llc.com>
>Subject: Re: EventMask info (was [Harbour] DBSELECTAR(), DBCLEARREL() )
>Reply-To: harbour@matrixlist.com
>
>** Reply to message from "Robert Haley" <rhaley@cheshire.net> on Thu,
>16 Aug 2001 23:29:57 -0400
>
>It has been pointed out to me that the "problem" with function
>identifiers that are longer than 10 characters is a "known problem" that
>has two existing solutions:
>
>1) Build Harbour with HB_C52_STRICT set.
>2) Build Harbour with HB_SYMBOL_NAME_LEN set to 10.
>
>And that adding all those extra mappings to Harbour would be a wrong
>solution. However, if somebody wants to add a contrib module (or series
>of modules) that map the 10 to actual length - 1 variations to the
>appropriate long function names (either as functions or as
>translations), then that would be fine.

Maybe with an reduced approach will be suffcient, and not for (length-1)
variations

If I use 
REQUEST DBRLOCKLIS, DBSETDRIV, DBSETFILTE ....
and so on (note, I use 10 characters in many of them), compiling/linking
with Harbour 0.37/OS/2/gcc/BLD.CMD I get:

e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_DBRLOCKLIS referenced from
data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_DBSETDRIVE referenced from
data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_DBSETFILTE referenced from
data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_DBSETRELAT referenced from
data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_GETPOSTVALID referenced
from data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_GETPREVALID referenced from
data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_MEMOSETSUP referenced from
data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_MENUMODAL referenced from
data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_ORDLISTREB referenced from
data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_ORDSETRELA referenced from
data segment
e:\tcpip\tmp\cca00083: Undefined symbol _HB_FUN_ORDLISTCLE referenced from
data segment

There are many more functions with name longer than 10 char but truncated
to 10

I do not when, where and how ocurr in Clipper the truncation to 10
characters maximum in function's names

My sugest  in an intermediate point between:
>1) Build Harbour with HB_C52_STRICT set.
>2) Build Harbour with HB_SYMBOL_NAME_LEN set to 10.

consisting in:
a) Apply an limit of 10 characters to all the functions which belong to
"native Clipper" (Clipper.lib, Extend.lib, Terminal.lib, Dbfntx.lib, ..... )
b) Do not apply an limit of 10 characters to all the function that does not
belong to "native Clipper", like extensions in Harbour, third party
libraries, UDF, and so on

An pseudo code can be:
- Take the name of the funcion ---> cFunc := "Function1234567890"
- Verify if this function name truncated to 10 chars belong to "native
Clipper".
  To verify this can refer to an list with functions names of "native
Clipper" limited to 10 chars
     some like:  LEFT( cFunc, 10 ) contained in list names limited to 10
chars. This make unnecesary to check for all variations for the name
     The list can be some like the "RESERVED NAMES in Clipper"
  + Yes:   Apply  an limit to 10 characters  "Function1234567890"  ->
"Function12"  truncated to 10   (cFunc:=LEFT(cFunc,10))
  + No:   Do not limit   "Function1234567890" to 10 char
- Apply reference to Harbour cFunc:="_HB_FUN_"+cFunc

Obviously, in the libraries for Harbour the functions name for "native
Clipper" functions will have the form: "_HB_FUN_"+(function name limited to
10)
As example:  _HB_FUN_DBSELECTAR in place of  _HB_FUN_DBSELECTAREA

With this approach, we can manage legacy Clipper source code with 10 or
more chars in Clipper function name (like
DBSELECTAR(),DBSELECTARE(),DBSELECTAREA(), because is truncating to 10 as
Clipper do), and "new" Harbour code not belonging to Clipper with more than
10 char (if the programmer wish to use it), and in consecuence not limiting
the new posibilities opened by Harbour (function names longer than 10 chars).
In the last point, when an programmer compile in Clipper, an Harbour code
with functions names not belonging to "native Clipper", must consider that
those functions names with be truncated to 10 chars BY Clipper, as do with
all functions

Where should be applied this approach ? I do not know. Maybe in the same
place when the function name is converted to "_HB_FUN_"+function. I think
is an good place

I include an list of  ALL the functions listed in Clipper 5.3 Norton Guide
This list can be consider as the "native Clipper" functions, plus others
not included in NG, as example ISDISK()
Note that this is not valid for functions in Extend.lib and maybe others,
but cover allmost the functions that an "typical"  Clipper programmer use

Gracias,
David Macias

REQUEST AADD,ABS,ACHOICE,ACLONE,ACOPY,ADEL,ADIR,AEVAL,AFIELDS,AFILL,AINS, ;
 ALERT,ALIAS,ALLTRIM,ALTD,ARRAY,ASC,ASCAN,ASIZE,ASORT,AT
REQUEST ATAIL,BIN2I,BIN2L,BIN2W
// REQUEST BLOBDIRECTEXP,BLOBDIRECTGET,BLOBDIRECTIMP, 
//  BLOBDIRECTPUT,BLOBEXPORT,BLOBGET,BLOBIMPORT,BLOBROOTGET,BLOBROOTLOCK, ;
//  BLOBROOTPUT, BLOBROOTUNLOC
REQUEST BOF,BREAK,BROWSE,CDOW,CHR,CMONTH
REQUEST COL,COLORSELECT,CTOD,CURDIR,DATE,DAY,DBAPPEND

REQUEST DBCLEARFIL,DBCLEARIND,DBCLEARREL,DBCREATEIN

REQUEST DBCLOSEALL,DBCLOSEAREA,DBCOMMIT,DBCOMMITALL,DBCREATE,DBDELETE, ;
 DBEDIT,DBEVAL,DBF,DBFIELDINFO
REQUEST DBFILEGET,DBFILEPUT,DBFILTER,DBGOBOTTOM,DBGOTO,DBGOTOP,DBINFO, ;
 DBORDERINFO,DBRECALL,DBRECORDINFO,DBREINDEX

REQUEST DBRELATION,DBRSELECT

REQUEST DBSELECTAR
REQUEST DBRLOCK,DBRLOCKLIS,DBRUNLOCK,DBSEEK,DBSETDRIVE, ;
 DBSETFILTE,DBSETINDEX

//REQUEST DBSETRELAT,DIRMAKE
REQUEST DBSETRELAT

REQUEST DBSETORDER,DBSKIP,DBSTRUCT,DBUNLOCK,DBUNLOCKALL, ;

 DIRREMOVE,DISKCHANGE,DISKNAME,DISKSPACE,DISPBEGIN,DISPBOX
REQUEST DISPCOUNT,DISPEND,DISPOUT,DOSERROR,DOW,DTOC,DTOS,EMPTY,EOF, ;
 ERRORBLOCK,ERRORLEVEL,EVAL,EXP,FCLOSE,FCOUNT,FCREATE,FERASE,FERROR, ;
 FIELDBLOCK,FIELDGET,FIELDNAME
REQUEST FIELDPOS,FIELDPUT,FIELDWBLOCK,FILE,FKLABEL,FKMAX,FLOCK,FOPEN,FOUND,;
 FREAD,FREADSTR,FRENAME,FSEEK,FWRITE
// REQUEST GBMPDISP,GBMPLOAD,GELLIPSE
REQUEST GETACTIVE,GETAPPLYKEY,GETDOSETKEY,GETENV
// REQUEST GETPOSTVALID,GETPREVALID,GFNTERASE

REQUEST GETPOSTVALID,GETPREVALID

// REQUEST GFNTLOAD,GFNTSET,GFRAME,GGETPIXEL,GLINE,GMODE,GPOLYGON,GPUTPIXEL, ;
//  GRECT,GSETCLIP,GSETEXCL,GSETPAL,GWRITEAT
REQUEST GETREADER,HARDCR,HEADER,I2BIN 
// REQUEST IF, IIF

 LUPDATE

REQUEST MEMOSETSUP,MENUMODAL

REQUEST MAX,MAXCOL,MAXROW,MCOL,MDBLCLK,MEMOEDIT,MEMOLINE,MEMOREAD,MEMORY, ;
 MEMOTRAN,MEMOWRIT,MEMVARBLOCK,MHIDE,MIN,MLCOUNT, ;
 MLCTOPOS,MLEFTDOWN,MLPOS
// REQUEST MSETCLIP,MSTATE
REQUEST MOD,MONTH,MPOSTOLC,MPRESENT,MRESTSTATE,MRIGHTDOWN,MROW,MSAVESTATE, ;
 MSETBOUNDS,MSETCURSOR,MSETPOS,MSHOW
REQUEST
NETERR,NETNAME,NEXTKEY,NOSNOW,ORDBAGEXT,ORDBAGNAME,ORDCOND,ORDCONDSET, ;
 ORDCREATE,ORDDESCEND,ORDDESTROY,ORDFOR,ORDISUNIQUE,ORDKEY,ORDKEYADD, ;
 ORDKEYCOUNT,ORDKEYDEL,ORDKEYGOTO,ORDKEYNO,ORDKEYVAL,ORDLISTADD

REQUEST ORDLISTREB,ORDSETRELA

REQUEST ORDLISTCLE

REQUEST ORDNAME,ORDNUMBER,ORDSCOPE,ORDSETFOCUS, ;
 ORDSKIPUNIQUE,OS,OUTERR,OUTSTD,PAD,PCOL,PCOUNT,PROCLINE, ;
 PROCNAME,PROW,QOUT,RAT,RDDLIST,RDDNAME
REQUEST RDDSETDEFAULT,READEXIT,READFORMAT,READINSERT,READKEY,READKILL, ;
 READMODAL,READUPDATED,READVAR,RECCOUNT,RECNO,RECSIZE,REPLICATE,RESTSCREEN, ;
 RIGHT,RLOCK,ROUND,ROW,RTRIM,SAVESCREEN,SCROLL
REQUEST SECONDS,SELECT,SET,SETBLINK,SETCANCEL,SETCOLOR,SETCURSOR,SETKEY, ;
 SETMODE,SETPOS,SETPRC,SOUNDEX,SPACE,SQRT,STR,STRTRAN,STUFF,SUBSTR,TIME, ;
 TONE,TRANSFORM
REQUEST TRIM,TYPE,UPDATED,UPPER,USED,VAL,VALTYPE,VERSION,WORD,YEAR

> David Macias:

>   You made some very important observations about Ron's interactions

>   oversimplified things to imply it was all Ron's fault.
>   You have no right to lay it all at his feet as if he created all
>   the tense energy alone.  Surely there's a saying in Spanish similar
>   to "it takes two to Tango"?
>
>   If you want to recite all the topics of the past year that you didn't
>   like reading about in the list, then your sense of philosophy should
>   require you to review the ChangeLogs.  Do you have ANY idea how many
>   times someone reported a problem--anywhere from a superficial bug to
>   a major hole in processing--and NO ONE else responded?
>   Ron fixed HUNDREDS of things for people like yourself when no one
>   else would take the time to help.
>
>   This last macro issue started as one such topic--he was "fixing" an
>   issue that someone raised. OK, some other developers questioned his
>   method, and he tried to explain a complex technical issue in his own
>   way that is antagonistic with the other players involved.
>   The fact is, if anyone else had offered that code, it would have
>   been received differently. Ponder this, please.
>   The fact is, Harbour is NOT error-compatible with Clipper in MANY
>   places. Ron tried to explain many times that, within the macro code,
>   Harbour is NOT error-compatible with Clipper because of other
>   enhancements done by others.  Yet he got drilled with critiques
>   because his code helping a very unusual case wasn't either.
>
>   It is terribly unfortunate that his communication style clashed with
>   others. This wasn't all his fault. It is terribly unfortunate, IMHO,
>   that he couldn't ever let go of something for the sake of keeping
>   the peace.  This *is* his fault -- though some see it as a virtue.
>
>   So perhaps it is best he work independently now.  But if you are
>   going to step in and write an epitaph for a man's work, you can't
>   just write about the dirty laundry.  Every time you deliver an app
>   using Harbour, it will be using more of his code than you know.
>   Until you check those ChangeLogs.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 19 18:07:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (JF Lefebvre)
Date: Sun Aug 19 17:07:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Compiler error  on & character !!!
In-Reply-To: <01081916445505.21628@gizmo.the-oasis.net>
Message-ID: <3B8046A8.24446.DB9DD5@localhost>

Hi All,

I finally finished my modification about ::Super(::nX) as 
::Super:classname() wich was not returning the superclassname. (I 
will publish it in the next ours.

During my last test this WE, I discovered a GPF compiling certain 
test code wich where correctly compiled one or two weeks ago.

I finally reduced it to a very small prg of 3 lines.

/* This program will cause Harbour to GPF at compile time */
function main
Local a := Local a := { "&a", "Ch" }

return nil

/* But this one will compile correctly */
function main
Local a := Local a := { "a", "Ch" }
return nil

/* and now ... even more misterious ... this one appear also to 
compile */
function main
Local a := Local a := { "&a", "ab" }
return nil

In fact only the sequence where the first string contain at least two 
char wich the first equal to & and the second string _MUST_ begin 
wich Ch to cause the error.

This code was compiling I think two weeks ago.
The problem is the same either with Flex or Simplex version. I 
cleaned all my modifs and redo the test with the same result, (so 
it's not my code ;-)) )

Anyone any idea ?

Best regards,

J. Lefebvre,
Bruxelles,
Belgium

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 19 20:30:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes)
Date: Sun Aug 19 19:30:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] First procedure
References: <LLBBIKAMMCMELKOPIPANGEHGGIAA.alberto@a2sistemi.it>
Message-ID: <003001c12905$e2d268a0$f4d4d7c8@culik>

Alberto

> the first file linked is the startup code c0w32, after there are the
others
> file.
Now i got your point
> I think initial procedure is the first procedure of the first obj linked.

Harbour process the symbols in the follow way.
First all init procedures and functions.
If your app has an Main() function then this is the follow function that is
processed (the main function can be defined on the first file linked , or
any other that is in the link script)
Otherwise. the initial procedure processed is the first procedure/function
of the first obj linked.

 --

Regards

Luiz Rafael Culik

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 03:18:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 20 02:18:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Compiler error on & character !!!
In-Reply-To: <01081921495100.22583@gizmo.the-oasis.net>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Sun, Aug 19, 2001 at 09:49:51PM -0400
References: <000201c12919$3e1d18a0$0f2aa8c0@first> <01081921495100.22583@gizmo.the-oasis.net>
Message-ID: <20010820071719.O1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Sun, Aug 19, 2001 at 09:49:51PM -0400, Phil Barnett wrote:
> On Sunday 19 August 2001 21:41, you wrote:
>
> > If Ron is leaving Harbour (we don't know it yet for sure) we may
> > consider to drop the simplex version, unless someone may be able to
> > continue his simplex work...
> 
> Is there something wrong with it?
> 
> If the criteria that we drop a contribution is that the contributor
> leaves, then we have a whole lot more than Simplex to worry about.

I think Antonio's concern here was onward development and upkeep. SimpLex is
in a pretty unique position of being a (and I don't mean this in a negative
way) redundant body of code within harbour. If the author of that code no
longer wishes to work on harbour and if nobody else is able or willing to
look after that body of code there's a danger that it'll fall behind the
Flex code. We'd then be in danger of having two internal versions of the
compiler that are very different.

Antonio's concern might be premature, but it seems well founded.

-- 
Harbour is a free   | Harbour Web Site: http://www.harbour-project.org/
software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 04:50:25 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 20 03:50:25 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: [HarbourTalk] Class syntax help
In-Reply-To: <004a01c128e6$77992980$93b472c3@map>; from paliwoda@inetia.pl on Sun, Aug 19, 2001 at 09:36:15PM +0200
References: <004a01c128e6$77992980$93b472c3@map>
Message-ID: <20010820074343.R1437@hagbard.davep.org>

[This would probably have been better on the harbour user's mailing list]

On Sun, Aug 19, 2001 at 09:36:15PM +0200, Marek Paliwoda wrote:

> I am looking for a way how to do something like this :
> 
> SomeClassName:SomeClassMethod()
> 
> where SomeClassName is a class name, not an object name.
> 
> In C++ I can do (not very interesting example):
> 
> class SomeClassA {
>     friend class SomeClassB;
> 
> public:
>     int MethodA() { return SomeClassB::MethodB() };
> }
> 
> class SomeClassB : public SomeClassB {
>     static int SomeVar;
> protected:
>     static int MethodB() {return SomeVar};
> }
> 
> How could it be simulated in Harbour ?

Perhaps I'm missing something here but you seem to be asking how to have
class variables and class methods in harbour (see below) but the important
part of your example seems to revolve around the idea of friend classes. Is
the idea of friend class supposed to be important in the above?

> Also could someone give me a short example of a working code which uses
> CLASSMETHOD <MethodName> clause ? I don't know the exact syntax.

Here's a quick and dirty example that simply works with class variables:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
#include "hbclass.ch"

Class NothingSpecial

   Exported:

      ClassVar nCount Init 0

      Method init

End Class

/////

Method init Class NothingSpecial

   ::nCount++

Return( self )

/////

Function Main()
Local n

   For n := 1 to 10

      // Create, and throw away, an instance of NothingSpecial.
      NothingSpecial():new()

      // Print the instance count class variable
      ? NothingSpecial():nCount

   Next

Return( NIL )
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

However, in playing with the above I can't get class methods to work how I'd
expect either. I suspect there might be a compiler bug lurking around here
some place.

I was expecting something like this:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
#include "hbclass.ch"

Class NothingSpecial

   Exported:

      ClassVar nCount Init 0

      Method init

      Class Method sayInstanceCount

End Class

/////

Method init Class NothingSpecial

   ::nCount++

Return( self )

/////

Method sayInstanceCount Class NothingSpecial

   ? "We've had " + alltrim( str( ::nCount ) ) + " instances."

Return( self )

/////

Function Main()
Local n

   For n := 1 to 10

      // Create, and throw away, an instance of NothingSpecial.
      NothingSpecial():new()

      // Print the instance count class variable
      ? NothingSpecial():nCount

   Next

Return( NIL )
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

to work but that won't compile:

,----
| foo.prg(25) Error E0010 'Method "sayInstanceCount" not declared in class:
|                          NothingSpecial '
`----

Either I've got the above syntax wrong or the compiler has a problem with
class methods.

I'll CC this to the developer's list for their comments.

-- 
Harbour is a free   | Harbour Web Site: http://www.harbour-project.org/
software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

DETAILS_FLOAT
   The building of the double in val.c is simply different than how it 
   gets created when coded in source or read from a dbf 
   See Harbour archives under the subject
      Some numbers are not as equal as others

Done. If anyone does have any objections please note that all I've down is
remove old releases. Anyone wishing to maintain the file download section of
harbour's SourceForge page should step forward if they want to see it up to
date.

Annoyingly it would appear that it isn't possible to switch off the "Latest
File Releases" panel so it now reports:

,----
| This Project Has Not Released Any Files
`----

which is slightly misleading but I think we can live with it.

I've also turned off some of the other panels that we either don't use or no
longer make sense (for example, the news panel was way out of date and is
better served by the news on the front page of the harbour web site).

Shout if you've got any problems with the above.

>  way that is antagonistic with the other players involved.
>  The fact is, if anyone else had offered that code, it would have
>  been received differently. Ponder this, please.
>  The fact is, Harbour is NOT error-compatible with Clipper in MANY
>  places. Ron tried to explain many times that, within the macro code,
>  Harbour is NOT error-compatible with Clipper because of other
>  enhancements done by others.  Yet he got drilled with critiques
>  because his code helping a very unusual case wasn't either.

>  It is terribly unfortunate that his communication style clashed with

>  the peace.  This *is* his fault -- though some see it as a virtue.

Brian:

I read some times your message, but strictly speaking, I do not found the
reasons or the directions about what you try to say. Seem to be clear, but
inside, are just impressions

Really, does not have to much sense to answer this, but I did because maybe
is necesary some kind of communication and clarification

You seem to stay in some kind of "shock" or confution, like when you see
how an friend is "offended" and you "feel" the responsability to react and
defend him, even if that is not true, or if he is guilty or cause those
reactions. By my side, I see different what is happening

Yes, I "grossly  oversimplified things" because I only remarked what was
happening, in others words, only expose the "hurt not closed", but I never
"imply it was all Ron's fault", I only say that the group were in other
"Ron's endless discussion"
About "as if he created all  the tense energy alone", you, I and many know
that in an group exist this kind of discussions, many are healthy, but many
others just spoil to all and should be limited, not caring who or the
quality of the guilty. The common benefit is the best in the groups

>  Do you have ANY idea how many
>  times someone reported a problem--anywhere from a superficial bug to
>  a major hole in processing--and NO ONE else responded?

attend and redirect this reports

>  So perhaps it is best he work independently now.  But if you are
>  going to step in and write an epitaph for a man's work, you can't
>  just write about the dirty laundry. =20
Remember, no one crucified Ron, and your message seem to try to state like
if this happened

>  Ron fixed HUNDREDS of things for people like yourself when no one
>  else would take the time to help.
>Every time you deliver an app
>  using Harbour, it will be using more of his code than you know.
>  Until you check those ChangeLogs.
You seem to stay offended when you said this, thinking that the other side
does not have knowledge of what was happening
Many of us know, because you and I and others are not fool, that Ron have
one of the highest rating of contributions to Harbour, from short fixing to
big models, and simulate to ignore that is "hipocresia". But remember, even
if that people is the best but some aspects affect the group, it should be
remarked and tried to correct. The succesful in some models does not imply
liberty to impose all the models
The final decision of "how" each one can contribute, is personal. This is
the right of everyone, but must see how their right affect the rights of an
group. Harbour Is not an personal project of an single dancer, is an
"Tango' dancer group"

If you review this "daily digest", you can see an big change on it. Many of
the messages refer to an "todo list" to an specific goal. The last time
that I see that intention and that degree of enthusiasm(?) was more than
one year ago. Every one want to participate

Maybe now Harbour can join again people like Matt Hamilton,  Peter
Townsend,  Patrick Mast ,  Jean-Francois Lefebvre,   Richard-Alexandre
Cuylen,  Felipe Coury,  Luiz Rafael Culik ,  Paul Tucker,  Bil Simser,
April White,  Leslee Griffith,  Gonzalo Diethelm,  Dave Pearson,  Victor
Szak=E1ts,  Andi Jahja, Chen Kedem,  Matteo Baccan ,  Maurilio Longo ,  Kwon=
,
Oh-Chul ,  Eddie Runia, Robert Arseniuk, Ryszard Glab,  Alexander S.
Kresin, Vladimir Kazimirchik , Rab Thomson,  Antonio Linares ,  Ignacio
Ortiz de Zuniga , Bruno Cantero , Jose Lalin, Manuel Ruiz, David G. Holm ,
Mark W. Schumann, Phil Barnett , Tim Stone ,  Jon Berg Stoker,  Ross
Presser, Janica Lubos, Nicolas del Pozo,  and Brian Hays,  Ron Pinkas=20

(No, I am not an genius. I only took the Crew list )
Many of them are active, other long time ago leave the group (tired, I do
not know), and others are not mentionated, as example some which sign as
Mabster, Wosniak, ...., and some with references to third party RDD,
magazine reviews, and so on ...
Of course, must be included too the invaluable "anonymous user" and "heroic
tester", who sometimes remember us the goals and "back to earth" with an
simple "talk" about "Harbour is not working ! "

Forget to see this like "against Ron", that is not happening, and you must
be sure about what I am saying

If you still have some kind of doubts about the needs of Harbour movement
and specifics goals to the group, review the included messages of more than
one year old

Gracias,
David Macias

>Message: 12
>   Date: Thu, 25 May 2000 13:39:12 +0200
 >  From: "Andrzej P. Wozniak" <alias@polnet.cc>
>Subject: New syntax - users's point of view=20

>Ron, Ryszard, Victor and all others in alphabetical order!

>Harbour is not even Clipper yet. Many users try to test their programs with
>Harbour with no success. How can I use may databases without indexing?
>I know, any extensions to Clipper are great and welcome, but only with
>Harbour working.

>I think, before to put some big extensions to Harbour, it should go to beta
>phase. All other non-(Clipper compatibility or functionality) work should=
 go
>to the contrib directory (or maybe completely aside). This should be the
>best way to reach beta phase in any finite time.
>In the beta phase all the Clipper-headed community can decide if any of
>contributions should be included into the root of Harbour project.

>I know, discovering new horizons is fascinating, but we cannot start it now
>yet. First we must have a solid ship (and it already exists - called
>Clipper) and a solid port in Harbour for it to get ready for our voyages to
>promised lands.

>Let us, users, work with Harbour instead of Clipper, please, and we give
>you, developers, even more problems than you can imagine.

>This is my version and i will stick to it.
>(Taka jest moja wersja i tego sie bede trzymal  :-))

>(=20
>--=20
>Regards from the Harbour mirror in Poland
>Andrzej P. Wozniak
>alias@polnet.cc   harbour@harbour.pl.eu.org

>Message: 18
>  Date: Fri, 26 May 2000 04:38:43 +0200
>   From: "Victor Szakats" <info@szelvesz.hu>
>Subject: Stopping

>Seeing the current direction of Harbour, I've decided to stop contributing=
=20
>to the project.

>My goal was to make a compiler which runs an existing Clipper application,=
=20
>I thought this goal was in sync with the goal of the Harbour-Project. I
considered=20
>this a major challenge in itself. I think that the current method of
extending it will=20
>lead to something I always tried to avoid in software development.

>My reason is that I seem to be pretty much left alone (with handful of=20
>people) with my views about the principal goals, and about software=20
>development methods in general.

>I'm neither a politician, nor somebody with infinite time to wrestle with
some=20
>people here.

>I'll stay here, watching what happens, but don't expect CVS sessions=20
>or any discussions from me until I see the current phenomenon.

>I'm quite sad that this happened.

>Victor Szakats

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------

>Message: 24
 >  Date: Fri, 26 May 2000 00:12:09 -0700
>   From: "Brian Hays" <bhays@abacuslaw.com>
>Subject: Stopping  YADSWAD

>Dear All:
>What's the goal?  Short term?  Long term?
>One of my favorite sayings is that Software development, like a gas,=
 expands
>to fill the space alotted to it.
>Without a clear focus, it's very difficult to really _finish_.

>That was one of the things that impressed me with the Harbour project early
>on: the clarity of creating a Clipper-compatible compiler.  Initially I
>thought the limitations were misguided when the discussions turned to=
 strict
>re-creation of Clipper bugs, but I've since grown to crave the focus.

>I have participated very little for the past few weeks because A) I needed
>to tend to business more heavily than usual, and B) I was waiting for the
>"dust to settle", and C) as a minor contributor I felt sheepish about
>expressing my opinions too loudly.  It seemed massive additions to the
>feature set were getting tossed in, while fundamental elements remained
>untouched.

>I grew fearful of YADSWAD:  Yet Another Database System Without A Database.

>Unfortunately, I don't have the skills to write the hard part!  So I can
>hardly complain.
>But here I am, freshly committed to jump both feet into converting my
>FiveWin app to 32bit , and to do whatever I can to support ths wonderful
>Harbour project, and the dust is flying, not settling.  So here's my
>opinion:
>I think the CORE DEVELOPERS need to agree on a clear list of what features
>need to be finished to have a beta with all the desired functionality,
>including data drivers and whatever extensions are accepted for Version 1.
>I think the recent areas of dispute need to be put on a list and voted on=
 as
>either in or out of Version 1.
>I don't think anything else should get CVSed except in the Contrib area
>until after the party announcing Version 1 as done.

>The Goal:  Version 1!

>Brian "the forgotten one" Hays  ;-)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 06:14:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Mon Aug 20 05:14:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] dispbox() error
Message-ID: <3B80D495.5C8EAB89@libero.it>

Hi, this little program draws a line on screen if compiled with clipper,
but nothing if compiled
with harbour on OS/2 GCC emx or Win32 BCC

function Main()

   DispBox(1, 1, 1, 80, Space(9), "W+/B, N/BG")

return nil

And, looking at this problem, I've found out that someone wrote pieces
of gtos2.c which are wrong.

For example hb_gt_Replicate() is made on the assumption that if you
write inside screen memory you will see what you write on screen. But
this not true on OS/2 :-)

Not only that, there are FAR qualifiers which do nothing on OS/2.

regards.


--
 __________
|  |  | |__| md2520@mclink.it
|_|_|_|____| Team OS/2 Italia

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 07:44:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 20 06:44:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] 2001-08-19 21:45 GMT +1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>
In-Reply-To: <3B804AF5.27659.EC6B90@localhost>; from jfl@wanadoo.be on Sun, Aug 19, 2001 at 11:25:41PM +0200
References: <3B804AF5.27659.EC6B90@localhost>
Message-ID: <20010820113322.C1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Sun, Aug 19, 2001 at 11:25:41PM +0200, JF Lefebvre wrote:

>    harbour/source/vm/classes.c
>     * Changed the way MsgSuper() return a Super Object.
>       Now ::Super(::nX) is allowed
>           ::Super:Classname() return the superClassName.
>     * Added some code to check or validate puiClsTree
>     * improved validation of scoping

I think I might have found the reason why the profiler TBrowse reporter
example is now falling over with a RTE. Consider this code:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
#include "hbclass.ch"

Create Class Parent

   Exported:

      Method init

End Class

Method init Class Parent

   ? "Parent::init()"

Return( self )

Create Class Child

   Exported:

      Method init

End Class

Method init Class Child

   ::super:init()
   ? "Child::init()"

Return( self )

Function Main()

   Child():new()

Return( NIL )
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

The output I'd expect from that code is:

,----
| Parent::init()
| Child::init()
`----

but all I get is:

,----
| Child::init()
`----

It would appear that the super call simply isn't happening.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 08:12:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Mon Aug 20 07:12:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: [HarbourTalk] Class syntax help
In-Reply-To: <20010820074343.R1437@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <004a01c128e6$77992980$93b472c3@map>; from paliwoda@inetia.pl on Sun, Aug 19, 2001 at 09:36:15PM +0200
Message-ID: <3B810C45.15649.7BA841@localhost>

Unfortunatly, Class Method are not working up to now... this is in 
my todo list.

On 20 Aug 2001, at 7:43, Dave Pearson wrote:

> [This would probably have been better on the harbour user's mailing
> list]
> 
> On Sun, Aug 19, 2001 at 09:36:15PM +0200, Marek Paliwoda wrote:
> 
> > I am looking for a way how to do something like this :
> > 
> > SomeClassName:SomeClassMethod()
> > 
> > where SomeClassName is a class name, not an object name.
> > 
> > In C++ I can do (not very interesting example):
> > 
> > class SomeClassA {
> >     friend class SomeClassB;
> > 
> > public:
> >     int MethodA() { return SomeClassB::MethodB() };
> > }
> > 
> > class SomeClassB : public SomeClassB {
> >     static int SomeVar;
> > protected:
> >     static int MethodB() {return SomeVar};
> > }
> > 
> > How could it be simulated in Harbour ?
> 
> Perhaps I'm missing something here but you seem to be asking how to
> have class variables and class methods in harbour (see below) but the
> important part of your example seems to revolve around the idea of
> friend classes. Is the idea of friend class supposed to be important
> in the above?
> 
> > Also could someone give me a short example of a working code which
> > uses CLASSMETHOD <MethodName> clause ? I don't know the exact
> > syntax.
> 
> Here's a quick and dirty example that simply works with class
> variables:
> 
> -- cut here
> ----------------------------------------------------------------
> #include "hbclass.ch"
> 
> Class NothingSpecial
> 
>    Exported:
> 
>       ClassVar nCount Init 0
> 
>       Method init
> 
> End Class
> 
> /////
> 
> Method init Class NothingSpecial
> 
>    ::nCount++
> 
> Return( self )
> 
> /////
> 
> Function Main()
> Local n
> 
>    For n := 1 to 10
> 
>       // Create, and throw away, an instance of NothingSpecial.
>       NothingSpecial():new()
> 
>       // Print the instance count class variable
>       ? NothingSpecial():nCount
> 
>    Next
> 
> Return( NIL )
> -- cut here
> ----------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> However, in playing with the above I can't get class methods to work
> how I'd expect either. I suspect there might be a compiler bug lurking
> around here some place.
> 
> I was expecting something like this:
> 
> -- cut here
> ----------------------------------------------------------------
> #include "hbclass.ch"
> 
> Class NothingSpecial
> 
>    Exported:
> 
>       ClassVar nCount Init 0
> 
>       Method init
> 
>       Class Method sayInstanceCount
> 
> End Class
> 
> /////
> 
> Method init Class NothingSpecial
> 
>    ::nCount++
> 
> Return( self )
> 
> /////
> 
> Method sayInstanceCount Class NothingSpecial
> 
>    ? "We've had " + alltrim( str( ::nCount ) ) + " instances."
> 
> Return( self )
> 
> /////
> 
> Function Main()
> Local n
> 
>    For n := 1 to 10
> 
>       // Create, and throw away, an instance of NothingSpecial.
>       NothingSpecial():new()
> 
>       // Print the instance count class variable
>       ? NothingSpecial():nCount
> 
>    Next
> 
> Return( NIL )
> -- cut here
> ----------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> to work but that won't compile:
> 
> ,----
> | foo.prg(25) Error E0010 'Method "sayInstanceCount" not declared in
> class: |                          NothingSpecial ' `----
> 
> Either I've got the above syntax wrong or the compiler has a problem
> with class methods.
> 
> I'll CC this to the developer's list for their comments.
> 
> --

> 
>    ::super:init()
>    ? "Child::init()"
> 
> Return( self )
> 
> Function Main()
> 
>    Child():new()
> 
> Return( NIL )
> -- cut here
> ----------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> The output I'd expect from that code is:
> 
> ,----
> | Parent::init()
> | Child::init()
> `----
> 
> but all I get is:
> 
> ,----
> | Child::init()
> `----
> 
> It would appear that the super call simply isn't happening.
> 
> -- 
> Land of the free? Yeah, right.
>                                    http://www.freesklyarov.org/

Some todo items:

- Optimizing out the need for the PUSHNIL opcode before 
each function call.

- Eliminating the "#pragma pack" type of hacks from the 
code (especially RDD), to make it more multiplatform, this 
mostly involves changing the direct writing of structures to the 
disk.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 09:30:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)

Subject: [Harbour] 2001-08-19 21:45 GMT +1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>

References: <3B804AF5.27659.EC6B90@localhost>

On Sun, Aug 19, 2001 at 11:25:41PM +0200, JF Lefebvre wrote:

> 2001-08-19 21:45 GMT +1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>

Having just refreshed harbour here and rebuilt everything I did a quick test
with the profiler.prg test code and suffered this runtime error:

,----
| Error BASE/1068  Argument error: array access
| Called from HB_PROFILEREPORTTOTBROWSE:CURRENTENTITY(773)
| Called from __EVAL(760)
| Called from EVAL(0)
| Called from TBCOLUMN:NEW(100)
| Called from TBCOLUMNNEW(142)
| Called from HB_PROFILEREPORTTOTBROWSE:ADDCOLUMNS(760)
| Called from HB_PROFILEREPORTTOTBROWSE:GENERATE(750)
| Called from MAIN(142)
`----

This is when the final array browsing test takes place. This wasn't
previously a problem. I'll do some more debugging to get to the bottom of
the problem but I thought it worth mentioning in the mean time as it appears
to be a change in behaviour of some valid test code due do to the above CVS
commit.

I also notice that the memoedit()'s used to view the text output in the
profiler.prg tests are now misbehaving too but I think that's unrelated. Can
anyone on platforms other than GNU/Linux have a play with that and see what
you get?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 10:54:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 20 09:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] 2001-08-19 21:45 GMT +1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>
In-Reply-To: <20010820121811.D1437@hagbard.davep.org>; from davep@davep.org on Mon, Aug 20, 2001 at 12:18:11PM +0100
References: <3B804AF5.27659.EC6B90@localhost>; <20010820113322.C1437@hagbard.davep.org> <3B810CDD.23943.7DFA0D@localhost> <20010820121811.D1437@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <20010820123639.G1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Aug 20, 2001 at 12:18:11PM +0100, Dave Pearson wrote:
> On Mon, Aug 20, 2001 at 01:13:01PM +0200, jfl@mafact.com wrote:
> 
> > Did you mean this code does'nt  work since my last modif ? 
> 
> Yes. I've also done some digging into the "memoedit" problem I mentioned
> in my other email and have realised that it's nothing to do with
> memoedit() failing to display anything, the problem is that my classes now
> no longer work because ::super: calls are, from what I can tell, no longer
> doing the right thing.

Hmm, I've just noticed that the above might not make sense in that the email
I'm referring to doesn't appear to have made it to the harbour mailing list
for some reason (unless it's delayed somewhere).

Anyway, since you committed the class system changes all sorts of odd things
have started to happen with the test code in profiler.prg. If you want to
test this out for yourself simply compile profiler.prg as:

,----
| harbour profiler -n -m -w -p -d__TEST__
`----

link it up and have a play. You'll notice that the string reporter no longer
returns the report as a string, instead the report gets written to screen.
This appears to be because the wrong ::writeLines() is being called (the one
from HB_ProfileReport instead of HB_ProfileReportToArray::writeLines(),
HB_ProfileReportToString inherits from HB_ProfileReportToArray which in turn
inherits from HB_ProfileReport).

--

software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

> 2001-08-19 21:45 GMT +1 JFL (mafact) <jfl@mafact.com>
>    harbour/include/hbapi.h
>     * changed structure of _HB_BASEARRAY (puiClsTree)
>     *         suppressed uiClsTree not anymore needed

>     * modified ArrayRelease() to handle the release of puiClsTree

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 13:28:01 2001

More tests show that:

1) This sample does not work either on OS/2 or on Win32 because nRight is >
than MaxCol()
2) Even if I set nRight < than MaxCol() this does not work on OS/2 because
of wrong functions
    inside gtos2.c
3) It always works on CLIPPER.

regards.


Maurilio Longo ha scritto:

> Hi, this little program draws a line on screen if compiled with clipper,
> but nothing if compiled
> with harbour on OS/2 GCC emx or Win32 BCC
>
> function Main()
>
>    DispBox(1, 1, 1, 80, Space(9), "W+/B, N/BG")
>
> return nil
>
> And, looking at this problem, I've found out that someone wrote pieces
> of gtos2.c which are wrong.
>
> For example hb_gt_Replicate() is made on the assumption that if you
> write inside screen memory you will see what you write on screen. But
> this not true on OS/2 :-)
>
> Not only that, there are FAR qualifiers which do nothing on OS/2.
>

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 13:29:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Mon Aug 20 12:29:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] To-do list
In-Reply-To: <3B814FAA.9641.1E657C0@localhost>
References: <3B814FAA.9641.1E657C0@localhost>
Message-ID: <196907981558.20010820093711@abacuslaw.com>

Ryszard:

  In a Windows app, we've been trying to call hb_gcAll() whenever a
  dialog closes as an attempt to get it called regularly.
  Though this helps, we've found in automated tests that the app
  eventually crashes from memory problems.
  If we assign hb_gcAll() to a menu option and call it directly in the
  test script, the app runs almost forever.

  It's my educated guess that having the garbage collector doing its
  thing while Windows is in the middle of doing lots of activity is
  not the way to go.  GC really should happen at an idle state.
  But we don't know a good way to do that....

  ---====---
  Brian Hays

RG> On 19 Aug 2001, at 17:53, Sid Saylors wrote:

>> May i ask if an idle state garbage collector make it
>> to somewhere near the top of this lisk?

RG>   Some more details?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 13:59:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 20 12:59:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Using SourceForge to tack TODO items
Message-ID: <20010820175841.T1437@hagbard.davep.org>

An alternative to using a file in the doc directory for tracking TODO items
might be to use SourceForge's tracker system. It's possible for an admin to
create any type of tracker so creating a tracker for TODO items would be
easy enough.

So, if there's a strong preference for managing this on-line we can use that
facility rather than doing it via a in-CVS file.

See <URL:http://sourceforge.net/tracker/?group_id=681> to see harbour's
current tracker items.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 18:23:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Aug 20 17:23:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] dispbox() error
In-Reply-To: <3B813A74.44F2429A@libero.it>
References: <3B80D495.5C8EAB89@libero.it> <3B813A74.44F2429A@libero.it>
Message-ID: <200108201722.0000015G@Internet>

** Reply to message from Maurilio Longo <maurilio.longo@libero.it> on
Mon, 20 Aug 2001 18:27:32 +0200

> 1) This sample does not work either on OS/2 or on Win32 because nRight is >
> than MaxCol()

I'm in the process of rewriting the box and line drawing functions to
do proper screen boundary clipping, like Clipper does. I only have gtwin
converted so far and I can't commit anything until I have all GT
libraries converted, because part of the change involves changing the
USHORT row and column variables to SHORT (which I'm only doing for the
box and line display functions).

This change also points out the idiocy of using type prefixes on
descriptive variable names, because now the functions have variables
named 'uiLeft', etc. that are no longer of type 'ui'. Had the variables
simply been named 'left', etc., I wouldn't be faced with the dilemma of
either wasting my time renaming the variables or leaving a future
maintenance problem...
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 19:03:06 2001

Seeing as I did up some of this (carrying forward what was already
created...) I will do this if you like.

I don't recall right now where the clipping took place in Clipper but if it
were at the higher level, then the current declaration would be correct.  (I
do plan to go over this one day, believe it or not :-)

Paul

> > 1) This sample does not work either on OS/2 or on Win32 because nRight
is >
> > than MaxCol()
>
> I'm in the process of rewriting the box and line drawing functions to
> do proper screen boundary clipping, like Clipper does. I only have gtwin
> converted so far and I can't commit anything until I have all GT
> libraries converted, because part of the change involves changing the
> USHORT row and column variables to SHORT (which I'm only doing for the
> box and line display functions).
>
> This change also points out the idiocy of using type prefixes on
> descriptive variable names, because now the functions have variables
> named 'uiLeft', etc. that are no longer of type 'ui'. Had the variables
> simply been named 'left', etc., I wouldn't be faced with the dilemma of
> either wasting my time renaming the variables or leaving a future
> maintenance problem...
> --
> David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
> Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

utils/hbmake/hbmake.prg    
    *some fixed to library editor mode

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 21:20:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Mon Aug 20 20:20:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug in DTOC, SetCentury
Message-ID: <12524940352.20010820173512@abacuslaw.com>


  DTOC does not obey __SetCentury status.  I works purely off of the
  DateFormat string Set(4).  Even if dateformat is "mm/dd/yyyy", if
  SET CENTURY  is OFF it must return a 2-digit year.

  Is anyone familiar  with the code in dateshb.c?  I'm not sure if the
  fix should be in dtoc itself or in the hb_dateFormat() that it calls.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 21:24:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Aug 20 20:24:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] dispbox() error
In-Reply-To: <001901c129c3$8ad745d0$b6122a0a@chasechevy>
References: <3B80D495.5C8EAB89@libero.it> <3B813A74.44F2429A@libero.it> <200108201722.0000015G@Internet>
 <001901c129c3$8ad745d0$b6122a0a@chasechevy>
Message-ID: <200108202023.0000015K@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Paul Tucker" <ptucker@sympatico.ca> on Mon,
20 Aug 2001 18:00:36 -0400

> Seeing as I did up some of this (carrying forward what was already
> created...) I will do this if you like.

I already have it mostly done.

> I don't recall right now where the clipping took place in Clipper but if it
> were at the higher level, then the current declaration would be correct.  (I
> do plan to go over this one day, believe it or not :-)

It could be, but the Harbour GT implementation leaves the details of
box and line drawing up to the individual GT library. Fortunately, most
of them use the exact same code and only a few have minor changes to the
code, so once I had the GTWIN code changed and tested, it was only a
matter of cut and paste for all but two of the libraries, GTCRS and
GTSLN, which only required doing a manual diff and porting back in the
minor code differences.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 21:38:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Aug 20 20:38:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug in DTOC, SetCentury
In-Reply-To: <12524940352.20010820173512@abacuslaw.com>
References: <12524940352.20010820173512@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <200108202037.0000015M@Internet>

** Reply to message from Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com> on Mon, 20 Aug 2001 17:35:12 -0700

>   DTOC does not obey __SetCentury status.  I works purely off of the
>   DateFormat string Set(4).  Even if dateformat is "mm/dd/yyyy", if
>   SET CENTURY  is OFF it must return a 2-digit year.

Then please explain why the following code gives the exact
same output with both Clipper 5.2e and Harbour 0.37:

C:\Test>type tt.prg
procedure main
	set century off
        set date format to "yyyy-mm-dd"
        ? DATE()
        ? dtoc(date())
        set century on
        ? DATE()
        ? dtoc(date())
	set century off
        ? DATE()
        ? dtoc(date())
quit
C:\Test>tt

2001-08-20
2001-08-20
2001-08-20
2001-08-20
01-08-20
01-08-20

> Is anyone familiar  with the code in dateshb.c?  I'm not sure if the
> fix should be in dtoc itself or in the hb_dateFormat() that it calls.

I am intimately familiar with that code. There is nothing in
it that needs fixing.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 21:56:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Paul Tucker)
Date: Mon Aug 20 20:56:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug in DTOC, SetCentury
References: <12524940352.20010820173512@abacuslaw.com> <200108202037.0000015M@Internet>
Message-ID: <02a001c129db$b51a4960$b6122a0a@chasechevy>

David,

PMFJI, but your code is not asking the right question!

Try this:
proc main
set date format to 'yyyy-mm-dd'
? set(_SET_DATEFORMAT)
? __setcentury()
? date()
? dtoc(date())

set century off
? set(_SET_DATEFORMAT)
? __setcentury()
? date()
? dtoc(date())

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 22:18:02 2001

David:

  Well, what I really have to explain is why __setCentury works
  correctly in my small test too, but fails in the large app that has
  identical code.

  I may have just found it: My app has a saved setting for date
  format. There's nothing in Harbour that keeps us from setting the
  date format to yyyy when SetCentury is currently ON, putting things
  out of sync in the way it looks for a changed setting.

  Will confirm shortly...

DGH> same output with both Clipper 5.2e and Harbour 0.37:

DGH>         ? dtoc(date())
DGH>         set century off
DGH>         ? DATE()
DGH>         ? dtoc(date())

Paul:

Thanks.  It seems that Clipper will change the SetCentury setting to
.T. if the dateformat string has 4 y's.

The ultimate test is this simple:
? __setcentury()
set date format to 'mm/dd/yyyy'
? __setcentury() // changes to .t. in clipper
? dtoc(date())

misbehavior was so blatant I put up the msg before reducing it.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 23:54:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Aug 20 22:54:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug in DTOC, SetCentury
In-Reply-To: <02a001c129db$b51a4960$b6122a0a@chasechevy>
References: <12524940352.20010820173512@abacuslaw.com> <200108202037.0000015M@Internet>
 <02a001c129db$b51a4960$b6122a0a@chasechevy>
Message-ID: <200108202253.0000015O@Internet>

** Reply to message from "Paul Tucker" <ptucker@sympatico.ca> on Mon,
20 Aug 2001 20:53:35 -0400

> PMFJI, but your code is not asking the right question!
> 
> Try this: ...

This almost reveals the real problem. I added a ? __setcentury() ahead
of the set date format and discovered that the problem is that Clipper
sets century to true when a 4 digit date format is set, but Harbour does
not. Fortunately, this will be easy to fix.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 20 23:55:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Aug 20 22:55:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Bug in DTOC, SetCentury
In-Reply-To: <11327335566.20010820181507@abacuslaw.com>
References: <12524940352.20010820173512@abacuslaw.com> <11327335566.20010820181507@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <200108202254.0000015Q@Internet>

** Reply to message from Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com> on Mon, 20
Aug 2001 18:15:07 -0700

> I just tested Clipper.  The fix needs to be in __SetCentury!
>         SET CENTURY ON/OFF actually goes to the DateFormat and
>         replaces the "y" characters with 2 or 4 y's depending on the
>         setting.

Clipper *also* does this, but only if the set century value changes.
The *actual* bug is that Harbour doesn't set the century value to .T.
when setting a date format with a four digit year, so that when the SET
CENTURY OFF code executes, Harbour doesn't do anything, because it
thinks that century is already off. I'll fix the actual bug...
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 21 00:51:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Mon Aug 20 23:51:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-21 23:35 UTC-0400 David G. Holm
Message-ID: <200108202350.00000160@Internet>

2001-08-21 23:35 UTC-0400 David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com>

  * include/hbapigt.h
  * source/rtl/gtapi.c
  * source/rtl/gt_tpl/gt_tpl.c
  * source/rtl/gtcgi/gtcgi.c
  * source/rtl/gtcrs/gtcrs.c
  * source/rtl/gtdos/gtdos.c
  * source/rtl/gtos2/gtos2.c
  * source/rtl/gtpca/gtpca.c
  * source/rtl/gtsln/gtsln.c
  * source/rtl/gtstd/gtstd.c
  * source/rtl/gtwin/gtwin.c
    * Changed all row and column parameters for the box and line drawing
      functions from USHORT to SHORT.
    - Removed all box and line drawing boundary checks from gtapi.c
    + Added the appropriate box and line boundary checks to the various
      GT API library sources to properly implement clipping.

The GTCGI, GTOS2, GTSTD, and GTWIN libraries are tested (both
for boxes and lines). Testing the lines revealed a cursor
positioning bug in GTCGI that I haven't had time to fix yet.

Could somebody please test the GTCRS, and GTSLN libraries?
Here is the program that I used for testing:

#include "box.ch"

function Main()
local max_row, max_col

   SetMode(50, 80) // Remove or change, as needed.
   max_row := maxrow()
   max_col := maxcol()
   
   // Draw filled boxes centered around the four screen corners.
   DispBox(-10, -10, 10, 10, B_SINGLE + "X", "W+/B, N/BG")
   DispBox(-10, max_col - 10, 10, max_col + 10, B_SINGLE + "X", "W+/B, N/BG")
   DispBox(max_row - 10, -10, max_row + 10, 10, B_SINGLE + "X", "W+/B, N/BG")
   DispBox(max_row - 10, max_col - 10, max_row + 10, max_col + 10, B_SINGLE + "X", "W+/B, N/BG")
   
   // Draw non-filled boxes around the filled boxes.
   DispBox(-15, -15, 15, 15, 1, "W+/B, N/BG")
   DispBox(-15, max_col - 15, 15, max_col + 15, 1, "W+/B, N/BG")
   DispBox(max_row - 15, -15, max_row + 15, 15, 1, "W+/B, N/BG")
   DispBox(max_row - 15, max_col - 15, max_row + 15, max_col + 15, 1, "W+/B, N/BG")
   
   // Draw a box in the center, then two boxes off screen.
   
   DispBox( 20, 20, 25, 60, 2, "W+/B, N/BG")
   DispBox( -10, -10, -1, -1, 2, "W+/B, N/BG")
   DispBox( max_row + 1, max_col + 1, max_row + 10, max_col + 10, 2, "W+/B, N/BG")
   
   // Draw a line from off-screen to on-screen,
   // then draw a line from off-screen to off-screen,
   // and finally draw a line from on-screen to off-screen,
   DispBox(1, -10, 1, 10, B_SINGLE)
   DispBox(2, -10, 2, max_col + 10, B_DOUBLE)
   DispBox(3, max_col - 10, 3, max_col + 10, B_SINGLE)

return nil
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 21 02:09:00 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Bill Smith)
Date: Tue Aug 21 01:09:00 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-21 23:35 UTC-0400 David G. Holm
References: <200108202350.00000160@Internet>
Message-ID: <001501c129ff$a86d01c0$9fe69c40@K6BW>

I ran your suggested program in Clipper v5.1 and latest Harbour.
Environment:  DOS (Windows 98) and cygwin.

Both (Harbour and Clipper) line draw functions generate b/w lines across the
screen, including column 80.

However, using the (same?) functions to draw a box, it looks like column 80
does not display under Harbour, while it does under Clipper.   Deleting the
color options did not make a difference.

In other words, both screens look identical, except:

Clipper = 10 horizontal "x" characters in the filled boxes at the right side
of the screen.
Harbour = 9 horizontal "x" characters in the filled boxes at the right side
of the screen.

Both programs filled boxes with 10 "x" characters at the left side of the
screen.

Also, the system screen default is restored to 80x24 under Harbor, but is
left at 80x50 under Clipper 5.1 when the program exits.

The DOS system prompt appears on line 5 when the Clipper executable exits,
but appears on line 3 after the Harbour executable exits.

Bill

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 21 03:59:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Tue Aug 21 02:59:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2001-08-20 11:55 UTC-0800
Message-ID: <48960195097.20010821000725@abacuslaw.com>

2001-08-20 11:55 UTC-0800 Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>

   * contrib/rdd_ads/ads1.c
      * fixed subIndexing.
      * optimized DBI_GETLOCKARRAY and fixed memory leak
      * adsOrderListFocus() failed on space-padded strings
      * adsGoTo: if on same record, refresh. Fixed issues that arose
         from minor bugs in ADS when using relations in versions
         prior to 6.1
      * adsAppend() added error handling
      * fixed file lock/unlock, and record locking to support
         dbrlock lock list maintenance (and memory leak when
         no recno was passed to dbrlock())

   * contrib/rdd_ads/adsfunc.c
      * adssetServerType now returns any error numbers
      + added AdsRefreshRecord, AdsIsTableLocked, AdsIsRecordLocked

   * source/rdd/dbcmd.c
      * Set NetErr flag to True for failed dbAppend()
      * fixed ordCondSet parameters. See pptable.c below.

   + contrib/libgt/bitflags.c
      + Dave Pearson's bitflags.c, which I ported to Harbour.
        Has functions to use a Harbour string for storing On/Off
        bit flags.

   * contrib/libgt/doc/en/ht_gt.txt
      + added docs from Dave Pearson's bitflags.c

   * source/pp/pptable.c
      * Alexander Kresin's fix for 5.3 compatible parameters
      for INDEX ON and ordCondSet().
      WARNING! IF you had hard-coded calls to this function,
      and used any parameters after the 11th one,
      you have to change your code! Or, if you have a header
      that translates INDEX ON for clauses USECURRENT, ADDITIVE,
      CUSTOM or NOOPTIMIZE, these parameters are shifted back
      now.
      The parameter list was incorrectly handled before because
      of the 12th parameter that is always NIL.
      See Harbour Archives, subject "XINDEX warning" for details

 ---====---
 Brian Hays

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 21 04:27:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Tue Aug 21 03:27:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: CHANGELOG: 2001-08-20 11:55 UTC-0800
In-Reply-To: <48960195097.20010821000725@abacuslaw.com>
References: <48960195097.20010821000725@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <154961874181.20010821003524@abacuslaw.com>

Two issues from my recent changes need extra attention since they may
seem buried in the list, and one change may BREAK CURRENT CODE.

First, notice the bitflags.c in libgt. These are very handy routines
written by Dave Pearson for managing a bit-map of flags, stored in a
string variable or field. (Thanks, Dave!)
I made a few modifications to port to Harbour.

Now for the WARNING part:
OrdCondSet had an incorrect parameter list after the 11th parameter.
(The Clipper docs were wrong).
If you were using any of the fancy Clipper 5.3/COMIX clauses
for ADDITIVE, USECURRENT, CUSTOM or NOOPTIMIZE,
these parameters are shifted back now.

The current code and preprocessor are coordinated now, so if you
simply use the straight INDEX ON command, you probably don't need to
change your code.  But if you had altered any of your own headers to
work with the prior Harbour, or had hard-coded calls to OrdCondSet(),
you may need to change things to accommodate the NIL 12th parameter.

For more details, see the Harbour Archives, subject "XINDEX warning"

Brian Hays

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 21 05:26:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Tue Aug 21 04:26:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re:  Memory not released
In-Reply-To: <3.0.6.16.20010821025559.1edf86c4@mail.udg.mx>
References: <3.0.6.16.20010821025559.1edf86c4@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <40965398739.20010821013409@abacuslaw.com>

David:
DAMC> Can be included "Memory not released"in "todo list" for beta 1 ? This error
DAMC> happen often

  It doesn't really help to list it as a topic by itself, since
  any piece of code could result in unreleased blocks.
  
  What we *really* need from you and other Harbour users are specific
  examples of what produces the error.  It takes time to reduce the
  problem to a 10-line example, but if no one takes that time it won't
  get fixed. Often 95% of the effort in debugging is in clearly
  identifying it. The people doing the low-level coding usually won't
  spend hours chasing a vague bug if that first level of debugging
  hasn't been done to narrow down the possibilities.
  When an issue IS clearly defined, someone will usually fix it right
  away.

  Thanks again for your input--especially on the ordCondSet topic.
  Keep it coming.

  ---====---
  Brian Hays

      correctly report that no compiler command has been specified.
