From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 21 05:41:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Tue Aug 21 04:41:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2001-08-21 01:30 UTC-0800
Message-ID: <96966304011.20010821014914@abacuslaw.com>

2001-08-21 01:30 UTC-0800 Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>
   * contrib/libgt/bitflags.c
      added the cvs header
   + todo.txt
      first stab at a todo list

Since several people responded in the format I offered for a todo
list, I gathered the items and got it started.

I am not married to this format by any means, I'm just trying to keep
the ball rolling.  The SourceForge tools seem like a great idea, but
web interfaces are sometimes too time consuming and people just don't
take the time to update them.  If we decide to switch, I'll be happy
to make the initial conversion.

  ---====---
  Brian Hays

My assessment of whether a group (or individual) had progressed beyond the
project announcement stage was (1) project status and (2) whether any code
was released.  If the statement was made "This project has not released any
code", I took it to mean what it said.  Could be a small group was
developing a project in a closed environment, and would release code only
after reaching beta status, or perhaps code had been withdrawn or?

Bill

> Please find attached images of the outcome of running the test code. There
> appear to be significant differences.

The line drawing differences are due to the CRS line drawing functions
being used for line drawing. Apparently they won't draw if the start
area is off screen to the left.

For the box drawing, the same code is used in all libraries, aside from
minor differences in the character set hacks for GTCRS and GTSLN, so I'm
at a loss as to why GTCRS looks so different from everything else.

respect harbour level

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 22 04:04:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David Arturo Macias Corona)
Date: Wed Aug 22 03:04:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re:  Memory not released
In-Reply-To: <200108211600.f7LG0sn17419@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <3.0.6.16.20010822020324.1d474bd4@mail.udg.mx>

>From: Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>
>Subject: Re: [Harbour] Re:  Memory not released

>  It doesn't really help to list it as a topic by itself, since
>  any piece of code could result in unreleased blocks.
>  
>  What we *really* need from you and other Harbour users are specific
>  examples of what produces the error. 

This case seem different and do not belong to an "specific" error that the
user can re-produce

In the cases I have seen, nothing indicate some kind of problem. The
program run well, but at exit, show *sometimes* the message of "memory not
released". What cause the error ? None apparent process

For that I think that the review belong to the programmer. Seeing the
posible modules of Harbour code maybe he will find some "piece not set in
his place"

The "10 lines" that I included show one specific piece of code (fm.c)
Other start point could be what was refered a long time ago. Down I attach
the message
Remember, in many cases does not exist an "Runtime error" to have "memory
not released"

Remembering some of the previous message:

>fm.c:442: HB_TR_ERROR Block 10 (size 40) SGBLOCK(2966)

>In others runs, show different number of lines (blocks)

>Line SGBLOCK( 2966 ) is an code block creation:
>bBloque := &("{ "+bBloque+" }")
>where bBloque is an valid character expresion to create an code block,
including their | | characters

>This error has been happening along differents versions of Harbour
(0.33,0.34,0.35, ...0.37) in Windows 98, OS/2, WIndows 2000 ...

>Maurilio Longo reviewed something like this in OS/2 weeks ago. Ocurrs
mainly with creation and maybe evaluation of code blocks

I said too that the function SGBLOCK() refered in the "10 lines" make an
code block from an character expresion, using macros
One posibility could be the "management of memory" in the "macro process",
which maybe sometimes complete the process but not release some blocks of
memory used in that

Maybe others developers have seen others cases differents to "macro", where
"memory not released" happen. If only happen in macros, is an good point to
start the review

Gracias,
David Macias

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 22 06:25:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David Arturo Macias Corona)
Date: Wed Aug 22 05:25:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DBFCDX / ADS
In-Reply-To: <200108211600.f7LG0sn17419@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <3.0.6.16.20010822042341.1d4fde2a@mail.udg.mx>

I delayed this message for many months, but now is here at last

Maybe the Harbour developers are aware of the contents of this message, o
maybe not, as happened with OrdCondSet(); in such case, this information
can serve as reference

The content is focused to:
1.- Developers of RDD DBFCDX
2.- ADS support in Harbour

Time ago, when I made changes to an Clipper 5.3 program in order to manage:
- Clipper DBFNTX, Clipper DBFCDX
- Advantage DBFNTXAX, Advantage DBFCDXAX

I found that there are many differences between RDD's, specially between
Clipper DBFCDX - Advantage DBFCDXAX, mainly because Advantage DBFCDXAX is
"oriented" to FoxPro implementation, and NOT Clipper implementation

Because this can affect Clipper DBFCDX - Harbour DBFCDX compatibility, is
convenient to take it in care

Next are a brief discussion of differences
a.- OrdCondSet(): There are differents arguments and default values for
RDD. This was reviewed before and done in Harbour (I hope)

b.- CDXLOCK.obj: Advantage use the locking scheme of FoxPro. CDXLOCK.obj
must be linked with Clipper to acquire this scheme

c.- SET( _SET_MBLOCKSIZE, 64 )      //Igualar a DBFCDXAX y FoxPro
  FoxPro use 64 as default, 
  Advantage use 64 as default, 
  Clipper 5.3a use ** 32 ** as default, 
  Clipper 5.3b use ** 64 ** as default
  Below 32, there different behaviour between FoxPro, Advantage, Clipper

d.- AX_SetMemoBlock( 64 )           //Advantage RDD
  I am not sure why must be used in Advantage, but this is in AXNTXCDX.ch
#command SET MEMOBLOCK TO <value>                                          ;
      => AX_SetMemoBlock( <value> )                                        ;
       ; dbInfo( 39, <value> )                                      <-----
DAVID note: must be an DBF opened

  I apply:      SET( _SET_MBLOCKSIZE, 64 ) 
                     AX_SetMemoBlock( 64 )

e.-  AX_ChooseOrdBagExt( ".CDX" )    //de .IDX a .CDX, para igualar a DBFCDX
   Advantage use ".IDX" as index extension default
   Clipper       use ".CDX" as index extension default (or fixed?)

f.-   AX_MemoArrayStyle( "FlexFile" )  //Igualar a DBFCDX
  Advantage manage formats "FlexFile" and "Six", and use "Six" as default
  Clipper only manage "FlexFile"

Below the message are the code that I use to manage the differences between
RDD
Note that all RDD must be set before to the default RDD, in order to set
the proper values for each one and can be used later, in the form:
SGRDD("DBFCDX")
SGRDD("DBFCDXAX")
SGRDD("DBFNTX")   (really this is unnecesary)
SGRDD( cRDDomision )  //Establecer RDD por omision   (default RDD)

Observations:
1.- This is an question
  Are the functions mentionated in Advantage RDD for Clipper, included in
ADS support in Harbour ?
  By example:  AX_SetMemoBlock( 64 ),  AX_ChooseOrdBagExt( ".CDX" ),
AX_MemoArrayStyle( "FlexFile" )

2.- In Harbour DBFCDX, do not forget to review the Clipper compatibility in
the proper commands:
SET AUTOPEN 	Sets/Gets automatic open mode.  When a production index is
                attached to a data file, when that data file is USEd, the
                index is open automatically.  Setting AUTOPEN off will not
                open the production index file.

SET AUTORDER  	Allows control of the master index which is in effect when a
                production index is used.  Setting the order to 0, orders the
                database in natural order while setting the order to 1, sets
                the first index to the active index.

SET AUTOSHARE   Autoshare allows the CDX driver to automatically open the
                index in exclusive mode if not running on the network and in
                SHARED mode if running on a network.

SET MBLOCKSIZE 	Change the block size for memo files of newly created memo
SET MEMOBLOCK   files.  You cannot change the block size of existing files.

SET MFILEEXT	Change the extension used for memo fields.

SET OPTIMIZE    Query optimization can be turned off by using the SET OPTIMIZE
                OFF command.  By default, query optimization is on.

SET STRICTREAD  When creating an index with the CDX driver, _DBFCDX bypasses
                the standard RDD hierarchy calls which force "read one record
                at time".  Instead, by default, _DBFCDX reads several records
                at once (into a big buffer);  this makes index creation up to
                two times faster.  However, this technique defeats some
                libraries (such as encryption RDDs) which depend on the
                strict RDD hierarchy calls being made.  Thus, "strict reads"
                can be turned on via SET STRICTREAD ON.

Gracias,
David Macias

FUNC SGRDD( cRDD )
//Establecimiento de RDD por omision
IF ! ISCHARACTER( cRDD ) .OR. EMPTY( cRDD )
 RETU FALSE
ENDI
cRDD := UPPE( ALLTRIM( cRDD ) )
DO CASE
CASE cRDD == "DBFNTX"            //DBFNTX, compatible con DBFNTXAX
 RDDSETDEFAULT("DBFNTX")

CASE cRDD $ "+DBFCDX+_DBFCDX+"   //DBFCDX, compatible con DBFCDXAX
 RDDSETDEFAULT("DBFCDX")
 SET( _SET_MFILEEXT, ".FPT" )    //Extension para archivos Memo
 // ( _SET_MBLOCKSIZE y _SET_AUTORDER no afectan a DBFNTX )
 SET( _SET_MBLOCKSIZE, 64 )      //Igualar a DBFCDXAX y FoxPro
 SET( _SET_AUTORDER,1 )          //Indice controlador al abrir archivo de
produccion
 SET( _SET_AUTOPEN, FALSE )      //No abrir automaticamente indice de
produccion
//DAVID: SET STRICTREAD ON       //Lectura de registro por registro en CDX

CASE cRDD == "DBFNTXAX"          //DBFNTXAX, compatible con DBFNTX
 RDDSETDEFAULT("DBFNTXAX")

CASE cRDD == "DBFCDXAX"          //DBFCDXAX, compatible con DBFCDX
 RDDSETDEFAULT("DBFCDXAX")
 SET( _SET_MFILEEXT, ".FPT" )    //Extension para archivos Memo
 // ( _SET_MBLOCKSIZE y _SET_AUTORDER no afectan a DBFNTX )
 SET( _SET_MBLOCKSIZE, 64 )      //Igualar a DBFCDXAX y FoxPro
 AX_SetMemoBlock( 64 )           //Advantage RDD
 SET( _SET_AUTORDER,1 )          //Indice controlador al abrir archivo de
produccion
 SET( _SET_AUTOPEN, FALSE )      //No abrir automaticamente indice de
produccion
//DAVID: SET STRICTREAD ON       //Lectura de registro por registro en CDX
 AX_ChooseOrdBagExt( ".CDX" )    //de .IDX a .CDX, para igualar a DBFCDX
 AX_MemoArrayStyle( "FlexFile" )  //Igualar a DBFCDX

ENDC
RETU TRUE

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 22 06:47:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David Arturo Macias Corona)
Date: Wed Aug 22 05:47:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Inter-platform
Message-ID: <3.0.6.16.20010822044548.1d5f063a@mail.udg.mx>

For those OS/2 users:

I have runned some programs 
   Harbour  0.37/BCC55.1/Windows 98/DBFNTX/DBFCDX

under OS/2, using lastest Odin files, and they run allmost fine

Curiosity, maybe I am wrong: Could an Harbour program compiled in Linux,
run under xFree86/OS2 ?

Gracias,
David Macias


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 22 07:06:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Wed Aug 22 06:06:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Inter-platform
References: <3.0.6.16.20010822044548.1d5f063a@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <3B8383DA.F1D21DA9@libero.it>

David Arturo,

Since we have an OS/2 version of harbour (on which I've spent a _lot_ of
hours :-)) I would not use Odin (which is a Win32 emulator like Wine) to run
them and, to answer your second question, a program compiled on linux cannot
run under XFree86/2 since executable file formats are quite different and
OS/2 cannot load a linux exutable (not to mention that this linux executable
could request linux dynamic libraries).

Sadly enough I don't have time to look at FiveWin sources which could be
ported to OS/2 (OS/2 PM and Win32 are very similar in a lot of aspects like
WM_ messages, resouce files, event handling etc) with, in my opinion, a
modest effort.

regards.


David Arturo Macias Corona ha scritto:

> For those OS/2 users:
>
> I have runned some programs
>    Harbour  0.37/BCC55.1/Windows 98/DBFNTX/DBFCDX
>
> under OS/2, using lastest Odin files, and they run allmost fine
>
> Curiosity, maybe I am wrong: Could an Harbour program compiled in Linux,
> run under xFree86/OS2 ?
>
> Gracias,
> David Macias
>

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 22 13:10:04 2001

In-Reply-To: <3B82EFDC.15084E38@libero.it>
References: <3B82EFDC.15084E38@libero.it>
Message-ID: <200108221209.0000016O@Internet>

** Reply to message from Maurilio Longo <maurilio.longo@libero.it> on
Wed, 22 Aug 2001 01:33:49 +0200

> NOTE: Never call hb_gt_DispBegin()/hb_gt_DispEnd() from inside gtos2.c
>            if you do you'll slow down everything and you will not respect harbour level
>            DispBegin()/DispEnd() calls.

In that case, shouldn't this apply to all of the GT libraries?
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 22 13:31:00 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Wed Aug 22 12:31:00 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2001-08-22 01:25 GMT+2
References: <3B82EFDC.15084E38@libero.it> <200108221209.0000016O@Internet>
Message-ID: <3B83DE26.A4D0DCED@libero.it>

David,

I don't know, this is an issue which arises from the way VIO windows work.

If you write onto the Logical Video Buffer whatever you write won't be shown on screen until
after you call VioShowBuf().

hb_gt_DispEnd() inside gtos2.c resyncs all of the LVB even if you changed a single character
(maybe via hb_gt_xPutch()) so calling hb_gt_DispBegin()/hb_gt_DispEnd() from, say,
hb_gt_xPutch() is a big waste of time, and if, for any reason you want every write to happen
on screen imediatly those calls will not respect the harbour level code logic.

regards.


"David G. Holm" ha scritto:

> ** Reply to message from Maurilio Longo <maurilio.longo@libero.it> on
> Wed, 22 Aug 2001 01:33:49 +0200
>
> > NOTE: Never call hb_gt_DispBegin()/hb_gt_DispEnd() from inside gtos2.c
> >            if you do you'll slow down everything and you will not respect harbour level
> >            DispBegin()/DispEnd() calls.
>
> In that case, shouldn't this apply to all of the GT libraries?
> --
> David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
> Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

looping till inkey() == 0 doesn't get stuck in a loop, but neither does a

Subject: [Harbour] Files
Message-ID: <001201c12b68$2b940a80$dfd4d7c8@culik>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0009_01C12B44.2C8A0DA0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Dear Friends

    Harbour binaries build with Borland C++ 5.5.1 by default can only open
48 files at an time, the attached file, increase this ability to 255 files
open under Borland C++ 5.5.1, Just link the files to your application or add
them to your rtl.lib(both files was compiled with bcc32 5.5.1)

 --

Regards

Luiz Rafael Culik

>Date: Wed, 22 Aug 2001 00:56:13 -0700
>From: Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>
>Subject: Re: [Harbour] Re:  Memory not released

Brian:

>  All I can offer at the moment is that I have a large FW app that is
>  based on runtime compilation of codeblocks. If I turn tracing on, I
>  no longer get any unreleased blocks reported (I did at one time).
>  Does it only happen when using DBFNTX? Last I heard, there was still
>  a lot to be finished in that rdd, which could be the source of leaks.
>
>  Can you produce any reported leaks using only RDDADS?

I still think that this does not have nothing with RDD. Remember and think
it account:
>>This error has been happening along differents versions of Harbour
>(0.33,0.34,0.35, ...0.37) in Windows 98, OS/2, WIndows 2000 ...

Older releases do not use DBFNTX, DBFCDX
and, until 0.37, I begun to use databases, and not before. I still do not
use RDDADS in Harbour, just an single DBFNTX or DBFCDX file without index

What means: " If I turn tracing on, I no longer get any unreleased blocks
reported (I did at one time)." ?

I think the error is around "macros" and their memory management

>>Line SGBLOCK( 2966 ) is an code block creation:
>>bBloque := &("{ "+bBloque+" }")
>>where bBloque is an valid character expresion to create an code block,
>including their | | characters
>One posibility could be the "management of memory" in the "macro process",
>which maybe sometimes complete the process but not release some blocks of
>memory used in that
>
>Maybe others developers have seen others cases differents to "macro", where
>"memory not released" happen. If only happen in macros, is an good point to
>start the review

Gracias,
David Macias

LRCG> Dear Friends

LRCG>     Harbour binaries build with Borland C++ 5.5.1 by default can only open
LRCG> 48 files at an time, the attached file, increase this ability to 255 files
LRCG> open under Borland C++ 5.5.1, Just link the files to your application or add
LRCG> them to your rtl.lib(both files was compiled with bcc32 5.5.1)

LRCG>  --

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 04:18:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Thu Aug 23 03:18:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Inter-platform
References: <3.0.6.16.20010822211016.1edf0018@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <3B84ADF5.9AE2C59F@libero.it>

David Arturo,

A linux program (a linux executable) cannot be run by OS/2, they have a
completely different format and request different services to the operating
system.

XFree86/2 is an OS/2 executable recompiled from XFree86 sources.

The same holds true for the linux version of harbour which is a linux executable.
Win32 harbour can be run by OS/2 using Odin because Odin reads the Win32
executable (which OS/2 doesn't know how to handle) and converts it (on the fly)
into an OS/2 one.

About OS/2 - harbour - MySQL/2 I can say that speed is good and stability is also
very good. I have only little utilities which use my /contrib/mysql class but
some of them require a couple of days of continous work to convert flat files
into MySQL tables and they work nicely.

regards.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 08:05:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Luiz Rafael Culik Guimaraes)
Date: Thu Aug 23 07:05:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Files
References: <001201c12b68$2b940a80$dfd4d7c8@culik> <631128324404.20010822224934@abacuslaw.com>
Message-ID: <001901c12bc2$74264740$ead4d7c8@culik>

Brian


>
> Luiz:
>
>   I don't understand.  My app now has 74 files open with no problem.
>
>   Where is the documentation of the 48 file limit? Is this under DOS,
>   not Windows?

Just try the code below on harbour win32 console mode with and with out the
patch. I suggest you to use the harbour/tests directory for the test

func main
Local aDir:={}
local aHand:={}
Local iHand
Local nPos
adir:=directory('*.*')

   for nPos:=1 to len(adir)
      ? 'Cur Position',nPos
      iHand:=fopen(adir[npos,1])
      aadd(ahand,ihand)
      ?'curhandle',iHand
   next
for nPos:=1 to len(aHand)
   fclose(ahand[nPos])
next

return nil

 --

Regards

Luiz Rafael Culik


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 08:14:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Aug 23 07:14:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Inter-platform
In-Reply-To: <000201c12bc0$0b80f340$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Thu, Aug 23, 2001 at 12:40:36PM +0200
References: <000101c12bbe$d9783940$0f2aa8c0@first> <000201c12bc0$0b80f340$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010823120936.X1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Aug 23, 2001 at 12:40:36PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> But we (FiveTech) are so used to GUIs, that I believe that we could build
> some basic GUIs elements without too much work, that could run on all
> operating systems quite easily, without having to use GTK or so...
> 
> Any comments ?

To work in X at the GUI level you're probably used to working at you'd want
to be looking at something like GTK (note I'm only thinking about X oriented
platforms here). AIUI, without it or something similar, you'll be having to
personally implement all the controls you're used to using under many GUIs.

X is more of a networking protocol than it is a GUI, hence the reason that
"widget sets" such as QT and GTK exist.

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 09:53:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Thu Aug 23 08:53:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour for OS2
References: <000a01c12bc7$92cd5120$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <3B84FC7D.9A4924EF@libero.it>

Antonio,

mainwin.c does not create any window.

An OS/2 PM program is the very same VIO program which issues a
WinInitialize() and a WinCreateMsgQueue() call.

At this point PM changes screen context from VIO to PM; I think I should
not call WinCreateStdWin() but simply enter vm_Do().

I mean, are FiveWin windows created by .PRG code (which, calls some C
helper function) or are they created by main() function before calling
vm_Do()?

As soon as I have your answer I'll write mainpm.c (since PM is the
difference and not OS/2).

regards.

> Maurilio,

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 10:29:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Thu Aug 23 09:29:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour for OS2
In-Reply-To: <3B84FC7D.9A4924EF@libero.it>
Message-ID: <000f01c12bd7$03142760$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

> An OS/2 PM program is the very same VIO program which issues a
> WinInitialize() and a WinCreateMsgQueue() call.

This is basically the code we used (adapted to Harbour):

#define INCL_BASE
#define INCL_WIN
#define INCL_GPI

#include <os2.h>
#include "hbapi.h"

HAB  hab;         /* Anchor Table handle */
HMQ  hmq;         /* Message Queue handle */

int main( int argc, char * argv[] )
{
   hab = WinInitialize( 0 );
   hmq = WinCreateMsgQueue( hab, 0 );

   hb_cmdargInit( argc, argv );
   hb_vmInit( TRUE );

   WinDestroyMsgQueue( hmq );
   WinTerminate( hab );

   hb_vmQuit();

   return 0;
}

HAB GetHab( void ) { return hab; }

HB_FUNC( GETHAB ) 
{ 
   hb_retnl( ( LONG ) GetHab() ); 
}

> At this point PM changes screen context from VIO to PM; I think I should
> not call WinCreateStdWin() but simply enter vm_Do().

right,

> I mean, are FiveWin windows created by .PRG code (which, calls some C
> helper function) or are they created by main() function before calling
> vm_Do()?

They are created from PRG code.

> As soon as I have your answer I'll write mainpm.c (since PM is the
> difference and not OS/2).

you are right,


Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 10:38:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Thu Aug 23 09:38:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour for OS2
In-Reply-To: <3B84FC7D.9A4924EF@libero.it>
Message-ID: <001001c12bd8$4de57c20$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

> This is basically the code we used (adapted to Harbour):

If it is ok, then we may already show a simple PM wellcome
message from a Harbour Test.prg:

function Main()

   MsgInfo( "Wellcome to Harbour for OS2 PM" )

return nil


msgbox.c

#define INCL_BASE
#define INCL_WIN
#define INCL_GPI

#include <OS2.h>
#include "hbapi.h"

HBFUNC( MSGINFO )
{
   HWND hWnd = WinQueryActiveWindow( HWND_DESKTOP, 0 );
   LPSTR szCaption = IF( PCOUNT() > 1 && ISCHAR( 2 ), hb_parc( 2 ),
"Information" );

   hb_retnl( WinMessageBox( HWND_DESKTOP, hWnd, hb_parc( 1 ), szCaption,
             0, MB_INFORMATION | MB_OK | MB_MOVEABLE | MB_APPLMODAL ) );
}


Antonio

Antonio,

WinTerminate returns so hb_vmQuit() should be called after it but, at
this point there, is no way to display anything on screen and we cannot
call any WinXXX() function from inside hb_vmQuit().

Look at the attachement :-)))))))))

regards.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 18:20:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Thu Aug 23 17:20:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] CHANGELOG: 2001-08-23 23:13 GMT+2
Message-ID: <3B857351.D65E64BA@libero.it>

2001-08-23 23:13 GMT+2 Maurilio Longo <maurilio.longo@libero.it>
   * source/vm/Makefile
     + if HB_GT_LIB == os2pm then compiles mainpm.c instead of main.c
   * source/vm/mainpm.c
     * little changes to make it work.

   NOTE: after gcc creates an executable file you need to issue an:
            emxbind -ep filename.exe
         to mark it as a PM executable, failing to do so the executable
file is a
         VIO one and all calls to WinXxx() functions will fail

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 18:40:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Thu Aug 23 17:40:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour GUI
In-Reply-To: <000301c12c19$d2edf820$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <000401c12c1b$af00f820$0f2aa8c0@first>

Up to now we already have a multiplatform code,
(very basic, I agree) but it completely hides the
own complexity of each operating system.

When we do:

function Main()

   MsgInfo( "Welcome to Harbour GUI" )

return nil

we don't need to worry about the underlaying
operating system specific requirements. That
is great! :-) We don't force the
programmer to learn each operating system
own API functions. That is the key! :-)

On a next step, we may focus on developing
a very basic Class TForm, that again may run
on any operating system, without requiring
source code changes.

Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 19:26:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Thu Aug 23 18:26:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DBFCDX / ADS
In-Reply-To: <3.0.6.16.20010822042341.1d4fde2a@mail.udg.mx>
References: <3.0.6.16.20010822042341.1d4fde2a@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <18719228238.20010823152955@abacuslaw.com>

David:

I can respond regarding rddads. Remember, it is using the ACE32.DLL
which lacks some capabilities they were able to code into the clipper
rdd (ace32 can be used by any Windows app and is not
clipper-specific).

DAMC> Next are a brief discussion of differences
DAMC> a.- OrdCondSet(): There are differents arguments and default values for
DAMC> RDD. This was reviewed before and done in Harbour (I hope)
OrdCondSet() has a single implementation with Clipper 5.3b's parameter
list.  Only rddads uses parameters after #11 now.

DAMC> b.- CDXLOCK.obj: Advantage use the locking scheme of FoxPro. CDXLOCK.obj
DAMC> must be linked with Clipper to acquire this scheme
I don't think this is an option in rddads (32-bit Advantage clients
are limited to ACE32.DLL capabilities).
I'll double-check.

DAMC> c.- SET( _SET_MBLOCKSIZE, 64 )      //Igualar a DBFCDXAX y FoxPro
DAMC>   FoxPro use 64 as default, 
DAMC>   Advantage use 64 as default, 
DAMC>   Clipper 5.3a use ** 32 ** as default, 
DAMC>   Clipper 5.3b use ** 64 ** as default
DAMC>   Below 32, there different behaviour between FoxPro, Advantage, Clipper
See Advantage docs for their specifications.
All the SET commands can be better integrated when we have the SET
LISTENER stuff available. For now, you need to use ads.ch to try to
integrated these, but there's no way to enforce consistency until the
Listener stuff works.
Some of the SETs you mention are in ads.ch. Rather than add the
others, I'll wait to see how the Listener works.

DAMC> e.-  AX_ChooseOrdBagExt( ".CDX" )    //de .IDX a .CDX, para igualar a DBFCDX
DAMC>    Advantage use ".IDX" as index extension default
DAMC>    Clipper       use ".CDX" as index extension default (or fixed?)
This depends on index type. CDX is used for multi-bag, idx for single

DAMC> f.-   AX_MemoArrayStyle( "FlexFile" )  //Igualar a DBFCDX
DAMC>   Advantage manage formats "FlexFile" and "Six", and use "Six" as default
DAMC>   Clipper only manage "FlexFile"
This won't happen in Harbour unless someone wants to hack the FlexFile
formats. Current ACE32 docs don't say anything about "Six" array
support.  I created my own arrayToString functions and converted my
stored arrays. The Remote Server doesn't know anything about Harbour
Array structures. Then there are the issues of whether Type(memofield)
returns "A" or not. I recommend biting the bullet on this one and
converting.

DAMC> Observations:
DAMC> 1.- This is an question
DAMC>   Are the functions mentionated in Advantage RDD for Clipper, included in
DAMC> ADS support in Harbour ?
DAMC>   By example:  AX_SetMemoBlock( 64 ),  AX_ChooseOrdBagExt( ".CDX" ),
DAMC> AX_MemoArrayStyle( "FlexFile" )
There are no ax* functions in Harbour. There are some ads* functions
in adsfunc.c and ads1.c (most are documented, but not all).
BUT my intention with the changes I've made to
rddads is to integrate features as much as
possible with the 5.3 rdd calls so the rdd is truly replaceable with
dbfcdx.  Ideally, no other function calls are needed, although there
are special features in ads that aren't generalized in the rdd
(encryption, etc.)

DAMC> 2.- In Harbour DBFCDX, do not forget to review the Clipper compatibility in
DAMC> the proper commands:
DAMC> SET AUTOPEN     Sets/Gets automatic open mode.  When a production index is
DAMC>                 attached to a data file, when that data file is USEd, the
DAMC>                 index is open automatically.  Setting AUTOPEN off will not
DAMC>                 open the production index file.
In ads, you cannot turn this off. Structural indexes are always opened
and cannot be closed.

DAMC> SET AUTORDER    Allows control of the master index which is in effect when a
DAMC>                 production index is used.  Setting the order to 0, orders the
DAMC>                 database in natural order while setting the order to 1, sets
DAMC>                 the first index to the active index.
This could happen.

DAMC> SET AUTOSHARE   Autoshare allows the CDX driver to automatically open the
DAMC>                 index in exclusive mode if not running on the network and in
DAMC>                 SHARED mode if running on a network.
This one's not likely. Let me know if there's any indication of such
capability in ace32, I couldn't find it.

 HTH
 
 ---===--- 
 Brian Hays

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 23 21:31:01 2001

Dear Friends

is the follow valid

char *szBuffer[6];
sprintf(szBuffer,"%n:%n\n",(fsFile.ft_ftime>>11)&0x1f,(fsFile.ft_ftime>>5)&0
x3f);

Where fsFile point to the ffblk Structure(dos.h)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 00:59:13 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Horacio_Rold=E1n?=)
Date: Thu Aug 23 23:59:13 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Help on expression
References: <001101c12c33$080fec20$b5d4d7c8@culik>
Message-ID: <00a801c12c51$6f5f1540$349e2dc8@ksoft20000507>

Should be:
char szBuffer[6]; // without the '*'

but take care of sizes in the buffer or you could get an overflow.
The numbers you 'sprintf' may be 2 digits and so the total string will be 6
+ 1 (for the \0) = 7 !

Also if you want to have fixed lenght strings you could use the format
string "%2.2n:%2.2n\n".

regards
Horacio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 04:28:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 03:28:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <000301c12c19$d2edf820$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <000501c12c6d$d03b7720$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

Lets go now for a very basic PRG code:

function Main()

   local oForm := TForm():New()

   oForm:ShowModal()

return nil

That is my idea about a generic Class TForm
for Harbour, that may run on any operating
system. Doing it that way, we hide the 
specific requirements of each operating system.

Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 05:29:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 04:29:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm for OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <000301c12c19$d2edf820$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <000601c12c76$5f7d6120$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

Lets try the following code:
(hopefully it may works :-)

TFORM.PRG

#include "hbclass.ch"
#include "os2pm.ch"   // Needed to store some OS/2 PM constant values

CLASS TForm

   DATA      hWnd

   CLASSDATA lRegistered

   METHOD    New()

   METHOD    ShowModal()

ENDCLASS

METHOD New() CLASS TForm

   local hWndClient

   DEFAULT ::lRegistered TO .f.

   if ! ::lRegistered

      // Notice that this code may be moved to a method Register()
      // so we hide again the OS API details

      WinRegisterClass( "HB_TFORM",;
                        nOr( CS_SIZEREDRAW, 0x2000001 ), 0 )
      ::lRegistered = .t.
   endif

   // Again this code may be moved to a method Create() to hide the
   // OS API details

   ::hWnd = WinCreateStdWindow( HWND_DESKTOP,;
                                WS_VISIBLE,;
                                nOr( FCF_TITLEBAR, FCF_SYSMENU,;
                                FCF_SIZEBORDER, FCF_TASKLIST,;
                                FCF_MINMAX, FCF_SHELLPOSITION ),;
                                "HB_TFORM", "Harbour TForm",;
                                nOr( WS_SYNCPAINT, WS_VISIBLE ),,,;
                                @hWndClient ) // Not used yet

return Self

METHOD ShowModal() CLASS TForm

   HB_PM_ShowModal()

return nil


Now we need a os2pm.c module with the wrappers
to the OS2 PM functions:

#define INCL_BASE
#define INCL_WIN
#define INCL_GPI

#include <os2.h>
#include "hbapi.h"

HAB hb_pm_GetHab( void );

HB_FUNC( WINREGISTERCLASS )
{

   hb_retl( WinRegisterClass( hb_pm_GetHab(),   /* anchor block handle */
                              hb_parc( 1 ),     /* Class Name */
                              ( PFNWP ) WinDefWindowProc,  /* default Class
procedure */
                              hb_parnl( 2 ),     /* style */
                              hb_parnl( 3 ) ) ); /* extra bytes */
}

HB_FUNC( WINCREATESTDWINDOW )
{
   ULONG lFrame = hb_parnl( 3 );
   HWND hWndClient, hWndFrame;

   hb_retnl( ( LONG ) hWndFrame =
             WinCreateStdWindow( ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 ), /* hWndParent */
                                 hb_parnl( 2 ), /* style */
                                 &lFrame,       /* lFrame */
                                 hb_parc( 4 ),  /* cClassName */
                                 hb_parc( 5 ),  /* cCaption */
                                 hb_parnl( 6 ), /* lStyleClient */
                                 hb_parnl( 7 ), /* hModule */
                                 hb_parnl( 8 ), /* nId */
                       ( PHWND ) &hWndClient ) ); /* Window client handle */

   hb_stornl( ( LONG ) hWndClient, 9 );
}

HB_FUNC( HB_PM_SHOWMODAL )
{
   QMSG qmsg;
   HAB  hab = hb_pm_GetHab();

   while( WinGetMsg( hab, &qmsg, 0, 0, 0 ) )
   {
      WinDispatchMsg( hab, &qmsg );
   }
}

/* nOr() is a very used function */

HB_FUNC( NOR )
{
   LONG lRet = 0;
   WORD i = 0;

   while( i < hb_pcount() )
      lRet = lRet | hb_parnl( ++i );

   hb_retnl( lRet );
}

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 05:40:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 04:40:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
In-Reply-To: <20010824092928.L1437@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <000701c12c77$dca1b4c0$0f2aa8c0@first>

Dave,

> Might I suggest that something be done to "namespace" such classes? I'd
> imagine that TForm would be a very common class name amongst OO coding
> Clipper programmers.

It is a good suggestion, but I don't think it will
be needed in the future. I explain why:

Later on, all forms will inherit from TForm, so they
may be named Class TForm1, TForm2, or TWhatEver. 

Besides that, Harbour (as Clipper) provides a Class TBrowse,
and there seems no need to name it as HB_TBrowse.

If we turn Class TForm into a Harbour standard, then I don't
think that will be a big problem.

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 06:29:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 24 05:29:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm for OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <000601c12c76$5f7d6120$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 10:25:46AM +0200
References: <000301c12c19$d2edf820$0f2aa8c0@first> <000601c12c76$5f7d6120$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010824102810.M1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 10:25:46AM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> Lets try the following code:
> (hopefully it may works :-)
> 
> TFORM.PRG
> 
> #include "hbclass.ch"
> #include "os2pm.ch"   // Needed to store some OS/2 PM constant values
> 
> CLASS TForm
>
> [SNIP]

I know it's early days yet but I was thinking about how this would pan out.
>From what's been said so far it would appear that there is some interest in
designing a cross platform GUI framework, if only a high level approach (as
we all know, each platform has it's own unique ideas of what form part of a
"GUI").

So, in an idle moment, I was wondering about the design of this. Is the idea
that it would be designed kind of like the GT libraries? That is, a common
interface which is implemented in various libraries (one for Win32, one for
OS/2 PM, one for KDE, one for GTK+, one for Tk, one for Motif, one for...)?

Given this I was wondering if it might be an idea to map out some of the top
level classes (if only the form class for a moment) and implement it as an
abstract class. That way anyone wishing to have a crack at writing support
for their environment can give some thought, and input, into what the
interface of that abstract class would look like.

I'm thinking about this sort of thing (HGF == Harbour GUI Framework):

  rtl/hgf/absform.prg     - Includes HB_TAbstractForm()

  rtl/hgf/win32/form.prg  - HB_TForm() inherits from HB_TAbstractForm()
  rtl/hgf/os2pm/form.prg  - HB_TForm() inherits from HB_TAbstractForm()
  rtl/hgf/kde/form.prg    - HB_TForm() inherits from HB_TAbstractForm()
  rtl/hgf/gtk/form.prg    - HB_TForm() inherits from HB_TAbstractForm()
  ... and so on

This way there's a known interface that has to be implemented within each
GUI implementation library.

The reason I raise this so early is that it's my understanding that some GUI
systems work quite different from others and this might need to be taken
into account at the abstract level. For example, Win32, OS/2 and the Palm
GUI (to name three that I've had experience with) are all very much the
same. On the other hand, GTK is quite different because it employs callbacks
rather than using a central message cracker.

> /* nOr() is a very used function */
> 
> HB_FUNC( NOR )
> {
>    LONG lRet = 0;
>    WORD i = 0;
> 
>    while( i < hb_pcount() )
>       lRet = lRet | hb_parnl( ++i );
> 
>    hb_retnl( lRet );
> }

I was also thinking that HB_NOR() and friends might be useful (when
correctly namespaced) as part of the RTL proper.

--

software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 06:34:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 24 05:34:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Linux GUI
In-Reply-To: <000801c12c79$b2f2b500$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 10:49:34AM +0200
References: <000201c12c19$5b22dae0$0f2aa8c0@first> <000801c12c79$b2f2b500$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010824103327.N1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 10:49:34AM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> What do you think about creating a Linux GUI applications entry point ?
> 
> Is that possible ? 

I guess it's possible, but, as I said the other day, it's not so much a case
of creating a "Linux GUI" application entry point, it's more a case of
creating GUI entry points for someone's "widget set" of choice. The common
libraries for this sort of thing these days are, as you know, GTK and KDE.

In the unlikely event that I get some free time to play with this I'm
thinking that this is the perfect excuse for me to get back into GTK
programming (I've dabbled with KDE and GTK but never had the need to do
anything serious). Not that this should put off anyone with more time and
more need for this than I.

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 06:39:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 24 05:39:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
In-Reply-To: <000701c12c77$dca1b4c0$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 10:36:25AM +0200
References: <20010824092928.L1437@hagbard.davep.org> <000701c12c77$dca1b4c0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010824103820.O1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 10:36:25AM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > Might I suggest that something be done to "namespace" such classes? I'd
> > imagine that TForm would be a very common class name amongst OO coding
> > Clipper programmers.
> 
> It is a good suggestion, but I don't think it will be needed in the
> future. I explain why:
> 
> Later on, all forms will inherit from TForm, so they may be named Class
> TForm1, TForm2, or TWhatEver.

Perhaps you've missed the thrust of my point? I'm thinking about existing
Clipper code for programmers that do OO. TForm would seem to be quite an
obvious and common name for all sorts of uses and anything we can do to keep
the namespace as wide as possible has to be a good thing.

Put another way, it doesn't hurt for us to add a prefix to help make the
namespace wider does it? It might hurt someone if we don't.

> Besides that, Harbour (as Clipper) provides a Class TBrowse, and there
> seems no need to name it as HB_TBrowse.

That's something entirely different. We're implementing a Clipper compatible
compiler and RTL so obviously we didn't need to do that. However, there is a
standard rule in harbour that if we add a new symbol to the RTL it should be
prefixed so as to place it well and truely within the HB_ namespace. That
way anyone using harbour knows that the number of symbol clashes are reduced
and that they've only got problems if their code contains symbols that are
prefixed with HB_.

> If we turn Class TForm into a Harbour standard, then I don't think that
> will be a big problem.

This is what I'm getting at, if we're going to create a standard we should
be environmentally friendly about it. We should namespace those standard
names. It doesn't cost us anything but it does deliver benefits.

-- 
Harbour is a free   | Harbour Web Site: http://www.harbour-project.org/
software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

> it as an abstract class.

I fully agree :-)

> I'm thinking about this sort of thing (HGF == Harbour GUI Framework):

>   ... and so on

Looks great, Dave.

> I was also thinking that HB_NOR() and friends might be useful (when
> correctly namespaced) as part of the RTL proper.

Yes, as they are used a lot of times, when
it comes to manage GUIs constant values,

(I don't like so many HB_ around, but... :-)

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 06:44:39 2001

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 07:14:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Fri Aug 24 06:14:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
Message-ID: <OF2EC72246.50BF546E-ONCA256AB2.0037FBF6@bunge.com.au>

harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 07:59:46 PM:

> > Instead of HB_TForm, I'd go with THBForm, or THBGForm, or even
> > THarbourForm.
> 
>   THarbourForm looks nice. It is a long name, but
>   it should not matter, as later on a Visual IDE will
>   write it automatically ;-)
> 
> > perhaps it's worth emulating that to some degree ?
> 
> Haven't you already noticed it ? ;-)
> ssshhhhhhh...

I noticed it in the name, but not in the execution (the code snippet you 
posted before). For example, the VCL's TForm isn't a base class - it's 
derived from TWinControl (or something like that). It makes sense this 
way, since windows are controls, too. I'm pretty sure this holds in most 
of the GUIs around today (considering MS just ripped-off the existing ones 
of the time when they created the Windows API).

Perhaps it's necessary to derive a THarbourControl from TObject, and build 
off that?

Mabster

That's an impossible question to answer, which is why I raised the issue int
he first place. Not to mention that it's a long standing "standard" that
when adding new symbols to harbour's RTL, wherever possible, we prefix them.

> Anyhow, the name is not the main thing... 

Agreed, I never suggested it was, but it's worth ironing out any obvious
wrinkles as early as possible and using up the namespace without a prefix
seems to be one such wrinkle.

may refine it more and more.

The target now it should be that we all get a clear
understanding about how we are building the Harbour GUI
layer.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 07:32:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 24 06:32:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Linux GUI
In-Reply-To: <000b01c12c80$ce4d6820$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 11:40:27AM +0200
References: <20010824103327.N1437@hagbard.davep.org> <000b01c12c80$ce4d6820$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010824113150.T1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 11:40:27AM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > it's more a case of creating GUI entry points for someone's "widget set"
> > of choice.
> 
> I guess that even those "widget sets", may have a common entry point.

Sure they do, that's my point.

> Doesn't Linux provide a standard -basic- way to show a MsgInfo() alike GUI
> message on the screen ?

But you seem to have missed my point. Asking if Linux as a function for
placing a message box on a GUI makes no sense. Linux is a kernel. Even if we
take the wider meaning of Linux (AKA GNU/Linux), the one that means a whole
operating system, the GUI isn't embedded in the operating system, it's an
optional extra that works on top of the OS. Hence the reason that the GUI
that is commonly used (The X Window System) has been ported to other
operating systems (Win32, OS/2, ...).

It's the "widget sets" that provide this sort of thing and very few, if any,
of these widget sets have anything to do with Linux itself. The likes of
KDE, GTK, Tk, Motif, etc.. are generally cross platform.

So, in answer to your question, no, it doesn't.

--

http://www.davep.org/           |  sawfish.el - Sawfish mode.
Emacs:                          |  uptimes.el - Record emacs uptimes.
http://www.davep.org/emacs/     | quickurl.el - Recall lists of URLs.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 07:37:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 06:37:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Linux GUI
In-Reply-To: <20010824104326.P1437@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <001001c12c88$52c06740$0f2aa8c0@first>

Dave,

> <URL:http://www.gtk.org/tutorial/ch-gettingstarted.html> might be of
> interest to anyone wanting to see what your average GTK application looks
> like at the code level.

I am pretty sure we may organize the GTK messages
mapping into a much better and simpler way. 

Once we start reviewing how to map GUI messages from
the Harbour GUI layer, you will see how GTK management
will look really different and much simpler.

Probably we may just need now something like this:

Linux GTK application entry point proposal:

int main( int argc, char * argv[] )
{
   gtk_init( &argc, &argv );

   hb_cmdargInit( argc, argv );
   hb_vmInit( TRUE );
   hb_vmQuit();   

   gtk_main_quit();

   return 0;
}


Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 07:51:24 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)

Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?

harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 08:33:13 PM:

> On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 12:22:02PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> 
> > All controls are specialized windows, so its easier to inherit a
> > THarbourControl from a THarbourForm.
> 
> So you're not expecting to create support for non-visual controls? Won't
> that cause problems for the GUI builder you have in mind?

Excellent point, except that off the cuff I can't think of a "non-visual 
control". Perhaps the notion of shortcut keys etc could be considered 
"controls"?

Also, the VCL derives TWinControl from TControl, which means that 
non-windowed controls (ie controls that can't get focus, like the buttons 
in the caption of a form) are supported too.

Mabster

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 08:02:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Fri Aug 24 07:02:02 2001

Antonio,

harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 08:46:58 PM:

> > So you're not expecting to create support for non-visual controls? 
Won't
> > that cause problems for the GUI builder you have in mind?
> 
> We may just create a Class THarbourNonVisualControl(), without
> inheriting it from THarbourForm().

I think there are countless workarounds you could employ, but to be honest 
the best thing to do now (before the coding really starts) is sit down and 
draw up a really detailed plan of the class heirarchy. The framework 
you're imagining will be great for RAD, but you can't use RAD paradigms to 
create it - it'll have to be done the hard way :)

That said, I'll be happy to discuss the heirarchy itself and lend my 
opinions whether or not they're asked for :)

Mabster

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 08:28:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 24 07:28:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
In-Reply-To: <OF10F5E19C.B817F060-ONCA256AB2.003B6722@bunge.com.au>; from mhamilton@bunge.com.au on Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 08:50:32PM +1000

Message-ID: <20010824122701.D4867@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 08:50:32PM +1000, mhamilton@bunge.com.au wrote:
> harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 08:33:13 PM:
> 
> > On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 12:22:02PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> > 
> > > All controls are specialized windows, so its easier to inherit a
> > > THarbourControl from a THarbourForm.
> > 
> > So you're not expecting to create support for non-visual controls? Won't
> > that cause problems for the GUI builder you have in mind?
> 
> Excellent point, except that off the cuff I can't think of a "non-visual
> control". Perhaps the notion of shortcut keys etc could be considered
> "controls"?

The VCL is chock full of non-visual controls (think of TTimer, TMainMenu,
TPopupMenu, any of the dialog controls or many of the database oriented
controls for example). Moreover, programmers themselves write lots of
non-visual controls. A large class hierarchy that I've written for Delphi
has lots of non-visual controls in it that allow other programmers to
drag/drop an application without the need to actually write any code.

I'd say that well over half of the controls in that library are non-visual.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 08:30:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (phil krylov)
Date: Fri Aug 24 07:30:03 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] Linux GUI
In-Reply-To: <001101c12c88$ee51d7c0$0f2aa8c0@first>
References: <001101c12c88$ee51d7c0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <8943448125.20010824153057@mail.ru>

Hello Antonio,

Some time ago I started writing an XBase++ library (with Harbour
in mind) which is an XBase OO layer for GTK (currently it
uses XBase++ and GTK+ for Windows, but sure I want it to compile with
Harbour and GTK/Linux). For now, about 1/3 of all GTK objects are
implemented.

Maybe we should start a sourceforge group for this library so that
other people can take part in development?

This is the sample hello.prg:

/* -*- mode: xpp -*- example-start helloworld helloworld.prg */
#include "gtk.ch"

#ifdef __HARBOUR__
#define PValue __PValue
#endif


INIT PROCEDURE gtkinit(par)
  LOCAL aPar:={}
  FOR i:=1 TO PCount()
    AAdd(aPar, PValue(i))
  NEXT
  /* This is called in all GTK applications. Arguments are parsed
   * from the command line and are returned to the application. */
  gtk_init(Len(aPar), aPar)
RETURN
  
FUNCTION main
  LOCAL oWindow, oButton, oBox1
  PUBLIC stop:=.F.

  gdk_threads_enter()
  
  /* create a new window */
  oWindow = GtkWindow():new()
  oWindow:set_title("Hello buttons!")
    
  /* When the window (GtkObject) is given the "delete_event" signal (this is given
   * by the window manager, usually by the "close" option, or on the
   * titlebar), we ask it to run a code block. */
    /* If you return .F. in the "delete_event" signal handler,
     * GTK will emit the "destroy" signal. Returning .T. means
     * you don't want the window to be destroyed.
     * This is useful for popping up 'are you sure you want to quit?'
     * type dialogs. */
  oWindow:signal_connect("delete_event", {|o,e| gtk_main_quit(), .F. })
    
  /* Sets the border width of the window (GtkContainer). */
  oWindow:set_border_width(10)
  
  /* We create a box to pack widgets into.  This is described in detail
   * in the "packing" section. The box is not really visible, it
   * is just used as a tool to arrange widgets. */
  oBox1 = GtkHBox():new(.F., 0)
  oWindow:add(oBox1)
    
  /* Creates a new button with the label "Hello World". */
  oButton = GtkButton():new("Button1")
  
  /* When the button receives the "clicked" signal, it will call the
   * specified code block. */
  oButton:signal_connect("clicked", {|o| g_print("hello ") })
  
  /* Instead of gtk_container_add, we pack this button into the invisible
   * box, which has been packed into the window. */
  oBox1:pack_start(oButton, .T., .T., 0)

  oButton = GtkButton():new("Button 2")
  oButton:signal_connect("clicked", {|o| g_print("hello2 "), o:destroy() })
  oBox1:pack_start(oButton, .T., .T., 0)
    
  /* The final step is to display this newly created widgets and the window. */
  oWindow:show_all()
  
  /* All GTK applications must have a gtk_main(). Control ends here and waits
  * for an event to occur (like a key press or mouse event). */
  gtk_main()
  gdk_threads_leave()
  RETURN 0
/* example-end */

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 08:50:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)

if the proposed Harbour Linux GTK entry point may work or not.

GtkWidget * gtk_input_dialog_new( void );

seems something easy to test, though it is not exactly
a MessageBox() alike function.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 08:56:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 07:56:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
In-Reply-To: <20010824122701.D4867@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <001b01c12c93$2b890820$0f2aa8c0@first>

Dave,

> The VCL is chock full of non-visual controls (think of TTimer, TMainMenu,
> TPopupMenu, any of the dialog controls or many of the database oriented
> controls for example). 

But that is a totally different concept.

Those non-visual controls are in fact visual controls
(i.e. you see them, you can click, drag, delete them,
I mean from the builder itself).

But later on, when the app is running, the builder does
not create visual controls for them.

Anyhow, those non visual controls are specifically 
managed and created by the builder (the visual IDE),
so there is no point to care about them now. And
just one Class will be enough to support them.

Antonio

phil krylov ha scritto:

> Hello Antonio,
>
> Some time ago I started writing an XBase++ library (with Harbour
> in mind) which is an XBase OO layer for GTK (currently it
> uses XBase++ and GTK+ for Windows, but sure I want it to compile with
> Harbour and GTK/Linux). For now, about 1/3 of all GTK objects are
> implemented.
>
> Maybe we should start a sourceforge group for this library so that
> other people can take part in development?
>
> This is the sample hello.prg:
>
> /* -*- mode: xpp -*- example-start helloworld helloworld.prg */
> #include "gtk.ch"
>
> #ifdef __HARBOUR__
> #define PValue __PValue
> #endif
>
> INIT PROCEDURE gtkinit(par)
>   LOCAL aPar:={}
>   FOR i:=1 TO PCount()
>     AAdd(aPar, PValue(i))
>   NEXT
>   /* This is called in all GTK applications. Arguments are parsed
>    * from the command line and are returned to the application. */
>   gtk_init(Len(aPar), aPar)
> RETURN
>
> FUNCTION main
>   LOCAL oWindow, oButton, oBox1
>   PUBLIC stop:=.F.
>
>   gdk_threads_enter()

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 09:06:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 08:06:02 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] Linux GUI
In-Reply-To: <8943448125.20010824153057@mail.ru>
Message-ID: <001c01c12c94$99406240$0f2aa8c0@first>

Phil,

Your help on the GTK issues may be very important here.
Many thanks in advance! :-)

I have reviewed your GTK proposal, but I have a
different approach on mind. I am not saying yours is
wrong. Yours is API based, so the programmers needs
to know GTK, and that is what we want to hide :-)

We do want to have a multiplatform Class THarbourForm
that may run on any GUI without having to change the
application source code.

Just a first question :-)

Is there a Windows MessageBox() alike function on GTK ?
We want to check if we have a valid Linux GTK entry point.

I am sure we may use a lot of portions and feedback
from your source code, if you agree.

thanks again,

Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 09:15:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Fri Aug 24 08:15:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
Message-ID: <OF13BF8902.3A437A02-ONCA256AB2.00420902@bunge.com.au>

harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 09:27:01 PM:

> On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 08:50:32PM +1000, mhamilton@bunge.com.au wrote:
> > harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 08:33:13 PM:
> >
> > Excellent point, except that off the cuff I can't think of a 
"non-visual
> > control". Perhaps the notion of shortcut keys etc could be considered
> > "controls"?
> 
> The VCL is chock full of non-visual controls (think of TTimer, 
TMainMenu,
> TPopupMenu, any of the dialog controls or many of the database oriented
> controls for example). Moreover, programmers themselves write lots of
> non-visual controls. A large class hierarchy that I've written for 
Delphi
> has lots of non-visual controls in it that allow other programmers to
> drag/drop an application without the need to actually write any code.
> 
> I'd say that well over half of the controls in that library are 
non-visual.

Ah. This is just a terminology thing. I think of things like TTimer as 
just "components", rather than "non-visual controls". A "control" to me 
*means* that it's visual.

TMenu and TPopupMenu, however, walk a fine line between "non-visual" and 
"visual" when you think about it. Dialogs, too.

But this is all academic if Antonio wants to forge ahead with his original 
design.

My suggestion:

TObject
  THarbourControl
    THarbourWinControl
      THarbourForm (or maybe THarbourWindow)
      THarbourButton
      THarbourEdit
      etc etc
    THarbourMainMenu
    THarbourTimer
    THarbourToolbar
    THarbourToolButton
    THarbourStatusBar
    THarbourDialog
      THarbourOpenDialog
      THarbourSaveDialog
      THarbourPrintDialog
      etc etc

And of course you'd have to build into this the same sort of features the 
VCL has, such as Persistance and the neat Event mechanism (or maybe a 
smarter "publish and subscribe" mechanism like JBuilder's component 
library).

Mabster

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 09:19:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Fri Aug 24 08:19:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
Message-ID: <OFC56EA9B3.6FAD5ED3-ONCA256AB2.00437CA0@bunge.com.au>

harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 09:38:19 PM:

> > > We may just create a Class THarbourNonVisualControl(), without
> > > inheriting it from THarbourForm().
> >
> > That would then make enumerating controls on a form just a little 
harder
> > than is required.
> 
> I don't understand what you mean.
> 
> What is it "enumerating controls" ?

This sort of thing (Delphi code, more or less):

begin
  for i := 0 to MainForm.ComponentCount - 1 do
  begin
    if MainForm.Components[i].ClassNameIs('TForm') then
      {...}
    else if MainForm.Components[i].ClassNameIs('TMenu') then
      {...}
  end;
end;

HTH,
Mab

Hello Maurilio,

Phil.

ML> regards.

ML> phil krylov ha scritto:

>> Hello Antonio,
>>
>> Some time ago I started writing an XBase++ library (with Harbour
>> in mind) which is an XBase OO layer for GTK (currently it
>> uses XBase++ and GTK+ for Windows, but sure I want it to compile with
>> Harbour and GTK/Linux). For now, about 1/3 of all GTK objects are
>> implemented.
>>
>> Maybe we should start a sourceforge group for this library so that
>> other people can take part in development?
>>
>> This is the sample hello.prg:
>>
>> /* -*- mode: xpp -*- example-start helloworld helloworld.prg */
>> #include "gtk.ch"
>>
>> #ifdef __HARBOUR__
>> #define PValue __PValue
>> #endif
>>
>> INIT PROCEDURE gtkinit(par)
>>   LOCAL aPar:={}
>>   FOR i:=1 TO PCount()
>>     AAdd(aPar, PValue(i))
>>   NEXT
>>   /* This is called in all GTK applications. Arguments are parsed
>>    * from the command line and are returned to the application. */
>>   gtk_init(Len(aPar), aPar)
>> RETURN
>>
>> FUNCTION main
>>   LOCAL oWindow, oButton, oBox1
>>   PUBLIC stop:=.F.
>>
>>   gdk_threads_enter()

ML> --
ML>  __________
ML> |  |  | |__| md2520@mclink.it
ML> |_|_|_|____| Team OS/2 Italia


ML> _______________________________________________
ML> Harbour mailing list
ML> Harbour@matrixlist.com
ML> http://www.matrixlist.com/mailman/listinfo/harbour

ML> Thank you for participating in The Harbour Project.  Be sure to check
ML> http://www.Harbour-Project.org

 phil                            mailto:phil@mail.ru


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 09:30:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (phil krylov)
Date: Fri Aug 24 08:30:03 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] Linux GUI
In-Reply-To: <001a01c12c92$5f7a9140$0f2aa8c0@first>
References: <001a01c12c92$5f7a9140$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <16747035863.20010824163045@mail.ru>

Hello Antonio,

Friday, August 24, 2001, 3:46:12 PM, you wrote:

AL> Dave,

>>> Does the GTK provides a Win MessageBox() alike function ?
>> 
>> I think it does, but I can't say with any degree of certainty. See
>> <URL:http://www.gtk.org/> for the GTK documentation.

AL> I am just looking for an easy and quick sample to check
AL> if the proposed Harbour Linux GTK entry point may work or not.

AL> GtkWidget * gtk_input_dialog_new( void );

AL> seems something easy to test, though it is not exactly
AL> a MessageBox() alike function.

This is what i borrowed from GTK 1.3(unstable) reference. The stable
version 1.2 doesn't support it:

 dialog = gtk_message_dialog_new (main_application_window,
                                  GTK_DIALOG_DESTROY_WITH_PARENT,
                                  GTK_MESSAGE_ERROR,
                                  GTK_BUTTONS_CLOSE,
                                  "Error loading file 's': s",
                                  filename, g_strerror (errno));
 response = gtk_dialog_run (GTK_DIALOG (dialog));
 gtk_widget_destroy (dialog);
 
-- 
Best regards,
 phil                            mailto:phil@mail.ru

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 09:52:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 08:52:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
In-Reply-To: <OF13BF8902.3A437A02-ONCA256AB2.00420902@bunge.com.au>
Message-ID: <002001c12c9a$fb4e8f60$0f2aa8c0@first>

Mabster,

> Ah. This is just a terminology thing. I think of things like TTimer as
> just "components", rather than "non-visual controls". A "control" to me
> *means* that it's visual.

I agree. But again, I insist that "components" are just
classes to be used by the "builder". Now we are at a source
code level, not at an automatic builder level.

> My suggestion:
>
> TObject

All Harbour objects automatically inherit from Harbour TObject.
So we already have that. Your hierarchy proposal seems ok to me.

> And of course you'd have to build into this the same sort of features the
> VCL has, such as Persistance

Harbour will have a wonderfull and incredible simple
"persistance" technology, but that is something I will keep
secret by now ;-)

> and the neat Event mechanism

Same for Harbour. Why not ? :-)


Antonio



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 09:54:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 08:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
In-Reply-To: <OFC56EA9B3.6FAD5ED3-ONCA256AB2.00437CA0@bunge.com.au>
Message-ID: <002101c12c9b$61f231e0$0f2aa8c0@first>

Mab,

Class THarbourForm may have a aControls and
a aComponents arrays. That simple! :-)

for n = 1 to MainForm:nComponentCount
   if MainForm:aComponents[ n ]:ClassName() == "TForm"
      ...
   else
      ...
next


Antonio

> begin
>   for i := 0 to MainForm.ComponentCount - 1 do
>   begin
>     if MainForm.Components[i].ClassNameIs('TForm') then
>       {...}
>     else if MainForm.Components[i].ClassNameIs('TMenu') then
>       {...}
>   end;
> end;

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 10:04:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 24 09:04:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
In-Reply-To: <001901c12c91$460690c0$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 01:38:19PM +0200
References: <20010824122334.C4867@hagbard.davep.org> <001901c12c91$460690c0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010824140201.A1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 01:38:19PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > That would then make enumerating controls on a form just a little harder
> > than is required.
> 
> I don't understand what you mean.
> 
> What is it "enumerating controls" ?

Have you used any of the MS Window's Enum functions? Similar to that sort of
thing. 

IOW looping over all the siblings of a control and doing something with
them. If the class hierarchy is constructed well it makes filtering the
items you enumerate quite easy.

To illustrate, here's a little function I use a lot when doing component
work in Delphi:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
Function FindFirstComponentOfType( AClass : TComponentClass; oWhere : TComponent ) : TComponent;
Var
  i : Integer;
Begin

  // Nil is the result if nothing is found.
  Result := Nil;

  // Loop thru all the child components of oWhere...
  For i := 0 To oWhere.ComponentCount - 1 Do
    // ...is this of the right kind of class?
    If oWhere.Components[ i ] Is AClass Then
    Begin
      // It is, return it.
      Result := oWhere.Components[ i ];
      Break;
    End;

End;
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

If the hierarchy goes from least specific to most specific (non-visual to
visual in the case of this discussion) then it makes things like the above
work well.

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 10:04:42 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 24 09:04:42 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
In-Reply-To: <001b01c12c93$2b890820$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 01:51:54PM +0200
References: <20010824122701.D4867@hagbard.davep.org> <001b01c12c93$2b890820$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010824135505.Z1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 01:51:54PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > The VCL is chock full of non-visual controls (think of TTimer,
> > TMainMenu, TPopupMenu, any of the dialog controls or many of the
> > database oriented controls for example).
> 
> But that is a totally different concept.

Different from what? The point here is that there's a common ancestor of all
types of "controls". That's something that VCL has. For example, in VCL a
TForm inherits from a TCustomForm which inherits via a couple of other
levels. from TComponent (which is where non visual controls inherit from).

> Those non-visual controls are in fact visual controls (i.e. you see them,
> you can click, drag, delete them, I mean from the builder itself).

Except when you instantiate them at run-time, but that's beside the point.
The point here is that the various non-visual controls inherit from
TComponent, as does (for example) TForm. All types of control, visual and
non-visual, have a common ancestor. That's what the mabster was getting at.

> Anyhow, those non visual controls are specifically managed and created by
> the builder (the visual IDE), so there is no point to care about them now.
> And just one Class will be enough to support them.

Those controls aren't specifically created by the builder, not in Delphi
anyway. They're as much under my control as they are under the control of
Delphi's IDE.

--

On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 10:06:00PM +1000, mhamilton@bunge.com.au wrote:
> harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 09:27:01 PM:
> 
> > I'd say that well over half of the controls in that library are
> > non-visual.
> 
> Ah. This is just a terminology thing. I think of things like TTimer as
> just "components", rather than "non-visual controls". A "control" to me
> *means* that it's visual.

Apologies, I was trying to keep away from Delphi terminology to keep things
as generic as possible but I guess I've confused the Delphi hackers now? <g>

My point was, as you'll probably agree, that there are "controls" that
actually take up space on a form (visual controls) and there are controls
that don't (non-visual controls, AKA components in Delphi speak). What we
both seem to agree on is that "non-visual" is the parent of "visual". As per
VCL. Yeah?

> My suggestion:
> 
> TObject
>   THarbourControl
>     THarbourWinControl
>       THarbourForm (or maybe THarbourWindow)
> [SNIP]

Yeah, that's exactly the sort of thing I had in mind too. Note that we'd
probably want to be inserting some abstract classes in there too as the
anchor points for the platform specific splits (see my other email about
that).

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 10:35:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 24 09:35:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
In-Reply-To: <002101c12c9b$61f231e0$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 02:50:41PM +0200
References: <OFC56EA9B3.6FAD5ED3-ONCA256AB2.00437CA0@bunge.com.au> <002101c12c9b$61f231e0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010824143437.C1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 02:50:41PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> Class THarbourForm may have a aControls and
> a aComponents arrays. That simple! :-)

Why would you want to separate controls from components?

> for n = 1 to MainForm:nComponentCount
>    if MainForm:aComponents[ n ]:ClassName() == "TForm"
>       ...
>    else
>       ...
> next
> 
> > begin
> >   for i := 0 to MainForm.ComponentCount - 1 do
> >   begin
> >     if MainForm.Components[i].ClassNameIs('TForm') then
> >       {...}
> >     else if MainForm.Components[i].ClassNameIs('TMenu') then
> >       {...}
> >   end;
> > end;

You're both missing a key point here because you're both testing class
names. Often you want to enumerate classes based on their capability, not
their names. Capability is tested by checking that a class is of or is
descended from a certain type.

This is why getting the inheritance tree "just so" is important. This is why
it would be normal to have (for example) a Form, a "non-visual control" and
some other control have a common ancestor, it lets the programmer filter the
enumeration at any level they wish.

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 10:42:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (phil krylov)
Date: Fri Aug 24 09:42:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Linux GUI
In-Reply-To: <631282531.20010824171606@belacy.belgorod.su>
References: <001101c12c88$ee51d7c0$0f2aa8c0@first>
 <8943448125.20010824153057@mail.ru>
 <631282531.20010824171606@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <16251374482.20010824174303@mail.ru>

Hello Alexander,

Friday, August 24, 2001, 5:16:06 PM, you wrote:

ASK> On  Friday, August 24, 2001, 15:30 phil krylov <phil@mail.ru> wrote:

pk>> Some time ago I started writing an XBase++ library (with Harbour
pk>> in mind) which is an XBase OO layer for GTK (currently it
pk>> uses XBase++ and GTK+ for Windows, but sure I want it to compile with
pk>> Harbour and GTK/Linux).

ASK>  Just for interest, what is the reason to write XBase++ GTK layer ?
ASK>  Haven't they its own native GUI functionality ?

Well, there is such reason as cross-platform portability (i have
no XBase on Unix or Mac), but this is not the real reason.
The real reason is GTK's open-sourceness. XBaseParts don't have such
enhanced functionality as GTK has, and I can not enhance them.

We're writing (converting to GUI from old Clipper code) a
clipper-based DBMS for comparative linguistics. Databases we're using
contain a lot of text in mixed languages, encodings and scripts.
What we really need from GTK (unavailable in XBParts) is GtkText
 - a formatted multifont text editor control. Currently we're using
 standard windows RichEdit control, but it is awfully buggy,
 non-portable to other platforms and non-extendable.

-- 
Best regards,
 phil                            mailto:phil@mail.ru

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 11:02:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 10:02:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm for OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <000601c12c76$5f7d6120$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <002b01c12ca4$d2485920$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

Lets add these two methods to get a feeling
how to manage properties a la Delphi :-)

   // Should we call it "Caption" only ?

   METHOD cCaption() INLINE WinGetText( ::hWnd ) 

   METHOD _cCaption( cNewCaption ) INLINE ;
                    WinSetWindowText( ::hWnd, cNewCaption )

...

HB_FUNC( WINSETWINDOWTEXT )
{
   hb_retl( WinSetWindowText( ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 ), hb_parc( 2 ) ) );
}

HB_FUNC( WINGETTEXT )
{
   BYTE bBuffer[ 255 ];

   WinQueryWindowText( ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 ), 254, bBuffer );
   hb_retc( bBuffer );
}

Now you may enhance the little sample:

function Main()

   local oForm := TForm():New()

   oForm:cCaption = "Hello World!"

   MsgInfo( oForm:cCaption )

   oForm:ShowModal()

return nil


BTW, I would propose to change DATA hWnd into DATA Handle,
as on other GUIs we may be talking about "handles" (widgets, and
so on) instead of "windows" :-)

Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 11:05:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Fri Aug 24 10:05:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
Message-ID: <OFA60E65BC.A245DD49-ONCA256AB2.004CFFCF@bunge.com.au>

harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 11:09:45 PM:

> My point was, as you'll probably agree, that there are "controls" that
> actually take up space on a form (visual controls) and there are 
controls
> that don't (non-visual controls, AKA components in Delphi speak). What 
we
> both seem to agree on is that "non-visual" is the parent of "visual". As
> per VCL. Yeah?

Definitely. Both visual and non-visual "controls" share common attributes 
that don't appear in TObject (an "owner" object, for example - so that a 
menu is free'd when it's window is), so it doesn't make sense to only 
derive them from TObject - there should be an intemediary class like 
THarbourControl (as I outlined in my example heirarchy). Hmm . . . this 
makes it sound like I'm arguing with you, Dave - I'm not. I'm simply 
reiterating what we both believe.

> > My suggestion:
> >
> > TObject
> >   THarbourControl
> >     THarbourWinControl
> >       THarbourForm (or maybe THarbourWindow)
> > [SNIP]
> 
> Yeah, that's exactly the sort of thing I had in mind too. Note that we'd
> probably want to be inserting some abstract classes in there too as the
> anchor points for the platform specific splits (see my other email about
> that).

Yep. Like the VCL's TCustomControl etc.

Mabster

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 11:09:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Fri Aug 24 10:09:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
Message-ID: <OFAC7C3493.005645A7-ONCA256AB2.004D7015@bunge.com.au>

harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 24/08/2001 11:34:37 PM:

> On Fri, Aug 24, 2001 at 02:50:41PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> 
(snip)
> >
> > > begin
> > >   for i := 0 to MainForm.ComponentCount - 1 do
> > >   begin
> > >     if MainForm.Components[i].ClassNameIs('TForm') then
> > >       {...}
> > >     else if MainForm.Components[i].ClassNameIs('TMenu') then
> > >       {...}
> > >   end;
> > > end;
> 
> You're both missing a key point here because you're both testing class
> names. Often you want to enumerate classes based on their capability, 
not
> their names. Capability is tested by checking that a class is of or is
> descended from a certain type.

To be fair, the ClassNameIs method is identical to the "is" keyword that 
you used in your example, Dave.

I guess my example doesn't really demonstrate what you're talking about, 
though, since it draws a distinction between classes lower in the 
heirarchy, rather than looking for, say, components which derive from 
TControl.

> This is why getting the inheritance tree "just so" is important. This is
> why it would be normal to have (for example) a Form, a "non-visual 
control" and
> some other control have a common ancestor, it lets the programmer filter
> the enumeration at any level they wish.

On this we could not agree more.

Mab

> > You're both missing a key point here because you're both testing class
> > names. Often you want to enumerate classes based on their capability,
> > not their names. Capability is tested by checking that a class is of or
> > is descended from a certain type.

> you used in your example, Dave.

,----
| ClassNameIs performs much the same function as the is operator, except
| that it requires an exact match, returning False for descendants of the
| named class.
`----

Or am I misreading the Delphi docs?
