From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 14:09:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Fri Aug 24 13:09:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
Message-ID: <200108241307_MC3-DD8E-71B4@compuserve.com>

Dave et al,

> You're both missing a key point here because you're both testing class
> names.

Yes. :-(  Almost always shows non-OO (or bad OO).

> Often you want to enumerate classes based on their capability, not
> their names. Capability is tested by checking that a class is of or is
> descended from a certain type.

It's probably better to use something like Java's interfaces.  Your
use of the word "capability" very much points to that. :-)

In case anyone isn't familiar with the idea of an interface, it's
where you state the (publicly visible) messages needed/provided by
something.  (If you know about "design by contract" this should look
familiar.)

This means that if object oSender expects interface iXXX to be
implemented by an object, then oSender can send messages to any
objects which implement iXXX.  Those objects may or may not be in the
same inheritance hierarchy (it doesn't matter).

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 14:09:34 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Fri Aug 24 13:09:34 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm for OS2 GUI
Message-ID: <200108241307_MC3-DD8E-71B5@compuserve.com>

Dave et al,

The idea to be careful about namespace issues looks right.

What is the T for in e.g. HB_TAbstractForm?  Borland's Delphi uses T
as a prefix; MFC uses C.  Would make sense for Harbour to use some
other letter (or none). :-)

BTW, Clip-4-Win uses W (not quite always, but let's not get into
that!), so please have Harbour not use W. :-)

John.

Antonio:

  Borland adopted the standard for a "T" to preface their class names,
  and Microsoft "C".   If you stick with T, you're very likely to
  collide with others adopting the Borland way.
  As I see it, Borland's whole point was to use "T" for _Their_ stuff,
  and let the programmer design his own class names differently.

  What is special about a T for Harbour ?????? It is meaningless.

  So why not HForm, HWidget etc. (if hb_ is too ugly) and we can claim
  1/26th of the worldwide namespaces just like the big boys?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 17:11:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 16:11:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TMenu for OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <003601c12cc4$b7136bc0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <000001c12cd8$7538cf60$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

Lets place a menu on the form:
(notice I have not tested this code
as it is here, but hopefully it may work :-)

menu.prg

#include "hbclass.ch"

CLASS TMenu

   DATA   nHandle
   DATA   aItems

   METHOD New( oForm )
   METHOD Add( oMenuItem )

ENDCLASS

METHOD New( oForm ) CLASS TMenu

   ::aItems  = {}
   ::nHandle = WinCreateMenu( oForm:hWnd )

return Self

METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) CLASS TMenu

   WinAddMenuItem( ::nHandle, oMenuItem:cCaption, Len( ::aItems ),;
                   nil, oMenuItem:nId, oMenuItem:lActive )

   AAdd( ::aItems, oMenuItem )

return nil

We also need a menuitem.prg:

#include "hbclass.ch"

CLASS TMenuItem

   DATA   cCaption
   DATA   cAction
   DATA   nId
   DATA   lActive

   CLASSDATA nIdStart

   METHOD New()

ENDCLASS

METHOD New() CLASS TMenuItem

   DEFAULT :nIdStart TO 110

   ::cCaption = ""
   ::nId      = ::nIdStart++
   ::lActive  = .t.

return Self

And finally we need these new code on class TForm:

   DATA     oMainMenu

   METHOD   oMenu() INLINE ::oMainMenu
   METHOD   _oMenu( oNewMenu )

METHOD _oMenu( oNewMenu ) CLASS TForm

   ::oMainMenu = oNewMenu

   WinSetParent( oNewMenu:nHandle, ::hWnd, .t. )
   WinSetOwner( oNewMenu:nHandle, ::hWnd )
   WinSendMsg( ::hWnd, WM_UPDATEFRAME, FCF_MENU, 0 )

return nil

So now, on our little sample we may do:

function Main()

   local oForm := TForm():New()
   local oMenu := TMenu():New( oForm )
   local oMenuItem

   oForm:cCaption = "Hello World!"

   oMenuItem = TMenuItem():New()
   oMenuItem:cCaption = "Hello"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem )

   oForm:oMenu = oMenu

   oForm:ShowModal()

return nil


These should be added at os2pm.c

HB_FUNC( WINCREATEMENU )
{
   hb_retnl( ( LONG ) WinCreateMenu( ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 ),
             ( PVOID ) hb_parnl( 2 ) ) );
}

/* Some xBase for C language */
#define IF(x,y,z) ((x)?(y):(z))

HB_FUNC( WINADDMENUITEM )
{
   MENUITEM mit;

   mit.iPosition   = hb_parni( 3 );
   mit.afStyle     = IF( ISCHAR( 2 ), MIS_TEXT, MIS_SEPARATOR );
   mit.afAttribute = IF( ! hb_parl( 6 ), MIA_DISABLED, 0 );
   mit.id          = hb_parni( 5 );
   mit.hwndSubMenu = hb_parnl( 4 );
   mit.hItem       = 0;

   hb_retni( ( LONG ) WinSendMsg( ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 ), MM_INSERTITEM,
                                  &mit, ( MPARAM ) hb_parc( 2 ) ) );
}

HB_FUNC( WINSETPARENT )
{
   hb_retl( WinSetParent( ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 ), ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 2 ),
                           hb_parl( 3 ) ) );
}

HB_FUNC( WINSETOWNER )
{
   hb_retl( WinSetOwner( ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 ), ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 2 ) ) );
}

HB_FUNC( WINSENDMSG )
{
   hb_retnl( ( LONG ) WinSendMsg( ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 ), hb_parni( 2 ),
             ( MPARAM ) IF( ISCHAR( 3 ), hb_parc( 3 ), hb_parnl( 3 ) ),
             ( MPARAM ) IF( ISCHAR( 4 ), hb_parc( 4 ), hb_parnl( 4 ) ) ) );
}

good luck! ;-)

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 24 18:41:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 24 17:41:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TMenu for OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <3B86C744.A616D0B@libero.it>
Message-ID: <000101c12ce5$02037b00$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

> And presto!!

Cool! We are having luck ;-)

Lets try to add some more menuitems:

function Main()

   local oForm := TForm():New()
   local oMenu := TMenu():New( oForm )
   local oMenuItem1, oMenuItem2, oMenuItem3

   oForm:cCaption = "Hello World!"

   oMenuItem1 = TMenuItem():New()
   oMenuItem1:cCaption = "One"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem1 )

   oMenuItem2 = TMenuItem():New()
   oMenuItem2:cCaption = "Two"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem2 )

   oMenuItem3 = TMenuItem():New()
   oMenuItem3:cCaption = "Three"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem3 )

   oForm:oMenu = oMenu

   oForm:ShowModal()

return nil

Many thanks for your cooperation,

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug 25 00:50:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Fri Aug 24 23:50:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
Message-ID: <OFBF90E10F.80FB146C-ONCA256AB3.0014E070@dingoblue.net.au>

John,

I was going to cite interfaces as an example, but then realised that 
they're actually an argument *against* properly structure class 
heirarchies. Why? Because an interface can be "injected" into *any* class, 
regardless of what it descends from. We could simply have every single 
class descend from TObject, and implement an "IWinControl" interface.

So while interfaces are great, they're not helping our cause :-)

Mabster

harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 25/08/2001 03:07:47 AM:

> Dave et al,
> 
> > You're both missing a key point here because you're both testing class
> > names.
> 
> Yes. :-(  Almost always shows non-OO (or bad OO).
> 
> > Often you want to enumerate classes based on their capability, not
> > their names. Capability is tested by checking that a class is of or is
> > descended from a certain type.
> 
> It's probably better to use something like Java's interfaces.  Your
> use of the word "capability" very much points to that. :-)
> 
> In case anyone isn't familiar with the idea of an interface, it's
> where you state the (publicly visible) messages needed/provided by
> something.  (If you know about "design by contract" this should look
> familiar.)
> 
> This means that if object oSender expects interface iXXX to be
> implemented by an object, then oSender can send messages to any
> objects which implement iXXX.  Those objects may or may not be in the
> same inheritance hierarchy (it doesn't matter).


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug 25 00:52:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)

Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?

harbour-admin@matrixlist.com wrote on 25/08/2001 04:16:58 AM:

> 
> Antonio:
> 
>   Borland adopted the standard for a "T" to preface their class names,
>   and Microsoft "C".   If you stick with T, you're very likely to
>   collide with others adopting the Borland way.
>   As I see it, Borland's whole point was to use "T" for _Their_ stuff,
>   and let the programmer design his own class names differently.
> 
>   What is special about a T for Harbour ?????? It is meaningless.
> 
>   So why not HForm, HWidget etc. (if hb_ is too ugly) and we can claim
>   1/26th of the worldwide namespaces just like the big boys?
> 
>   ---====---
>   Brian Hays

Problem there is that many people use things like HWidget to represent the 
"Handle" to a widget (a standard Microsoft use a lot) so that's not the 
answer either.

I like TForm, but then I'm a Borland guy from way back, so it's kind of 
in-grained. :-)

Mabster

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug 25 04:49:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Sat Aug 25 03:49:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TMenu for OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <3B86CCCC.F3BE2AF@libero.it>
Message-ID: <000701c12d39$ce7bf320$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

Lets do some changes on Class TMenuItem to
allow to add some pulldown menuitems:
(I am not sure if it may works as expected,
but we may get quite closer)

#include "common.ch"
#include "hbclass.ch"

CLASS TMenuItem

   DATA   cCaption  // Specifies the text of the menu item
   DATA   cAction   // A character description of the method to invoke
   DATA   nId       // Command value to send to the container form
   DATA   lEnabled  // Specifies whether the menu item is enabled
   DATA   aItems    // Contains the menu items in the submenu of the menu
item
   DATA   oParent   // Identifies the parent menu item of this menu item
   DATA   nHandle   // The handle of the submenu of this menu item

   CLASSDATA nIdStart   // start value for commands value to assign to menu
items

   METHOD New( oOwner ) // Creates a new menu item
   METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) // Adds a new drop down menu item

ENDCLASS

METHOD New( oOwner ) CLASS TMenuItem

   DEFAULT ::nIdStart TO 110

   ::cCaption = ""
   ::nId      = ::nIdStart++
   ::lEnabled = .t.
   ::oParent  = oOwner

return Self

METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) CLASS TMenuItem

   DEFAULT ::aItems  TO {}
   DEFAULT ::nHandle TO WinCreateMenu( ::oParent:nHandle )

   WinAddMenuItem( ::nHandle, oMenuItem:cCaption, Len( ::aItems ),;
                   ::oParent:nHandle, oMenuItem:nId, oMenuItem:lEnabled )

   AAdd( ::aItems, oMenuItem )

return nil


Please notice this method also changes:

METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) CLASS TMenu

   WinAddMenuItem( ::nHandle, oMenuItem:cCaption, Len( ::aItems ),;
                   nil, oMenuItem:nId, oMenuItem:lEnabled )

   AAdd( ::aItems, oMenuItem )

return nil


And now, our little sample may be like this:

function Main()

   local oForm := TForm():New()
   local oMenu := TMenu():New( oForm )
   local oMenuItem1, oMenuItem2, oMenuItem3
   local oSubItem1, oSubItem2

   oForm:cCaption = "Hello World!"

   oMenuItem1 = TMenuItem():New( oMenu )
   oMenuItem1:cCaption = "One"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem1 )

   oSubItem1 = TMenuItem():New( oMenuItem1 )
   oSubItem1.cCaption = "Hello"
   oMenuItem1.Add( oSubItem1 )

   oSubItem2 = TMenuItem():New( oMenuItem1 )
   oSubItem2.cCaption = "Bye"
   oMenuItem1.Add( oSubItem2 )

   oMenuItem2 = TMenuItem():New( oMenu )
   oMenuItem2:cCaption = "Two"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem2 )

   oMenuItem3 = TMenuItem():New( oMenu )
   oMenuItem3:cCaption = "Three"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem3 )

   oForm:oMenu = oMenu

   oForm:ShowModal()

return nil


Thanks for your help,

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug 25 05:55:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David Arturo Macias Corona)
Date: Sat Aug 25 04:55:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] DBFCDX / ADS
In-Reply-To: <200108240956.f7O9uOn21248@mail.udg.mx>
Message-ID: <3.0.6.16.20010825035403.1e8fa11a@mail.udg.mx>

>Date: Thu, 23 Aug 2001 15:29:55 -0700
>From: Brian Hays <bhays@abacuslaw.com>

>I can respond regarding rddads. Remember, it is using the ACE32.DLL
>which lacks some capabilities they were able to code into the clipper
>rdd (ace32 can be used by any Windows app and is not
>clipper-specific).
OK, you refer only to RDDADS
And before you explained me about how RDD Advantage for Clipper are
specific and in some cases more complete than ACE32.dll, which is more generic

>OrdCondSet() has a single implementation with Clipper 5.3b's parameter
>list.  Only rddads uses parameters after #11 now.
--------->  Remember, DBFCDX must use parameters after #11 too. This must
be considered by DBFCDX developers, including that the default values are
differents
--------->  You can refer to my now "old" message about it

>I don't think this is an option in rddads (32-bit Advantage clients
>are limited to ACE32.DLL capabilities).
>I'll double-check.
Maybe  Advantage-ACE32.dll use the locking scheme of FoxPro, and in those
case the Clipper/DBFCDX programs must include CDXLOCK.obj, in order to
share "locking" with Harbour/DBFCDX - RDDADS - FoxPro

>All the SET commands can be better integrated when we have the SET
>LISTENER stuff available. 
>Some of the SETs you mention are in ads.ch. Rather than add the
>others, I'll wait to see how the Listener works.
David G. Holm gave the good notice. 
Is suppose that is pending to add this SET commands

>This depends on index type. CDX is used for multi-bag, idx for single
Yes I know it
CLIP53a.txt say:
   "The file extensions that will be created when using the CDX driver are
.CDX
    files.  Files with an extension of .IDX are not supported."

Which will be the default for Harbour/DBFCDX, if it will support .idx files ?

>DAMC>    Advantage use ".IDX" as index extension default
>DAMC>    Clipper       use ".CDX" as index extension default (or fixed?)

>DAMC> f.-   AX_MemoArrayStyle( "FlexFile" )  //Igualar a DBFCDX
>DAMC>   Advantage manage formats "FlexFile" and "Six", and use "Six" as
default
>DAMC>   Clipper only manage "FlexFile"
>This won't happen in Harbour unless someone wants to hack the FlexFile
>formats. Current ACE32 docs don't say anything about "Six" array
>support.  I created my own arrayToString functions and converted my
>stored arrays. The Remote Server doesn't know anything about Harbour
>Array structures. Then there are the issues of whether Type(memofield)
>returns "A" or not. I recommend biting the bullet on this one and
>converting.

And how will manage Harbour it ? Clipper do it in some specific way: type
"FlexFile". As I understand, the type is stored in some place in database file
Will be included in Harbour some equivalent to store/retrieve arrays in
Memo files, as you did for your needs ? And in that case we may "forget"
types "Six" and "FlexFile". Your arrayToString functions can be the choice ?
That could used as generic functions for all RDD: DBFNTX(?); DBFCDX, RDDADS
Something as:  MemoArrayPut( memofield, aArray ), MemoArrayGet( memofield )

But, as I understand, if RDD Advantage for Clipper or Clipper DBFCDX are
storing an type "Array" value in an type memo field , they put the style
"Six" or "FlexFile" in the memo field, in order to determine the style when
will retrieve the array
In such case can work this, as NG Advantage for Clipper say:
-  PUT:  test->memofield := {{ 1, "hi there", .T. }, { .F., 3.14159 }}
  // This array data will be written to the FPT memo file using
  //   the FlexFile syntax                     <--- if FlexFile is the
active style
-  GET:  aArrayData := test->memofield
  // This will read the array data stored in the FPT memo file no
  // matter which "style" was used when it was written.

Maybe Harbour DBFCDX should have an verification of the value type when
storing/retrieving values in memo fields
PUT: If value is an array, store "style" used plus array values
GET: If exist style value, assume an array type and read/return the array

The DBFCDX developers must see which will be the better approach to have
Clipper compatibility

>There are no ax* functions in Harbour. There are some ads* functions
>in adsfunc.c and ads1.c (most are documented, but not all).
>BUT my intention with the changes I've made to
>rddads is to integrate features as much as
>possible with the 5.3 rdd calls so the rdd is truly replaceable with
>dbfcdx.  Ideally, no other function calls are needed, although there
>are special features in ads that aren't generalized in the rdd
>(encryption, etc.)
Agree

>DAMC> SET AUTOPEN     Sets/Gets automatic open mode.  When a production
index is
>In ads, you cannot turn this off. Structural indexes are always opened
>and cannot be closed.
Harbour/DBFCDX should support it, and the rest commands

>DAMC> SET AUTORDER    Allows control of the master index which is in
effect when a
>DAMC> SET AUTOSHARE   Autoshare allows the CDX driver to automatically
open the

Brian, thanks for your attention

David Macias

I see how Antonio is working hard and so fast, in order to develop an
"Harbour GUI layer"
Maurilio is trying and getting to maintain the rhytm

Congratulations to both, they are having good results, as I can see in the
messages

Antonio seem have an "enthusiastic episode" similar to the joy of an
"summer lover". Maybe in an episode like the actual, Harbour was born ...

I thinked about an "Harbour GUI", and I conclude that this may an "Must" in
Harbour, for this reason:
Allmost all the actual programs are GUI based, and the text based are few.
If Harbour is released only for text mode, could not be competitive against
GUI mode programs, even if Harbour is better. If Harbour can be GUI based,
then can compete immediatly even if his GUI model is basic. At end, will
have "GUI look and feeling" as the final user want and are now used

Maybe this step is the "Harbour second air" that will guaranted an long
life and use to Harbour, which reach allmost to 2023 year, as now we know
by an reliable voyager who came from the future

The goal is give to Harbour "weight reasons" to be used by programmers in
an competitive way

If everyone support this and colaborate, Harbour can have in an short time
an "GUI layer"
Antonio and Maurilio proved that

Gracias,
David Macias

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sat Aug 25 17:42:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Marek Paliwoda)
Date: Sat Aug 25 16:42:03 2001
Subject: Re[2]: [Harbour] Linux GUI

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

--Boundary_(ID_n/6OOpDod/Qilj+A7K5rLA)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

Antonio Linares wrote on Saturday, August 25, 2001 5:30 PM

> Marek,
> 
> >> Is there a Windows MessageBox() alike function on GTK ?
> 
> > As far as I know GTK 1.2  there is no such a function ready 
> > to use, until You write it yourself.
> 
> Then we may need to build it ourselves.
> I believe it may be quite easy (based
> on the Hello source code sample we already
> reviewed).

Attached is a *cut and paste* a very simple example of such a function
from my Harbour for Gtk bindings which I wrote almost a year ago.

-- 

  Marek Paliwoda
paliwoda@inetia.pl




--Boundary_(ID_n/6OOpDod/Qilj+A7K5rLA)
Content-type: application/octet-stream; name=msginfo.c
Content-disposition: attachment; filename=msginfo.c
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable

/*
 * $"Id"$
 */

/*
 * Harbour Project source code:
 * Gtk bindings for Harbour
 *
 * Copyright 2000 Marek Paliwoda <paliwoda@inetia.pl>
 * www - http://www.harbour-project.org
 *
 * This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
 * it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
 * the Free Software Foundation; either version 2 of the License, or
 * (at your option) any later version.
 *
 * This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
 * but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
 * MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
 * GNU General Public License for more details.
 *
 * You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
 * along with this program; if not, write to the Free Software
 * Foundation, Inc., 675 Mass Ave, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA (or visit
 * their web site at http://www.gnu.org/).
 *
 */

/* =
*************************************************************************=
 */

#include <glib.h>
#include <gtk/gtk.h>

#include <hbapi.h>

/* =
*************************************************************************=
 */

/* default MultiLine delimiters - they allow to divide  */
/* single string into MultiLine string by putting these */
/* delimiters into it */
extern gchar *MultiLineDelimiters;

/* when this widget is destroyed an application quits */
extern GtkWidget *MainApplicationWidget;

/* =
*************************************************************************=
 */

static void GtkMsgInfoCallback( GtkWidget *Widget, gpointer Data )
{
    if( GTK_IS_WIDGET( ( GtkWidget * ) Data ) )
        gtk_widget_destroy( ( GtkWidget * ) Data );

    /* return from a nested gtk_main() */
    gtk_main_quit();
}

/* =
*************************************************************************=
 */

HB_FUNC( HB_GTKMSGINFO )
{
    /* convert MultiLineDelimiters to \n (line feed) */
    gchar *Message =3D g_strdelimit(
                                     ( gchar * ) hb_parc( 1 ),
                                     MultiLineDelimiters, '\n'
                                 );
    /* Create the widgets */
    GtkWidget *InfoWin =3D gtk_dialog_new();
    GtkWidget *Label =3D gtk_label_new( Message );
    GtkWidget *BtnOK =3D gtk_button_new_with_label( "Ok" );

    /* set InfoWin properies */
    gtk_window_set_title( GTK_WINDOW( InfoWin ), "Message" );
    gtk_window_set_position( GTK_WINDOW( InfoWin ), GTK_WIN_POS_CENTER =
);
    gtk_container_border_width( GTK_CONTAINER( InfoWin ), 0 );
    gtk_container_border_width
    (
        GTK_CONTAINER( GTK_BOX( GTK_DIALOG( InfoWin )->vbox ) ), 5
    );

    /* set InfoWin to modal state and disable resizing */
    gtk_window_set_modal( GTK_WINDOW( InfoWin ), TRUE );
    gtk_window_set_policy( GTK_WINDOW( InfoWin ), FALSE, FALSE, FALSE );
    gtk_window_set_transient_for( GTK_WINDOW( InfoWin ), GTK_WINDOW( =
MainApplicationWidget ) );

    /* Ensure that the InfoWin is destroyed when the user requests it */
    gtk_signal_connect
    (
        GTK_OBJECT( InfoWin ),
        "destroy",
        GTK_SIGNAL_FUNC( ( GtkSignalFunc ) GtkMsgInfoCallback ),
        NULL /* this prevents calling gtk_widget_destroy recursivly for =
InfoWin */
    );

    /* Ensure that the InfoWin is destroyed when the user clicks OK =
button */
    gtk_signal_connect
    (
        GTK_OBJECT( BtnOK ),
        "clicked",
        GTK_SIGNAL_FUNC( ( GtkSignalFunc ) GtkMsgInfoCallback ),
        ( gpointer ) InfoWin
    );

    /* add the label to the InfoWin */
    gtk_box_pack_start
    (
        GTK_BOX( GTK_BOX( GTK_DIALOG( InfoWin )->vbox ) ),
        Label, TRUE, TRUE, 10
    );

    /* add the button to the InfoWin */
    gtk_box_pack_start
    (
        GTK_BOX( GTK_BOX( GTK_DIALOG( InfoWin )->action_area ) ),
        BtnOK, TRUE, TRUE, 10
    );

    /* and show everything we've created */
    gtk_widget_show_all( InfoWin );

    /* we will remain here until a button is pressed */
    gtk_main();
}

/* =
*************************************************************************=
 */


--Boundary_(ID_n/6OOpDod/Qilj+A7K5rLA)--

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 26 12:51:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Ignacio_Ortiz_de_Z=FA=F1iga?=)
Date: Sun Aug 26 11:51:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Mpostolc() function
Message-ID: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEAECGCHAA.ignacio@ozs.com>

I am working right now on the Mpostolc function, which returns the row and
column of a given string offset based on the typical Clipper Memo functions.

The problem that I have is that the original Clipper function returns some
values that at least for me are completely wrong. Suppose the following
string:

//           1              2
//  1234567890123456789     0 1
   "This is just a test" + CRLF

Clipper function: (Remember column is zero based)

Mpostolc(cStr,,01) --> {1,0}  // correct line 1, column 0
Mpostolc(cStr,,19) --> {1,18} // correct line 1, column 18
Mpostolc(cStr,,20) --> {1,19} // incorrect since is the CR offset it should
be 18 ?
Mpostolc(cStr,,21) --> {1,21} // completely incorrect since even the maximum
value is 20

As you can see it works correct until it starts the CRLF pair, it treats the
CR as any other char, and when it reaches the LF it even adds one to the
column value. (remember columns are zero based).

Normally this problem has not affect any one since these two functions are
used for search and replace routines inside MemoEdit(), but I believe it
makes no sense to have strict compatibility with Clipper.

I like better to return the maximum column value (in our sample 18) when is
given the offset of the CR (20), and return the pair {2,0} (line 2, column
0) when the offset given is the LF char.

What do you think ?

BTW Mlctopos() is finished, I wil cvs the two functions when we solve this
problem. :-))

Regards,

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Sun Aug 26 21:30:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Brian Hays)
Date: Sun Aug 26 20:30:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] HB_FM_STATISTICS
Message-ID: <24320631894.20010826173811@abacuslaw.com>

 hbsetup.h has this turned on by default:
 #define HB_FM_STATISTICS
  
 For a final release, it makes sense to turn it off as it creates
 about a 30% increase in speed overall.

 It seems the only way to do this is to change the file (comment out
 that line) and rebuild harbour.

 This means the next time I post to cvs it appears as a changed file.

 Am I missing something?  Is there a mechanism to un-set this via
 environment variables or external headers?  If not, shouldn't there
 be?
 
 ---====---
 Brian Hays


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 27 03:30:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Mon Aug 27 02:30:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TMenu for OS2 GUI
References: <000701c12d39$ce7bf320$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <3B89E8C1.E73063DC@libero.it>

Antonio,

this time it doesn't work. Sadly I've always used resource files to create menu
so I'll have to spend a little more time to find out what is wrong.

regards.


Antonio Linares ha scritto:

> Maurilio,
>
> Lets do some changes on Class TMenuItem to
> allow to add some pulldown menuitems:
> (I am not sure if it may works as expected,
> but we may get quite closer)
>
> #include "common.ch"
> #include "hbclass.ch"
>
> CLASS TMenuItem
>
>    DATA   cCaption  // Specifies the text of the menu item
>    DATA   cAction   // A character description of the method to invoke
>    DATA   nId       // Command value to send to the container form
>    DATA   lEnabled  // Specifies whether the menu item is enabled
>    DATA   aItems    // Contains the menu items in the submenu of the menu
> item
>    DATA   oParent   // Identifies the parent menu item of this menu item
>    DATA   nHandle   // The handle of the submenu of this menu item
>
>    CLASSDATA nIdStart   // start value for commands value to assign to menu
> items
>
>    METHOD New( oOwner ) // Creates a new menu item
>    METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) // Adds a new drop down menu item
>
> ENDCLASS
>
> METHOD New( oOwner ) CLASS TMenuItem
>
>    DEFAULT ::nIdStart TO 110
>
>    ::cCaption = ""
>    ::nId      = ::nIdStart++
>    ::lEnabled = .t.
>    ::oParent  = oOwner
>
> return Self
>
> METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) CLASS TMenuItem
>
>    DEFAULT ::aItems  TO {}
>    DEFAULT ::nHandle TO WinCreateMenu( ::oParent:nHandle )
>
>    WinAddMenuItem( ::nHandle, oMenuItem:cCaption, Len( ::aItems ),;
>                    ::oParent:nHandle, oMenuItem:nId, oMenuItem:lEnabled )
>
>    AAdd( ::aItems, oMenuItem )
>
> return nil
>
> Please notice this method also changes:
>
> METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) CLASS TMenu
>
>    WinAddMenuItem( ::nHandle, oMenuItem:cCaption, Len( ::aItems ),;
>                    nil, oMenuItem:nId, oMenuItem:lEnabled )
>
>    AAdd( ::aItems, oMenuItem )
>
> return nil
>
> And now, our little sample may be like this:
>
> function Main()
>
>    local oForm := TForm():New()
>    local oMenu := TMenu():New( oForm )
>    local oMenuItem1, oMenuItem2, oMenuItem3
>    local oSubItem1, oSubItem2
>
>    oForm:cCaption = "Hello World!"
>
>    oMenuItem1 = TMenuItem():New( oMenu )
>    oMenuItem1:cCaption = "One"
>    oMenu:Add( oMenuItem1 )
>
>    oSubItem1 = TMenuItem():New( oMenuItem1 )
>    oSubItem1.cCaption = "Hello"
>    oMenuItem1.Add( oSubItem1 )
>
>    oSubItem2 = TMenuItem():New( oMenuItem1 )
>    oSubItem2.cCaption = "Bye"
>    oMenuItem1.Add( oSubItem2 )
>
>    oMenuItem2 = TMenuItem():New( oMenu )
>    oMenuItem2:cCaption = "Two"
>    oMenu:Add( oMenuItem2 )
>
>    oMenuItem3 = TMenuItem():New( oMenu )
>    oMenuItem3:cCaption = "Three"
>    oMenu:Add( oMenuItem3 )
>
>    oForm:oMenu = oMenu
>
>    oForm:ShowModal()
>
> return nil
>
> Thanks for your help,
>
> Antonio
>

> Harbour mailing list
> Harbour@matrixlist.com
> http://www.matrixlist.com/mailman/listinfo/harbour
>

> http://www.Harbour-Project.org

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 27 05:40:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon Aug 27 04:40:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TMenu for OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <3B89E8C1.E73063DC@libero.it>
Message-ID: <000401c12ed3$5ca6d8a0$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

> this time it doesn't work.

Please try this little change:

METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) CLASS TMenuItem

   DEFAULT ::aItems  TO {}
   DEFAULT ::nHandle TO WinCreateMenu( ::oParent:nHandle )

   WinAddMenuItem( ::oParent:nHandle, oMenuItem:cCaption, Len( ::aItems ),;
                   ::nHandle, oMenuItem:nId, oMenuItem:lEnabled )

   AAdd( ::aItems, oMenuItem )

return nil

Thanks,

Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 27 07:49:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Mon Aug 27 06:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Linux GUI
In-Reply-To: <000c01c12ed8$410450a0$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Mon, Aug 27, 2001 at 11:11:28AM +0200
References: <001101c12daa$4e432cc0$0f2aa8c0@first> <000c01c12ed8$410450a0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010827114525.A18579@hagbard.davep.org>

On Mon, Aug 27, 2001 at 11:11:28AM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> Do you know what GUI engine (GTK, KDE, GLIB, Gnome, etc...) does Kilyx use
> ?

Kylix, or, more correctly, CLX, uses QT. However, it's my understanding that
it is (or will) be possible to have CLX target GTK too. Doubtless a Google
search for "kylix kde gtk" or something like that will tell you everything
you need to know.

BTW, what do you mean when you say GLIB? I'm not aware of a widget set by
that name.

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 27 08:37:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon Aug 27 07:37:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Harbour GUI
In-Reply-To: <441802478.20010827150359@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <000e01c12eeb$f7d4df80$0f2aa8c0@first>

Alexander,

>  I've reviewed this stuff today and converted os2pm.c to Win32.
>  Also I was needed to do some changes in tform.prg - some places there
>  are specific for OS/2.

many thanks!

I guess we may need to implement Dave's proposed directories
structure, even if we keep them on the contrib directory by now.

>  But I think, that it would be better, if all OS specific stuff will
>  be on C level ( os2pm.c, etc. ). Harbour level code ( tform.prg, etc.
>  ) should be platform independent.

I don't think we may be able to use the same tform.prg source
code for all the GUIs. That is why, Dave's proposal looks ok to me.

Those different tform.prg must offer some set of
basic datas and methods, but obviously some of them may offer
some extra features that are not supported on other GUIs.

i.e. Windows has the MDI feature, where OS/2 PM (as far as I
know it) don't provide such feature. Probably the same happens
for GTK. 

The idea is that at least a set of features that are available
on all GUIs are common on all different tform.prg. So we may
advise the Harbour programmer, what GUI features are portable
and which ones aren't.

Antonio



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 27 08:56:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)
Date: Mon Aug 27 07:56:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Class TMenu for OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <000401c12ed3$5ca6d8a0$0f2aa8c0@first>
References: <000401c12ed3$5ca6d8a0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <1634719299.20010827155235@belacy.belgorod.su>

On 27.08.2001 12:36, Antonio Linares <alinares@fivetech.com> wrote:

AL> Please try this little change:

AL> METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) CLASS TMenuItem
AL>    DEFAULT ::aItems  TO {}
AL>    DEFAULT ::nHandle TO WinCreateMenu( ::oParent:nHandle )
AL>    WinAddMenuItem( ::oParent:nHandle, oMenuItem:cCaption, Len( ::aItems ),;
AL>                    ::nHandle, oMenuItem:nId, oMenuItem:lEnabled )
AL>    AAdd( ::aItems, oMenuItem )
AL> return nil

 This doesn't work, too, at least, with my converted to Win32 files.
 To make it properly work, we need to do something like:

METHOD Add( oMenuItem ) CLASS TMenuItem
   DEFAULT ::aItems  TO {}
   DEFAULT ::nHandle TO WinCreateSubMenu( ::oParent:nHandle, ::nId )

   WinAddMenuItem( ::nHandle, oMenuItem:cCaption, Len( ::aItems ),;
                   Nil, oMenuItem:nId, oMenuItem:lEnabled )
   AAdd( ::aItems, oMenuItem )
return nil

, where WinCreateSubMenu() creates new menu with CreateMenu() at
assignes it to the oMenuItem. Don't know, how it can be done under
OS/2, but under Win32 the following code works Ok:

HB_FUNC( WINCREATESUBMENU )
{

   MENUITEMINFO mii;
   HMENU hSubMenu = CreateMenu();

   mii.cbSize = sizeof( MENUITEMINFO );
   mii.fMask = MIIM_SUBMENU;
   mii.hSubMenu = hSubMenu;

   SetMenuItemInfo( ( HMENU ) hb_parnl( 1 ),
     hb_parni( 2 ), 0, &mii );
   hb_retnl( (LONG) hSubMenu );
}

Best regards,
 Alexander
http://www.geocities.com/alkresin/



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 27 09:04:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Mon Aug 27 08:04:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Re: Class TMenu for OS2 GUI
In-Reply-To: <1634719299.20010827155235@belacy.belgorod.su>
Message-ID: <000f01c12eef$c4c6aa20$0f2aa8c0@first>

Alexander,

So is this code working ok on Win32 ?

function Main()

   local oForm := TForm():New()
   local oMenu := TMenu():New( oForm )
   local oMenuItem1, oMenuItem2, oMenuItem3
   local oSubItem1, oSubItem2

   oForm:cCaption = "Hello World!"

   oMenuItem1 = TMenuItem():New( oMenu )
   oMenuItem1:cCaption = "One"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem1 )

   oSubItem1 = TMenuItem():New( oMenuItem1 )
   oSubItem1.cCaption = "Hello"
   oMenuItem1.Add( oSubItem1 )

   oSubItem2 = TMenuItem():New( oMenuItem1 )
   oSubItem2.cCaption = "Bye"
   oMenuItem1.Add( oSubItem2 )

   oMenuItem2 = TMenuItem():New( oMenu )
   oMenuItem2:cCaption = "Two"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem2 )

   oMenuItem3 = TMenuItem():New( oMenu )
   oMenuItem3:cCaption = "Three"
   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem3 )

   oForm:oMenu = oMenu

   oForm:ShowModal()

return nil


Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Mon Aug 27 09:24:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Alexander S.Kresin)

Subject: [Harbour] Re: Harbour GUI
In-Reply-To: <000e01c12eeb$f7d4df80$0f2aa8c0@first>
References: <000e01c12eeb$f7d4df80$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <1096435178.20010827162111@belacy.belgorod.su>

On 27.08.2001 15:32, Antonio Linares <alinares@fivetech.com> wrote:

AL> I don't think we may be able to use the same tform.prg source
AL> code for all the GUIs. That is why, Dave's proposal looks ok to me.

AL> Those different tform.prg must offer some set of
AL> basic datas and methods, but obviously some of them may offer
AL> some extra features that are not supported on other GUIs.

AL> i.e. Windows has the MDI feature, where OS/2 PM (as far as I
AL> know it) don't provide such feature. Probably the same happens
AL> for GTK.

  Those extra features may be realized on C level. Appropriate
  functions in files for other platforms may be empty.
  Remember the RDD code ? There is high level modules, which are the
  same for all RDD, and some function's parameters, defined there, and
  even some functions may be unused in specific low level drivers.

AL> The idea is that at least a set of features that are available
AL> on all GUIs are common on all different tform.prg. So we may
AL> advise the Harbour programmer, what GUI features are portable
AL> and which ones aren't.

  I'm afraid that we will have problems with synchronizing these
  different tform.prg when they become big enough, and even an
  interface may become different.
  I suggest to have it the same now, and try to keep it the same as
  far, as possible. If later we will see, that it becomes impossible,
  we may to divide it.
  

Best regards,
 Alexander
http://www.geocities.com/alkresin/

In-Reply-To: <3B86CCCC.F3BE2AF@libero.it>

Message-ID: <200108271512.0000019Q@Internet>

** Reply to message from Maurilio Longo <maurilio.longo@libero.it> on
Fri, 24 Aug 2001 23:53:16 +0200

Maurilio,

    Could you please either CVS the test program that you are using or
email me a copy of it, so that I can test the new PM mode code with the
IBM C++ complier?

    So far, I found one change that is needed one line 83 in os2pm.c:
The intermediate variable assignment for the window handle is not
needed, because it's a local variable that never gets used again and the
assignment confuses the IBM C++ compiler.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

Opinions?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 05:36:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Ignacio_Ortiz_de_Z=FA=F1iga?=)
Date: Tue Aug 28 04:36:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] RE: Mpostolc() function
In-Reply-To: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEAECGCHAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
Message-ID: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEAECNCHAA.ignacio@ozs.com>

Since I did not receive any feedback about this issue, I will do it as I
proposed.

Regards,

Ignacio Ortiz de Zúñiga
ignacio@ozs.com
http://www.ozs.com

-----Mensaje original-----
De: Ignacio Ortiz de Zúñiga [mailto:ignacio@ozs.com]
Enviado el: domingo, 26 de agosto de 2001 17:53
Para: Harbour
Asunto: Mpostolc() function


I am working right now on the Mpostolc function, which returns the row and
column of a given string offset based on the typical Clipper Memo functions.

The problem that I have is that the original Clipper function returns some
values that at least for me are completely wrong. Suppose the following
string:

//           1              2
//  1234567890123456789     0 1
   "This is just a test" + CRLF

Clipper function: (Remember column is zero based)

Mpostolc(cStr,,01) --> {1,0}  // correct line 1, column 0
Mpostolc(cStr,,19) --> {1,18} // correct line 1, column 18
Mpostolc(cStr,,20) --> {1,19} // incorrect since is the CR offset it should
be 18 ?
Mpostolc(cStr,,21) --> {1,21} // completely incorrect since even the maximum
value is 20

As you can see it works correct until it starts the CRLF pair, it treats the
CR as any other char, and when it reaches the LF it even adds one to the
column value. (remember columns are zero based).

Normally this problem has not affect any one since these two functions are
used for search and replace routines inside MemoEdit(), but I believe it
makes no sense to have strict compatibility with Clipper.

I like better to return the maximum column value (in our sample 18) when is
given the offset of the CR (20), and return the pair {2,0} (line 2, column
0) when the offset given is the LF char.

What do you think ?

BTW Mlctopos() is finished, I wil cvs the two functions when we solve this
problem. :-))

Regards,

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 07:42:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Tue Aug 28 06:42:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
Message-ID: <200108280640_MC3-DDF2-E5FC@compuserve.com>

Mabster,

> I was going to cite interfaces as an example, but then realised that =

> they're actually an argument *against* properly structure class =

> heirarchies. Why? Because an interface can be "injected" into *any* cla=
ss, =

>regardless of what it descends from.

It's not necessarily true that "an interface can be "injected" into
*any* class".

But suppose it is; why would that be a problem?

> We could simply have every single =

> class descend from TObject, and implement an "IWinControl" interface.

Could or should?

> So while interfaces are great, they're not helping our cause :-)

Why not?

I see OO (OOA, OOD, OOP) as a useful (small) step forward to better
software.  Interfaces look to be another (small) step.

John.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 08:03:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (harbour@matrixlist.com)
Date: Tue Aug 28 07:03:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Class TForm ?
Message-ID: <OF7598D3A2.440FD7CA-ONCA256AB6.003C3D27@dingoblue.net.au>

Hmm. Sorry, John - I didn't mean to dis interfaces at all. I use them in 
my own code sometimes. It's just that Dave and I were arguing in favour of 
a strong class heirarchy, and interfaces (like a lot of language features) 
enable sloppy programmers to "patch up" their code after the fact.

That said, I'm *very* strongly in favour of interfaces over something like 
multiple inheritance.

Cheers,
Mabster

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 10:41:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Tue Aug 28 09:41:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Sircam Virus
In-Reply-To: <01082802173801.29992@gizmo.the-oasis.net>; from midnight@the-oasis.net on Tue, Aug 28, 2001 at 02:17:38AM -0400
References: <01082802173801.29992@gizmo.the-oasis.net>
Message-ID: <20010828142152.V1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Tue, Aug 28, 2001 at 02:17:38AM -0400, Phil Barnett wrote:
> 
> Pay attention, folks.
> 
> I just deleted 35 instances of the Sircam virus coming into this list.
> 
> The only reason they bounced is because of our 100k byte limit.
> 
> I propose we lower that to 50k for a while.
> 
> Opinions?

One other thing I forgot to mention. Unless I'm mistaken your 100k byte
limit is more than enough to capture all SirCam emails anyway. It is my
understanding that the SirCam payload that is added to the head of the
attachment is always in excess of 100k bytes (137217 bytes to be exact).

It seems unlikely that dropping the limit to 50k will capture any more
SirCam emails.

For what it's worth, here's what I use to strip the payload from SirCam
attachments so you can have a look at what people have being unwittingly
emailing to you:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
#!/bin/sh

if [ "$1" ]
then
    if [ -f "$1" ]
    then
        FILENAME=${2:-$(basename "$1" | sed -e 's/\....$//')}
        tail +137217c "$1" > "$FILENAME"
        echo "Extracted $FILENAME from $1"
    else
        echo "Can't open $1 for reading"
    fi
else
    echo "$0 <filename> [<target>]"
fi
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 13:49:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Tue Aug 28 12:49:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] TMenuItm and OS/2 menus
In-Reply-To: <3B8BC0D8.11366D57@libero.it>
Message-ID: <001b01c12fe0$b6c925a0$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

> Problem is tmenuitems didnt' have ::nHandle instance variable correctly
> setup inside New() method

As far as I understand it, ::nHandle should
not be initialized (it may remain nil) unless
that menu item has sub menu items.


Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 13:52:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Tue Aug 28 12:52:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] TMenuItm and OS/2 menus
In-Reply-To: <3B8BC450.EC226D18@libero.it>
Message-ID: <001c01c12fe1$2d19d7e0$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

> as it stands now we need to different methods, one to add 
> submenus, and one to add menuitems

We are following the VCL rules:

You may add a menuitem to a menu:

   oMenu:Add( oMenuItem )

and you may add a menuitem to a menuitem:
(a drop down item)

   oMenuItem:Add( oMenuItem )


Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 13:57:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Tue Aug 28 12:57:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour GUI
In-Reply-To: <001b01c12fe0$b6c925a0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <001d01c12fe1$f4e6d480$0f2aa8c0@first>

Now we need to develop the Harbour Linux GTK
GUI to match the level we already have on Win32
and OS2 PM.

I have asked a friend (a Linux user) to do some
tests, to check if the proposed Linux GTK entry
point works ok.

If some of you could also test it, that would be
great.

many thanks,

Antonio

Linux GTK application entry point proposal

harbour/source/vcl/mainlgtk.c  

#include <gtk/gtk.h>
#include "hbapi.h"
#include "hbvm.h"

int main( int argc, char * argv[] )
{
   gtk_init( &argc, &argv );

   hb_cmdargInit( argc, argv );
   hb_vmInit( TRUE );
   hb_vmQuit();   

   gtk_exit( 0 );

   return 0;
}




From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 14:20:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Maurilio Longo)
Date: Tue Aug 28 13:20:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] TMenuItm and OS/2 menus
References: <001b01c12fe0$b6c925a0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <3B8BD26C.83AC2BC7@libero.it>

Antonio, I will cvs code in minutes,

but, on OS/2 a menu item has hWndSubmenu <> null if that item has a drop down
associated with it. In this case hWndSubmenu contains the handle of the
window of class WC_MENU wich contains that menu item.

The code as it stands works for a two level menu system since TMenu fills
hWndSubmenu and TMenuItem does not or else every menu item will have a
"greater than" sign to give you a hint that there is a drop down associated
with it.

When we add a drop down to a menu item we need to get back from OS/2 the
handle of that menu item and update its MENUINFO structure with the needed
infos.

regards.

> > setup inside New() method

> not be initialized (it may remain nil) unless
> that menu item has sub menu items.
>

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 14:54:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (John Skelton)
Date: Tue Aug 28 13:54:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] bug: class name ignored in method definition
Message-ID: <200108281352_MC3-DDF5-B3F8@compuserve.com>

The sample below shows a bug introduced fairly recently (sorry, I
don't know exactly when - could be a few weeks as I missed out on
updates for a while).

A work-around is to re-order the code. :-(

John.
---cut here---
#include "hbclass.ch"

function main()
local	o :=3D One{}		// or One():New() if you prefer
return 0

class One
	method SomeMethod
endclass

class Two
endclass

method SomeMethod class One	// ERROR: is defined as being in class Two!
return self

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 16:59:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (JF Lefebvre)
Date: Tue Aug 28 15:59:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] bug: class name ignored in method definition
In-Reply-To: <200108281352_MC3-DDF5-B3F8@compuserve.com>
Message-ID: <3B8C13F2.4116.D45AA@localhost>

Hi John,

This is due to Ron's error tracking implementation within 
HBCLASS.CH. I think there is no way to change that while keeping 
the ability to check for badly declared Classes. You code is 
working if you add this #define _before_ including HBCLASS.CH.

#define HB_CLS_NO_OO_ERR

PS: This is why your code worked for me :-((( I added it within my 
own topclass.ch... and forgot I added it !

Hope it help.

> The sample below shows a bug introduced fairly recently (sorry, I
> don't know exactly when - could be a few weeks as I missed out on
> updates for a while).
> 
> A work-around is to re-order the code. :-(
> 
> John.
> ---cut here---
> #include "hbclass.ch"
> 
> function main()
> local	o := One{}		// or One():New() if you prefer
> return 0
> 
> class One
>  method SomeMethod
> endclass
> 
> class Two
> endclass
> 
> method SomeMethod class One	// ERROR: is defined as being in class
> Two! return self _______________________________________________
> Harbour mailing list Harbour@matrixlist.com
> http://www.matrixlist.com/mailman/listinfo/harbour
> 
> Thank you for participating in The Harbour Project.  Be sure to check
> http://www.Harbour-Project.org
> 
> 



Best regards,

J. Lefebvre,

Belgium


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 17:18:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Marek Paliwoda)
Date: Tue Aug 28 16:18:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour GUI
References: <001d01c12fe1$f4e6d480$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <007601c12ffe$b330c100$6bb272c3@map>

Antonio Linares wrote on Tuesday, August 28, 2001 6:53 PM

> Now we need to develop the Harbour Linux GTK
> GUI to match the level we already have on Win32
> and OS2 PM.
  ....
> If some of you could also test it, that would be
> great.
>
> many thanks,
>
> Antonio
>
> Linux GTK application entry point proposal
>
> harbour/source/vcl/mainlgtk.c
>
> #include <gtk/gtk.h>
> #include "hbapi.h"
> #include "hbvm.h"
>
> int main( int argc, char * argv[] )
> {
>    gtk_init( &argc, &argv );
>
>    hb_cmdargInit( argc, argv );
>    hb_vmInit( TRUE );
>    hb_vmQuit();
>
>    gtk_exit( 0 );
>
>    return 0;
> }


I think a little bit better entry point would be as follow :

------------- cut --------------------
#include <gtk/gtk.h>
#include "hbapi.h"
#include "hbvm.h"

int main( int argc, char * argv[] )
{
   HB_TRACE(HB_TR_DEBUG, ("main(%d, %p)", argc, argv));

   gtk_set_locale();
   if( gtk_init_check( &argc, &argv ) )
   {
      hb_cmdargInit( argc, argv );
      hb_vmInit( TRUE );
      hb_vmQuit();
      /* uncoment the next line if hb_vmQuit() returns */
      /* return 0; */
    }
    else
       fprintf( stderr, "%s\n", "Could not initialize GTK++ subsystem" );

    return( 1 );
}
------------- cut --------------------

but I really dubt we need it at all on X like platforms, instead of a simple
wraper around an initialization code, which is called at a begining of a PRG.
The reason is that, I think a special entry point idea will cause a need of at
least two versions of a libvm - one for a pure console applications and one
for a GUI based aplications on X like platforms, until you explicitly put a
proper mainstd.o or main<gui>.o object file into your link command.

--

  Marek Paliwoda
paliwoda@inetia.pl

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Tue Aug 28 21:08:02 2001

------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C13069.E46C80E0
Content-Type: application/octet-stream;
	name="tmysql.prg"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: attachment;
	filename="tmysql.prg"

/*
 * $Id: tmysql.prg,v 1.15 2001/04/12 18:24:40 dholm Exp $
 */

/*
 * Harbour Project source code:
 * MySQL DBMS classes.
 * These classes try to emulate clipper dbXXXX functions on a SQL query
 *
 * Copyright 2000 Maurilio Longo <maurilio.longo@libero.it>
 * www - http://www.harbour-project.org
 *
 * This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
 * it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
 * the Free Software Foundation; either version 2, or (at your option)
 * any later version.
 *
 * This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
 * but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
 * MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
 * GNU General Public License for more details.
 *
 * You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
 * along with this software; see the file COPYING.  If not, write to
 * the Free Software Foundation, Inc., 59 Temple Place, Suite 330,
 * Boston, MA 02111-1307 USA (or visit the web site =
http://www.gnu.org/).
 *
 * As a special exception, the Harbour Project gives permission for
 * additional uses of the text contained in its release of Harbour.
 *
 * The exception is that, if you link the Harbour libraries with other
 * files to produce an executable, this does not by itself cause the
 * resulting executable to be covered by the GNU General Public License.
 * Your use of that executable is in no way restricted on account of
 * linking the Harbour library code into it.
 *
 * This exception does not however invalidate any other reasons why
 * the executable file might be covered by the GNU General Public =
License.
 *
 * This exception applies only to the code released by the Harbour
 * Project under the name Harbour.  If you copy code from other
 * Harbour Project or Free Software Foundation releases into a copy of
 * Harbour, as the General Public License permits, the exception does
 * not apply to the code that you add in this way.  To avoid misleading
 * anyone as to the status of such modified files, you must delete
 * this exception notice from them.

 * If you write modifications of your own for Harbour, it is your choice
 * whether to permit this exception to apply to your modifications.
 * If you do not wish that, delete this exception notice.

#include "hbclass.ch"
#include "common.ch"
#include "dbstruct.ch"
#include "mysql.ch"



// Every single row of an answer
CLASS TMySQLRow

   DATA  aRow              // a single row of answer
   DATA  aDirty            // array of booleans set to .T. if =
corresponding field of aRow has been changed
   DATA  aOldValue         // If aDirty[n] is .T. aOldValue[n] keeps a =
copy of changed value if aRow[n] is part of a primary key

   DATA  aFieldStruct      // type of each field
   DATA  cTable            // Name of table containing this row, empty =
if TMySQLQuery returned this row

   DATA  cWhere

   METHOD   New(aRow, aFStruct, cTableName)     // Create a new Row =
object

   METHOD   FieldGet(cnField)          // Same as clipper ones, but =
FieldGet() and FieldPut() accept a string as
   METHOD   FieldPut(cnField, Value)   // field identifier, not only a =
number
   METHOD   FieldName(nNum)
   METHOD   FieldPos(cFieldName)

   METHOD   FieldLen(nNum)             // Length of field N
   METHOD   FieldDec(nNum)             // How many decimals in field N
   METHOD   FieldType(nNum)            // Clipper type of field N

   METHOD   MakePrimaryKeyWhere()    // returns a WHERE x=3Dy statement =
which uses primary key (if available)

   ERROR HANDLER OnError( cMsg, nError )

ENDCLASS


METHOD New(aRow, aFStruct, cTableName) CLASS TMySQLRow

   default cTableName to ""
   default aFStruct to {}

   ::aRow :=3D aRow
   ::aFieldStruct :=3D aFStruct
   ::cTable :=3D cTableName

   ::aDirty :=3D Array(Len(::aRow))
   ::aOldValue :=3D Array(Len(::aRow))

   AFill(::aDirty, .F.)

return Self


METHOD FieldGet(cnField) CLASS TMySQLRow

   local nNum

   if ValType(cnField) =3D=3D "C"
      nNum :=3D ::FieldPos(cnField)
   else
      nNum :=3D cnField
   endif

   if nNum > 0 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aRow)

      // Char fields are padded with spaces since a real .dbf field =
would be
      if ::FieldType(nNum) =3D=3D "C"
         return PadR(::aRow[nNum], =
::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_LENGTH])
      else
         return ::aRow[nNum]
      endif

   endif

return nil


METHOD FieldPut(cnField, Value) CLASS TMySQLRow

   local nNum

   if ValType(cnField) =3D=3D "C"
      nNum :=3D ::FieldPos(cnField)
   else
      nNum :=3D cnField
   endif

   if nNum > 0 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aRow)

      if Valtype(Value) =3D=3D Valtype(::aRow[nNum]) .OR. =
Empty(::aRow[nNum])

         // if it is a char field remove trailing spaces
         if ValType(Value) =3D=3D "C"
            Value :=3D RTrim(Value)
         endif

         // Save starting value for this field
         if !::aDirty[nNum]
            ::aOldValue[nNum] :=3D ::aRow[nNum]
            ::aDirty[nNum] :=3D .T.
         endif

         ::aRow[nNum] :=3D Value

         return Value
      endif
   endif

return nil


// Given a field name returns it's position
METHOD FieldPos(cFieldName) CLASS TMySQLRow

   local cUpperName, nPos :=3D 0

   cUpperName :=3D Upper(cFieldName)

   nPos :=3D AScan(::aFieldStruct, {|aItem| =
iif(Upper(aItem[MYSQL_FS_NAME]) =3D=3D cUpperName, .T., .F.)})

   /*while ++nPos <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      if Upper(::aFieldStruct[nPos][MYSQL_FS_NAME]) =3D=3D cUpperName
         exit
      endif
   enddo

   // I haven't found field name
   if nPos > Len(::aFieldStruct)
      nPos :=3D 0
   endif*/

return nPos


// Returns name of field N
METHOD FieldName(nNum) CLASS TMySQLRow

   if nNum >=3D1 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      return ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_NAME]
   endif

return ""


METHOD FieldLen(nNum) CLASS TMySQLRow

   if nNum >=3D1 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      return ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_LENGTH]
   endif

return ""


METHOD FieldDec(nNum) CLASS TMySQLRow

   if nNum >=3D1 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      return ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_DECIMALS]
   endif

return ""


METHOD FieldType(nNum) CLASS TMySQLRow

   local cType :=3D "U"

   if nNum >=3D1 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      do case
         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_TINY_TYPE
            cType :=3D "L"

         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_SHORT_TYPE .OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_LONG_TYPE =
.OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_LONGLONG_TYPE .OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_FLOAT_TYPE .OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_DOUBLE_TYPE
            cType :=3D "N"

         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_DATE_TYPE
            cType :=3D "D"

         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_BLOB_TYPE
            cType :=3D "M"

         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_VAR_STRING_TYPE .OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_STRING_TYPE
            cType :=3D "C"

         otherwise
            cType :=3D "U"

      endcase
   endif

return cType


// returns a WHERE x=3Dy statement which uses primary key (if available)
METHOD MakePrimaryKeyWhere() CLASS TMySQLRow

   local ni, cWhere :=3D " WHERE "

   IF ::cWhere <> NIL
      RETURN ::cWhere
   ENDIF

   for nI :=3D 1 to Len(::aFieldStruct)

      // search for fields part of a primary key
      if (sqlAND(::aFieldStruct[nI][MYSQL_FS_FLAGS], PRI_KEY_FLAG) =
=3D=3D PRI_KEY_FLAG) .OR.;
         (sqlAND(::aFieldStruct[nI][MYSQL_FS_FLAGS], MULTIPLE_KEY_FLAG) =
=3D=3D MULTIPLE_KEY_FLAG)

         cWhere +=3D ::aFieldStruct[nI][MYSQL_FS_NAME] + "=3D"

         // if a part of a primary key has been changed, use original =
value
         if ::aDirty[nI]
            cWhere +=3D ClipValue2SQL(::aOldValue[nI])
         else
            cWhere +=3D ClipValue2SQL(::aRow[nI])
         endif

         cWhere +=3D " AND "
      endif

   next

   // remove last " AND "
   cWhere :=3D Left(cWhere, Len(cWhere) - 5)

return cWhere

METHOD OnError( uParam1 ) CLASS TMySQLRow
   local cMsg :=3D __GetMessage()
   LOCAL nField :=3D 1

   IF SubStr( cMsg, 1, 1 ) =3D=3D "_"
      IF( ( nField :=3D ::FieldPos( SubStr( cMsg, 2 ) ) ) !=3D 0 )
         ::FieldPut( nField, uParam1 )
      ELSE
         _ClsSetError( _GenError( , ::ClassName(), SubStr( cMsg, 2 ) ) )
      ENDIF
   ELSE
      IF ( ( nField :=3D ::FieldPos( cMsg ) ) !=3D 0 )
         RETURN ::FieldGet( nField )
      ELSE
         _ClsSetError( _GenError(  , ::ClassName(), cMsg ) )
      ENDIF
   ENDIF

RETURN NIL



/* =
-------------------------------------------------------------------------=
---------------*/

// Every single query submitted to MySQL server
CLASS TMySQLQuery

   DATA  nSocket           // connection handle to MySQL server
   DATA  nResultHandle     // result handle received from MySQL

   DATA  cQuery            // copy of query that generated this object

   DATA  nNumRows          // number of rows available on answer NOTE =
MySQL is 0 based
   DATA  nCurRow           // I'm currently over row number

   DATA  nNumFields        // how many fields per row
   DATA  aFieldStruct      // type of each field, a copy is here a copy =
inside each row

   DATA  lError            // .T. if last operation failed

   METHOD   New(nSocket, cQuery)       // New query object
   METHOD   Destroy()
   METHOD   Refresh()                  // ReExecutes the query (cQuery) =
so that changes to table are visible

   METHOD   GetRow(nRow)               // return Row n of answer

   METHOD   Skip(nRows)                // Same as clipper ones

   METHOD   Bof() INLINE ::nCurRow =3D=3D 1
   METHOD   Eof() INLINE ::nCurRow =3D=3D ::nNumRows
   METHOD   RecNo() INLINE ::nCurRow
   METHOD   LastRec() INLINE ::nNumRows

   METHOD   FCount()

   METHOD   NetErr() INLINE ::lError         // Returns .T. if something =
went wrong
   METHOD   Error()                          // Returns textual =
description of last error and clears ::lError

ENDCLASS


METHOD New(nSocket, cQuery) CLASS TMySQLQuery

   local nI, aField, rc

   ::nSocket :=3D nSocket
   ::cQuery :=3D cQuery

   ::lError :=3D .F.
   ::aFieldStruct :=3D {}
   ::nCurRow :=3D 1
   ::nResultHandle :=3D nil
   ::nNumFields :=3D 0
   ::nNumRows :=3D 0

   if (rc :=3D sqlQuery(nSocket, cQuery)) =3D=3D 0

      // save result set
      if (::nResultHandle :=3D sqlStoreR(nSocket)) > 0

         ::nNumRows :=3D sqlNRows(::nResultHandle)
         ::nNumFields :=3D sqlNumFi(::nResultHandle)

         for nI :=3D 1 to ::nNumFields

            aField :=3D sqlFetchF(::nResultHandle)
            AAdd(::aFieldStruct, aField)

         next

      else
         // Should query have returned rows? (Was it a SELECT like =
query?)

         if (::nNumFields :=3D sqlNumFi(nSocket)) =3D=3D 0

            // Was not a SELECT so reset ResultHandle changed by =
previous sqlStoreR()
            ::nResultHandle :=3D nil

         else
            ::lError :=3D .T.

         endif
      endif
   else
      ::lError :=3D .T.

   endif

return Self


METHOD Refresh() CLASS TMySQLQuery

   local rc

   // free present result handle
   sqlFreeR(::nResultHandle)

   ::lError :=3D .F.

   if (rc :=3D sqlQuery(::nSocket, ::cQuery)) =3D=3D 0

      // save result set
      ::nResultHandle :=3D sqlStoreR(::nSocket)
      ::nNumRows :=3D sqlNRows(::nResultHandle)

      // NOTE: I presume that number of fields doesn't change (that is =
nobody alters this table) between
      // successive refreshes of the same

      // But row number could very well change
      if ::nCurRow > ::nNumRows
         ::nCurRow :=3D ::nNumRows
      endif

   else
      ::aFieldStruct :=3D {}
      ::nResultHandle :=3D nil
      ::nNumFields :=3D 0
      ::nNumRows :=3D 0
      ::lError :=3D .T.

   endif

return !::lError


METHOD Skip(nRows) CLASS TMySQLQuery

   // NOTE: MySQL row count starts from 0
   default nRows to 1

   if nRows =3D=3D 0
      // No move

   elseif nRows < 0
      // Negative movement
      ::nCurRow :=3D Max(::nCurRow + nRows, 1)

   else
      // positive movement
      ::nCurRow :=3D Min(::nCurRow + nRows, ::nNumRows)

   endif

   sqlDataS(::nResultHandle, ::nCurRow - 1)

return Self


/* Given a three letter month name gives back month number as two char =
string (ie. Apr -> 04) */
static function NMonth(cMonthValue)

   static cMonths :=3D {"Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Jul", =
"Ago", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec" }
   local nMonth

   nMonth :=3D AScan(cMonths, cMonthValue)

return PadL(nMonth, 2, "0")


// Get row n of a query and return it as a TMySQLRow object
METHOD GetRow(nRow) CLASS TMySQLQuery

   local aRow :=3D NIL
   local oRow :=3D NIL
   local i

   default nRow to 0

   if ::nResultHandle <> NIL
      if nRow >=3D 1 .AND. nRow <=3D ::nNumRows

         // NOTE: row count starts from 0
         sqlDataS(::nResultHandle, nRow - 1)
         ::nCurRow :=3D nRow
      else
         ::nCurRow++
      endif

      aRow :=3D sqlFetchR(::nResultHandle)

      if aRow <> NIL

         // Convert answer from text field to correct clipper types
         for i :=3D 1 to ::nNumFields
            do case
               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_TINY_TYPE
                  aRow[i] :=3D iif(Val(aRow[i]) =3D=3D 0, .F., .T.)

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_SHORT_TYPE .OR.;
                    ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_LONG_TYPE .OR.;
                    ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_LONGLONG_TYPE
                  aRow[i] :=3D Val(aRow[i])

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_DOUBLE_TYPE .OR.;
                    ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_FLOAT_TYPE
                  aRow[i] :=3D Val(aRow[i])

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_DATE_TYPE
                  if Empty(aRow[i])
                     aRow[i] :=3D CToD("")
                  else
                     // Date format YYYY-MM-DD
                     aRow[i] :=3D CToD(SubStr(aRow[i], 6, 2) + "/" + =
Right(aRow[i], 2) + "/" + Left(aRow[i], 4))
                  endif

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_BLOB_TYPE
                  // Memo field

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_STRING_TYPE .OR.;
                    ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_VAR_STRING_TYPE
                  // char field

               otherwise
                  Alert("Unknown type from SQL Server" + =
Str(::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE]))

            endcase
         next

         oRow :=3D TMySQLRow():New(aRow, ::aFieldStruct)
      endif
   endif

return iif(aRow =3D=3D NIL, NIL, oRow)


// Free result handle and associated resources
METHOD Destroy() CLASS TMySQLQuery

   sqlFreeR(::nResultHandle)

return Self


METHOD FCount() CLASS TMySQLQuery

return ::nNumFields


METHOD Error() CLASS TMySQLQuery

   ::lError :=3D .F.

return sqlGetErr(::nSocket)

/* =
-------------------------------------------------------------------------=
---------------*/

// A Table is a query without joins; this way I can Insert() e Delete() =
rows.
// NOTE: it's always a SELECT result, so it will contain a full table =
only if
//       SELECT * FROM ... was issued
CLASS TMySQLTable FROM TMySQLQuery

   DATA  cTable               // name of table

   METHOD   New(nSocket, cQuery, cTableName)
   METHOD   GetRow(nRow)

   METHOD   Update(oRow)      // Gets an oRow and updates changed fields
   METHOD   Delete(oRow)      // Deletes passed row from table
   METHOD   Append(oRow)      // Inserts passed row into table
   METHOD   GetBlankRow()     // Returns an empty row with all available =
fields empty

ENDCLASS


METHOD New(nSocket, cQuery, cTableName) CLASS TMySQLTable

   super:New(nSocket, AllTrim(cQuery))

   ::cTable :=3D Lower(cTableName)

return Self


METHOD GetRow(nRow) CLASS TMySQLTable

   local oRow :=3D super:GetRow(nRow)

   if oRow <> NIL
      oRow:cTable :=3D ::cTable
   endif

return oRow


/* Creates an update query for changed fields and submits it to server =
*/
METHOD Update(oRow) CLASS TMySQLTable

   local cUpdateQuery :=3D "UPDATE " + ::cTable + " SET "
   local i, cField

   ::lError :=3D .F.

   // is this a row of this table ?
   if oRow:cTable =3D=3D ::cTable

      for i :=3D 1 to Len(oRow:aRow)

         if oRow:aDirty[i]
            cUpdateQuery +=3D oRow:aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_NAME] + =
"=3D" + ClipValue2SQL(oRow:aRow[i]) + ","
         endif
      next

      // remove last comma
      cUpdateQuery :=3D Left(cUpdateQuery, Len(cUpdateQuery) -1)

      cUpdateQuery +=3D oRow:MakePrimaryKeyWhere()

      if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cUpdateQuery) =3D=3D 0

         // All values are commited
         Afill(oRow:aDirty, .F.)
         Afill(oRow:aOldValue, nil)

      else
         ::lError :=3D .T.

      endif

   endif

return !::lError


METHOD Delete(oRow) CLASS TMySQLTable

   local cDeleteQuery :=3D "DELETE FROM " + ::cTable

   // is this a row of this table ?
   if oRow:cTable =3D=3D ::cTable

      cDeleteQuery +=3D oRow:MakePrimaryKeyWhere()

      if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cDeleteQuery) =3D=3D 0
         ::lError :=3D .F.

      else
         ::lError :=3D .T.

      endif

  endif

return !::lError


// Adds a row with values passed into oRow
METHOD Append(oRow) CLASS TMySQLTable

   local cInsertQuery :=3D "INSERT INTO " + ::cTable + " ("
   local i, cField

   // is this a row of this table ?
   if oRow:cTable =3D=3D ::cTable

      // field names
      for i :=3D 1 to Len(oRow:aRow)
         cInsertQuery +=3D oRow:aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_NAME] + ","
      next
      // remove last comma from list
      cInsertQuery :=3D Left(cInsertQuery, Len(cInsertQuery) -1) + ") =
VALUES ("

      // field values
      for i :=3D 1 to Len(oRow:aRow)
         cInsertQuery +=3D ClipValue2SQL(oRow:aRow[i]) + ","

      next

      // remove last comma from list of values and add closing =
parenthesis
      cInsertQuery :=3D Left(cInsertQuery, Len(cInsertQuery) -1) + ")"

      if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cInsertQuery) =3D=3D 0
         return .T.
      else
         ::lError :=3D .T.
      endif

   endif

return .F.


METHOD GetBlankRow() CLASS TMySQLTable

   local i
   local aRow :=3D Array(::FCount())

   // crate an array of empty fields
   for i :=3D 1 to ::FCount()

      do case
      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_STRING_TYPE =
.OR.;
           ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_VAR_STRING_TYPE =
.OR.;
           ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_BLOB_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D ""

      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_SHORT_TYPE =
.OR.;
           ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_LONG_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D 0

      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_TINY_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D .F.

      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_DOUBLE_TYPE =
.OR.;
           ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_FLOAT_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D 0.0

      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_DATE_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D CToD("")

      otherwise
         aRow[i] :=3D nil

      endcase
   next

   return TMySQLRow():New(aRow, ::aFieldStruct, ::cTable, .F.)

return nil


/* =
-------------------------------------------------------------------------=
---------------*/

// Every available MySQL server
CLASS TMySQLServer

   DATA  nSocket                 // connection handle to server =
(currently pointer to a MYSQL structure)
   DATA  cServer                 // server name
   DATA  cDBName                 // Selected DB
   DATA  cUser                   // user accessing db
   DATA  cPassword               // his/her password
   DATA  lError                  // .T. if occurred an error

   METHOD   New(cServer, cUser, cPassword)   // Opens connection to a =
server, returns a server object
   METHOD   Destroy()                        // Closes connection to =
server

   METHOD   SelectDB(cDBName)    // Which data base I will use for =
subsequent queries

   METHOD   CreateTable(cTable, aStruct)  // Create new table using the =
same syntax of dbCreate()
   METHOD   DeleteTable(cTable)           // delete table
   METHOD   TableStruct(cTable)           // returns a structure array =
compatible with clipper's dbStruct() ones
   METHOD   CreateIndex(cName, cTable, aFNames, lUnique) // Create an =
index (unique) on field name(s) passed as an array of strings aFNames
   METHOD   DeleteIndex(cName, cTable)                   // Delete index =
cName from cTable

   METHOD   ListDBs()            // returns an array with list of data =
bases available
   METHOD   ListTables()         // returns an array with list of =
available tables in current database

   METHOD   Query(cQuery)        // Gets a textual query and returns a =
TMySQLQuery or TMySQLTable object

   METHOD   NetErr() INLINE ::lError         // Returns .T. if something =
went wrong
   METHOD   Error()                          // Returns textual =
description of last error

ENDCLASS


METHOD New(cServer, cUser, cPassword) CLASS TMySQLServer

   ::cServer :=3D cServer
   ::cUser :=3D cUser
   ::cPassword :=3D cPassword
   ::nSocket :=3D sqlConnect(cServer, cUser, cPassword)
   ::lError :=3D .F.

   if ::nSocket =3D=3D 0
      ::lError :=3D .T.
   endif

return Self

METHOD Destroy() CLASS TMySQLServer

   sqlClose(::nSocket)

return Self


METHOD SelectDB(cDBName) CLASS TMySQLServer

   if sqlSelectD(::nSocket, cDBName) =3D=3D 0
      ::cDBName :=3D cDBName
      return .T.
   else
      ::cDBName :=3D ""
   endif

return .F.


// NOTE: OS/2 port of MySQL is picky about table names, that is if you =
create a table with
// an upper case name you cannot alter it (for example) using a lower =
case name, this violates
// OS/2 case insensibility about names
METHOD CreateTable(cTable, aStruct) CLASS TMySQLServer

   /* NOTE: all table names are created with lower case */
   local cCreateQuery :=3D "CREATE TABLE " + Lower(cTable) + " ("
   local i

   // returns NOT NULL if extended structure has DBS_NOTNULL field to =
true
   local cNN :=3D {|aArr| iif(Len(aArr) > DBS_DEC, =
iif(aArr[DBS_NOTNULL], " NOT NULL ", ""), "")}

   for i :=3D 1 to Len(aStruct)
      do case
      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "C"
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " char(" + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_LEN])) + ")" + Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","

      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "M"
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " text" + Eval(cNN, =
aStruct[i]) + ","

      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "N"
         if aStruct[i][DBS_DEC] =3D=3D 0
            cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " int(" + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_LEN])) + ")" + Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","
         else
            cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " real(" + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_LEN])) + "," + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_DEC])) + ")" + Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","
         endif

      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "D"
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " date " + Eval(cNN, =
aStruct[i]) + ","

      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "L"
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " tinyint "  + =
Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","

      otherwise
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " char(" + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_LEN])) + ")" + Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","

      endcase

   next

   // remove last comma from list
   cCreateQuery :=3D Left(cCreateQuery, Len(cCreateQuery) -1) + ")"

   if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cCreateQuery) =3D=3D 0
      return .T.
   else
      ::lError :=3D .T.
   endif

return .F.


METHOD CreateIndex(cName, cTable, aFNames, lUnique) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local cCreateQuery :=3D "CREATE "
   local i

   default lUnique to .F.

   if lUnique
      cCreateQuery +=3D "UNIQUE INDEX "
   else
      cCreateQuery +=3D "INDEX "
   endif

   cCreateQuery +=3D cName + " ON " + Lower(cTable) + " ("

   for i :=3D 1 to Len(aFNames)
      cCreateQuery +=3D aFNames[i] + ","
   next

   // remove last comma from list
   cCreateQuery :=3D Left(cCreateQuery, Len(cCreateQuery) -1) + ")"

   if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cCreateQuery) =3D=3D 0
      return .T.

   endif

return .F.


METHOD DeleteIndex(cName, cTable) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local cDropQuery :=3D "DROP INDEX " + cName + " FROM " + =
Lower(cTable)

   if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cDropQuery) =3D=3D 0
      return .T.
   endif

return .F.


METHOD DeleteTable(cTable) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local cDropQuery :=3D "DROP TABLE " + Lower(cTable)

   if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cDropQuery) =3D=3D 0
      return .T.

   endif

return .F.


METHOD Query(cQuery) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local oQuery, cTableName, i, cUpperQuery, nNumTables, cToken

   default cQuery to ""


   cUpperQuery :=3D Upper(AllTrim(cQuery))
   i :=3D 1
   nNumTables :=3D 1

   while (cToken :=3D __StrToken(cUpperQuery, i++, " ")) <> "FROM" .AND. =
!Empty(cToken)
   enddo

   // first token after "FROM" is a table name
   // NOTE: SubSelects ?
   cTableName :=3D __StrToken(cUpperQuery, i++, " ")

   while (cToken :=3D __StrToken(cUpperQuery, i++, " ")) <> "WHERE" =
.AND. !Empty(cToken)
      // do we have more than one table referenced ?
      if cToken =3D=3D "," .OR. cToken =3D=3D "JOIN"
         nNumTables++
      endif
   enddo

   if nNumTables =3D=3D 1
      oQuery :=3D TMySQLTable():New(::nSocket, cQuery, cTableName)
   else
      oQuery :=3D TMySQLQuery():New(::nSocket, cQuery)
   endif

   if oQuery:NetErr()
      ::lError :=3D .T.
   endif

return oQuery


METHOD Error() CLASS TMySQLServer

   ::lError :=3D .F.

return iif(::nSocket > 0, sqlGetErr(::nSocket), "No connection to =
server")


METHOD ListDBs() CLASS TMySQLServer

   local aList

   aList :=3D sqlListDB(::nSocket)

return aList


METHOD ListTables() CLASS TMySQLServer

   local aList

   aList :=3D sqlListTbl(::nSocket)

return aList


/* TOFIX: Conversion creates a .dbf with fields of wrong dimension =
(often) */
METHOD TableStruct(cTable) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local nRes, aField, aStruct, aSField, i


   aStruct :=3D {}

   /* TODO: rewrite for MySQL
   nRes :=3D sqlListF(::nSocket, cTable)

   if nRes > 0
      for i :=3D 1 to sqlNumFi(nRes)

         aField :=3D sqlFetchF(nRes)
         aSField :=3D Array(DBS_DEC)

         // don't count indexes as real fields
         if aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] <=3D MSQL_LAST_REAL_TYPE

            aSField[DBS_NAME] :=3D Left(aField[MSQL_FS_NAME], 10)
            aSField[DBS_DEC] :=3D 0

            do case
            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_INT_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "N"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D 11

            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_UINT_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "L"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D 1

            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_CHAR_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "C"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D aField[MSQL_FS_LENGTH]

            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_DATE_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "D"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D aField[MSQL_FS_LENGTH]

            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_REAL_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "N"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D 12
               aSFIeld[DBS_DEC] :=3D 8

            otherwise

            endcase

            AAdd(aStruct, aSField)
         endif
      next

      sqlFreeR(nRes)

   endif*/

return aStruct


// Returns an SQL string with clipper value converted ie. Date() -> =
"'YYYY-MM-DD'"
static function ClipValue2SQL(Value)

   local cValue :=3D ""

   do case
      case Valtype(Value) =3D=3D "N"
         cValue :=3D AllTrim(Str(Value))

      case Valtype(Value) =3D=3D "D"
         if !Empty(Value)
            // MySQL dates are like YYYY-MM-DD
            cValue :=3D "'" + Str(Year(Value), 4) + "-" + =
PadL(Month(Value), 2, "0") + "-" + PadL(Day(Value), 2, "0") + "'"
         else
            cValue :=3D "''"
         endif

      case Valtype(Value) $ "CM"
         cValue :=3D "'" + StrTran(Value, "'", "\'") + "'"

      case Valtype(Value) =3D=3D "L"
         cValue :=3D AllTrim(Str(iif(Value =3D=3D .F., 0, 1)))

      otherwise
         cValue :=3D "''"       // NOTE: Here we lose values we cannot =
convert

   endcase

return cValue


------=_NextPart_000_0001_01C13069.E46C80E0--
