#include "hbclass.ch"
#include "common.ch"
#include "dbstruct.ch"
#include "mysql.ch"



// Every single row of an answer
CLASS TMySQLRow

   DATA  aRow              // a single row of answer
   DATA  aDirty            // array of booleans set to .T. if =
corresponding field of aRow has been changed
   DATA  aOldValue         // If aDirty[n] is .T. aOldValue[n] keeps a =
copy of changed value if aRow[n] is part of a primary key

   DATA  aFieldStruct      // type of each field
   DATA  cTable            // Name of table containing this row, empty =
if TMySQLQuery returned this row

   DATA  cWhere

   METHOD   New(aRow, aFStruct, cTableName)     // Create a new Row =
object

   METHOD   FieldGet(cnField)          // Same as clipper ones, but =
FieldGet() and FieldPut() accept a string as
   METHOD   FieldPut(cnField, Value)   // field identifier, not only a =
number
   METHOD   FieldName(nNum)
   METHOD   FieldPos(cFieldName)

   METHOD   FieldLen(nNum)             // Length of field N
   METHOD   FieldDec(nNum)             // How many decimals in field N
   METHOD   FieldType(nNum)            // Clipper type of field N

   METHOD   MakePrimaryKeyWhere()    // returns a WHERE x=3Dy statement =
which uses primary key (if available)

   ERROR HANDLER OnError( cMsg, nError )

ENDCLASS


METHOD New(aRow, aFStruct, cTableName) CLASS TMySQLRow

   default cTableName to ""
   default aFStruct to {}

   ::aRow :=3D aRow
   ::aFieldStruct :=3D aFStruct
   ::cTable :=3D cTableName

   ::aDirty :=3D Array(Len(::aRow))
   ::aOldValue :=3D Array(Len(::aRow))

   AFill(::aDirty, .F.)

return Self


METHOD FieldGet(cnField) CLASS TMySQLRow

   local nNum

   if ValType(cnField) =3D=3D "C"
      nNum :=3D ::FieldPos(cnField)
   else
      nNum :=3D cnField
   endif

   if nNum > 0 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aRow)

      // Char fields are padded with spaces since a real .dbf field =
would be
      if ::FieldType(nNum) =3D=3D "C"
         return PadR(::aRow[nNum], =
::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_LENGTH])
      else
         return ::aRow[nNum]
      endif

   endif

return nil


METHOD FieldPut(cnField, Value) CLASS TMySQLRow

   local nNum

   if ValType(cnField) =3D=3D "C"
      nNum :=3D ::FieldPos(cnField)
   else
      nNum :=3D cnField
   endif

   if nNum > 0 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aRow)

      if Valtype(Value) =3D=3D Valtype(::aRow[nNum]) .OR. =
Empty(::aRow[nNum])

         // if it is a char field remove trailing spaces
         if ValType(Value) =3D=3D "C"
            Value :=3D RTrim(Value)
         endif

         // Save starting value for this field
         if !::aDirty[nNum]
            ::aOldValue[nNum] :=3D ::aRow[nNum]
            ::aDirty[nNum] :=3D .T.
         endif

         ::aRow[nNum] :=3D Value

         return Value
      endif
   endif

return nil


// Given a field name returns it's position
METHOD FieldPos(cFieldName) CLASS TMySQLRow

   local cUpperName, nPos :=3D 0

   cUpperName :=3D Upper(cFieldName)

   nPos :=3D AScan(::aFieldStruct, {|aItem| =
iif(Upper(aItem[MYSQL_FS_NAME]) =3D=3D cUpperName, .T., .F.)})

   /*while ++nPos <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      if Upper(::aFieldStruct[nPos][MYSQL_FS_NAME]) =3D=3D cUpperName
         exit
      endif
   enddo

   // I haven't found field name
   if nPos > Len(::aFieldStruct)
      nPos :=3D 0
   endif*/

return nPos


// Returns name of field N
METHOD FieldName(nNum) CLASS TMySQLRow

   if nNum >=3D1 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      return ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_NAME]
   endif

return ""


METHOD FieldLen(nNum) CLASS TMySQLRow

   if nNum >=3D1 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      return ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_LENGTH]
   endif

return ""


METHOD FieldDec(nNum) CLASS TMySQLRow

   if nNum >=3D1 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      return ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_DECIMALS]
   endif

return ""


METHOD FieldType(nNum) CLASS TMySQLRow

   local cType :=3D "U"

   if nNum >=3D1 .AND. nNum <=3D Len(::aFieldStruct)
      do case
         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_TINY_TYPE
            cType :=3D "L"

         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_SHORT_TYPE .OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_LONG_TYPE =
.OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_LONGLONG_TYPE .OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_FLOAT_TYPE .OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_DOUBLE_TYPE
            cType :=3D "N"

         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_DATE_TYPE
            cType :=3D "D"

         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_BLOB_TYPE
            cType :=3D "M"

         case ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_VAR_STRING_TYPE .OR.;
              ::aFieldStruct[nNum][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_STRING_TYPE
            cType :=3D "C"

         otherwise
            cType :=3D "U"

      endcase
   endif

return cType


// returns a WHERE x=3Dy statement which uses primary key (if available)
METHOD MakePrimaryKeyWhere() CLASS TMySQLRow

   local ni, cWhere :=3D " WHERE "

   IF ::cWhere <> NIL
      RETURN ::cWhere
   ENDIF

   for nI :=3D 1 to Len(::aFieldStruct)

      // search for fields part of a primary key
      if (sqlAND(::aFieldStruct[nI][MYSQL_FS_FLAGS], PRI_KEY_FLAG) =
=3D=3D PRI_KEY_FLAG) .OR.;
         (sqlAND(::aFieldStruct[nI][MYSQL_FS_FLAGS], MULTIPLE_KEY_FLAG) =
=3D=3D MULTIPLE_KEY_FLAG)

         cWhere +=3D ::aFieldStruct[nI][MYSQL_FS_NAME] + "=3D"

         // if a part of a primary key has been changed, use original =
value
         if ::aDirty[nI]
            cWhere +=3D ClipValue2SQL(::aOldValue[nI])
         else
            cWhere +=3D ClipValue2SQL(::aRow[nI])
         endif

         cWhere +=3D " AND "
      endif

   next

   // remove last " AND "
   cWhere :=3D Left(cWhere, Len(cWhere) - 5)

return cWhere

METHOD OnError( uParam1 ) CLASS TMySQLRow
   local cMsg :=3D __GetMessage()
   LOCAL nField :=3D 1

   IF SubStr( cMsg, 1, 1 ) =3D=3D "_"
      IF( ( nField :=3D ::FieldPos( SubStr( cMsg, 2 ) ) ) !=3D 0 )
         ::FieldPut( nField, uParam1 )
      ELSE
         _ClsSetError( _GenError( , ::ClassName(), SubStr( cMsg, 2 ) ) )
      ENDIF
   ELSE
      IF ( ( nField :=3D ::FieldPos( cMsg ) ) !=3D 0 )
         RETURN ::FieldGet( nField )
      ELSE
         _ClsSetError( _GenError(  , ::ClassName(), cMsg ) )
      ENDIF
   ENDIF

RETURN NIL



/* =
-------------------------------------------------------------------------=
---------------*/

// Every single query submitted to MySQL server
CLASS TMySQLQuery

   DATA  nSocket           // connection handle to MySQL server
   DATA  nResultHandle     // result handle received from MySQL

   DATA  cQuery            // copy of query that generated this object

   DATA  nNumRows          // number of rows available on answer NOTE =
MySQL is 0 based
   DATA  nCurRow           // I'm currently over row number

   DATA  nNumFields        // how many fields per row
   DATA  aFieldStruct      // type of each field, a copy is here a copy =
inside each row

   DATA  lError            // .T. if last operation failed

   METHOD   New(nSocket, cQuery)       // New query object
   METHOD   Destroy()
   METHOD   Refresh()                  // ReExecutes the query (cQuery) =
so that changes to table are visible

   METHOD   GetRow(nRow)               // return Row n of answer

   METHOD   Skip(nRows)                // Same as clipper ones

   METHOD   Bof() INLINE ::nCurRow =3D=3D 1
   METHOD   Eof() INLINE ::nCurRow =3D=3D ::nNumRows
   METHOD   RecNo() INLINE ::nCurRow
   METHOD   LastRec() INLINE ::nNumRows

   METHOD   FCount()

   METHOD   NetErr() INLINE ::lError         // Returns .T. if something =
went wrong
   METHOD   Error()                          // Returns textual =
description of last error and clears ::lError

ENDCLASS


METHOD New(nSocket, cQuery) CLASS TMySQLQuery

   local nI, aField, rc

   ::nSocket :=3D nSocket
   ::cQuery :=3D cQuery

   ::lError :=3D .F.
   ::aFieldStruct :=3D {}
   ::nCurRow :=3D 1
   ::nResultHandle :=3D nil
   ::nNumFields :=3D 0
   ::nNumRows :=3D 0

   if (rc :=3D sqlQuery(nSocket, cQuery)) =3D=3D 0

      // save result set
      if (::nResultHandle :=3D sqlStoreR(nSocket)) > 0

         ::nNumRows :=3D sqlNRows(::nResultHandle)
         ::nNumFields :=3D sqlNumFi(::nResultHandle)

         for nI :=3D 1 to ::nNumFields

            aField :=3D sqlFetchF(::nResultHandle)
            AAdd(::aFieldStruct, aField)

         next

      else
         // Should query have returned rows? (Was it a SELECT like =
query?)

         if (::nNumFields :=3D sqlNumFi(nSocket)) =3D=3D 0

            // Was not a SELECT so reset ResultHandle changed by =
previous sqlStoreR()
            ::nResultHandle :=3D nil

         else
            ::lError :=3D .T.

         endif
      endif
   else
      ::lError :=3D .T.

   endif

return Self


METHOD Refresh() CLASS TMySQLQuery

   local rc

   // free present result handle
   sqlFreeR(::nResultHandle)

   ::lError :=3D .F.

   if (rc :=3D sqlQuery(::nSocket, ::cQuery)) =3D=3D 0

      // save result set
      ::nResultHandle :=3D sqlStoreR(::nSocket)
      ::nNumRows :=3D sqlNRows(::nResultHandle)

      // NOTE: I presume that number of fields doesn't change (that is =
nobody alters this table) between
      // successive refreshes of the same

      // But row number could very well change
      if ::nCurRow > ::nNumRows
         ::nCurRow :=3D ::nNumRows
      endif

   else
      ::aFieldStruct :=3D {}
      ::nResultHandle :=3D nil
      ::nNumFields :=3D 0
      ::nNumRows :=3D 0
      ::lError :=3D .T.

   endif

return !::lError


METHOD Skip(nRows) CLASS TMySQLQuery

   // NOTE: MySQL row count starts from 0
   default nRows to 1

   if nRows =3D=3D 0
      // No move

   elseif nRows < 0
      // Negative movement
      ::nCurRow :=3D Max(::nCurRow + nRows, 1)

   else
      // positive movement
      ::nCurRow :=3D Min(::nCurRow + nRows, ::nNumRows)

   endif

   sqlDataS(::nResultHandle, ::nCurRow - 1)

return Self


/* Given a three letter month name gives back month number as two char =
string (ie. Apr -> 04) */
static function NMonth(cMonthValue)

   static cMonths :=3D {"Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr", "May", "Jun", "Jul", =
"Ago", "Sep", "Oct", "Nov", "Dec" }
   local nMonth

   nMonth :=3D AScan(cMonths, cMonthValue)

return PadL(nMonth, 2, "0")


// Get row n of a query and return it as a TMySQLRow object
METHOD GetRow(nRow) CLASS TMySQLQuery

   local aRow :=3D NIL
   local oRow :=3D NIL
   local i

   default nRow to 0

   if ::nResultHandle <> NIL
      if nRow >=3D 1 .AND. nRow <=3D ::nNumRows

         // NOTE: row count starts from 0
         sqlDataS(::nResultHandle, nRow - 1)
         ::nCurRow :=3D nRow
      else
         ::nCurRow++
      endif

      aRow :=3D sqlFetchR(::nResultHandle)

      if aRow <> NIL

         // Convert answer from text field to correct clipper types
         for i :=3D 1 to ::nNumFields
            do case
               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_TINY_TYPE
                  aRow[i] :=3D iif(Val(aRow[i]) =3D=3D 0, .F., .T.)

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_SHORT_TYPE .OR.;
                    ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_LONG_TYPE .OR.;
                    ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_LONGLONG_TYPE
                  aRow[i] :=3D Val(aRow[i])

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_DOUBLE_TYPE .OR.;
                    ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_FLOAT_TYPE
                  aRow[i] :=3D Val(aRow[i])

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_DATE_TYPE
                  if Empty(aRow[i])
                     aRow[i] :=3D CToD("")
                  else
                     // Date format YYYY-MM-DD
                     aRow[i] :=3D CToD(SubStr(aRow[i], 6, 2) + "/" + =
Right(aRow[i], 2) + "/" + Left(aRow[i], 4))
                  endif

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_BLOB_TYPE
                  // Memo field

               case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_STRING_TYPE .OR.;
                    ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D =
MYSQL_VAR_STRING_TYPE
                  // char field

               otherwise
                  Alert("Unknown type from SQL Server" + =
Str(::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE]))

            endcase
         next

         oRow :=3D TMySQLRow():New(aRow, ::aFieldStruct)
      endif
   endif

return iif(aRow =3D=3D NIL, NIL, oRow)


// Free result handle and associated resources
METHOD Destroy() CLASS TMySQLQuery

   sqlFreeR(::nResultHandle)

return Self


METHOD FCount() CLASS TMySQLQuery

return ::nNumFields


METHOD Error() CLASS TMySQLQuery

   ::lError :=3D .F.

return sqlGetErr(::nSocket)

/* =
-------------------------------------------------------------------------=
---------------*/

// A Table is a query without joins; this way I can Insert() e Delete() =
rows.
// NOTE: it's always a SELECT result, so it will contain a full table =
only if
//       SELECT * FROM ... was issued
CLASS TMySQLTable FROM TMySQLQuery

   DATA  cTable               // name of table

   METHOD   New(nSocket, cQuery, cTableName)
   METHOD   GetRow(nRow)

   METHOD   Update(oRow)      // Gets an oRow and updates changed fields
   METHOD   Delete(oRow)      // Deletes passed row from table
   METHOD   Append(oRow)      // Inserts passed row into table
   METHOD   GetBlankRow()     // Returns an empty row with all available =
fields empty

ENDCLASS


METHOD New(nSocket, cQuery, cTableName) CLASS TMySQLTable

   super:New(nSocket, AllTrim(cQuery))

   ::cTable :=3D Lower(cTableName)

return Self


METHOD GetRow(nRow) CLASS TMySQLTable

   local oRow :=3D super:GetRow(nRow)

   if oRow <> NIL
      oRow:cTable :=3D ::cTable
   endif

return oRow


/* Creates an update query for changed fields and submits it to server =
*/
METHOD Update(oRow) CLASS TMySQLTable

   local cUpdateQuery :=3D "UPDATE " + ::cTable + " SET "
   local i, cField

   ::lError :=3D .F.

   // is this a row of this table ?
   if oRow:cTable =3D=3D ::cTable

      for i :=3D 1 to Len(oRow:aRow)

         if oRow:aDirty[i]
            cUpdateQuery +=3D oRow:aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_NAME] + =
"=3D" + ClipValue2SQL(oRow:aRow[i]) + ","
         endif
      next

      // remove last comma
      cUpdateQuery :=3D Left(cUpdateQuery, Len(cUpdateQuery) -1)

      cUpdateQuery +=3D oRow:MakePrimaryKeyWhere()

      if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cUpdateQuery) =3D=3D 0

         // All values are commited
         Afill(oRow:aDirty, .F.)
         Afill(oRow:aOldValue, nil)

      else
         ::lError :=3D .T.

      endif

   endif

return !::lError


METHOD Delete(oRow) CLASS TMySQLTable

   local cDeleteQuery :=3D "DELETE FROM " + ::cTable

   // is this a row of this table ?
   if oRow:cTable =3D=3D ::cTable

      cDeleteQuery +=3D oRow:MakePrimaryKeyWhere()

      if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cDeleteQuery) =3D=3D 0
         ::lError :=3D .F.

      else
         ::lError :=3D .T.

      endif

  endif

return !::lError


// Adds a row with values passed into oRow
METHOD Append(oRow) CLASS TMySQLTable

   local cInsertQuery :=3D "INSERT INTO " + ::cTable + " ("
   local i, cField

   // is this a row of this table ?
   if oRow:cTable =3D=3D ::cTable

      // field names
      for i :=3D 1 to Len(oRow:aRow)
         cInsertQuery +=3D oRow:aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_NAME] + ","
      next
      // remove last comma from list
      cInsertQuery :=3D Left(cInsertQuery, Len(cInsertQuery) -1) + ") =
VALUES ("

      // field values
      for i :=3D 1 to Len(oRow:aRow)
         cInsertQuery +=3D ClipValue2SQL(oRow:aRow[i]) + ","

      next

      // remove last comma from list of values and add closing =
parenthesis
      cInsertQuery :=3D Left(cInsertQuery, Len(cInsertQuery) -1) + ")"

      if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cInsertQuery) =3D=3D 0
         return .T.
      else
         ::lError :=3D .T.
      endif

   endif

return .F.


METHOD GetBlankRow() CLASS TMySQLTable

   local i
   local aRow :=3D Array(::FCount())

   // crate an array of empty fields
   for i :=3D 1 to ::FCount()

      do case
      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_STRING_TYPE =
.OR.;
           ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_VAR_STRING_TYPE =
.OR.;
           ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_BLOB_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D ""

      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_SHORT_TYPE =
.OR.;
           ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_LONG_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D 0

      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_TINY_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D .F.

      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_DOUBLE_TYPE =
.OR.;
           ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_FLOAT_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D 0.0

      case ::aFieldStruct[i][MYSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MYSQL_DATE_TYPE
         aRow[i] :=3D CToD("")

      otherwise
         aRow[i] :=3D nil

      endcase
   next

   return TMySQLRow():New(aRow, ::aFieldStruct, ::cTable, .F.)

return nil


/* =
-------------------------------------------------------------------------=
---------------*/

// Every available MySQL server
CLASS TMySQLServer

   DATA  nSocket                 // connection handle to server =
(currently pointer to a MYSQL structure)
   DATA  cServer                 // server name
   DATA  cDBName                 // Selected DB
   DATA  cUser                   // user accessing db
   DATA  cPassword               // his/her password
   DATA  lError                  // .T. if occurred an error

   METHOD   New(cServer, cUser, cPassword)   // Opens connection to a =
server, returns a server object
   METHOD   Destroy()                        // Closes connection to =
server

   METHOD   SelectDB(cDBName)    // Which data base I will use for =
subsequent queries

   METHOD   CreateTable(cTable, aStruct)  // Create new table using the =
same syntax of dbCreate()
   METHOD   DeleteTable(cTable)           // delete table
   METHOD   TableStruct(cTable)           // returns a structure array =
compatible with clipper's dbStruct() ones
   METHOD   CreateIndex(cName, cTable, aFNames, lUnique) // Create an =
index (unique) on field name(s) passed as an array of strings aFNames
   METHOD   DeleteIndex(cName, cTable)                   // Delete index =
cName from cTable

   METHOD   ListDBs()            // returns an array with list of data =
bases available
   METHOD   ListTables()         // returns an array with list of =
available tables in current database

   METHOD   Query(cQuery)        // Gets a textual query and returns a =
TMySQLQuery or TMySQLTable object

   METHOD   NetErr() INLINE ::lError         // Returns .T. if something =
went wrong
   METHOD   Error()                          // Returns textual =
description of last error

ENDCLASS


METHOD New(cServer, cUser, cPassword) CLASS TMySQLServer

   ::cServer :=3D cServer
   ::cUser :=3D cUser
   ::cPassword :=3D cPassword
   ::nSocket :=3D sqlConnect(cServer, cUser, cPassword)
   ::lError :=3D .F.

   if ::nSocket =3D=3D 0
      ::lError :=3D .T.
   endif

return Self

METHOD Destroy() CLASS TMySQLServer

   sqlClose(::nSocket)

return Self


METHOD SelectDB(cDBName) CLASS TMySQLServer

   if sqlSelectD(::nSocket, cDBName) =3D=3D 0
      ::cDBName :=3D cDBName
      return .T.
   else
      ::cDBName :=3D ""
   endif

return .F.


// NOTE: OS/2 port of MySQL is picky about table names, that is if you =
create a table with
// an upper case name you cannot alter it (for example) using a lower =
case name, this violates
// OS/2 case insensibility about names
METHOD CreateTable(cTable, aStruct) CLASS TMySQLServer

   /* NOTE: all table names are created with lower case */
   local cCreateQuery :=3D "CREATE TABLE " + Lower(cTable) + " ("
   local i

   // returns NOT NULL if extended structure has DBS_NOTNULL field to =
true
   local cNN :=3D {|aArr| iif(Len(aArr) > DBS_DEC, =
iif(aArr[DBS_NOTNULL], " NOT NULL ", ""), "")}

   for i :=3D 1 to Len(aStruct)
      do case
      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "C"
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " char(" + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_LEN])) + ")" + Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","

      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "M"
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " text" + Eval(cNN, =
aStruct[i]) + ","

      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "N"
         if aStruct[i][DBS_DEC] =3D=3D 0
            cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " int(" + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_LEN])) + ")" + Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","
         else
            cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " real(" + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_LEN])) + "," + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_DEC])) + ")" + Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","
         endif

      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "D"
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " date " + Eval(cNN, =
aStruct[i]) + ","

      case aStruct[i][DBS_TYPE] =3D=3D "L"
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " tinyint "  + =
Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","

      otherwise
         cCreateQuery +=3D aStruct[i][DBS_NAME] + " char(" + =
AllTrim(Str(aStruct[i][DBS_LEN])) + ")" + Eval(cNN, aStruct[i]) + ","

      endcase

   next

   // remove last comma from list
   cCreateQuery :=3D Left(cCreateQuery, Len(cCreateQuery) -1) + ")"

   if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cCreateQuery) =3D=3D 0
      return .T.
   else
      ::lError :=3D .T.
   endif

return .F.


METHOD CreateIndex(cName, cTable, aFNames, lUnique) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local cCreateQuery :=3D "CREATE "
   local i

   default lUnique to .F.

   if lUnique
      cCreateQuery +=3D "UNIQUE INDEX "
   else
      cCreateQuery +=3D "INDEX "
   endif

   cCreateQuery +=3D cName + " ON " + Lower(cTable) + " ("

   for i :=3D 1 to Len(aFNames)
      cCreateQuery +=3D aFNames[i] + ","
   next

   // remove last comma from list
   cCreateQuery :=3D Left(cCreateQuery, Len(cCreateQuery) -1) + ")"

   if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cCreateQuery) =3D=3D 0
      return .T.

   endif

return .F.


METHOD DeleteIndex(cName, cTable) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local cDropQuery :=3D "DROP INDEX " + cName + " FROM " + =
Lower(cTable)

   if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cDropQuery) =3D=3D 0
      return .T.
   endif

return .F.


METHOD DeleteTable(cTable) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local cDropQuery :=3D "DROP TABLE " + Lower(cTable)

   if sqlQuery(::nSocket, cDropQuery) =3D=3D 0
      return .T.

   endif

return .F.


METHOD Query(cQuery) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local oQuery, cTableName, i, cUpperQuery, nNumTables, cToken

   default cQuery to ""


   cUpperQuery :=3D Upper(AllTrim(cQuery))
   i :=3D 1
   nNumTables :=3D 1

   while (cToken :=3D __StrToken(cUpperQuery, i++, " ")) <> "FROM" .AND. =
!Empty(cToken)
   enddo

   // first token after "FROM" is a table name
   // NOTE: SubSelects ?
   cTableName :=3D __StrToken(cUpperQuery, i++, " ")

   while (cToken :=3D __StrToken(cUpperQuery, i++, " ")) <> "WHERE" =
.AND. !Empty(cToken)
      // do we have more than one table referenced ?
      if cToken =3D=3D "," .OR. cToken =3D=3D "JOIN"
         nNumTables++
      endif
   enddo

   if nNumTables =3D=3D 1
      oQuery :=3D TMySQLTable():New(::nSocket, cQuery, cTableName)
   else
      oQuery :=3D TMySQLQuery():New(::nSocket, cQuery)
   endif

   if oQuery:NetErr()
      ::lError :=3D .T.
   endif

return oQuery


METHOD Error() CLASS TMySQLServer

   ::lError :=3D .F.

return iif(::nSocket > 0, sqlGetErr(::nSocket), "No connection to =
server")


METHOD ListDBs() CLASS TMySQLServer

   local aList

   aList :=3D sqlListDB(::nSocket)

return aList


METHOD ListTables() CLASS TMySQLServer

   local aList

   aList :=3D sqlListTbl(::nSocket)

return aList


/* TOFIX: Conversion creates a .dbf with fields of wrong dimension =
(often) */
METHOD TableStruct(cTable) CLASS TMySQLServer

   local nRes, aField, aStruct, aSField, i


   aStruct :=3D {}

   /* TODO: rewrite for MySQL
   nRes :=3D sqlListF(::nSocket, cTable)

   if nRes > 0
      for i :=3D 1 to sqlNumFi(nRes)

         aField :=3D sqlFetchF(nRes)
         aSField :=3D Array(DBS_DEC)

         // don't count indexes as real fields
         if aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] <=3D MSQL_LAST_REAL_TYPE

            aSField[DBS_NAME] :=3D Left(aField[MSQL_FS_NAME], 10)
            aSField[DBS_DEC] :=3D 0

            do case
            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_INT_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "N"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D 11

            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_UINT_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "L"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D 1

            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_CHAR_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "C"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D aField[MSQL_FS_LENGTH]

            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_DATE_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "D"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D aField[MSQL_FS_LENGTH]

            case aField[MSQL_FS_TYPE] =3D=3D MSQL_REAL_TYPE
               aSField[DBS_TYPE] :=3D "N"
               aSField[DBS_LEN] :=3D 12
               aSFIeld[DBS_DEC] :=3D 8

            otherwise

            endcase

            AAdd(aStruct, aSField)
         endif
      next

      sqlFreeR(nRes)

   endif*/

return aStruct


// Returns an SQL string with clipper value converted ie. Date() -> =
"'YYYY-MM-DD'"
static function ClipValue2SQL(Value)

   local cValue :=3D ""

   do case
      case Valtype(Value) =3D=3D "N"
         cValue :=3D AllTrim(Str(Value))

      case Valtype(Value) =3D=3D "D"
         if !Empty(Value)
            // MySQL dates are like YYYY-MM-DD
            cValue :=3D "'" + Str(Year(Value), 4) + "-" + =
PadL(Month(Value), 2, "0") + "-" + PadL(Day(Value), 2, "0") + "'"
         else
            cValue :=3D "''"
         endif

      case Valtype(Value) $ "CM"
         cValue :=3D "'" + StrTran(Value, "'", "\'") + "'"

      case Valtype(Value) =3D=3D "L"
         cValue :=3D AllTrim(Str(iif(Value =3D=3D .F., 0, 1)))

      otherwise
         cValue :=3D "''"       // NOTE: Here we lose values we cannot =
convert

   endcase

return cValue

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 29 05:44:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Wed Aug 29 04:44:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] TMySql  change
In-Reply-To: <000001c13064$be9fc890$0200a8c0@fivetech2k>; from Charles@fivetech.net on Wed, Aug 29, 2001 at 05:29:38PM +0900
References: <3B8C90E0.8FE89BF0@libero.it> <000001c13064$be9fc890$0200a8c0@fivetech2k>
Message-ID: <20010829094320.I1437@hagbard.davep.org>

[Quotes rearranged to have a more logical flow]

On Wed, Aug 29, 2001 at 05:29:38PM +0900, Kwon,OJun (Charles Kwon) wrote:

> > just a question, isn't it a bit slow to cause an exception every time
> > you need to update a field?
> 
> It is not update every time
> 
> TMySql just update when oRow:Update() are not? :-)

I think he's asking if it's a little slow to manage named column access, via
message sends, using the error handler for every access/assign of a column.
It's not uncommon to do this sort of thing using a metaclass that generates
messages when you instantiate it (or perhaps when you connect it to a query
or table) but you seem to have taken a different approach here.

-- 
Land of the free? Yeah, right.
                                                http://www.freesklyarov.org/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 29 05:47:02 2001

Charles,

no, you have an error every time you change a field,

oRow:Field1 := "a"
oRow:Field2 := "b"
cValue1 := oRow:Field3
cValue2 := oRow:Field4

these are four exceptions which get caught by the error handler and routed
to a ::FieldPut()/FieldGet() call.

Now think about a TBrowse which repaints cells :-)

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 29 10:41:06 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Wed Aug 29 09:41:06 2001
Subject: [Harbour] contrib/hgf
In-Reply-To: <002601c13083$d53a47a0$f0d4d7c8@culik>
Message-ID: <000e01c1308f$a927d0e0$0f2aa8c0@first>

Luiz,

> Does in  contrib/hgf/win32 only goes tform wrapper or can also go utilites
> function for the respective platform.

My opinion is that only the classes and
wrappers should go there.

We are working to offer the highest
GUI compatibility level. If we start
adding utilities that are not supported
on other GUIs, then we will be breaking
such compatibility.

Antonio



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 29 10:41:56 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Wed Aug 29 09:41:56 2001
Subject: [Harbour] contrib/hgf
In-Reply-To: <3B8CE1A1.5C7CBB00@libero.it>
Message-ID: <000f01c1308f$b7990540$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

> I'll surely do, but, there is a way to tell the cvs server to move a file
> or do have I to delete them from contrib/os2pm and add them back to
> hgf/os2pm?

I really don't know it :-(


Antonio



From harbour@matrixlist.com  Wed Aug 29 17:10:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Martin Vogel)
Date: Wed Aug 29 16:10:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] contrib/hgf
Message-ID: <006501c130c7$59899ae0$8be0fe91@martinvogel>

Maurilio,

>I'll surely do, but, there is a way to tell the cvs server to move a file
>or do have I to delete them from contrib/os2pm and add them back to
>hgf/os2pm?


In CVS, you have to

1) move the files locally to the new location
2) make a "cvs del <file1> <file2>..." in the old location (note that this
works only if the files are not in the old location any more)
3) make a "cvs add <file1> <file2>..." in the new location.

IIRC the cvs manual, that is the only way to move files.

HTH

Martin

-----Original Message-----
From: harbour-admin@matrixlist.com [mailto:harbour-admin@matrixlist.com]
On Behalf Of Antonio Linares
Sent: Wednesday, August 29, 2001 10:37 PM
To: harbour@matrixlist.com
Subject: RE: [Harbour] contrib/hgf


Luiz,

> Does in  contrib/hgf/win32 only goes tform wrapper or can also go 
> utilites function for the respective platform.

My opinion is that only the classes and
wrappers should go there.

We are working to offer the highest
GUI compatibility level. If we start
adding utilities that are not supported
on other GUIs, then we will be breaking
such compatibility.

Antonio

Martin,

Martin Vogel ha scritto:

> Maurilio,
>
> >I'll surely do, but, there is a way to tell the cvs server to move a file
> >or do have I to delete them from contrib/os2pm and add them back to
> >hgf/os2pm?
>
> In CVS, you have to
>
> 1) move the files locally to the new location
> 2) make a "cvs del <file1> <file2>..." in the old location (note that this
> works only if the files are not in the old location any more)
> 3) make a "cvs add <file1> <file2>..." in the new location.
>
> IIRC the cvs manual, that is the only way to move files.
>
> HTH
>
> Martin
>
> _______________________________________________

> Harbour@matrixlist.com

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 05:11:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Thu Aug 30 04:11:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OS2 PM GUI
In-Reply-To: <3B8DF103.137E7374@libero.it>
Message-ID: <003601c1312a$4c94eb60$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio,

You may use this windows procedure to avoid
the painting problem:

MRESULT EXPENTRY WindowProc( HWND hwnd, USHORT msg, MPARAM mp1, MPARAM mp2 )
{
   HPS hps;

   switch( msg )
   {
      case WM_ERASEBACKGROUND:
           return FALSE;

      case WM_PAINT:
           hps = WinBeginPaint( hwnd, 0L, NULL );
           WinEndPaint( hps );
           return 0;

    }

    return WinDefWindowProc( hwnd, msg, mp1, mp2 );
}

HB_FUNC( WINREGISTERCLASS )
{

   hb_retl( WinRegisterClass( hb_pm_GetHab(),               /* anchor block
handle */
                              hb_parc( 1 ),                 /* Class Name */
                              ( PFNWP ) WindowProc,         /* default Class
procedure */
                              hb_parnl( 2 ),                /* style */
                              hb_parnl( 3 ) ) );            /* extra bytes
*/
}


Antonio

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 05:25:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Thu Aug 30 04:25:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OS2 PM GUI, Win32 GUI
In-Reply-To: <003601c1312a$4c94eb60$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <003701c1312c$602f01e0$0f2aa8c0@first>

Maurilio, Alexander,

Another property a la 'Delphi':

CLASS TForm

   ...

   METHOD   nWidth() INLINE WinGetWidth( ::hWnd )

   METHOD   _nWidth( nNewWidth ) INLINE ;
               WinSetWidth( ::hWnd, nNewWidth )


HB_FUNC( WINGETWIDTH ) 
{
   HWND hWnd = ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 );
   RECTL rcWnd;

   WinQueryWindowRect( hWnd, &rcWnd );

   hb_retnl( rcWnd.xRight - rcWnd.xLeft );
}

HB_FUNC( WINSETWIDTH )
{
   HWND hWnd = ( HWND ) hb_parnl( 1 );
   RECTL rcWnd;

   WinQueryWindowRect( hWnd, &rcWnd );

   rcWnd.xRight = rcWnd.xLeft + hb_parnl( 2 );

   WinSetWindowPos( hWnd, HWND_TOP, rcWnd.xLeft,
                    rcWnd.yTop, rcWnd.xRight, rcWnd.yBottom,
                    SWP_MOVE | SWP_SIZE | SWP_SHOW );
}

(note: The above C functions must be adapted to Win32 API)


Antonio

Maurilio,

It is not a trick :-) 
It is how Harbour OO engine really works.

Anyhow, feel free to change them into ASSIGN, ACCESS clauses.


Antonio

Subject: [Harbour] OS2 PM GUI
References: <004301c1314e$40e14600$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <3B8E3869.6AC537E1@libero.it>

Questo è un messaggio a più sezioni in formato MIME.
--------------9EF321DE40F0884F161D3E32
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Antonio,

here it is with a width of 300 points set with a oForm:nWidth := 300

Please note that under OS/2 WinQueryWindowRect() returns a RECTL
structure which members are absolute to the window size, that is it has
always 0,0 as x,y starting coordinates, while WinQueryWindowPos() returns
a SWP structure which members are relative to the present screen
resolution so WinSetWidth() needs to use a WinQueryWindowPos() call to
correcly change TForm width only.

One other thing we should start to consider is that OS/2 PM origin of
axis is bottom left while win32 is, if I remeber correctly, top left and
I don't know X one.

So we should decide which is TForm origin of axis (I vote for OS/2 one
since it is a cartesian one :-))

regards.




Antonio Linares ha scritto:

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 10:06:55 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Aug 30 09:06:55 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Question
In-Reply-To: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEIELGCGAA.ignacio@ozs.com>; from ignacio@ozs.com on Thu, Aug 30, 2001 at 01:46:33PM +0200
References: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEIELGCGAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
Message-ID: <20010830140314.G1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Aug 30, 2001 at 01:46:33PM +0200, Ignacio Ortiz de Z=FA=F1iga wrote:

> I need to revert some CVS files to their previous revision. Could some one
> tell me how it can be done. I try to do it browsing the CVS tree directly
> from Sourceforge web site, but I have not see any option for deleting the
> last revision.

What I've done in the past is download the version of the file I want from
SF's CVS browser, copy it over the file in question and then re-commit. This
has the effect of creating a new revision rather than rolling back but that
might actually be desirable (it seemed to be the time I did it).

--=20

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 10:13:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Thu Aug 30 09:13:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] OS2 PM GUI
In-Reply-To: <3B8E3869.6AC537E1@libero.it>; from maurilio.longo@libero.it on Thu, Aug 30, 2001 at 02:58:17PM +0200
References: <004301c1314e$40e14600$0f2aa8c0@first> <3B8E3869.6AC537E1@libero.it>
Message-ID: <20010830141206.H1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Thu, Aug 30, 2001 at 02:58:17PM +0200, Maurilio Longo wrote:

> So we should decide which is TForm origin of axis (I vote for OS/2 one
> since it is a cartesian one :-))

While I agree that OS/2 got it more right than most other GUI systems (hey,
I'm an OS/2 fan, of course I'm biased <g>) I think it would be unwise to
adopt an origin that isn't widely used for GUI systems these days.

IIRC the issue of axis origin was one of the things that kept upsetting lots
of people when Xbase/2 was ported to Win32 and become Xbase++.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 13:06:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Aug 30 12:06:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Question
In-Reply-To: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEIELGCGAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
References: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOEIELGCGAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
Message-ID: <200108301204.000001BA@Internet>

** Reply to message from Ignacio Ortiz de Z=FA=F1iga <ignacio@ozs.com> on
Thu, 30 Aug 2001 13:46:33 +0200

> I need to revert some CVS files to their previous revision. Could some one
> tell me how it can be done. I try to do it browsing the CVS tree directly
> from Sourceforge web site, but I have not see any option for deleting the
> last revision.

Take a look at the following web page for information on extracting an
ol version of a file and replacing the new version with the old version.
http://elib.cs.berkeley.edu/admin/cvs/cvsrevert.html

You can also merge out changes, as follows, after which you would
commit the merged version:

> Merging differences between any two revisions
> 
> With two `-j revision' flags, the update (and checkout) command can
> merge the differences between any two revisions into your working file. 
> 
> 
> $ cvs update -j 1.5 -j 1.3 backend.c
> 
> will remove all changes made between revision 1.3 and 1.5. Note the order =
of the revisions! 
> 
> If you try to use this option when operating on multiple files,
> remember that the numeric revisions will probably be very different
> between the various files that make up a module. You almost always use
> symbolic tags rather than revision numbers when operating on multiple
> files.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 13:08:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)

Subject: [Harbour] Question
In-Reply-To: <20010830140314.G1437@hagbard.davep.org>

Message-ID: <200108301206.000001BC@Internet>

** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Thu, 30 Aug
2001 14:03:14 +0100

> What I've done in the past is download the version of the file I want from
> SF's CVS browser, copy it over the file in question and then re-commit. This
> has the effect of creating a new revision rather than rolling back but that
> might actually be desirable (it seemed to be the time I did it).

It's the method that the CVS documentation recommends using.

> Dave

> 
> An Brazilian Harbour user asker why their isnt an .tar.gz version of the
> last CVS snapshot

A .tar.gz version of what exactly? The source or a binary build? If they
mean the source then a .tar.gz of that is available (or, it was the last
time I looked at the downloads page).

If they mean a .tar.gz of a binary build of harbour then they'll probably
need to be clear about what platform they are asking about. As it is I don't
think anyone is maintaining a .tar.gz binary distribution for any platform.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 14:02:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Vera_L=FAcia_P._de_Lemos?=)
Date: Thu Aug 30 13:02:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] For condition in index file bag
Message-ID: <001b01c13174$5dc14880$fc15fea9@micro-vera>

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0018_01C1315B.33DEA9E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

The following function does not work in C language for Windows in two =
different cases:=20
1) If we use ".T." as condition in index array, the system works as if =
the key list was modified each time it is run.=20
2) If we substitute the ".T." in the index condition matriz by "",  the =
system recognizes the index list as constant but it occurs an error an =
ORDCREATEADD in line 69 on the function bellow.
=20
We've told to use ADS RDD because the for condition isn't totally =
implemented at DBFCDX RDD. The system however continuous behaving as in =
the previous case. What should I do?=20
=20
Function  according the case 1:
FUNC CDX_TST
PARA cdx0,cdx1 && file name, key and condition array
LOCAL tela_cdx
PRIVATE cdx2,cdx3,cdx4,cdx5,cdx6,cdx7,cdx8
cdx2=3DSTRTRAN(cdx0,'DBF','CDX')
cdx3=3DLEN(cdx1[1])
IF !FILE(cdx2)
   IF DISKSPACE() < FILESIZE(cdx2)*2.5
      CENTRO_ESP('Nao ha  espa=E7o suficiente para indexa=E7=E3o.')
      CAI_FORA()
   ENDIF
   cdx10 =3D STRTRAN(cdx0,'DBF','INDICE')
   tela_cdx =3D SAVESCREEN(18,01,22,78)
   @ 22,01 CLEAR TO 22,78=20
   IF TYPE('sistema') # 'U'
      IF sistema =3D 'GV'
         @ 19,01 CLEAR TO 20,78    =20
      ELSE
         @ 18,01 CLEAR TO 20,78
      ENDIF
   ELSE=20
      @ 18,01 CLEAR TO 20,78
   ENDIF
   @ 19,06 SAY 'Indexando o arquivo: '+cdx0
   @ 20,06 SAY 'Arquivo de =A1ndice : '+cdx2
   COPY FILE &cdx0 TO &cdx10
   SELECT 0
   USE &cdx10
   COPY STRU TO &cdx0
   USE
   USE_EX(cdx0)
   cdx4=3DLASTREC()
   FOR cdx5 =3D 1 TO cdx3
       cdx6=3Dcdx1[1,cdx5]
       cdx7=3Dcdx1[2,cdx5]
       cdx8=3D"_"+LTRIM(STR(cdx5))
       INDEX ON &cdx6 TAG &cdx8 TO &cdx2 FOR &cdx7
       SET ORDER TO 0
       GO TOP
   NEXT
   APP_DBF(cdx10)
   USE
   DELETE FILE &cdx10
   RESTSCREEN(18,01,22,78,tela_cdx)
ELSE
   SELECT 0
   USE &cdx0
   IF NETERR()
      @ 20,01 CLEAR TO 20,78
      @ 20,01 SAY 'Arquivo: '+cdx0
      CENTRO_ESP('Arquivo em uso exclusivo pela rede. Tente mais =
tarde.')
      CAI_FORA()
   ENDIF
   SET INDEX TO &cdx2
   IF FLOCK()
      FOR cdx5 =3D 1 TO cdx3
          SET ORDER TO cdx5
          IF ORDKEY(cdx5) <> cdx1[1,cdx5] .OR. ORDFOR(cdx5) <> =
cdx1[2,cdx5]
             USE
             F_DEL(cdx2)
             CDX_TST(cdx0,cdx1)
             RETURN
          ENDIF
      NEXT
   ENDIF
   USE
ENDIF
RELEASE ALL LIKE cdx*
RETURN

This is one of functions containing the array who contains the keys and =
the conditions used by the function above:=20
=20
FUNC G02_INDEX (g02_ind0)
&& g02_ind0 =3D alias
PRIVATE g02_ind1[2]
IF g02_ind0 =3D 550=20
   g02_ind1[1] =3D {'YEAR(DATA)'}
   g02_ind1[2] =3D {'.T.'}
ELSEIF g02_ind0 =3D 2120=20
   g02_ind1[1] =3D {'PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',;
                  'PADR(GUERRA,10)+STRZERO(SERV,4)',;
                  'PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(CODFAB),15)',;
                  'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+PADR(GUERRA,10)',;
                  'STRZERO(SERV,4)+GUERRA',;
                  'PADR(JURIDICA(CODFAB),15)+PADR(GUERRA,10)'}
   g02_ind1[2] =3D {'!EMPTY(INSUMO)','SERV>0','.T.','!EMPTY(INSUMO)',;
                  'SERV>0','.T.'}
ELSEIF g02_ind0 =3D 2530
   g02_ind1[1] =3D ;=20
        =
{'STRZERO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)+DTOS(DATA)+PADR(JURIDICA=
(INSUMO),11) =
+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+GUERRA+STRZERO(MAQ,4)',;
         =
'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)+DESCEND(D_C)+STRZE=
RO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)+STRZERO(MAQ,4)',;
         =
'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+D_C+STRZERO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(S=
EG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         'DTOS(DATA)+STRZERO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)',;
         =
'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+DESCEND(DTOS(DATA)+HORAEN)',;
         'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',;
         'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',;
         'DI',;
         'DI',;
         'TIPO+PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         =
'STRZERO(SEG,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(MAQ,4)+DTOS(DATA)+STR(H=
ORIM)',;
         =
'DESCEND(STRZERO(LR,6))+DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),=
11)',;
         =
'DESCEND(DTOS(DATA))+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+STRZERO(A=
TIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)',;
         'DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',;
         'STRZERO(GCGA,5)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         'GCGA',;
         'GUERRA',;
         =
'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)+STRZERO(ATIV,3)+ST=
RZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)+TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)',;
         'ALMOX',;
         'SEG',;
         'SERV',;
         'STRZERO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)',;
         =
'DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',; =
&& saidas 24
         'DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+STRZERO(DOC,6)',; && entradas 25
         'DTOS(DATA)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         =
'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         =
'GUERRA+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         'GUERRA+DTOS(DATA)',;
         =
'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         =
'DTOS(DATA)+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         =
'STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         =
'PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;=

         'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(MAQ,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         =
'DESCEND(STRZERO(DOC,6))+DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO)=
,11)',;
         'EXPORT'}
   g02_ind1[2] =3D =
{'.T.','.T.','.T.','.T.','TIPO=3D"PV"','!EMPTY(HORAEN)',;
         =
'D_C=3D"C"','D_C=3D"D"','CV','!CV','.T.','MAQ>0','TIPO=3D"RD"',;
         '.T.','TIPO=3D"RD"','TIPO$"GP,RM,GD,GT,IV,DL"','GCGA>0',;
         '!EMPTY(GUERRA)','STATUS=3D"C".AND.COMPROM>0','ALMOX>0',;
         =
'SEG>0','SERV>0','TIPO=3D"GP"','D_C=3D"C"','D_C=3D"D"','TIPO=3D"IV"',;
         =
'.T.','STATUS=3D"F"','STATUS=3D"F"','TIPO=3D"RA"','TIPO=3D"EA"',;
         'TIPO=3D"AC"','TIPO=3D"AC"','MAQ>0','TIPO=3D"GP"','!EXPORT'}
ENDIF
RETURN g02_ind1
=20

Function according to item 2:
=20
FUNC CDX_TST
PARA cdx0,cdx1
LOCAL tela_cdx
PRIVATE cdx2,cdx3,cdx4,cdx5,cdx6,cdx7,cdx8
cdx2=3DSTRTRAN(cdx0,'DBF','CDX')
cdx3=3DLEN(cdx1[1])
IF !FILE(cdx2)
   IF DISKSPACE() < FILESIZE(cdx2)*2.5
      CENTRO_ESP('Nao ha  espa=E7o suficiente para indexa=E7=E3o.')
      CAI_FORA()
   ENDIF
   cdx10 =3D STRTRAN(cdx0,'DBF','INDICE')
   tela_cdx =3D SAVESCREEN(18,01,22,78)
   @ 22,01 CLEAR TO 22,78=20
   IF TYPE('sistema') # 'U'
      IF sistema =3D 'GV'
         @ 19,01 CLEAR TO 20,78    =20
      ELSE
         @ 18,01 CLEAR TO 20,78
      ENDIF
   ELSE=20
      @ 18,01 CLEAR TO 20,78
   ENDIF
   @ 19,06 SAY 'Indexando o arquivo: '+cdx0
   @ 20,06 SAY 'Arquivo de =A1ndice : '+cdx2
   COPY FILE &cdx0 TO &cdx10
   SELECT 0
   USE &cdx10
   COPY STRU TO &cdx0
   USE
   USE_EX(cdx0)
   cdx4=3DLASTREC()
   FOR cdx5 =3D 1 TO cdx3
       cdx6=3Dcdx1[1,cdx5]
       cdx7=3Dcdx1[2,cdx5]
       cdx8=3D"_"+LTRIM(STR(cdx5))
       INDEX ON &cdx6 TAG &cdx8 TO &cdx2 FOR IIF(cdx7>'',&cdx7,.T.)
       SET ORDER TO 0
       GO TOP
   NEXT
   APP_DBF(cdx10)
   USE
   DELETE FILE &cdx10
   RESTSCREEN(18,01,22,78,tela_cdx)
ELSE
   SELECT 0
   USE &cdx0
   IF NETERR()
      @ 20,01 CLEAR TO 20,78
      @ 20,01 SAY 'Arquivo: '+cdx0
      CENTRO_ESP('Arquivo em uso exclusivo pela rede. Tente mais =
tarde.')
      CAI_FORA()
   ENDIF
   SET INDEX TO &cdx2
   IF FLOCK()
      FOR cdx5 =3D 1 TO cdx3
          SET ORDER TO cdx5
          IF ORDKEY(cdx5) <> cdx1[1,cdx5] .OR. ORDFOR(cdx5) <> =
cdx1[2,cdx5]
             USE
             F_DEL(cdx2)
             CDX_TST(cdx0,cdx1)
             RETURN
          ENDIF
      NEXT
   ENDIF
   USE
ENDIF
RELEASE ALL LIKE cdx*
RETURN
=20
FUNC G02_INDEX (g02_ind0)
&& g02_ind0 =3D alias
PRIVATE g02_ind1[2]
IF g02_ind0 =3D 550=20
   g02_ind1[1] =3D {'YEAR(DATA)'}
   g02_ind1[2] =3D {''}
ELSEIF g02_ind0 =3D 2120
   g02_ind1[1] =3D {'PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',;
                  'PADR(GUERRA,10)+STRZERO(SERV,4)',;
                  'PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(CODFAB),15)',;
                  'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+PADR(GUERRA,10)',;
                  'STRZERO(SERV,4)+GUERRA',;
                  'PADR(JURIDICA(CODFAB),15)+PADR(GUERRA,10)'}
   g02_ind1[2] =3D {'!EMPTY(INSUMO)','SERV>0','','!EMPTY(INSUMO)',;
                  'SERV>0',''}
ELSEIF g02_ind0 =3D 2530
   g02_ind1[1] =3D ;=20
        =
{'STRZERO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)+DTOS(DATA)+PADR(JURIDICA=
(INSUMO),11) =
+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+GUERRA+STRZERO(MAQ,4)',;
         =
'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)+DESCEND(D_C)+STRZE=
RO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)+STRZERO(MAQ,4)',;
         =
'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+D_C+STRZERO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(S=
EG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         'DTOS(DATA)+STRZERO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)',;
         =
'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+DESCEND(DTOS(DATA)+HORAEN)',;
         'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',;
         'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',;
         'DI',;
         'DI',;
         'TIPO+PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         =
'STRZERO(SEG,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(MAQ,4)+DTOS(DATA)+STR(H=
ORIM)',;
         =
'DESCEND(STRZERO(LR,6))+DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),=
11)',;
         =
'DESCEND(DTOS(DATA))+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+STRZERO(A=
TIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)',;
         'DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',;
         'STRZERO(GCGA,5)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         'GCGA',;
         'GUERRA',;
         =
'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)+STRZERO(ATIV,3)+ST=
RZERO(SEG,6)+STRZERO(SERV,4)+TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)',;
         'ALMOX',;
         'SEG',;
         'SERV',;
         'STRZERO(ATIV,3)+STRZERO(SEG,6)',;
         =
'DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)',; =
&& saidas 24
         'DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+STRZERO(DOC,6)',; && entradas 25
         'DTOS(DATA)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         =
'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         =
'GUERRA+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         'GUERRA+DTOS(DATA)',;
         =
'TIPO+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         =
'DTOS(DATA)+STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)',;
         =
'STRZERO(DOC,6)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         =
'PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(ALMOX,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;=

         'PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO),11)+STRZERO(MAQ,4)+DTOS(DATA)',;
         =
'DESCEND(STRZERO(DOC,6))+DTOS(DATA)+PADR(GUERRA,10)+PADR(JURIDICA(INSUMO)=
,11)',;
         'EXPORT'}
   g02_ind1[2] =3D {'','','','','TIPO=3D"PV"','!EMPTY(HORAEN)',;
         'D_C=3D"C"','D_C=3D"D"','CV','!CV','','MAQ>0','TIPO=3D"RD"',;
         '','TIPO=3D"RD"','TIPO$"GP,RM,GD,GT,IV,DL"','GCGA>0',;
         '!EMPTY(GUERRA)','STATUS=3D"C".AND.COMPROM>0','ALMOX>0',;
         =
'SEG>0','SERV>0','TIPO=3D"GP"','D_C=3D"C"','D_C=3D"D"','TIPO=3D"IV"',;
         '','STATUS=3D"F"','STATUS=3D"F"','TIPO=3D"RA"','TIPO=3D"EA"',;
         'TIPO=3D"AC"','TIPO=3D"AC"','MAQ>0','TIPO=3D"GP"','!EXPORT'}
ENDIF
RETURN g02_ind1

in C=20

condition in=20

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 15:05:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Marek Paliwoda)

Subject: [Harbour] Harbour GUI

Antonio Linares wrote on Wednesday, August 29, 2001 11:02 AM

> Marek,
> 
> Many thanks!
> 
> Have you tested it with Harbour ?

Yes, under Win32 and under Linux. And I think anyone interested in, 
including you, can easily test it too at least on Win32. One only needs 
to download a Gtk for Win libraries, set a proper compiler (MingW in 
my case) and prepare a make_gtk.bat(.sh) compiling script.

BTW, seems to me you've ignored a problem with a libvm library, 
I mentioned previously. I think you are complicating things instead
of simplifying them, forcing an existing of a special entry point for 
platforms which do not need it.

-- 

  Marek Paliwoda
paliwoda@inetia.pl






From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 15:44:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Thu Aug 30 14:44:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] Harbour GUI
In-Reply-To: <00ed01c1317e$6bbbe1c0$2bb372c3@map>
Message-ID: <004f01c13182$54c52400$0f2aa8c0@first>

Marek,

>> Have you tested it with Harbour ?
> 
> Yes, under Win32 and under Linux. 

ok, many thanks!

> I think you are complicating things instead
> of simplifying them, forcing an existing of a special entry point for 
> platforms which do not need it.

We are using the same model we have applied
for OS/2. There is a mainstd.c for console apps,
and a mainpm.c for GUI apps. 

mainlgtk.c should only be linked for Linux GTK
GUI apps.

Marek, if you review contrib/hgf/..., do you think
you could adapt those little classes to work with
GTK ? 

Antonio

It's only mainstd.c for Windows console apps. OS/2 console apps use the
same main.c that all other non-Windows apps use.

(from main.c)

/* NOTE: This is only a container source file, don't put real program
         code here. */

#if   defined(HARBOUR_MAIN_STD)
   #include "mainstd.c"
#elif defined(HARBOUR_MAIN_WIN)
   #include "mainwin.c"
#else
   #include "mainstd.c" /* Use the standard ANSI C entry point if not
speficied

(from main.c)

so it just links mainstd.c for not windows apps.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Thu Aug 30 17:36:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Thu Aug 30 16:36:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-30 16:30 UTC-0400 David G. Holm
Message-ID: <200108301635.000001C6@Internet>

2001-08-30 16:30 UTC-0400 David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com>

  * config/os2/gcc.cf
  * config/os2/icc.cf
    + Automatically deal with different linker requirements for
      Presentation Manager programs and VIO programs.

  * contrib/hgf/os2/os2pm.c
    ! Removed hWndFrame variable from HB_FUNC( WINCREATESTDWINDOW ),
      because it isn't needed and causes problems in C++ mode.

  * doc/gmake.txt
    + Added mention of w32/bcc32.
    + Added mention of os2/gcc and os2/icc with the new os2pm.

  * source/vm/Makefile
    ! Always build both main and mainpm for OS/2 builds, because
      the choice of which to use is a program link-time choice,
      not a Harbour build-time choice.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 03:33:01 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (JF Lefebvre)
Date: Fri Aug 31 02:33:01 2001
Subject: [Harbour] :isDerivedFrom method
In-Reply-To: <2792809142.20010831011408@mail.ru>
Message-ID: <3B8F4BBE.11454.20ACB52@localhost>

Hi phil

> Hello,
> 
> Please tell me if Harbour class engine has a method equivalent to
> XBase++'s :isDerivedFrom(cSuperClassName) that returns .T. if object
> is a descendant of the given superclass.

This should give you what you want :

__objDerivedFrom( oObject, xSuper )

oObject is the object to test and xSuper can be either an object or 
a className.

I will add soon the method :Isderivedfrom(xSuper) with the same 
functionalities. (In fact I already added it but for an unknow reason, 
I let it remmed within the source (tobject.prg)... 


Best regards,

J. Lefebvre,
Bruxelles,
Belgium

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 08:13:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (=?iso-8859-1?Q?Ignacio_Ortiz_de_Z=FA=F1iga?=)
Date: Fri Aug 31 07:13:02 2001

>>Probably we can use the GTK for win32 apps too.

No, please do not put another software wrap, the benefits are so low against
the enormous harms we may have:

- speed
- Dependency
- Inherited bugs
- Incompatibilities on OS new versions or specific Client PC's

Remember that one of the great advantages of Harbour is that is a self
contained EXE and for that reason runs always fine on any PC, please do not
lose that great feature.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 08:39:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 31 07:39:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-31 11:32 GMT+1
In-Reply-To: <000501c13200$1b530920$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 31, 2001 at 11:34:18AM +0200
References: <20010831085441.Q1437@hagbard.davep.org> <000501c13200$1b530920$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010831123549.R1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 31, 2001 at 11:34:18AM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> 2001-08-31 11:32 GMT+1 Antonio Linares <alinares@fivetech.com>
>    + harbour/source/vm/mainlgtk.c
>       Added Marek Paliwoda's Linux GTK application entry point
> 
> Please notice Linux make should be updated 
> (I don't know how to do it :-)  

Updating the Makefile is trivial so I would do it, but, what I don't
understand (and can't find any docs for) is how all these various "main"
files are supposed to work.

Can anyone explain how it should work? For example, looking at the OS/2
version, there are two main files for OS/2: main.c and mainpm.c. If I'm
reading it correctly this results in two versions of main() being added to
libvm. How does the harbour user then control which main() gets used?

The same problem with occur with GNU/Linux and GTK. How should I, as someone
using harbour on GNU/Linux, say that one program is a terminal oriented
program while another is a GTK oriented program.

Can anyone give a brief explanation (perhaps even sticking said explanation
in the doc directory for future reference)?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 08:45:11 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 31 07:45:11 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-31 11:32 GMT+1
In-Reply-To: <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOECEMGCGAA.ignacio@ozs.com>; from ignacio@ozs.com on Fri, Aug 31, 2001 at 01:10:50PM +0200
References: <000001c13207$39e121e0$66d4d7c8@culik> <ANEEJCPNEPCPMGBDJOOECEMGCGAA.ignacio@ozs.com>
Message-ID: <20010831124438.S1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 31, 2001 at 01:10:50PM +0200, Ignacio Ortiz de Z=FA=F1iga wrote:

> Remember that one of the great advantages of Harbour is that is a self
> contained EXE and for that reason runs always fine on any PC, please do
> not lose that great feature.

All of which might be true, to varying degrees, if someone were suggesting
that GTK *only* be used to implement Win32 GUI support. That, however,
didn't seem to be the suggestion. The suggestion seemed to be that people
shouldn't keep associating GTK with GNU/Linux and only GNU/Linux. Someone
might wish to ensure that GTK support works on Windows too. That seems fine
to me.

Moreover, a GTK using harbour executable would be self-contained in exactly
the same way as a Win32 GUI using harbour exactly is self-contained, or an
ADO using harbour executable is self-contained, or an ADS using harbour
executable is self-contained. A harbour executable, for Windows, that uses
the GUI, which doesn't require external code (even if it is code that is
supplied by the OS) would be quite a feat.

I see no harm at all in allowing someone to develop and maintain
cross-platform GTK support. That won't affect or have any impact on native
Win32 GUI support (for example). Where's the harm in that?

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 12:02:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 31 11:02:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-31 11:32 GMT+1
In-Reply-To: <001301c1321e$5e1dbf20$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 31, 2001 at 03:10:55PM +0200
References: <20010831140049.V1437@hagbard.davep.org> <001301c1321e$5e1dbf20$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010831160021.W1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 31, 2001 at 03:10:55PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:

> For Win32 there is not such problem, as console and GUI apps, both use the
> same entry point (mainwin.c).

This is where this dichotomy gets confusing for me. Speaking in the general
case, your average GNU/Linux program also has the same entry point[1], it's
what happens once the program is running that dictates if output goes to a
terminal or graphical windows are created (both can happen, or neither).

On the surface I can see why it makes life easier to have alternate entry
points for the same "environment" (I choose that word carefully but I'm also
aware that it's not the best fit) but I'm also wondering if there's a more
dynamic approach waiting to be discovered.

For example, imagine something like this as the standard main entry point
(note that I've not fully considered what needs to be passed by value and
what needs to be passed by "reference", we probably want to be passing the
address of argc in all of this, not the value of it):

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
int main( int argc, char **argv )
{
    if ( hb_mainInitHook( argc, argv ) )
    {
        hb_cmdargInit( argc, argv );
        hb_vmInit( TRUE );
        hb_mainExitHook();
        hb_vmQuit();
    }
    
    return 0;
}
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

the key here is hb_mainInitHook() and hb_mainExitHook(). The correct
initHook and exitHook would be supplied at link-time by linking in the
required init module. hb_mainInitHook() and hb_mainExitHook() for your
"normal" application would simply look like:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
int hb_mainInitHook( int argc, char **argv )
{
    HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( argc );
    HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( argv );

    return 1;
}

void hb_mainExitHook( void )
{
    /* Does nothing and does it well. */
}
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

whereas the init hook for a GTK+ oriented application would look something
like:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
int hb_mainInitHook( int argc, char **argv )
{
    gtk_set_locale();
    
    return gtk_init_check( &argc, &argv );
}
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

For OS/2 PM it would something along the lines of:

-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------
static HAB hab;
static HMQ hmq;

int hb_mainInitHook( int argc, char **argv )
{
    HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( argc );
    HB_SYMBOL_UNUSED( argv );

    hab = WinInitialize( 0 );
    hmq = WinCreateMsgQueue( hab, 0 );

    return 1; /* hab && hmq? */
}

void hb_mainExitHook( void )
{
    WinDestroyMsgQueue( hmq );
    WinTerminate( hab );
}
-- cut here ----------------------------------------------------------------

and so on and so forth.

Not that I'm actually proposing such a system, but I am wondering if
something like this could be done so that the choice of "entry point" has
nothing to do with having different main*.c files but, instead, is a choice
of using a chosen init/exit module. An approach like this would also allow
harbour users to add their own low-level init/exit hooks.

Thoughts?

-----
[1]  int main( { void | int argc, char **argv } )

-- 
Harbour is a free   | Harbour Web Site: http://www.harbour-project.org/
software, cross     | Harbour FAQ.....: http://www.harbour-project.org/faq/
platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 13:05:04 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Antonio Linares)
Date: Fri Aug 31 12:05:04 2001
Subject: [Harbour] entry points
In-Reply-To: <20010831160021.W1437@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <000001c13236$18855aa0$0f2aa8c0@first>

Dave,

> the choice of "entry point" has
> nothing to do with having different main*.c files but, 
> instead, is a choice of using a chosen init/exit module

I may be missing something, but your
proposal simply moves the problem from
mainxxx.c files to init/exit modules.

But the same linking problem persists.

I guess the solution is on the libraries
the user needs to select to build for his
selected OS target.


Antonio


From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 13:35:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Aug 31 12:35:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-31 11:32 GMT+1
In-Reply-To: <20010831123549.R1437@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <20010831085441.Q1437@hagbard.davep.org> <000501c13200$1b530920$0f2aa8c0@first>
 <20010831123549.R1437@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <200108311234.000001CW@Internet>

** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Fri, 31 Aug
2001 12:35:49 +0100

> Can anyone explain how it should work? For example, looking at the OS/2
> version, there are two main files for OS/2: main.c and mainpm.c. If I'm
> reading it correctly this results in two versions of main() being added to
> libvm. How does the harbour user then control which main() gets used?

The first module will get linked in, unless overridden on the link
command line by includin one of the main object modules, which is what
happens for os2pm for os2/gcc and happens for both vio and os2pm for
os2/icc. In hindsight, I should probably have replaced main with mainstd
for OS/2 in the Makefile, because main has such convoluted includes.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 13:35:57 2001

Fri, 31 Aug 2001 13:42:41 +0200

> on OS/2 (gcc.cf) adds to vm.a only one module, mainpm.c is hb_gt_lib is equal to
> os2pm, gtstd.c if not.

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 13:43:02 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (Dave Pearson)
Date: Fri Aug 31 12:43:02 2001
Subject: [Harbour] entry points
In-Reply-To: <000001c13236$18855aa0$0f2aa8c0@first>; from alinares@fivetech.com on Fri, Aug 31, 2001 at 06:00:46PM +0200
References: <20010831160021.W1437@hagbard.davep.org> <000001c13236$18855aa0$0f2aa8c0@first>
Message-ID: <20010831173825.Z1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 31, 2001 at 06:00:46PM +0200, Antonio Linares wrote:
> Dave,
> 
> > the choice of "entry point" has nothing to do with having different
> > main*.c files but, instead, is a choice of using a chosen init/exit
> > module
> 
> I may be missing something, but your proposal simply moves the problem
> from mainxxx.c files to init/exit modules.

The point of what I wrote was that it moves the init/exit stuff totally out
of the VM and into environment specific libraries, exactly like the GT API
or the proposed HGF hierarchy.

As I understand it (and this comes from my understanding being confirmed by
other posters here), at the moment, the choice of entry point is a harbour
build time decision. That is, you build harbour itself so that it's VM entry
point targets a given environment (in the GNU/Linux case plain old terminal
vs GTK+, lets add QT, LessTif and Tk in the mix for fun too).

Building different VM's for different aspects of the same environment seems
quite painful and inefficient. This is the reason that we've got different
GT libraries.

What I was suggesting is that the entry point "problem" take a similar
approach to the GT API.

> But the same linking problem persists.

What I suggested presents no linking problem at all. At least, no more of a
linking problem than the problem of linking (on GNU/Linux, for example) the
curses or slang GT layer.

> I guess the solution is on the libraries the user needs to select to build
> for his selected OS target.

Exactly, that's exactly what I was suggesting. I was, however, wondering if
it could be done in a very granular way, just like the GT layer.

--

platform, Clipper   | My Harbour Pages: http://www.davep.org/harbour/
compatible compiler | Harbour News....: http://www.davep.org/harbour/news/

Subject: [Harbour] ChangeLog 2001-08-31 11:32 GMT+1

References: <20010831085441.Q1437@hagbard.davep.org> <000501c13200$1b530920$0f2aa8c0@first> <20010831123549.R1437@hagbard.davep.org> <200108311234.000001CW@Internet>
Message-ID: <20010831174653.A1437@hagbard.davep.org>

On Fri, Aug 31, 2001 at 12:34:01PM -0400, David G. Holm wrote:

> The first module will get linked in, unless overridden on the link command
> line by includin one of the main object modules, which is what happens for
> os2pm for os2/gcc and happens for both vio and os2pm for os2/icc. In
> hindsight, I should probably have replaced main with mainstd for OS/2 in
> the Makefile, because main has such convoluted includes.

So, if I'm following this correctly, a binary distribution of harbour (of
OS/2 anyway) will ship with the VM as a library, with one of the entry
points linked in, but will also ship with both entry points build as object
files for the user to optionally link in ahead of VM library?

I'm left wondering where the HGF code will live, especially for platforms
where there might be the option of more then one widget set (yes, I know
that's not directly tied to the issue of entry points but it does appear to
be the next obvious question).

From harbour@matrixlist.com  Fri Aug 31 14:27:03 2001
From: harbour@matrixlist.com (David G. Holm)
Date: Fri Aug 31 13:27:03 2001
Subject: [Harbour] entry points
In-Reply-To: <20010831173825.Z1437@hagbard.davep.org>
References: <20010831160021.W1437@hagbard.davep.org> <000001c13236$18855aa0$0f2aa8c0@first>
 <20010831173825.Z1437@hagbard.davep.org>
Message-ID: <200108311325.000001D0@Internet>

** Reply to message from Dave Pearson <davep@davep.org> on Fri, 31 Aug
2001 17:38:25 +0100

> As I understand it (and this comes from my understanding being confirmed by
> other posters here), at the moment, the choice of entry point is a harbour
> build time decision. That is, you build harbour itself so that it's VM entry
> point targets a given environment (in the GNU/Linux case plain old terminal
> vs GTK+, lets add QT, LessTif and Tk in the mix for fun too).

That's not true for Harbour for OS/2. Regardless of how you build
Harbour for OS/2, the choice of PM vs. VIO is made when you link your
Harbour program, based upon whether or not your HB_GT_LIB environment
variable is set to os2pm.
-- 
David G. Holm, Set Captain and all around
Harbour Project Clipper Compatibility fanatic.

2001-08-31 14:30 UTC-0400 David G. Holm <dholm@jsd-llc.com>

  * config/os2/icc.cf
  * source/vm/Makefile
    * Build and use mainstd.c for OS/2 instead of main.c in order
      to avoid the main.c build dependencies.

    Note to builders of OS/2 binary distributions: Please be
    sure to include both the mainstd and mainpm object files!
